div.p: THE MEMOIRS OF THE Count De ROCHEFORT, CONTAINING An Account of what pat mot memorable, under the Minitry of Cardinal RICHELIE, AND Cardinal MAZARIN, WITH Many particular paages of the Reign of Lewis the Great.
Made Englih from the French.

LONDON, Printed by F. L. for James Knapton at the Crown in St. Pauls Church-yard; Richard Parker at the nicorn under the Piazza of the Royal Exchange; and Tho. Nott at the Queens Arms in the Pall-mall. 1696.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: THE Tranlation of this Book may perhaps tand in as much need of an Apology as another, to make ome Excue for a great many Errors; but the Tranlator profees, he has that indifference for it, that he had rather own 'em all, and leave it to the Readers Dicretion to damn or forgive 'em, as he pleaes, than trouble himelf any more about it.

For one Excue, amongt a thouand others us'd upon thee occaions, he might ay that the Tranlation uffers extreamly for want of Leiure, but he has not the Face to pretend uch a thing, when
'tis but too apparent that it uffers indeed for want of a little Application. This Negligence is his nhappines, but too late to be helpt now: Nay, what's wore, if it was to be done again, 'tis to be fear'd he could not be prevaild on to take the pains to revie it, for the Reputation of Writing never o correctly.

As for the Work it elf; the Tranlator when he read it, fancy'd he found omething more pleaant and entertaining in it than ordinary, and that engag'd him to make it Englih, which when he had once undertaken, he was no longer at liberty to reject ome other things that to him appear'd trifling enough. To make amends for which it mut be confet, that thro the whole Book there is a great Variety of very urpriing Paages, and that mot of 'em are very diverting. If any doubts the truth of them, he is referr'd to the French Preface, which is
writ on purpoe to jutify the Author's Sincerity. Tho after all, the paage about his Birth is reckon'd by ome not only a doubtful Story, but an Impoibility: But perhaps he might himelf be impos'd on in that; for 'tis no New Practice to call uch Births Miraculous, which happen a little too oon for the Credit of the Family.

As for the Stile, if after what has been aid the Reader will be o unreaonable, as to expect the Language in the Tranlation to be very pure and jut, he mut be inform'd, that the Original in that repect is none of the mot finiht pieces in its own Tongue. For tho the Author was a peron of Quality, and of extraordinary Parts and Addres, yet 'twas his Misfortune, that his Education was not only far from that of a Man of Learning, but much inferior to his Condition.

His Subject, is the Particularities of his own Life, which requir'd no more than a free, eay, and natural Style, and that he has for the mot part oberv'd well enough. 'Tis ufficient then if the Tranlator has not mitaken his Sene, and that 'tis hop'd he has not done, nor in the main done him any great Injury.

div.head: THE French Publihers PREFACE.
div.p:
THE Count de Rochefort was a peron o well known, and dy'd o lately, that it eems almot needles to offer to jutify any thing that he has mention'd in his Memoirs. There is none of thoe Gentlemen, who knew him either at Court, or in the Camp, but know that in his Converation, he was o avere from diguiing the Truth, or relating any thing fictitious, that it can never be imagin'd he hould be guilty of writing a Fality, with a Deign to impoe upon the World. There has not liv'd for thee many Ages a Man of greater Honour than he was, which I do not peak, becaue I have ever profet a Friendhip for him, but becaue I am oblig'd to do him that Jutice. If therefore in the beginning of thee Memoirs, he relates omething of his Father, which is very urprizing, the Reader is not immediately from thence to call his Reputation in quetion, as if it were not true. We are o us'd every day to extraordinary Adventures, that none but thoe who are unacquainted with Paris, are any longer urpriz'd at them. There is not a Year paes, but this great City affords Subject of Sorrow to ome, while others laugh at
their Expence. Yet is the Story of his Brother-in-law and Siter not o very uncommon. How many Husbands have puru'd their Wives, and courted them to a Reconcilement, when the Separation has not been upon the account of Devotion, as in this cae; but upon uch jut and good grounds, as extreme Weaknes only could forget. I know ome, that have been at a great deal of Cot and Pains to have themelves declar'd Cuckolds, and it has been done very much to their Satisfaction; yet afterwards have expret as great Impatience to have the Dear Spoue home again, (tho a little faulty) as ever they hew'd Deire for a Divorce. This is no more than what I know my elf to be true; or ele it would appear more incredible, than that a Man hould take his Wife again, whom he never had any other reaon but to eteem. But perhaps it may be objected, that the peron who we are talking of, was turn'd Priet, and after that ought not to have taken his Wife again. But why not? Since the Parliament judg'd it lawful, and a Man of Honour has affirm'd it; whoe Sincerity too appears the more in this, that he recounts thoe things of his own Family, which a great many others in his place would have indutriouly conceal'd. And I will add this further proof of the Truth on't; that happening t'other day to be in the Company of Monieur, the Preident Bailleul, and my Mind running upon thee Memoirs, I askt him if he did not remember uch a Proces, and ome other particulars which the Count de Rochefort had mention'd of him, and he told me, that he remember'd it as perfectly well, as if the thing had been done but that moment. After this can it poibly be doubted, Monieur de Bailleul being a peron of that noted Integrity, that his Tetimony alone is enough to convince the mot incredulous? Yet I mut confes I was an Infidel my elf, with repect to what Monieur the Count tells us of the Swis: For who could ever imagine, there were
any people in Nature o imple, as to take Puppits for young Devils? Yet is there nothing more certainly true than this. For I was not content only with inquiring the Truth of it from Biroche, but from Monieut Du Mont too, with whom I was very well acquainted. They both own'd it to me, but in a different manner; for Biroche made his Brags of it, as if he has hewn a great piece of Wit; whereas Du Mont could not think of it without flying out into uch a paion, as was a ign he had not yet forgot his Digrace.

If then the Count de Rochefort is o jut in a Story, which has o much the Air of a Fiction, how incere mut we conclude him in his other Relations? In effect, where lies the Difficulty of believing what he ays of Cardinal Richlieu? Are not all Miniters of State myterious, or hould be o at leat, and was not that a quality which the Cardinal affected above all things, as the Count de Rochefort takes very good notice? Is there any thing more natural than what that Miniter made Sauve to do; or is there any thing more urprizing, than the Ambition of that Man, who was content to acrifice his Wife to advance his Fortune? All which may erve for intructions for our own Conduct, which is one of the greatet advantages we can gain from the reading of any Book. I am perwaded too, that the Count de Rochefort was not o much induced to write out of vanity, to hew he was concern'd in the private Intrigues of State, as out of a deire to render other People wier by his Example: And I am the more confirm'd in this opinion, when I reflect how often he reproaches himelf for making o ill ue of Cardinal Richlieu's favour, and o everely reprehends his own Follies. However, hould thee Memoirs not prove o very profitable, I am confident they will be found to be very curious, dicovering a great many things which are no where ele to be met with. I believe too they will be
found to be very diverting, and that none will ever think them tedious. But Friendhip perhaps may be thought to have a large hare in this Dicoure, and indeed the Author of thee Memoirs, and my elf, were uch dear Friends, that I mut confes I have a trange Indulgence for any thing of his; yet as I have not been the only peron that has read 'em, but others have been of my Tat, I hall venture to declare 'em once again, the mot agreeable of their kind.

There is another thing too I mut confes, but from that I know not how I hall be abolv'd; I publih here thee Memoirs againt the Lat Will and Intention of the Author, who upon his Death, which happen'd in a month or two after his Retirement, order'd me to uppres 'em. I cannot imagine for what reaon, except that being then upon the point of leaving the World, he was willing to pare ome People, whom he had formerly had ome differences with, and whom he had no great caue to peak well of. But this did not appear to me a ufficient reaon to deprive the Publick of a Work o curious; therefore uch as I receiv'd it without either adding or diminihing, here 'tis at the Readers Service.

div.head: MEMOIRS OF The Count de Rochefort, &c.
div.p:
BEtween Paris and Etampes, on the Right hand of Chatres, lies a Catle call'd Olinville, which had formerly been one of the Kings Houes, but now belongs to the Family of Marillac. My Father going once to pay a viit there, being related to Monieur De Marillac, took my Mother along with him, who was big, and above four months and an half gone with Child: As they went, they call'd at one Monieur Grigni's, a Gentleman of the Neighbourhood, where their Coachman having got drunk, made bold to overturn the Coach at the very gate of Olinville, tho the way was the moothet and bet in the World. By this accident, my Father, intead of the diverion he expected there, met with an inexpreible affliction: For my Mother, who receiv'd ome hurt, having brought me into the world the next day, liv'd but two days after it; to the grief of the whole family, who had a very great repect for her. My Father was in uch a paion, that
had it not been for Monieur de Marillac, he had certainly kill'd the Coachman: It was impoible tho to perwade him, but that he was guilty of the death of my Mother, (as caually indeed he was) o he had his Proces made, but after two or three months Imprionment he was acquitted.

No body imagining that I could live, they took care to have me immediately Baptiz'd: Monieur De Marillac. and one Madam D' Arboville, who happen'd to be in the houe, perform'd the Offices for me at the Font. I was call'd Charles Caear, which was my Fathers Name, and given me to oblige him. They took a Nure for me there, whom my Father ent with me to his Catle, which was at the entrance into the Forret of Orleans, and having ome buines at Paris, went himelf thither. My Father having no more Children, and every body believing (as I aid) that I could hardly live, they all advis'd him to marry; and he who was till young, and no hater of the Sex, was eaily prevail'd on. Several young Ladies were propos'd to him of the bet Families in Paris; but being deirous to ee before he engag'd with any, he found none that he lik'd; whether it was that none of them were really fine Women, or that his Fate had reerv'd for him the accident I am now to relate; and for me the wort Mother-in-law that ever was in the world. However it was that he eem'd o difficult, a relation of his who was Curate of one of the bet Churches in Paris, and had the Character of a very holy man, as indeed he was; came earnetly to tell him, that he had done his buines for him, in finding a young Lady, very well made, handome, rich, vertuous, and of quality; in hort, a Jewel for the age, that was o extremely corrupted. Tho my Father knew 'twas a dangerous thing to
take a Woman on the word of a Priet, yet the anctity of this Curate atisfy'd him, as knowing, that there was no general rule without exception; he made him this anwer, That he knew better than himelf what was fit for him; that he was extreamly oblig'd to him for his kindnes; and for the Lady, he would make no enquiries of her, after the character he had given her: The Curate return'd, That this Confidence of his was the caue that he had preferr'd him to many of his other relations, whoe fortunes would have been made by uch a Match: That the Lady would have an Etate of twenty thouand Livres per annum: That he was of the Family De la Force, one of the mot coniderable houes among thoe of the pretended Reform'd Religion; of which he had lately made her abjuration to him; that as oon as he had marry'd her, he might get the Etate of the Family into his hands, of which the ucceion was vacant; and for her Mother, he might eaily oblige her by his addres; that his Wife's changing her Religion hould be no prejudice to him.

It is impoible to ay how this dicoure charm'd my Father, he was impatient to ee the Lady; and the Curate having how'd her to him at the Convent where he was retreated, he return'd o mitten that he could not ret till the affair was concluded: However, as he was a Man not to be fool'd, or at leat thought himelf uch, he wrote to ome Friends of his at Agen, where the Ladies Etate was aid to be; and they giving him an account that he was a very virtuous Lady, had a very good Fortune, and was only retir'd to Paris to make her Abjuration; he married her, fancying himelf the happiet man in the world: His happines continued about three weeks, in which time, no young Lover could have caret
his Mitris with more paion than he did his new Bride: He carried her to the Ball, to the Play, to the publick Walks, and in hort, when ever he was oblig'd to be abent from her but an hour or two, he would return with uch eagernes as was almot unpardonable for a Husband; every body was urpriz'd that enjoyment had not moderated his tranports: but he told all thoe who hinted any uch thing to him, that if it us'd to be o with repect to other Wives, it was not o with him, ince his had nothing in her capable of diguting the Appetite.

In all this hurry I was eaily forgotten, and if ometimes I was poken of, it was only to ask if I was not yet dead; for my Father not doubting but he hould oon have Children by his new Wife, and retaining no more the remembrance of my Mother, began already to advance the entiments of tendernes that are o common to thoe of a econd Bed.

He believ'd himelf now at that pitch of Happines as to be exempt from the attacks of Fortune, and dreamt of nothing but how to pas away the time till the Spring hould come on, when they reolv'd to make a hort Journey to view his Wives Etate; in the mean time he preented her with a very rich Coach, and all things agreeable. But all this could not divert her, till there appear'd on her face an air of Dicontent, and a melancholly o deeply rooted as extreamly afflicted my Father; he was every moment preing her to tell him if he wanted any thing, adding, that he needed but to peak, ince the man whoe heart he o entirely poet could deny her nothing; joyning to this obliging dicoure the tendret Carees in the world: But one day as he was treating her in this ort, he perceiv'd omething more than ordinary under her Shift upon her houlder, he
demands of her what it was: But he intead of anwering him trove to get from him, which increaing his upicion, he took hold of her and would ee what it was, then he us'd intreaties with him, told him it was nothing, and tried again to get looe from him, but finding it in vain he truggl'd with him, nor was it but with great difficulty that he pull'd down her Shift, which dicover'd to him a thing, that had he not been in Bed had trook him to the ground, he aw (hall I dare to peak it) the fair impreion of aThe mark with which they brand Malefactors in that Country. Flower-de-luce, which at once undeceiv'd him in the good opinion he had had of her; he who had o often prov'd the force of her Carees, attempted to calm him by a kis, and he who was become inenible, uffer'd her without the leat notice; but in a moment recovering himelf, Go infamous Creature, aid he, if I cannot have o much jutice as to have you hang'd, you hall certainly die by my own hand: He got up in all hate and immediately finds out the Curate, and treats him with the wort Language that rage and depair could inpire him with; but eeing that all this was to no pnrpoe, he demands of him what remedy he would pretend to apply to the Dieae he had procur'd him.

The poor Curate could not oon be perwaded to believe him, but being atisfi'd at lat that it was but too true, he threw himelf at his feet begging his pardon, and lifting up his eyes made a thouand exclamations upon the abominable wickednes of the woman, who had under covert of Confeion made him a party to her impotures. But my Father till continuing almot ditracted, o that the people began to croud about them, a Priet that had formerly been an Advocate tept to him and told him, 'twas
indeed a ad Cae but not altogether incurable, that he had counterfeited her Name, and therefore the Marriage was void; that he had no more to do but immediately to enter his Action, and tho he might meet with ome difficulty (the Parliament being very nice in uch caes) yet he mut follow it cloe, and needed not to doubt the ucces. As in a general Shipwrack men catch at any thing that's likely to ave them, my Father embrac'd this advice as if it had been ent from Heaven, and running directly to the The Palace is in Paris, as Wetminter-Hall is here the place for the Courts of Jutice. Palace, he conults with three of the mot able Councel, who all of them were of the ame opinion; but told him withal that it would be needful for him to make ome Friends, epecially if he found he had any body to tand by her; this diturb'd my Father above all, who was aham'd to make ue of his Friends about uch a buines as this, and 'twas everal days before he could be brought to it, till he found a coniderable peron engage in the affair for her, which oblig'd him to do that which otherwie he would never have done.

But to his orrow he found that he had out-witted him there too, that he had not chang'd her Name, but was really call'd Madelain de Caumont, jut as he had ign'd the Contract, and had alo given the true names of her Father and Mother; and all the falification they could fix upon her, was, that he had dignifi'd her Father with the Title of Knight, and Lord of everal Mannors, and her Mother with that of a very great Lady, intead of what they really were, a Miller and the Millers Wife. The cae being o very nice, they advis'd my Father to treat with the young woman for a um of Money to conent to a decree
againt the Marriage; but her Friend owing my Father an ill turn on the account of an old quarrel, and glad of this opportunity to pay it him, would hearken to no accommodation; upon which my Father was advis'd to engage the Judge Advocate on his ide, and to proecute her for an abue to Religion: for indeed he had made a publick Abjuration, whereas he was born a Catholick, and had always been o; this trick of the Law put both her and her friend to a tand: She abconded immediately, and et ome Perons to treat privately with my Father, who by this means got clear of her for a thouand Crowns, whereas before he had offer'd her two thouand.

My Relations, who aw plainly that this Match would have ruin'd me, were not orry for his mortification, hoping that this would teach him ome wit; but he was hardly out of one error before he had like to have fallen into another. He Lodg'd at a rich Merchants at the entrance into St. Dennis-treet, for the convenience of being near the Palace, who had in the houe an only Daughter between Nineteen and Twenty years of age, tollerably handom, but very well made; he had been extreamly pleas'd with her Converation, which very much diverted him when he had mot need of it: Having therefore ended his buines he thought he could not do better than to take up with her, who was a Woman of ene, brought up under the eye of her Mother, no wanton Coquet, that had an Etate, and who would think her elf honour'd in marrying a Peron of Quality. Her Father and Mother had everal times taken occaion to let him undertand, that having no more Children they hould be very glad to ee her well ettled; and he believing that
this would be a peron very fit for his turn, he breaks it to the Girl, who was eaily brought to be willing; he was overjoyed to find her o favourably inclin'd, and having now nothing to do but to gain her Father and Mother, he mov'd it to them, and had preently their conent.

As he had before made more hate than good peed, he now reolved for once to take advice, and Monieur de Marillac being one of the mot coniderable of his Friends, he was firt acquainted with it. My Father took a great deal of pains to reconcile him to a Match that eem'd dihonourable to the Family, and to that end fail'd not to magnifie the Peron of his Mitres, her Behaviour, her Breeding, her Dicretion, not forgeting her Etate, and the Honety of her Parents; and in hort, omitted nothing to remove any prejudice in his thoughts againt it. Monieur de Marillac, who was a Man of Honour, and vext to ee his Kinman going to match with a M • c •• nick, told him, he wondred he would run headlong upon uch an affair, in which he might perhaps find omething to dilike that he yet knew not of; that 'twas not his wonder that the young Lady, tho he had a good Etate, was o willing, becaue young Girls are all willing enough to be married; but that her Parents, who were Citizens, and conequently had a natural averion to a Country Gentleman, hould be o very forward, eem'd to him to have ome mytery in it, that deerved to be enquir'd into; and aving his repect for him, (aid he) while you think you are marrying a Maid, what if he hould chance to be a Widow? Had it been any body but Mr. de Marillac, my Father would never have born this dicoure with any patience; but having been born, as it were, with a repect for him, he only reply'd,
that there was nothing to be fear'd of that ort, and that he would venture it. Monieur de Marillac told him miling, That 'twas his own buines, and if he had aid any thing in it, 'twas purely for that he thought himelf oblig'd to it; not only as he was his Relation, but alo from the Friendhip which had always been between the two Families.

The matter reted there, and my Father reolved to go through with it, notwithtanding all this good counel. There was in the Country a Couin German of his, a jolly old Fellow, a Batchelour, who had never been o fond of marrying as he; and who deign'd to leave his Etate to our Family. My Father ends for him, and the Old Gentleman, before he would appear, would needs have ome fine Cloaths; and talking to his Taylor about the occaion of his coming to Town, that it was to the Wedding of his Couin and Heir, who was to be married to the Daughter of uch a Merchant. Bles me Sir! aid the Taylor, What does he mean? Is there no other Women in Paris? This tartled the Old Man, and asking him why he talkt at that rate? Why Sir, ays he, he has had a Child by one of her Fathers Prentices; but I hould not have poke of it, Sir, for it was but One, and I uppoe he is very honet • ow. How! ays the Old Gentleman, why then 'tis nothing with you here at Paris, for a Maid to have a Child? I don't ay o, Sir, replied the Taylor; and rather than a young Woman hould loe her Reputation, I was reolv'd never to have poke of it; but that 'tis a thouand pities, that an honest good Gentleman hould be cheated; for he not only continues her Debauchery, but 'tis come to that pas, that there's hardly a day comes over her head, but he is to be een at a certain place, right againt my Houe; he diguies her elf o, that he fancies he is not to be known, but he forgets that I
have formerly dealt with her Father, and know her well enough.

This dicoure, and the freedom and honety of the Taylor, very much urpriz'd our Couin; he ent preently for my Father, and repeating this tory, askt him what he meant, by medling with uch a creature. My Father lookt upon it all as Malice and Lyes; but the Old Man eeing him o reolute, told him in a rage, that for his part, he would not come to the Wedding, and beides that, would diinherit him if he proceeded any further in the matter. Yet my Father lighting all his threatnings, comes the ame day, and brings the Contract of Marriage for him to ign; intead of which, he natcht it out of the Notarys hands, and tore it in a thouand pieces; and not content with that, goes immediately to Monieur de Marillac, tells him the whole tory, and begs him to interpoe his Authority to prevent o candalous a thing. Monieur de Marillac tepping with him into his Coach, they came together to my Father, and told him, That knowing how obtinate he was, they did not come to deire him quite to break off the match, but to peruade him to inform himelf of the truth; that perhaps thee reports might be fale, but he mut own that they ought not to be neglected; that they only deign'd to open his Eyes, and if they could not make the thing plain to him, he was at his Liberty; that they deired but one thing of him, which was, that he would pretend extraordinary buines oblig'd him to go to his Houe in the Country for a few days, during which time, they offer'd to dicover the truth for him, or if not, they were content he hould proceed.

This was too reaonable a requet to be denied, o my Father having taken leave of his Mitres for
eight days, upon his promie to return then without fail, he went and lodg'd privately at the Taylors, where he plac'd himelf as Centinel, to watch for what he hardly dar'd to ee; 'twas but the next day that he very fairly aw his Lady, muffled up in her Scarf, going into the Bawdyhoue; but not truting his Eyes at that ditance, and through the Glas, he goes down, and throwing his Cloak over his Face, he talks up and down in the treet, till he hould come out; he knew her again well enough, but as if he would fain believe it was not he, he follow'd her to her Fa •• ers door, and confirm'd by her going in there, he was trangely confounded; but yet imagining that poibly there might be ome other family in that houe, he till jutify'd her in his thoughts, till he hould be inform'd how it was: But the Neighbours having atisfy'd him of the contrary, as alo the Taylor, he was reolv'd not to be convinc'd unles he could ee even what he did there with his own eyes: To which purpoe he goes himelf to that honet place, where he oon got acquaintance, and for his Money they brought him a Girl; he would not ask for another, for fear of giving upicion, but paid her very generouly, and o from that time pat for one of their bet Cutomers. The next day he came again, and having deir'd them to how him omething that was extraordinary, they brought him the peron he wiht for, or fear'd rather; for at the ight of her he was o toucht, as made him cry like a Child; and going out without peaking one word to her, took Hore and rode home to his own houe, without eeing o much as Monieur De Marillac.

But it is not o eaie a thing to get out of the hands of the Pariians; and my Father having had the dicretion, notwithtanding all that had been
aid to him, to ign the Contract, they fetcht him back ore againt his will, to clear himelf of the Eccleiatical Court, where they had obtain'd a Sentence againt him for two thouand Franks, with Damages and Interet. He never paid any thing in his life with o ill a will, wherefore he made an Appeal to the Parliament, and conulted with his Lawyers, eeing he was like to be cat, but all this did but encreae both his orrow and his debt; for the ame trick that had helpt him before, undid him now, and intead of his fine of two thouand Franks, he was forced to pay three thouand.

Tho he was incorrigible after the firt michance, every body thought that on the addition of this adventure, he had done with the thoughts of marrying: But it being decreed (as I aid) that I <> have a Mother-in-law, and that one as bad as poible, he married a Peron of Quality in the Country, who o mater'd his temper, that he was no ooner come home, but I was turn'd out of doors, and my Nure too: I was carried back to Olinville, on purpoe, as I uppoe, that as that place had been fatal to my Mother, it might be no better to me; I was kept there a whole year before my Nure ever heard a word from my Father, tho he had writ everal Letters to him, and her Husband had gone himelf to his Houe; but at lat one of his Carters paing near the Town, ent to tell my Nure, that he had order to leave with her about twelve Buhels of Wheat: As if that had been enough to atisfie her for my keeping; and to avoid being askt for Money, they let me lye there another whole year, without enquiring whether I was alive or dead: The poor people with whom I was, notwithtanding all this, us'd me like their own Child, whether taken with the little diverions
of my behaviour, or becaue they had no Children themelves, I know not, for they could have no other reaon for it.

My Father in the mean time forgot me with les difficulty, for that he had one Son already by my Mother-in-law, and he was ready to lye down of another; yet he could not avoid being often askt by the Neighbours what was become of me; my Mother had her anwer readier than my Father, (who was omething puzzl'd with thee quetions) and would reply briskly that I was well, but they did not fetch me home becaue I hould not bring the memory of my Mother into his mind; none but Sots could be wheedl'd with uch an anwer, and my Mothers Relations living above eighty Leagues off, and having no body to regard me, I continu'd three years longer with my Nure, and I believe hould have been there till had it not been for Monieur de Marillac; who eeing me at Mas at Olinville, asked notwithtanding the poor plight I was in, if I was not his Couin R's Son? I had always a good heart, and when I found my Nure would not anwer for me, I poke boldly to Monieur de Marillac, and told him that I was indeed the Son of Monieur L. C. De Rochefort, but that it had been my misfortune never to have een him that I remembred: my anwer pleas'd him, tho it was nothing but what I had learnt by hearing my Nure ay o; however being a brisk Boy, and if I may ay it, genteel enough, he made one of his Pages lead me to his Catle, where he order'd me to be cloath'd uitable to my quality; and having kept me there till he was oblig'd to return to Paris, he ent his Steward with me to my Father, to whom he writ, that I began now to be of an age in which he ought to take more care of me.

My Father receiv'd me becaue he could not help it, but much againt his will I am ure, for he ued me o roughly the very day I came to him, that as young as I was, I could plainly ee he did not much care for me; if I had dar'd, I would have askt him the reaon of it, and leave alo to return to my Nure, where I had received quite contrary uage; but being afraid to open my mouth, I tood in a corner as if I had not belong'd to the Family, while they caret and fondled one of her Children, tho he was as mangy and cabby as a Hound; this madded me intolerably, for being now almot ix years old, and beginning to have ome knowledge of matters, I was ready to burt with pleen. I liv'd thus however about a year and a half, eating with the Footmen, having no countenance from any body but from our Curate, who was a very good man; I pray'd him to teach me to read, for they never thought of putting me to School, and the Curate was o pleas'd with my motion, coming from my elf, that he took a great deal of pains with me, inomuch that in three or four months I could read perfectly in any ort of Books.

Every day my Mother-in-law plagu'd me with one thing or another, and not only did me all the michief he could, but told an hundred Lies of me to my Father, to et him againt me; and my Father, who did not much care for me, believ'd all he aid, and would often beat me without knowing for what, which made me o deperate that I reolved to poyon my elf. There was a Weed in the Garden which they had often told me was poion, I took ome of it; and after aying my Prayers I eat enough to have kill'd me twice over, if I had not happily wanted wit to know Hemlock from another Herb;
or, as I have often thought, that I was guided even by a Miracle to mitake, for I was o far from having any ymptoms of one that was poion'd, that it never o much as made me ick; I had newly begun to go to Confeion, and therefore could not conceal it from the Curate, who chid me everely, laying before me the heinounes of the in, and charg'd me to ask God forgivenes, and made me promie him never to do o any more without firt telling him of it.

The cruelty of my Mother-in-law and the unkindnes of my Father, not only continuing but encreaing, truly I ev'n reolv'd to run away; and o waiting for an opportunity, I told the Curate my intention, who told me I was fit for nothing at that age, being but eight years old; and therefore perwaded me to bear a little longer, till I was fit to go into the Army; but that being a long time, I told him reolutely that I neither could nor would endure it: He finding that unles I was prevented I hould quickly be gone, acquaints my Father with it, who eeming not to believe it, told him he hould not trouble him elf about me, but let me go if I would; the Curate eeing him o unnatural could not forbear weeping, and taking me in his arms entreated me once more to have a little patience; but finding it impoible to hake my reolution, he pull'd out of his Pocket two Crowns and gave them to me, telling me that he was enible I hould want them, and was orry he was not in a condition to ait me better; o praying God to bles me, told me I was always to remember that I was born a Gentleman, which oblig'd me to uffer a thouand deaths rather than to do a bae action, or any thing unworthy of my quality. My deign was to find out Monieur de
Marillac, from whom I had already receiv'd o much kindnes; but there happening at that time to be a Troop of Gypies in our Village I fell in with them, and asking them if they would take me with them, they told me with all their hearts, if I were able to travel.

This was enough to make me one of the Gang, and having left our houe without taking leave of any body, and oon forgetting the good advice of the Curate, I began that very day, like a true Gypie, to teal all the Cocks and Hens I could lay my hands on, not regarding that it was but at my Fathers door, and that all the Farmers thereabouts were his Tenants: Thus I went on without giving my elf leave to think what I was doing; and every one having got his booty they were to bring it to the Captain, who eeing me have ix or even Fowls for my hare, gave me a dram of the Bottle and told the ret what a hopeful beginning I had made, and that in time I hould make a brave fellow: we feated that Night at the expence of the Country, and as liberty is weetet to thoe who have been under contraint, I thought my elf in Heaven in comparion of the life I liv'd before.

I led this wretched ort of Life almot five years, in which time we travert not only all over France but many other Countries; at lat a mall misfortune befalling us (only that ome of our Society chanc'd to be hang'd) we were forc'd to take refuge in our Native Country; o we return'd into France through the Province of Burgundy, and taking the Road to Dijon we came into the Country of Lyonne, and from thence into Dauphine, and o into Languedoc, till at lat we came to the County of Foix: Here we thought our elves ecure, for the Country being Mountainous,
would the better helter us we fancy'd from the Peaants, if we found them o uncivil as to reent our Thieveries: but we had taken wrong meaures, and they were too cunning for us, for the very firt Night, while we were all catter'd here and there, after our Game, they came upon us and plundred our Baggage: this happen'd to us by the neglect of thoe we had left to look after it, who foolihly running after ome Fowls left on purpoe by the Peaants to draw them from their charge, they who had plac'd themelves in Ambucade urpriz'd our Camp and ruin'd our whole Army; and to add to our misfortune they had penn'd up all their Fowls, o that tho we came back very much fatigu'd, we were forc'd to take up our Lodging on the hard ground, and without our Supper.

This Life began to grow irkom to me at lat, tho I was pleas'd with it a while when I knew no better; for as my undertanding encreat I began to be aham'd of my elf, remembring my Birth and what that requir'd of me; I cry'd often by my elf, and finding no body to conult with, I was enible of the want of good advice; at lat calling to mind what the Curate had aid to me at my coming away, I eriouly askt my elf, Is this the Life of a Gentleman?

This thought, which had not o much as once came into my head before, made uch an impreion upon me that I reolv'd to deert, and being ent abroad as uual, I took that opportunity to get away; o making to the Mountains of Capi, I entred Rouillon by Ville Franche; as I went I aw on my right hand Canigout, one of the highet of the Pyrenees, on the top of which is a Lake, with abundance of very good Fih; but that which is mot trange is, that if one
throw a tone into it, it preently falls a raining: I askt the people thereabouts the reaon, but they could not tell me.

I had hitherto kept the Curates two Crowns in my Pocket, and they did me pecial ervice at this juncture. My deign was to lit my elf in the firt Company of Souldiers I could meet with, and did not quetion but I hould be entertain'd, for they did not meaure Souldiers by inches in thoe days. My Gypies complexion made me pas among the Spaniards for a Native of the Country; and tho we had War with Spain at that time, yet they neither topt me at Perpignan, nor at Sales; at lat I got to Locates, which was our Frontier on that ide, and lited in the Governours Company, who was Monieur De St. Aunais.

There was not a Party made out againt the Garrion of Sales but I would be one, and having learnt a little Spanih, I fancy'd that looking o like a Spaniard I might have an advantage one time or other to do omething that might ditinguih my elf: for I mut needs ay I began to depie the life of a common Souldier, and Ambition was o got into my Crown, tho but 15 years old, that I could not leep quietly for dreaming of great things: I askt leave however of Monieur De St. Aunais, and he gave it me, but eeing me come home always and nothing done, Souldier, aid he, you don't do well, a Man hould rather loe his Ears than do as you do; we may ee our Enemies when we will, but he that asks leave to ee them mut go near them. I have been near enough, Sir, return'd I, but we were too many of us, and I don't intend to hare the honour I hall get with a whole Company. Why, how many were you? aid he: We were eleven, Sir, aid I, and that was too many by nine; but if you pleae to let me go again
to morrow with only my Comrade, you hall have no caue to reproach me. Won't you run away then? aid the Governour: If I had a mind to run away, Sir, aid I, I would never come to ask leave: I have been twice up to the Enemies Palliades, and if I had intended to have gone over, no body could have hindred me. This boldnes pleas'd him, and he ask'd me who I was? I told him if I ucceeded in my deign I would give him an account, but if not I would wait for a more favourable opportunity: This anwer pleas'd him better till, and concluding by my dicoure that I was ome body more than ordinary, he lov'd me from that moment, and 'twas not long before he gave me proofs of it.

Having leave to go out the next day, and being come within two Muquet hot of Sales, I made my Comrade lie down in a Ditch while I advanc'd a little nearer, and having oberv'd when I was out before that an Officer of the Garrion, who had an intrigue with a Wench, us'd to meet her in the Ruines of an old houe, I thought to have hid my elf in the ame houe, but I had oberv'd too that he always ent a Souldier a little before him to ee if the Coat was clear, and I was loth to run the hazard of failing in my Enterprize; but having pitcht upon a place for my Ambucade, I made as if I was wahing of Clothes; till keeping an Eye upon the place; at lat out comes the Souldier, and having couted in every corner, he had no ooner made his report, but I perceiv'd Madamoielle coming one way, and Mr. Officer another; but while they were warm at it, I ruht in with a Pitol in each hand, and in this urprize he uffer'd me to diarm him as tamely as a Lamb: after which I bid him walk before me, and told him, if he offer'd to peak a word, I would hoot him into
the Guts: He did not think fit to try if I was a man of my word, and I thinking it proper to bring his Mitris along with me, if 'twere only to prevent her giving the Alarm, I brought them to the place where I had poted my Comrade, who having joyn'd me, and thereby taken from them all hopes of ecape, they were very diconolate; but for my part I was o tranported, that I hardly knew what I did: we marcht in this figure a long hour, till my Comrade, who took a fancy to the Girl, finding we were out of danger of the Enemy, would go no further, till he had had a touch with her; I askt him if he was mad, but he only laughing at me, was very fairly going to work with her. This put me into a paion, but finding he was reolv'd upon his deign, I threatned to hoot him. He told me he was ready for me, and preented his Pitol at me, I was not tartled at all, but coming boldly up to him with my Prioner in one hand, and my Pitol in the other, the Brute fir'd at me, but miing me, and expecting my return, made all the hate he could to get away: I did not much care to follow him, but made the bet of my way, for all my fear was he would run over to the Garrion of Sales, and give an account of the matter; and my afety was wholly owing to this peed, for jut as I imagin'd it fell out; I was hardly got under the Walls of the Town, when appear'd three Officers well mounted who had puru'd me; but eeing me jut at the Gates they thought not fit to advance any further. I entred Locates in triumph, every one running out into the treet to ee a Boy of ixteen years old bring in two Prioners, and I was well guarded to the Governours Houe. As oon as I aw him, Now, Sir, aid I, you ee I have been near enough to the Enemy, I told you a
great number would not do the buines, for tho we were but two, we were too many by one. He askt me what I meant by that? whereupon I told him in hort the Adventure with my Comrade. He was pleas'd to peak very much in my praie, and to magnify the Action much more than it deerv'd, and immediately giving me a Colours in the Regiment of Piccardy, which was wholly at his dipoal, as well as all the Vacancies of the Garrion; he very obligingly told me, he hould not top there, but would take particular care of my fortune.

But that which made the mot noie was, that the Prioner I had taken happen'd to be a Lieutenant to the King of Spain, and Monieur De St. Aunais having ent word of it to Court, and the particulars of the action, Cardinal Richelieu writ to him to end me forthwith to Paris, and order'd me a hundred Pitoles for the charges of my Journey. I leave you to imagine the inexpreible Joy I was in; and having given Monieur De St. Aunais all imaginable thanks, whom I acknowledg'd to be my Benefactor, he deired me before I went, to tell him who I was: o I gave him a brief account of all my little Adventures: He told me, that tho Virtue was to be valu'd where ever it was found, yet he was glad to hear I was a Gentleman, becaue it always receiv'd a Lutre from a Peron of Quality. Go, ays he, and wait on the Cardinal, he loves a bold man, and is very fond of engaging uch in his Service, and if I am not mitaken, he intends to do omething coniderable for you.

I left Locates with a great deal of atisfaction, having bought a couple of Hores, and got me a Man to wait on me; and that Pride which is o natural to youth, being gotten into my head, nothing would erve me, but I mut go how my elf in this figure
in my own Country; and never conidering the los of my time, I turn'd out of the great Road at Briare, and came that night to the Houe of my old Friend the Curate. He was urpriz'd, and overjoy'd to ee me, and after I had told him my adventures, and whether I was bound, I gave him a great many thanks for his former kindnees, and preenting him with ten Pitoles, I aur'd him, that if ever I made my fortune, I would not be unmindful of him: He told me I hould find my Fathers Family much encreat, that he had even Children, not reckoning me into the number; that his affairs alo were in no very good condition, having lately met with a very great los, which he believ'd was a judgment upon him for his cruelty to me; whereupon he gave me an account of a very trange accident which befel him, as you hall hear. There was one Courtilz, a Kinman of ours, a Peron of Quality, and related to mot of the Gentry of that Province, but had the misfortune not to have an Etate anwerable to his Birth, and to the figure he made, for he was one of the genteelet Men in the Kingdom; as he was waiting for ome Preferment his buines lay motly at Paris, and whether he was upply'd by ome of the Sex, or had a lucky hand at Play, he always liv'd high, and kept the bet Company; he falling in Love with a young Widow, that had a very good Etate, courted her in hopes to carry her by his Gallantry, and that obliging manner which was o peculiar to himelf; but the Lady, who either had no inclination for him, or which was mot likely, had oblig'd her elf to a religious Life, deir'd him in hort to trouble her no further: The difficulty encreat his Paion, he haunted her every where, and tho he had forbid him her Houe, he contriv'd his buines o well, that he aw her every
day, either at Church, or at ome friends houe or other; but he, to be rid of him for good and all, retir'd her elf into a Convent; this madded him o, that he threatned to fire the houe; and he, for fear he hould be as good as his word, was fain to remove: But finding that he continu'd reolute not to admit him, he contriv'd to teal her; of which having ome intimation, he prevented him by going privately out of Town, and having told no body of her going but one particular friend, nor taken any of her ervants with her, her relations were in a fright for her, and having not heard of her in everal days, they concluded Courtilz had carry'd her away, as he had been heard to ay he would do; o they complain'd to the Court of Jutice againt him, and upon the hearing of their Witnees they obtain'd an Arret againt him. Any man but Courtilz would have prevented all this, for he being innocent had nothing to fear; but whether he was otherwie employ'd, or thought it not worth his while, he wholly neglected it, till at lat he was fain to take Sanctuary at my Fathers, and finding himelf dicover'd there, was forc'd to remove from thence too. It happen'd jut at that time my Father had receiv'd a coniderable um of Money, about twenty thouand Crowns: Some Rogues having notice of all this, they dret themelves up like Pouruivants, and pretending to earch the houe for Courtilz, they eiz'd upon my Father, and clapping a Pitol to his throat, demanded where was his Money? which he, having no occaion to dye, was oblig'd to dicover to them; with which they loaded one of his own Hores, and he had the atisfaction of eeing them make their ecape over the Foret, from one of the Turrets of the Catle, where they had lockt up both him, and all the Family.

This was a great los for a Gentleman of but twenty thouand Livres a year Etate, and eight Children; o not doubting but he was very much concern'd, I did not know whether I had bet ee him or not, for my company being never very agreeable to him, I thought now it might encreae his affliction; but thinking alo he might reflect upon me if I was wanting in my Duty, I went to wait on him, and was received by him not a jot better than I expected: for my Mother-in-Law uppoing I was come to dwell with them again, and let I hould pretend to be one of the Family, forbid the Servants giving my Hores either Oats or Hay. My man giving me an account of this, I ent hi • for ome to the Curate; and my Father happening to be in the Stable, aw it all, without giving orders to the contrary: Tho this did not at all agree with me, and I was ready to burt with anger, yet being reolv'd to go away the next morning, I took no notice of it, but went up to my Chamber earlier than ordinary; and as I was jut going into Bed, up comes my Father, and my Mother-in-Law, and askt me in a ort of rallying, if I was going to wait upon the Cardinal by his order; as my Man it eems had aid among the Servants. I plainly aw the bottom of the Quetion, and that 'twas only to tand fair with me, in
• ae I hould chance to meet with any thing, and therefore anwer'd very coldly, that it was true; my Father told me he was very glad I was like to come to preferment; and with that word my Mother-in-Law invited me to tay, and told me I hould be welcome, and hop'd, he aid, that when I had made my own Fortune, I would not be unmindful of my Brothers: I anwer'd her in the ame tone of indifference, that 'twas not yet a thing done; but if I
hould be o fortunate as perhaps I might, I hould always return Good for Evil.

This ort of dicoure gave me light into her temper, and I dare ay was the occaion, that he began to make excues for her behaviour to me, and particularly for refuing Hay to my Hores; he told me 'twas becaue the Groom did not know me, and they had charg'd him ever ince their late misfortune to give none to Strangers; but he would take care to prevent it for the future. I knew well enough what I thought of this; but dicretion and repect obliging me to conceal my reentment, I told them that it was but a mall matter, and not worth taking notice of. My Father then began to enquire what had become of me all this while, and gave me a mall reprimand for never letting him hear from me, and begun to talk to me a little like a Father.

After a thouand other quetions, they left me to go to Bed; and having told them I mut go away the next day, I found in the Morning a Breakfat prepar'd as if there had been a Wedding. They ent two hours before day to all our Relations, that were any thing near, with a ort of a circular Letter, to acquaint them of the occaion of my going to Court, and to invite them all to come and take their leave of me: Away they come, ome on Foot, ome on Horeback; and I was mother'd with Compliments from a matter of ten or twelve Gentlemen, as if I had been already ome great Peron, and in a condition to make all their fortunes. To deliver my elf from this Farce, which was very uneay to me, I begg'd my Father to permit me to haten, for I had lot too much time already; and the Cardinal who expected People hould be punctual, would perhaps think me long: That I had come two
days Journey out of my way, on purpoe to pay my duty to him, but I hop'd he would not deire me to prejudice my elf. My Mother-in-Law, who was preent at this Compliment, no ooner heard it, but he goes her elf into the Kitchen, and never tirr'd thence till Dinner was erv'd up.

This which I aw at my Fathers, was but the very ame which I afterwards found to be the practice at Court. Aoon as I was arriv'd there, and it was known that I was the Cadet of Locates, every one made their Compliments to me; and I was trangely urpriz'd to ee thoe People, whom I hould have thought it honour enough to have poken to once a week, wait upon me to beg my friendhip. The Captain of the Guard to his Eminence, to whom I had addret my elf, having told him that I was in the Antichamber, I was order'd to be call'd in: Who eeing that I was but a Beardles Boy, and very hort too of my age, he turn'd to four or five great Lords that were with him, and aid miling St. Aunais urely has put a trick upon us: Why? This is but a Child.

My Lord, aid I, making a profound Reverence, I know not what Mr. de St. Aunais may have inform'd your Eminence, but if it was only that I took the King's Lieutenant of Sales, and his Mistris, I can aure you 'tis nothing but the Truth. Ay, but he has told us more than that, reply'd the Cardinal: We have a long Story here, how you prevented the Souldier that wou'd have kit the Girl; and how you attackt him, and he fir'd his Pitol at you; notwithtanding which, you drove him away and brought off your Prioners. 'Tis all very true, my Lord, aid I, but thee are but mall matters: I hope if I may be o happy as to find an opportunity, I hall perform much greater, for the Service of the King and of your Eminence.
He is a bold Lad, aid the Cardinal to the Lords again, but he is but a Boy till; and 'tis pitty to expoe him o young, and as it were to force nature. This dicoure put me in great fear he would do nothing for me, wherefore I return'd preently, I am more capable, my Lord, than you may think me, and your Eminence may find me o, if you pleae to command me any thing for your Service. He made me no anwer, but peaking oftly to the Captain of his Guards, bad him entertain me with the Gentlemen, and to inform himelf who I was, and o retir'd into his Cloet This both urpriz'd and afflicted me; for I expected that I hould no ooner have appear'd before him, but I hould have had ome great matter.

The Captain of the Guard not failing to do as he was directed, and having given the Cardinal an account that I was a Gentleman, after Dinner I was call'd into the Cloet, where his Eminence told me he had, as a mark of his favour, reolv'd to entertain me in his Service; that I hould be wie and faithful, and I hould have no caue to repent me. I made him a low Reverence in token of my acknowledgment, till expecting ome very coniderable Buines, or Office to be betow'd upon me; but I was urpriz'd to find all my preferment um'd up in a Livery, and that at lat I hould have come o far to be the Cardinals Footboy. I was not o much Mater of my paion, but that he perceiv'd it in my countenance: Let not this trouble you, aid he, with a weetnes that reconcil'd all things, 'Tis becaue I would have you always near me; time may be, I hall be perhaps but too kind to you.

The obliging way with which he poke this, catter'd all the dicontent that, as I aid, appear'd in my face, and having made him again a mot profound
reverence, I expected preently to go and change my figure, or at leat that ome body hould be order'd to take meaure of me for my Cloaths. But the Governour of the Pages told me, I mut write to my Father to end me four hundred Crowns for my Livery, and Trimming, and Preents that I mut make, and that nothing would be done before. I was in a great confuion at this, I knew well enough to how little purpoe 'twould be for me to write to my Father: I was content to ell my Hores, but that would not raie my Stock above fifty Pitoles, which was not half the Sum he talkt of: To ask my Relations I thought very improper, ince they all thought my fortune was made, and expected great things from me. I lept not a wink that night for thinking what method I hould take to get over this affair, I reolv'd at lat to try Monieur de Marillac, which was all the hopes I had left; but having been diorder'd all night, 'twas too late e're I got up to go to him till after dinner: And in the mean time to how my elf aiduous, I went to wait on the Cardinal, who no ooner aw me, but he askt me why I had not my Livery on? My Lord, aid I, 'tis truly for want of Money; and our Governour tells me, I mut bring him four hundred Crowns firt, and that then it hall be dip •• cht. What an exacting Rogue is this, aid he, to thoe that were about him, hrinking up his houlders, and turning to me, Go, ays he, and tell him from me, if he offers to take one Farthing of you, I hall turn him out of doors immediately; and further, that if it be not done by to morrow morning without fail, he hould pleae to eek out a new Mater.

You may eaily imagin I was very well pleas'd with this errand, and knowing I was well backt, I did not leave out a word of the meage, but told it with all the advantage I could, for his mortification;
however he oberv'd the order punctually, and I laid out only ten or twelve Pitoles to buy ome little necearies which he gave me not: and this the Cardinal not only paid me, but made them give me three times that um for my reimburement.

Tho I was to be but a Page, yet I fail'd not to be the Favourite, for his Eminence had none o agreeable to him as my elf; he would have me do every thing, and I to how my ene of his favour, was contantly at his Elbow, ready to receive his Command: at Table, 'twas I till that erv'd him the Wine, not for want of others readines, for they envy'd me for it, but he would call me by my name, as if there had been no body ele there, to prevent their diligence. When he went to Madam D' Eguillon 'twas the ame thing, there was no body but I went with him, where he plac'd me in the Antichamber, into which no body came, but if he wanted to peak with any body, I was ent to them, and brought them in, and let them out, by a private Stair-cae, that 'twas impoible for any body to dicover them.

I know 'twas reported he was in Love with that Lady, who was his Niece, I do not ay it was not o, he was handome enough to tempt as great a man as he; but this I am ure of, that for my part I hould have been tranported to have had but the eteem of o fine a creature, tho I had been a Cardinal my elf. And this I think my elf oblig'd to ay to undeceive poterity, that he went to ee her many times upon other buines than his diverion, where he lockt himelf up with perons that he could ee in no other place without upicion, epecially Strangers, ometimes diguis'd like Monks, ometimes like other Eccleiatics, and ometimes like Merchants
It fell out once, that after one of thee conferences, he order'd me to take a Bag, I know not what was in it, but 'twas very heavy, and to go along the road to Pontoie, telling me at the entrance into a Village called Sanois, I hould find a Capuchin aleep, with his Coul or Hood hanging down behind him; that I hould ay ne're a word to him, but put the Bag into the Coul, and come away: I found every thing jut as he had told me, and executed his orders punctually.

But before he employ'd me in uch ecret things as thee, he made tryal of me by a paage that was very particular. He had a Man call'd Sauvé, whom he us'd to employ about uch matters, and had ent him two or three times into Spain, to dicover ome intrigues that were carrying on there againt his interet. This man had a very handome Wife, and being order'd by the Cardinal to try my fidelity, he ets his Wife to work, with whom he uffer'd me to ue uch liberty, that one might wear for him he was not jealous. His Wife was at firt ight very free with me, and the deign being to entrap me, by the mot infallible nare in the world, epecially to a young man, he began to be pleaanter than ordinary. But having, by I know not what means, oblig'd her, he told me down-right the whole cheat, and caution'd me to have a care; after this he gave an account to her Husband jut as I directed her, and the Cardinal being inform'd from him (who to gain his favour, told him ingeniouly he had acrific'd his Wife, and would not tick to acrifice himelf for his ervice) he had from that time uch confidence in me, that I was always employ'd in affairs of the the greatet conequence.

A few days after this he order'd me to put off my Livery, and go into the Hore Market, to a certain houe which he directed me to; that I hould go up four pair of tairs, and if I found a Cros made with Chalk on a Chamber Door I hould come down, and tay below till Sauvé came to me. I found jut as he had aid, and having plac'd my elf at the Street Door, with my Cloak thrown over my face, Sauvé came to me, and askt me how it was? I told him I had found that which his Eminence deir'd; then he askt me if I had not een two men go out, one habited like a Priet, and the other with a hort Cloak like an Abbot; I told him No: he bid me look out harp, and if they hould appear, I hould walk along before them, till I came to the Hopital de la Pit • é; and if not, I hould tand Centinel there till he came again. It was an hour and half before he came again, but 'twas in good company when he did come, for he brought a Squadron of the Guards with him, of whom a Party beet the houe, and the ret went up tairs, where they found in the Chamber, the two men decrib'd to me, who they took and carry'd to the Batile: But there was but one of them committed, the other was let go, and I carry'd him the next day ten thouand Crowns in Gold, which was the recompence they had promis'd him, for betraying and elling his Companion.

Finding my elf employ'd in uch ecret affairs, I heartily wiht my elf a year or two older; for I fancy'd the Cardinal would find me other buines, when I was a little too old for a Page, and I long'd to be in the Wars, to which I had a particular inclination. In the mean time my Father, and my Mother-in-law, having inform'd themelves that all my hopes were ended in a Livery, were orry for thoe little
civilities they had done me; but this hindred me not from thinking, if I could poible, to do omething for my younger Brothers, who had need enough; and to give them aurance of my good will, I wrote to them all to give me notice, if any Benefice hould preent in their Country: but they ent me word, that I needed not to how my elf o vain, for they knew well enough what interet I had, and were content I hould make ue of it for whom I pleas'd.

I hould have taken this as a great affront from any body ele, and o I did from them too; and the Cardinal being pleas'd a little after that, to enquire of me about my Family, I told him not only this paage, but what uage I had receiv'd when I was but a Child; he was extreamly taken with all my freedom, and finding he delighted to hear me relate the little adventures of my life, I took occaion to tell him of the kindnes I had receiv'd from the Curate, magnifying the obligation I thought my elf under to him as much as I could: He told me he was glad to ee me o grateful; but at the ame time, as I happen'd to peak of the Meieurs de Marillac, he askt me if they knew I was with him, and if I had een any of them lately? I told him No, but I intended to wait on them with the firt conveniency: to which he anwer'd, that I mut not do o, if I thought of continuing in his favour. I durt not reply to o poitive a command
• and he perceiving that I was not only urpriz'd, but atoniht; At leat, aid he, if you hould meet with any of them, never open your Lips of what I have aid to you; and be aur'd if you ever hould, you have nothing more to hope for from me. I told him, 'twas enough for me to know his Pleaure, and that I hould know neither Friend nor Relation, when his Eminence's Service was the quetion.

He was very well atisfy'd with my anwer, and continu'd to employ me as freely as before; among the ret he ent me one time with a great Bag full of Gold, and order'd me to lay it under a broad Freetone, which I hould find upon a heap of other Stones, a little beyond Montfaucon, on the Road to St. Denis; and withal I was not to come back the ame way, that I might not ee, I uppoe, who hould come to fetch it: Another time I carried uch a like Cargo to Notre Dame, to a Man whom he told me I hould find leaning againt a Tree, with his head on one hand, and the other hand behind him, jut for all the world in uch a poture, as Moliere acts the covetous Phyician; I was to put the Money into that hand which he held behind him, but not to ee his face at all, and o to come my way; I thought there was more mytery in all this than there was occaion for, and that it was only to make proof of my Fidelity, or to render his management of affairs more valuable for its ecrecy. However it was, I pent two years in uch ort of buinees, in which time there were many Plots at Court to remove him from the Minitry, but all to no purpoe.

In the mean time, having writ to the Curate as well as to my Father, to inform me if any thing happen'd in their Country that I might beg for him, there came now an Expres to me from him, to tell me that a mall Abbey of about four thouand Franks per annum was become vacant, I immediately begg'd it of the Cardinal, and he granted it me at the firt word, but wou'd needs know who it was, I begg'd it for. My Lord, aid I, for our Curate, who taught me to read, and to whom I told your Eminence I had o many obligations. And why not for one of your Brothers, aid he, I think you told me you had everal, and they needy enough? 'Tis true,
my Lord, aid I, but as Providence has done by me, I am oblig'd to prefer my Gratitude before even my natural affection; thus your Eminence can judge, if after all the obligations I have to you, I ought not to erve you above all the world. We hall ee that, reply'd the Cardinal miling, and may chance to put you to the tryal ooner than you think of.

I was jut going to anwer him again, when the Prince of Conde came into the room, which made me poil my Compliment to help him to a Chair: He made but a hort viit, and the Cardinal waiting on him to the Chamber-door, py'd Monieur De Charrot, who was but an inconiderable peron then, but one who we have een ince Captain of the Guards du Corps, Governour of Calais, Duke, and Peer of France: The Cardinal had a mortal averion to him, o that he was no ooner tept back into his Chamber, but he order'd me to call the Captain of his Guard, whom he gave a trict charge, at any rate to rid him of that piece of Impertinence, and that he hould order the Guards to deny him entrance: The Captain of the Guard askt him if he hould turn him out of the Anti-chamber? I don't ay o, ays the Cardinal, but that you hould keep him out for the future. This Order being known all over the houe in a moment, every body turn'd their backs upon the poor Gentleman, and were as hye of him as if he had had the Plague: I know not whether he apprehended any thing, but he took no notice of it, and taid three long hours in the Antichamber. The Cardinal, who had a mind to go out, ent me to ee if he was there till, and having told him that he was, he choe rather to tay in his Chamber, than expoe himelf to his Compliment. The next day Charrot came to the door again, and offering to come
in as uual, the Guards thrut him away; and he asking to peak with their Captain, the Captain order'd them to tell him he was not within; he beieg'd the houe thus two days, before he could ee the Cardinal, but on the third day he put himelf jut in his way, as he went to Mas: The Guards routed him again, and would let him tand quietly no where; whereupon he leapt up into a Nich, that was deign'd to et a Statue in; and when the Cardinal came by, My Lord, aid he, your Guards have refus'd me entrance at your Gate; but if you hut me out at your Door, I'll come in at the Window. The Cardinal could not forbear laughing to ee him tand o like an Image; and finding him o very zealous to him, he was ever after very kind to him. Monieur de Charrot having thus gain'd admiion, continu'd to make his court to him very diligently, without asking any thing, tho he had need enough; the Cardinal was oblig'd the more at that, for he was always pleas'd if he aw himelf lov'd without a principle of Interet; and would do the more for any peron for not being importun'd. In the mean while an opportunity offer'd o happily for him, that now was his time to make ue of the Cardinals favour: wherefore waiting to find him in a good humour, he comes briskly to him one day; If I durt, my Lord, aid he, I would ask your Eminence to help me to 200000 Crowns, without one farthing charge, either to the King or your elf. How then, Charrot? reply'd the Cardinal miling. To Marry me, my Lord, with your own hand, return'd Charrot; I have found out a Fortune, and if your Eminence will but peak a word for me, my buines is done. If it tops only there, aid the Cardinal, you may reckon it done indeed. He threw himelf at his feet, and embrac'd his knees, in token of thankfulnes; telling him, that
all he deir'd of him, was to end and demand Madamoielle Lecalopier for him. The Cardinal did it, to the atonihment of all people, who knew that he never car'd to meddle in uch ort of things. The Relations of the Lady could not refue a man of his Authority; o Charrot having got uch a Fortune, was in a condition to buy ome coniderable place, and the Cardinal, who never uffer'd any body to be near the King but uch as were his own Creatures, and wholly at his ervice, treated for him to be Captain of the Guards du Corps.

In the mean time I got my little Abbey, as I aid before, and ent the Bulls all Perfum'd to the Curate, which wrought thee two different effects, that he was like to dye with Joy, and my Father and Mother-in-law with orrow: They came all to Paris, the Curate to give me thanks, and acknowledge my kindnes, and they to load me with a thouand reproaches: They askt me, If I was not aham'd to provide for trangers, when my own Brothers had o much occaion; but at lat, when they had vented their paion, they began to talk at another rate, and ell to perwading me to beg another Abbey of the Cardinal; I told them it was not my fault they had not this; but this was not the way at Court, for 'twas not always a fit time to ask, and the certain way to get nothing was to be always begging: That if the Cardinal had been o kind to me, being but his Page, I hop'd to be more in his favour, when I was in a better condition to erve him; that I was not without natural affections, tho I had no great reaon for it; but that I hould always conider what my honour oblig'd me to, without calling to mind any of my jut reentments; and with thee ort of hopes I appeas'd them. I had no ooner clear'd my hands of them,
but I had all our Province about me, thinking, becaue I had gotten this Abbey for our Curate, I could not but be very prodigal of my favours to them all; ome of them came from the very further end of Berry, whom I had never een nor heard of, • eizing me every hour with their Genealogy, making it out very plainly, that they were my Couins in the third degree, and therefore hop'd I would ue my Interet to procure them ome preferment. I made hort with them, and told them, I had as good a will to erve them as any man in the world, but it was not in my power, which they might eaily ee, for that I had got nothing yet for my Brothers, who being in the firt degree, 'twas but reaonable hould be firt regarded; and that then I had ome Relations in the econd Degree, who pretended to ome priviledge before them; that when I had preferr'd them all, then they might depend upon me, that I hould do them all the ervice I could: They undertood me well enough, and o getting rid of them they left me in quiet.

At lat the happy hour was come, which I had o long wiht for, when I hould lay down the office of a Page, with which I was never very well pleas'd; the Cardinal gave me two hundred Pitoles to buy me Clothes, and told me I hould be one of his Gentlemen. I had hopes now he would have done ome great thing for me; however I did not continue long idle, but went over into England, and into Scotland, with Letters written in Cyphers; and thoe Countries being in Arms, I was eiz'd by a Party of the King of England's Army, whom I was as much afraid of, as of thoe of the Parliaments: They immediately earcht me, but found nothing about me, for I had put my Letters into my Pot-hores Saddle; the
Plates of which I had made on purpoe at Paris, being of double Iron, contriv'd to hold the Letters in the inide, and unles they broke them, they did nothing. They ranackt the very Pummels of the Saddle, but to no purpoe, for they could not find my Packet: Then they askt me whence I came? whither I was going? and a thouand impertinent quetions; and I anwer'd them all as I found proper, being prepar'd to meet with uch like interruptions; telling them, I was a young Gentleman that was travelling: But this gave them the more upicion, finding my Equipage did not agree with the Character I gave my elf, o they topt me four or five days, at which I was very uneaie, for I carry'd along with me (if I am not very much mitaken) buines of no mall conequence; uch as if I hould be dicovered with, I knew my fate: but what comforted me was, that my Letters were perfect Magick, and written in uch a character, that the Devil could not have read them. They had no regular Alphabet, as is cutomary in uch caes, but the ame troke or dah would ignify twenty different words, that it was impoible but for them that had the key, to make any thing of it: as for example, you mut know it was agreed, that one troke hould ignify an entire word of a Line in St. Autin, and to know which it was, the figure of the Page was put under the troke, and the number of the line, and the number of the word in the line, and to make it the plainer, the mark or troke was to be the firt letter of the word. As to explain it; uppoe the word was Have, and that this word was to be found in the 10th Page of St. Autin, the 10th line, the 5th word in the line, the cypher would have been thus

This being o contriv'd, I leave any one to judge, if 'twas poible, without conjuring, to have found out my Errand, and yet I trembled every joynt of me; for I knew if they found out my Letters, the more difficulty they had in dicovering the Contents, the wore I might expect to be handled by them. But it being my good fortune not only to ecure my Packet, but alo that they believ'd me too young to be capable of uch ort of Negotiations, they let me go, and I deliver'd my dipatches, and return'd afe with an anwer. I was very well paid for this Journey; for I had an order to the Financier for two thouand Crowns, and one of the Pay-maters demanding a conideration of me for prompt payment, was turn'd out of his place upon my complaint to the Cardinal. I know not whether the Genius of the Englih Subject to take up Arms on every light occaion, or this Voyage of mine wrought the effects that follow'd, but thoe three Kingdoms, who, as I aid, were diturb'd before, immediately upon this broke out into confuion, inomuch that the King of England, who had given us no great marks of his good will in everal caes, found his hands o full at home, that there was no great fear of his being troubleom to us.

And what makes me think we had a deeper hand in this affair than others, is omething that happen'd to me three months after my return; being one morning, as I eldom mit, at the Cardinals Leve • , he whiper'd me, and bid me go to the Fauxbourg St. Marceau, over againt the Conduit, to the ign of a Woman without a Head, and to go up two pair of tairs, where I hould find a man lying on a Bed with yellow Curtains, whom I hould order to be at Madam D' Eguillons, at Eleven a Clock at night
without fail. I deliver'd my meage immediately, and being not forbidden to ee this mans face, as in other caes, I call'd to mind that I had een him in Scotland, and I believe he knew me too, for I oberv'd that he lookt earnetly at me, as if he would have recollected who I was; we neither of us aid any thing of what we thought, only that he told me he would not fail the appointment. At the time aforeaid, I was order'd to tay for him at the door, to introduce him into the Cardinals Cloet; he came diguis'd like one that crys Wafers in the Streets, and I, hearing a man cry Wafers, was far enough from imagining that 'twas he; but he knowing me, and dicovering himelf, I brought him to the Cardinal, with whom he was hut up till four a clock the next morning; all the Cardinals men had orders to go home, which gave further occaion to the talk that was made of him, and of his Neice Madam D. Eguillon; no body imagining he had any buines to keep him there all night, but to lye with her; beides they had taken out the Keys, that they might go out when they pleas'd, and this made the Ladys Servants be as forward as any in the report: I don't ay this to affirm that there was no privacies between them, but to hew, as I aid, that all the times he taid there were not the effects of an Amour.

The conference being over, my Wafer-merchant comes out of the Cloet, at the door whereof I had waited by the Cardinals order; his Eminence made me lend him my Cloak, for 'twas no time of night to cry Wafers, and order'd me at the ame time to go with him two Streets on his way. Two days after he call'd me to him again, and bid me go to Monieur de Bullion, Superintendant of the Finances, to order him from him to deliver me that parcel
which he had made up, and then to carry it into the Rue de • a Huchette, to the ame peron I have been mentioning, whom I hould find at his Lodgings, at the Sign of the Sow and Pigs, at the further end of the Court, up one pair of tairs; I found the parcel ready, but it was o heavy that it had more need of a Cart to carry it, which Mr. de Bullion knowing before, had provided one, and having put it into the Cart, he gave me a Note that contain'd the particulars of what was in it; telling me I mut take that, and give it to the peron I was to go to. Being come to the Sow and Pigs, I found my Gentleman walking up and down the Chamber, and having given him the Note, and told him the Goods were at the door, he lookt upon the Bill and gave it me again, telling me I was mitaken, that I was to go to ome other peron, for it did not belong to him. I told him that I was not mitaken, for he was enible that I knew him, and that my order was for him; but he throwing away with a ort of dicontent, walks about the Chamber again, and at lat aid to me, Sir, It is not for me, and you have no more to do but to return with it.

After I had taken a great deal of pains to perwade him to receive it, but found 'twas all to no purpoe, I e'en took his counel, and carry'd it back to M. de Bullion, and o went to give an account to the Cardinal; he askt me if I had the Note about me, I told him I had, which he looking upon, it put him into a violent paion at Bullion, aying, he would teach him another time to oberve his orders; and ending for him at the ame time, askt him the reaon why he ent but five hundred thouand Franks, when his order was for ix hundred thouand: Bullion reply'd, that he undertood his Emine • ce had
told him, but two days ago, that they hould manage that affair to get it as cheap as they could; that he did not quetion but the other would have been content with what he ent him, but eeing he was not, he would go and end him the ret.

By what I could undertand of this, for I was preent at their dicoure, it eem'd to me, that Mr. de Bullion had a mind to put a hundred thouand Franks in his own Pocket, tho he pretended only good husbandry for the public: in the mean time, while the other hundred thouand Franks was telling, his Eminence ent me to find out the man again, to tell him he hould have content, and that 'twas only the fault of the Superintendant; and order'd me to acquaint him, that I had een him reprove de Bullion for it. I found him making up his Baggage, as if he was to be gone, and eeming urpriz'd to ee me, he tept up to me, and askt me, if I had any thing to ay to him; I told him my buines, at which eeming indifferent. There is no Faith in man, aid he, with a urly ort of tone, and I cannot undertand it, that after having o poitive a promie, it hould be forgotten in two days. I went back immediately to Mr. de Bullion, and fetching the ix hundred thouand Franks, I brought them all to him, and return'd to the Cardinal, who was very uneaie till he knew what was done in it

Tho this ort of employment was not my element, and I had much rather have been in the Army, yet having o much the favour of my Mater, it was the pleaanter to me.
