Having one time ask'd me if I had yet een Mr. de Marillac, whoe Brother was now in great favour, for he was not only made a Marechal of France, but had marry'd a Relation of the Queen Mothers; I anwer'd, that I
remembred better than o, what his Eminence had commanded me; and that I had already told him, I hould know no Relations when his Service was the quetion, and that my greatet grief was, that I could give him no better proof of it yet. He told me with a voice that eem'd as if he were pleas'd, that it was well enough; and indeed if he had not been very confident of my fidelity, he would certainly never have truted me in a thing of uch a nature, as he did about a month after. In which, to dicover what temper he was of, 'twill be neceary to look back a little to the beginning of the tory.

The King was of a very mild and eay dipoition, came to the Crown very young, and left the government of all things to the Queen Mother, a Princes of a vat ambition, but not belov'd by the French; not only from a natural averion as he was an Italian, but alo becaue he made a Favourite of one of that Nation, whoe Merit was as mean as his Birth: As Governments are upported by fear ometimes, as well as by other methods, o this man had made himelf a terror, even to the Princes of the Blood; and his Wife (which was more intollerable than t'other) was come to that degree of Inolence, preuming on the Queens Favour, whom he entirely manag'd, that he trampled all the world, as it were, under her feet. It being however neceary for her to make ome Creatures of her own, to reit o many Enemies, the Queen Mother had gain'd ome already, and among them the two Brothers de Marillac, of whom one was a Stateman, the other a Souldier, and both very honet Gentlemen, and worthy of the great Places they enjoy'd; but notwithtanding all her forecat, the number of the contrary party was o great, that he could not ave her
Favourite from their hands. De Luines, whoe ambition could not bear the inolence of this Italian, ininuated to the King, that his Mother rendred him contemptible to the people, leaving the Government to be manag'd by Strangers. It is not certainly known, whether he accus'd her of Incontinence or not, and of making away the King his Father, but however it was, he knew well enough how to work upon the King, into whoe favour he had wrought himelf, by gratifying him in his little delights, and diverting him in uch manner as he found mot uitable to his inclination; he got a private order, to find out ome body to kill this Favourite, which was accordingly executed by Vitri, Captain of the Guards du Corps.

From hence forward de Luines endeavour'd to improve all the advantages of his Authority with the King to the prejudice of the Queen Mother; but as his houlders were too weak for uch a burthen, and on the other hand the Queens Party being jealous of his Minitry, and united againt him, he was forc'd to yield to the tronget ide. Thoe who were in her interets, and had abconded for fear they hould fall in the ame digrace with her Favourite, were immediately recall'd to Court, and as the Meieurs de Marillac were the chief of thee, o they had the greatet marks of her repect; he of the long Robe aim'd at no les than the Minitry, and eem'd o well qualify'd for it, that all people thought he deerv'd it: but the Queen Mother having taken into her ervice the Bihop of Luçon, afterwards Cardinal de Richelieu, this Genius did o in all things excel Monieur de Marillac, and hone with uch lutre, that the other was quite obcur'd.

The greater Marillac's ambition was, the more impatience he hew'd at the advancement of Richelieu, whoe deigns were at leat as great as his; and ambition being as ubject to jealouy as love, this produc'd a hatred o inveterate, that they could not endure one another; and the death of Luines making way for a more unlimited Minitry, very much encreat it: But Richelieu oon got above, not him only, but even the Queen Mother her elf. This Princes reented it extremely, and muter'd up all her Friends to joyn with her in pulling down this New Miniter, before he was ettled too fat. Monieur de Marillac and his Brother, having more reaon than any body to deire his fall, entirely embarkt in the deign with the Queen; they laid an infinite number of plots againt him, and any thing, but uch a Genius as his, mut have unk under the power of o many Enemies; but as he never willingly forgave an injury, o as oon as he had ettled himelf in his new Authority, he et himelf to uppres every one whom he had the leat reaon to fear; and not content to have forc'd the Queen Mother, who had been his Benefactres, to fly the Kingdom, he reolv'd the detruction of the two Marillac's.

This was the reaon of his asking me o often, if I had een them; but to make an effectual proof of my fidelity, and withal to take off the odium from himelf of apprehending the Marechal, who was a man generally belov'd; he aid to me one day, You have often aur'd me, that you would know no Relations, nor Friends, when my Service requir'd it, I hall now put you to the tryal. Here is an Order, aid he, giving me a Pacquet, to apprehend the Marechal de Marillac; You ee I am very willing you hould know what it is, go and carry it as directed, and remember, my Confidence in you merits very
well your Fidelity to me. This I'll aure you extreamly perplext me, and taking it, My Lord, aid I, if your Eminence would be content with this proof of my fidelity, that I know how to keep your ecrets, I hould have been very much oblig'd to you. I do not refue to obey you in this, but I beg you to conider, that if you hould employ another in uch a Meage as this, againt one of my nearet Relations, I hould not be les oblig'd to your Eminence. Go, I tell you, return'd the Cardinal, and take heed I don't do as you deire me.

I had nothing left me but to obey after o evere a command, tho I never got to Horeback with o much regret, and was often tempted to go and acquaint Monieur de Marillac, who was at Paris, of the misfortune that was coming upon the Marechal his Brother. I fancy'd ometimes the Cardinal, who was always o very ecret in his affairs, had put this into my hands on purpoe to make me run away; but at lat my duty carry'd it againt all the obligations I had to others, and I made uch hate to how my zeal for my Mater, that I deliver'd my Packet ix hours before they imagin'd I could be there.

The Imprionment of this great man made noie enough; every one accus'd the Cardinal of cruelty and injutice, o that daring not yet to bring things to the lat extremity, he to • t the coure of Jutice for a time, which was dipos'd to do any thing he deir'd. And I, after I had thus punctually obey'd him, thought he would have been generous enough to permit me to interceed for him, and the more too, becaue what I hould ask of him would but how him that I had a principle of honour, more than in hopes to effect any thing, where there was o powerful an Accuer; but I had no ooner dicover'd my intention, but I plainly aw, that great men are not
without their failings. He told me, all in a paion, that he was glad with all his heart, that one of his own Dometicks was againt him, and withal cat uch a look at me, as made me tremble from head to foot; and I may ay I was as much afraid, as if I had been in the Trenches, or in a et Battle.

I durt not come near him any more that day, but attending next morning at his Levee, he made as if he did not ee me, and o took no notice of me at all: As I had enemies enough in the houe, my digrace was preently publiht, epecially becaue one or other of them heard my Compliment, and the Cardinals anwer. The Count de Soions, who was an enemy to the Cardinal, and had a mind to erve him a trick, made this an opportunity of offering to entertain me in his ervice; but tho he was a Prince of the Blood, and propos'd to me great advantages, I return'd anwer, That I was too much oblig'd to the Cardinal, to think of changing my Mater. Another perhaps would have acquainted his Eminence of this propoal; indeed he could not endure to have any thing hid from him, epecially where his ervice was concern'd, but conidering the terms I tood in with him, he might think, I fancy'd, that I did it to ingratiate my elf again, o I never troubled his head with it.

La Ferté, the Father of him whom we have ince een Marechal of France, belong'd to this Count, but was a very treacherous Servant to his Mater; for he was a perfect Spy upon him for the Cardinal; and having dicover'd, I know not how, that I had been poken to, the Cardinal heard of it from him, and from that time reckon'd me a Traytor; and looking on me till with an evil eye, he askt me one day if I had nothing to acquaint him of? and I anwer'd him No, that he had lockt up my mouth by the anwer
he had given me. Have not I lockt up your heart too, reply'd he, ince that, and have you not had a mind to be reveng'd of me? Of you, my Lord! aid I, urpriz'd with his words (for I aw by his air and dicoure, that he had omething extraordinary that mov'd him) How is it poible for uch a thought to enter into my head? You, who have been uch a Mater, and who has made me what I am. I know all that well enough, reply'd he; but in hort what buines have you with the Count de Soions? and what are you two plotting together? I aw by thee words, I was betraid, and that nothing but telling the truth could ave me. My Lord, aid I, if I did not give you an account of that, it was not to make a ecret of it; but your Eminence having chid me, I thought 'twas enongh to do my duty, without making my court to you from the merit of my anwer to the Count de Soions; he ent to me indeed to entertain me in his ervice; but if thoe who told your Emin • nce that tory, had alo told you what return I made, 'twould have been o much to my advantage, as would effectually have re-etabliht me in your favour. I know all, ays the Cardinal, to me hatily, to terrify me, and if you would have me to pardon you, you mut confes the whole matter freely. I ask no Pardon, my Lord, aid I, but to do me Jutice only. I told him that I had too good a Mater to think of changing him, and I will always ay o, as long as your Eminence will pleae to accept of my ervice. Then you have nothing ele to ay, return'd the Cardinal very eriouly; Well, take heed, you will repent it before it be long.

I aid to him all that an innocent man could ay; but as he till doubted the truth of it, he continu'd eight whole days without taking any notice of me; in which time he employ'd La Fer • é to dicover how it was. La Ferté did all he could, but undertanding 'twas one Mezieres had poke to me, who was a
man very faithful to his Mater, and from whom he had no hopes to learn the ecret; he try'd if he could pump it out of the Prince himelf; he told him that I was a gallant Fellow, and behav'd my elf o at Locates, and had been very faithful ever ince I belong'd to the Cardinal, but that the Cardinal had us'd me very ill, and I had reaon for ome reentment; that this was the time for him to gain over uch a man into his ervice, who was worth having, and if he pleas'd he would attempt it. The Count de Soions, who was a man without artifice or diguie, told him 'twould be in vain, that Mezieres had poke to me already, but there was nothing to be done with me.

This retor'd me to the Cardinals good opinion, but not to any capacity to relieve Mr. de Marillac; on the other hand the Cardinal was reolv'd to cut him off, the more to depight the Queen Mother, who was always forming Parties againt him; and whereas the pretences on which he apprehended him were too weak, he came upon him for fale Muters, a fault that every Captain in the Army is more or les guilty of. And indeed what General can be afe, if he is anwerable for all the actions of his Subalterns? 'Twas on uch a light matter as this, that the Cardinal begun the ruine of o great a peron; and having gotten a Court Martial of his own Creatures, they quetion'd him on a thouand trifling tories, that as a very worthy Gentleman aid, if they had been all true, were not crimes ufficient to have whipt a Page, and he anwer'd them Article by Article o readily, and o directly, as puzzled all his Judges: But the Cardinal, who aw them wavering, ending them word they hould take heed what they did, the fear they had upon them of his dipleaure, made them pas the entence he deired, for they
condemn'd him to have his Head cut off; which was executed the ame Afternoon, in the Placé de Gr • ves. Knowing the nicety of his humour, I askt his Eminence, if he would give me leave to put my elf into Mourning; he told me I might do what I would, which I undertood too well to venture upon it.

A month or two after this, a match was propos'd to me, which eem'd to be much for my interet; the Cardinal alo was very much for it, but not for any reaon he aw in the thing, o much as for the averion he had to the Count de Soions; and the Lady was Niece, and Heir, to the Baron de Coupet, a worn Enemy to that Family. Indeed that Prince, who carry'd it very high, had ent the Captain of his Guards one day to abue a Baron in his own houe, on pretence that he had poken dihonourably of a certain Lady whom he had a repect for: This occaion'd a great deal of diturbance, all the Gentry who thought themelves toucht in uch an affront to a peron of Quality, were got together, an account of it being ent to them by the Baron de Coupet, and they all agreed that his Dignity ecur'd him from his reentment; but yet they reolv'd that from that time forward they would univerally light him, and not one of them come into his company; and that whoever he was that hould break this agreement hould not be lookt upon as a peron of honour. This reolution was exactly oberv'd, and the Prince, who had ome friends, and ome creatures, found himelf at once abandon'd by them all; he did all he could to regain the good opinion of the Nobility, but finding that not one of • hem would o much as ee him, he u'd for the Command of the Army, and the Enemy being at that time advanc'd as far as Corbie, the Ban and Arrierban was to be rais'd, which he thought to
be • fit occaion for his purpoe. He was prodigious extravagant, keeping twelve Tables of five and twenty Dihes for all come • s, careing every body, offering Money to everal, and ending it to others, whom he believ'd in want: By which means he recover'd the Friendhip of mot of them. But the Relations and Friends of the Baron de Coupet would never forgive him, and as they breath'd out nothing but revenge, or at leat pretended it, they cat their eyes upon me, in the propoal of this Marriage, hoping by that means to be protected by the Cardinal; they obtain'd it at firt word, and the Cardinal told me I could not do better: I was urpriz'd at the motion, I that had neither Etate nor Employment, at leat coniderable enough to expect a fortune, and at the ame time mitruting omething in the bottom; the ad example of my Father made me reolve to go fair and oftly: In the mean time I aw the young Lady, who was really very agreeable, but a little too free, for the very econd time I aw her, he was pleas'd to tell me, that being already as it were Man and Wife, if he did give me thoe little liberties I might deire, I hould not contrue it to her prejudice: This was enough for me, I could undertand the ret, and thee words made me examine her more nearly, and I fancy'd he lookt a little big, upon which I grew cold in my Courthip all of a udden. It eems I was not deceiv'd, for it was even o; and as her Relations were much in the right to get her a Husband with all peed, they took it mighty ill that I hould draw back, inomuch that the Baron de Coupet thought himelf o much affronted, as to fight me; and to ruine me effectually, they poet the Cardinal, that 'twas the Count de Soions that had diwaded me from this match, and that I had taken
his part o violently, that they believ'd I had quarrell'd with their Kinman upon that account, for that neither of us were to be found. They might well tell him this circumtance, for 'twas themelves who et us together by the ears. Nevertheles the Cardinal believing every word of the tory, had privately reolv'd my ruine, which appear'd plainly enough, for at my return he order'd me to be clapt up in Prion, without hearing me peak for my elf.

I apply'd my elf to La Houdiniere, the Captain of his Guards, who was my Friend, and having ent to beg him to come and ee me, I told him I was a lot man, unles he would peak for me; that my Enemies mut have prejudic'd the Cardinal againt me, or he could never have been brought to ue uch extremities with a man he had been pleas'd to trut in o many coniderable affairs; one of his Dometicks, and one who could never have o offended him, as to be deny'd the liberty to vindicate himelf. I begg'd him to ask the Cardinal what it was I tood charg'd with, and if I was guilty, he hould need no Judges to give entence upon me; that my own hand hould do the Office of the Executioner, and that I could not outlive the los of his preence and favour. La Houdiniere promis'd me all that I deir'd, and coming to ee me again the next day, he told me he was orry he had nothing but bad news to bring me; That the Cardinal was in uch a rage at me, that he wore he would have my throat cut; that he had nouriht a Serpent in his boom; that I kept correpondence with the Count de Soions, a • whoe intigation I had not only refus'd to marry the Niece of the Baron de Coupet, but had fought with the aid Baron to gratifie the Count. I could not forbear miling at this Accuation, and after having told him that great
men were mitaken ometimes as well as others, I deir'd him to tell the Cardinal from me, that I would not only be contented to have my throat cut, if it could be prov'd, I had either een, or heard from the Count de Soions, ince the buines he knew of, but to be broken alive upon the Wheel; That I would not indeed marry the Baron de Coupet's Niece, that is, I would not marry a Maid with Child, and none of my own getting neither; that he was at leat four months gone, and that his Eminence did not ue to require thoe ort of baenees from his Servants.

La Houdiniere carry'd this tory word for word to the Cardinal, and he was perfectly atoniht when he undertood this creature was with Child; and fixing his Eyes upon him, without peaking a word for a good while, at lat he cry'd out, Is it poible, La Houdiniere, that I hould be taken for a Fool? and that thee little ptarts hould have the Impudence to impoe upon me? La Houdiniere anwer'd, that ever ince he had known me, he had oberv'd me to be cautious enough, and ince I had affirm'd it, there mut certainly be omething in it, but that he had thought of a way for his Eminence to find out the truth, which was either to end for the Girl before him, or to order a Midwife to be ent to earch her. The Cardinal laught at this propoal, but at the ame time ending for the Baron de Coupet, who was at liberty, tho I was in Prion; he told him he hould have a care of telling him a lye; that he was upon his life; that the quetion was, whether his Niece was with Child or not? whether it was the Count de Soions who had broken off the Match? and whether he had any way been the occaion of our fighting? Such a quetion as this perplext the poor Baron, who would
fain have avoided giving a direct anwer; but the Cardinal beginning to thunder at him again, he threw himelf at his feet, and begg'd his pardon; upon which the Cardinal ent him immediately to Prion, and ent for me out. Aoon as I came into the preence, he gave me his hand to kis, telling me he would repair the injury he had done me. I kit it very repectfully, and ubmiively thankt him for his goodnes to me, begging him to believe, that I was wholly incapable of Treaon againt him.

Being thus in favour again, the Cardinal bad me a few days after go and liquor my Boots, and be ready for a little Journey he had for me: the deign was to Bruels, whether Madam de Chevreue was fled; he had pretended to manage the Queen Regent, and had made a thouand Plots in the State, and the Cardinal had a upicion, that he till correponded with ome of the Grandees, and I was intructed to dicover it. In the mean time, that it might not be upected, I was dret up like a Capuchin; and to make a little Brother, that was to be my Companion, believe that it was really o, I wore the habit everal days before I went; and beides, I was admitted to lodge at the Convent of the Capuchins, in the Rue St. Hon ••• e, a • if I had been of ome Convent in the Country. The Superior receiv'd me as one of the Religious, being before intructed about it by Father Joeph, the Cardinals Favourite; and I receiv'd alo my orders from the ame Father Joeph, who was a man that minded other buines ometimes than telling his Beads. Thus I parted for Bruels, purely from a principle of Paive Obedience, but otherwie very unfit to take o long a Journey on foot; however 'twas a cae of neceity, for fear I hould inform the young Monk how little I was of a Capuchin.
But being not able to bear uch fatigues, nor us'd to beg my ubitance for God's ake, I curt this Voyage a thouand times, and wiht as often that I had not been o far engag'd in the intrigue; I arriv'd however after fifteen days travel, and tho 'twas thought an ill thing in the Convent, I lay a bed two whole days after it, for I was all cut and gall'd with thoe hard Beds upon the Road, having been always us'd to other ort of Lodging; and to compleat my mifortune, I was call'd upon to officiate at the Church, o that I thought the Cardinal had ent me into Purgatory.

During this time I crap'd acquaintance with ome Frenchmen that us'd to come to our Convent, and making as if I did not know a certain man I aw oftentimes in the Cloiter, I askt them who it was, they told me it was the Marques de Laicques, who was the very man I wanted. He had been Madam Chevreue's humble Servant a great many years, but at lat, he being reolv'd to take him upon honour, he had now exchang'd the ceremony of a Gallant, for the familiarity of a Husband, and treated him as the late Mr. de Chevreue. I was intructed in all this at Paris, and that this Gentleman was the Arch-Dukes Favourite, but the Cardinals deign was to draw him off from the interets of the Archduke, or if that fail'd, I was to order it o, that I might inform the Archduke, and make him jealous that his Favourite held correpondence with the Cardinal.

De Laicques, who I long'd to be talking with, gave me a very fair opportunity, by coming directly up to me, and asking me everal things concerning the Convent; I fail'd not to lay hold of the occaion, I entertain'd him with dicoure, and making as if I poke broken French, I made my excue that my
Mother was a Walloon, and that my Father had had everal misfortunes, and receiv'd ome wrongs, and the like; he was very much pleas'd with my dicoure, and came very often into our Convent to ee me; till now, I durt not dicover my elf not to be a Capuchin, but he prevented me of his own accord, by asking me if I would venture to carry ome Letters of conequence into France? I told him I hould be very glad to erve him, but in this cae the danger was o great I durt not; he did what he could to encourage me, but I always excus'd my elf, that he might be the more eager, and withal to avoid all manner of upicion; he pret me again, telling me I hould do a ervice to my Country, for which I had expret o much inclination, that is to ay on account of my Mother, who I had told them was a Fleming. I till made excues, and to colour them the more, told him, that if I hould promie him to do it, it was not in my power, being under the ubjection of Governours, and beides what pretenions could I make for going into France; which they all knew I hated. This was the very argument he watcht for; he told me then, if that was all the difficulty, they would remove it without giving me any trouble, that I had nothing to do but to give them my word, and he would take care of the ret.

It was a long time before I could be perwaded, and eeming then to be prevail'd with by his importunity, they poke to the Superior, who being alo ollicited by the Archduke himelf, could not refue it; it was reolv'd then, that I hould pretend to go and drink the Waters at Forges, and that I hould end notice to the perons they would write to, to fetch their Letters there; in the mean time they gave me a Brother of the Habit to go with me, and
away we went to Forges, when we came about half way thither, I met a Courier which I had writ to the Cardinal to end me, to whom I deliver'd the Pacquet I receiv'd from de Laicques. The Cardinal after he had taken an account of the contents, eal'd it up again very exactly, return'd it to me, and commanded me to give notice to the peron for whom it was directed, that I was come; this was one la Pierre an Advocate, who liv'd in a blind Alley near the Place Maubert. He left Paris alo at the ame time to meet me there, but before I aw him, I had a man ready to watch him, that we might know whither he went. He mitruting nothing, at his return to Paris, went directly to the Count de Chalais, Grand Mater of the Wardrobe, which was ufficient to make us conclude, that the Pacquet was for him; and what was more, it was alo dicover'd, that this la Pierre, had been one of his Dometicks; but we needed none of thee remote circumtances, for the Count de Chalais wrote an anwer himelf, which I having ent to the Cardinal, his Eminence knew it immediately to be his own hand; he was very much urpriz'd at the contents, where they talkt of taking off the King, marrying the Queen to the Duke of Orleans, and for himelf, his death hould finih the Tragedy, to make way for the ucces of the Conpiracy. This was but too much to bring Chalais to the Block, and the King would have had him apprehended immediately, but the Cardinal being willing to dicover all the Conpirators, prevail'd with the King to delay it, on condition they hould keep a trict eye upon him, let he hould get away: In the mean time, to draw him from Paris, they made a pretence to take a progres into Bretagne, and I return'd with my dipatches to Bruels.
The Count de Chalais, who was far enough from the leat upicion of the misfor • une which attended him, had ent into Spain, puruant to the concert of matters in the Letters deliver'd him by la Pierre, which was to finih the Treaty they had begun at Bruels, and of which the King of Spain had been inform'd by an Expres from the Queen, who had a hand in the Conpiracy, that is, o far as it concern'd the Detruction of the Cardinal, whom he hated, but of all the ret he was innocent; and was o far from the thoughts of marrying the Duke of Orleans, that he did all he could to marry him to her Siter the Infanta of Spain. The King of Spain granted Chalais all that he deir'd, but he had no further enjoyment of it but in hopes, for his Courier was eiz'd upon at his return, and the Cardinal having now ufficient to convict him, delay'd no longer his Execution.

When this happen'd I was at Bruels, and knowing well enough what a hand I had in it, I was not without ome apprehenions of being erv'd in the ame kind, if I hould chance to be dicover'd; and any body may judge how it far'd with me in the Convent, where I receiv'd from time to time my orders from the Cardinal. The Marquis de Laicques was till very intimate with me, but told me not a word of what his intrigue had come to, being loth to dicourage me, by telling me of the ill ucces of their contrivances; for he had a deign of making further ue of me about a young Lady, whom he often poke to me of, and expret an extraordinary kindnes for: if I had not in appearance embarkt my elf o far in the Spanih interet, 'twould have been a very fair opportunity to have poken to him about reconciling himelf to the Cardinal, but I durt
not do it, conidering what had happen'd, for 'twould have been too plain a dicovery that I had a mind to deceive him. To peak of it to Madam De Chevreue or to her Gallant was to expoe my elf alo to an apparent danger, for they did nothing without one another; o finding I could not be any more erviceable in thoe parts, I earnetly ollicited the Cardinal to be recall'd; but he knowing that mot of the Grand • es were dicontented, and expecting they would all have their recoure to the Spanih Court, oblig'd me to continue there, that I might if poible dicover it.

I liv'd therefore in this fahion two whole years, tho I curt my Employment a thouand times a day: Here I was forc'd always to play the Hypocrite, and to talk in Diguie, a profeion very unpleaant to me; here I was forc'd to go a begging, work in the Garden, and to go with many a hungry belly: I often reflected upon my leaving Monieur de St. Aunais, to come to Court; it would not have been long before I hould have been a Captain there, and now I knew neither what I was, nor what I was like to be; but that which troubled me mot was, that I heard frequent conultations about the Wars, the thing my inclinations led me mot to, which made my preent condition the more intolerable.

In the mean time I went frequently to Monieur De Laicques, and was as well known there and at Madam De Chevre • e's, as I was at the Cardinals: One day as I was coming out of the door, there came two or three Gentlemen, and one of them topping to look full at me, In good faith 'tis Rochefort himelf, aid he to thoe with him, I am very certain of it. I no ooner heard my name, but without looking behind me, I began to mend my pace, and turn'd down
the next treet I came at, where, having my Begging Wallet at my back, I threw it in at a door, and going directly to a Brokers, I whiper'd him in the Ear, and told him that if he would ell me Suit of Clothes, I would give him his own price; for I always had a mall Pure about me, which was well provided, and in that I only differ'd from a Capuchin: The ight of my Money conquer'd the Concience of the Broker, who for a hare of my Gold made no cruple to ait a Capuchin to make his ecape; for he verily believ'd that I was only a Monk that had a mind to cat my Frock, upon which account the Rogue askt me three times the value of the things. I pitcht upon a Suit of Clothes of the Spanih mode, and he provided me with a Shirt, and a C • evat; and went out to fetch me a Perriwig, a Sword, and a pair of Boots, which compleated my accoutrements. In this equipage I hir'd Pot-hores, and riding on before the Pot-boy, I got out of the Town as fat as poible; fear gave me wings, and hope gave me new vigour and life beyond what I ever experienc'd before; and tho for not having been often on Horeback I could not bear it o well, yet I rid at uch a rate that I left the Pot-boy to come after me; I never topt till I got out of Flanders, where by this time they were making earch for me, for that peron who knew me again, happen'd to be the late Count de Chalais Gentleman, who was come to helter himelf at Bruels, not that he was concern'd in the deign with his Mater, but fearing to be apprehended on upicion, he choe to abent himelf for a while; he knew me, as we ay, as well as a Beggar knows his Dih; and being urpriz'd to ee me o trangely diguis'd, he would have run after me, to ask me how long I had been a Capuchin, who was never upected to have any inclination to turn
religious; but eeing that I, as it were ran from him, he began to doubt there was ome Roguery in the cae, and knowing well enough that I belong'd to the Cardinal, he thought himelf oblig'd to tell this adventure to the Marquis de Laicques. The Marquis told him he was mad, but he who knew well enough what he aid, jutify'd it with o much aurance, that the Marquis de Laicques run immediately to the Convent, expecting to find me, where being told that I was not yet come in, but they uppoed I would not be long, he asked to peak with the Superior, and told him, that as oon as I hould et my foot within the Convent, he hould be anwerable for my forth-coming; and that in the mean time he was going to acquaint the Archduke of omething that concern'd the State. In hort, going to the Archduke with the Count de Chalais's Gentleman, he urpriz'd him alo with the relation of this accident; he ent the Captain of his Guards to confirm the order from him, which the Marquis de Laicques had given to the Superior; and to make all ure, caus'd the Gates of the Town to be hut, that I hould not be able to make my ecape.

He made trict earch after me, and my diguie being o well order'd that no body perceiv'd me, they all perwaded the Archduke that I was till in the City: thee delays were my ecurity, and they found at night, eeing I did not come home, that I had mitruted omething, but till they fancy'd I was hid omewhere in the Town, and o they ent out a Proclamation for apprehending me, with a great Penalty to any that hould conceal me; but finding nothing come of it, they puru'd me, when 'twas too late.

The Cardinal was very much urpriz'd when he aw me, epecially returning without his order, and uppoing I came away only becaue I was weary of my employment, he began to chide me in a furious manner, but when I told him the danger I had been in, and how narrowly I ecapt, he chang'd his language, and told me I had done very well; and he himelf a little after gave me an account of the particulars I have related, and of the trouble the Archduke was in, that he could not find me out; and he told me alo, that my Companion was clapt up in Prion, and was till there, and he believ'd was not like to get out, till they had put him to the torture.

I found at my arrival everal changes at Court; the Marquis d' Humiers, Father of him who is now Governour of the new Conquets in Flanders, and Marechal of France, had receiv'd orders to quit his place of firt Gentleman of the Bed-chamber, and came every day to ollicit the Cardinal to endeavour the recovery of it; but the Cardinal told him, he mut addres himelf to the King, from whoe mouth he had receiv'd the entence. His digrace was occaion'd by a very light matter, and he had this atisfaction at leat, that it was not from any default of his: He was red-hair'd, and Pe • riwigs were not o commonly wore in thoe days; wherefore he knowing that the King hated the ight, comb'd his hair with a Comb made of black lead, which colour'd his hair as if it had been dy'd, o that the King knew nothing but that 'twas naturally black; till one day, as they were a hunting, there fell o much rain that waht out the artificial colour, and dicover'd the cheat; this was enough for the King to command him, as I mention'd, to lay down his Office, and all the Friends he could make, could not prevail with the King to re-admit him.

I receiv'd a great deal of kindnes from the Cardinal, after I had hown him the neceity there was for my return; but whether it was that he lov'd to have me always about him, or that he intended me no preferment, he contented himelf with gratifying me from time to time, without thinking of any ettlement for me: I had 2000 Louis d'ors given me at my return, which was a conideration noble enough, but I was not of a humour to be rich, and therefore laid up ne're a Groat: For I liv'd o extravagantly, that if I had had a hundred thouand Crowns per annum, I hould have ballanc'd the account at the years end; I knew well enough 'twas a foolih way, yet I could not tell how to help it: That I might therefore have omewhat to trut to, I askt the Cardinal to betow upon me a Company in the Guards, there happening a vacancy at that time; but he told me I knew not what I askt, for there was ne're a Captain in the Guards, but would change Pots with me, and beides, that he had omewhat for me to do. Now was I to think my elf oblig'd, and to thank him for the favour of his refual, tho I did not think it uch an obligation, as he was pleas'd to account it: however he gave me another Abbey of ix thouand Livres per annum, and I betow'd it upon one of my Brothers, at the very time when my Mother-in-law was telling every body, that I had no interet in the Cardinal, and that he had o little value for me, that I had lain two years in Prion for debt.

She meant my Journey to Bruels, when he talkt thus, which he undertood nothing of, but tho I heard this from everal, yet it did not at all hinder me from doing what I thought my duty; there was a great many in his condition who would have thankt me for this; but when I came to propoe, that he
honld give me a little conideration, as is uual in uch caes, he flew out againt me like a mad woman; he not only made a noie of the difference I had made between my Brother and the Curate, whoe Benefice I had given him gratis, but that I made my Brother pay more than 'twas worth; o away he goes to Orleans, to conult the Cauits, makes it a Cae of Concience, and deires to be inform'd, if he hould not be guilty of Symony, in accepting this Abbey for her Son.

All this did not hinder me from doing my endeavour for another of her Sons; knowing the eldet of them did but loe his time in a Country Village, I got him into the Academy, where I paid for his Entertainment, and at lat brought him to the Cardinal, and askt him how he would pleae to have me dipoe of him. My deign was to enter him among the grand Muqueteers, but knowing that the Cardinal was not very well with Treville who commanded them, I would not do it without acquainting him with it; I found I took the bet way too, for he told me, I hould have a care of doing o, and hould rather let him carry a Muquet in ome other Regiment; upon which I plac't him in the Guards, and in about ix months time, the Cardinal procur'd me a Colours for him, and he told me, when he gave it me, that I might ee what difference he made between thoe who were in his favour and others, for to thoe he gave leave to erve him if they pleas'd, but thee he took care to bind to him by obligations beyond their merit.

Thee things topt the mouth of my Mother-in-law for the preent, and he was indeed afraid to reflect upon me o openly, for fear people hould throw tones at her; but my Brother being unhappily kill'd the firt
Campagne he made, at the Siege of a Town in Flanders, he begun to open louder than before, telling about, that he knew me better than others; that I had made away my Brother, that I might get the Etate, and that 'twas for the ame deign I had gotten two more of her Children to Paris, where I had put them into the Academy, and if I had indeed gotten a Benefice for another, 'twas only that he might be oblig'd not to marry. Every one advis'd me to let her alone for a mad woman, (if I may o call her) and do no more for them; but what I did being for my own ake more than hers, I never let the Cardinal ret, till he had given me the Colours my Brother left, who was kill'd, to the eldet of the two that were in the Academy: In the mean time, when he came to march, I was fain to be at the charge of all his Equipage, o that I may truly ay, that I had the trouble and charge of Children, without having had the pleaure of getting them.

Thee things, together with my extravagant humor, empty'd my tock, which made me often tell the Cardinal in jet, that I was a Basket without a bottom, but that he was like to pay for it all. So when ever I was out of pocket, I would come to him and cry, Good my Lord, have pity upon a poor Father who has ix Children. 'Tis true I knew my time when 'twas fit to make thee ort of compliments, I took him when he was in a humour to laugh, and he eldom deny'd me any thing; in hort I got about fifteen thouand Livres a year of him in this manner, one year with another, beides the two Abbeys, and the two Enigns in the Guards; he plac'd alo one of my Siters in the Nunnery de Monmartre, without coting me a Farthing; all which made me lookt upon to be not a little in his favour, and yet I was till very much
dicontented with my condition, for 'twas a daily mortification to me to think that I had nothing certain, and if the Cardinal hould dye, I knew not where to hide my head. He was about this time building the Sorbonne, and waiting on him once thither, My Lord, aid I, if I might but one time or other come to have a Chamber here, with a Doctors allowance, I hould think my elf a very happy Fellow. Thou art never atisfy'd, aid he, thou costest me more than any four of my Servants, and yet thou art always grumbling. God forbid, my Lord, aid I, but I am young now, and am afraid of wanting when I grow old. Why art thou uch an ill husband then, reply'd he. Ah my Lord, return'd I, your Eminence knows very well what a charge of Children I have, and that I never ask you till I am in great neceity, and that notwithtanding all your bounty, I have not a penny aforehand. I know your meaning, aid he, you would have omething ettled on you in cae I hould dye; well, I will think of it. I thankt him very heartily, for thoe words comforted me exceedingly; 'twas above a fortnight after this, before his Eminence took any more notice of it; and thinking it not proper to importune him every day, I gave my attendance contantly without peaking a word more to him of it; but at lat he took me into his Cloet, and opening a little Cabinet, Thou askest, me, aid he, for ubitence, and 'tis but reaonable thou houldt have it; o pulling out a mall Parchment ty'd with little Ribbons he put it into my hands. Here, aid he, there is a thouand Crowns a year upon the Bank of Lions, I think thou art o ill a Husband that thou art not fit to be truted with it, but as it comes in annually.

You may eaily gues how overjoy'd I was at this noble preent, I was better pleas'd with it than if he had given me twenty thouand Crowns, for in hort
I knew my own humour, and was not ignorant, tho I could not help it, that I was not capable of laying up a penny. This created me a great deal of envy in the Family, when it was known how generous his Eminence had been to me; and the other Servants mutter'd at it, that all the kindnes was hown to the new comers, while the old tanders were neglected; but all this was nothing to the noie and outcrys of my Mother-in-law: She told about, that it was in vain to think to throw dut in her eyes, that my ill nature would appear too plain, whatever diguie I put upon it, but that it had never appear'd better than on this occaion, when I pretended to have receiv'd a Preent from the Cardinal, to colour my deign of cheating my lawful Heirs: That I had put the Money into the Bank my elf, and that I o conceal'd whatever I got with the ame deign. My Father coming up to Paris, I complain'd to him of this conduct of hers, but he poor man was o weak, and o cow'd by his Wife, that 'twas to no more purpoe to peak to him, than to run ones head againt the Wall.

We were very much at Ruel, where the Cardinal had a mot delicious Seat, and it being a very fine Country for port, which I extreamly lov'd, I never thought the time long we pent there. There was one Beaumont, who they nick-nam'd the Dragon, the Captain of St. Germain, and we being intimate friends he us'd to call me out often to hunt with him; and one day among the ret, having run down a Deer in the Forret, after the Sport was over, he would needs have me with him to ee a little piece of Gallantry that he kept at a by-houe, out of the road; I excus'd my elf for that time, and having left him, he went all alone, without o much as a Valet; as
he came back, he meets a Country Gentlemans man with a Fuee on his houlder, and having askt him, if he did not know that that was forbidden; the Fellow eeing him all alone anwer'd, Yes that he did, but he had a mind to kill a Hare, and what then? Beaumont, a little tirr'd with this anwer, askt him if he knew who he poke to. Know you? aid the Rogue inolently, Yes, very well, you are markt plain enough, any body may know you. Beaumont you mut undertand had but one Eye, and therefore was toucht to the quick with this impudent anwer; but eeing the fellow upon his guard, he blew his Horn, that if any body had been near him, they might come to his aitance; upon which the fellow, who was no Fool, retir'd immediately, and got away afe to his Maters houe, where I happen'd to be jut at that time; he told us not a word of what had happen'd to him, if he had, we could have made it up at firt with a word peaking, but as we were at Table, and he newly gone down into the Kitchin, we heard a noie in the Court, which made us rie to ee what was the matter; I was urpriz'd as well as the Mater of the Houe, to ee the Yard full of Blue Coats, being a party of the Guards, that Beaumont had ent. The fellow ignorantly came out to them himelf, and askt them their buines, who not knowing his face, enquir'd for him by his own name, which was enough to tell him their errand: So he took no notice at all, but told them, he would go in and call him. Intead of which he went and laid himelf all along upon a beam, which was but that morning put up in a houe his Mater was building, and he lay o, that 'twas impoible to ee him; in the mean time, the Gentleman taking this for a great affront, that thee men hould come thus into his
houe, was jut going to dicharge a Fuee at them, if I had not topt him gravely, by telling him, that the les paion, the les michief always, and tepping up to the Guards, who all knew me, I askt them what was the matter, they told me the whole tory as I have related it; o having deir'd them not to pres into the houe, till I came to them again, I went and told the Mater, and propos'd that he would let one of the Guards go in with me, to convince them that the Servant was not in the houe, I had a great deal of difficulty to bring him to this, but having told him the conequences of a refual, he was prevail'd on; in the mean time, the Guards having beet the houe, o that they were ure he could no way ecape, they were for earching every corner, and there was not a nook, nor a hole, but they pry'd into; but finding 'twas all in vain, and the fellow was not to be found, they concluded nothing les, than that he was beholding to the Devil to convey him away. The Gentleman knew no more what was become of him than they, till a good while after they were all gone, and the coat clear, that he aw him creeping down from the beam.

When the fellow undertood the danger he had been in, he did not think it convenient to trut himelf any longer there, but askt leave of his Mater to go home to his own friends, who liv'd ten or twelve Leagues beyond Paris; when he came home he found his Father ick of a violent Feaver, but expreing a great deal of joy to ee his Son before his death. The old man being poor, was but meanly lookt after in his illnes, and being as it were left alone, he call'd his Son to give him ome drink, which the fellow did once or twice, but the old man calling
very often, and he being too lazy to attend him, h •
brings the Pitcher, and etting it by him, bad him help himelf; this was a heart-breaking to the poor dying man, and reproaching him for his unnatural behaviour, this Racal takes up the Pitcher, and pours it all upon his Father, telling him he might drink his belly full if he was o thirty.

After o barbarous an action, he runs away to Paris, and going the next day to the Palace, he knocks before he was aware, at the Preident Seg • iers; which rudenes put the Preident into uch a paion, that he order'd his Officers to put him in Prion, and it being the cutom to examine uch as are committed for any inolences in the treets, they began to ask him the uual quetions in uch caes, when finding him faltring in his dicoure, and giving but a lame account of himelf; and whether he had a hanging look, or which is mot likely, the Vengeance of Heaven puru'd him for the horrid crime he had committed, the Judges order'd enquiry to be made at the Town where he aid he was born; the Officer who was ent, found his Father dead, but he had told o many People of the inhuman action of his Son, that the whole Town came in againt him; the Officer having made this report, and due proceedings being made thereon, they entenc'd him to be hang'd; he confet at the Gallows everal unheard of crimes, which had they been known before, he would have been broken alive upon the wheel.

This was without doubt a good leon to all thoe, who flatter themelves with hopes of ecaping divine vengeance, which tho it had permitted this man to go unpuniht for many great crimes, brought him at lat to publick hame for a trifle.

I had, as I aid, obtain'd an Enign in the Guards for my Brother, who had been at two or three Sieges which had been made that Campagne; and the Cardinal, being deirous to know how he had behav'd himelf, enquir'd of the Marechal de Grammont, who came one morning to make his Court to him; the Valet, who was in waiting at that time, told me of it, and that the Marechal made anwer, that he was a very brisk young fellow. I took my meaures from this, to do omething yet better for him, but being aham'd to be always asking, I went this way to work: we had yet a Brother whom the Cardinal had not een, who began now to be of age fit to go into the Army, and was a very compleat young Lad; I preented him to the Cardinal, and askt him, as I us'd to do of the others, how his Eminence pleas'd I hould dipoe of him? the Cardinal charm'd with the ight of him, told me I ought to be very well atisfy'd to have a Brother of his hape and meen. My Lord, aid I, at the ame time, an Enign of the Guards would it very well on uch a Gentleman as he is like to make, and a Lieutenancy on his Brother; and ince it happens that there is uch a Vacancy now in the ame Company, if your Eminence would pleae to betow it on him, I would ay, if I durt, that he will not be wanting in his Duty, or Courage for the Kings Service, when there hall be opportunity. He conider'd a while of what I aid, and then return'd upon me, You have a mind to bring me, and Monieur d' Epernon together by the Ears; don't you know he will let no body encroach upon his Office, and that t'other day he would needs quarrel with the King, for but offering to give away a Company in the Guards which belong'd to him. My Lord, aid I miling, if he quarrels with your Eminence, here is three Brothers of us will be your Seconds; and the ret, as they grow up, hall
all engage on your ide. Thou paeket fair, ays the Cardinal, but go to him from me, and tell him, he will oblige me in gratifying you. I did not fail to return him thanks for o coniderable a favour, and going immediately to Monieur d' Epernon, he was pleas'd to tell me, that I needed not his Eminences Recommendation for o mall a matter, which I hould have commanded from him at a word from my elf.

Certainly the bounty of my Mater, the Cardinal, was without example, and all my trouble was, that I was not able to make any uitable return for o many obligations; I ought however, as much as it was poible, for opportunities to expres my gratitude; and being one day drinking with everal Gentlemen, one of them, that was an Englihman, began to reflect upon the Cardinal, whether it was that the Wine was gotten into his head, and o talkt he knew not what, or that he had ome private malice againt him, I know not, but I deir'd him very civilly to peak in other language of my Mater, unles he reolv'd to dioblige me; but he talking the more reproachfully for my taking notice of it, I lot all patience at that, and taking up a Plate I threw it at his head; he was preently for drawing out his Sword, but I was ready for him, o he lot his deign, which was to have urpriz'd me before I could have drawn; our Friends tepping in, prevented our fighting for that time, and endeavour'd to reconcile us, but it was impoible to bring him to any thing, for going out he made a motion to me to wait upon him. Every one of the Company offer'd me their ervice, but I thankt them, and told them I aw no occaion to fear, however two of them would not leave me till they aw me at my Lodgings, that if we had met him, who had alo two friends, who went out with
him, we might have been upon equal terms, but we aw no body, tho we went the direct way on purpoe.

The next morning before I was up, my Valet de Chambre came and told me, there was one wanted to peak with me; I preently imagin'd it was from the Gentleman, and bid him let him in, and deir'd him to it down by my bed ide. I knew him immediately to be one of thoe two perons, that went out with him; o making a ign to him to ay nothing of his buines, till I had ent my man out of the way, I held him in dicoure of one thing or another, as if we had been very well acquainted, till I made an errand to end away my man, and then he made me his compliment, which was thus, That I had affronted his Friend, who was a Peron of Quality, and that nothing but my life could repair the injury I had offer'd him: That he waited for me with one of his friends, not reckoning himelf, o that I mut bring two of mine along with me to entertain them.

There was nothing in all his compliment which troubled me, but that I hould involve any body in my quarrel; I could not tell who to think on a good while, but immediately recollecting that I had two Brothers, who had ome right to the quarrel, as having o greatly har'd of the Cardinals bounty, I reolv'd to eek no further; o I ent for them, and taking them with me towards the Bois de Boulogne, which was the place appointed, where we found our Adveraries ready; we immediately drew, and fell to it. My younger Brother was wounded the firt Pas, and tho it was a very dangerous thrut, yet he at the ame time diarm'd and wounded his man; I had done the ame with mine, and going together to ait our eldet Brother, his Adverary at that very
moment made a Pas through his body, with which he fell dead at his feet: This was a ight enough to have mov'd any Brother to revenge; beides the blood which flow'd from his wound who was left, had arguments in it to urge me to refue him quarter; but he begging his life upon our preing him very hard, I thought it would not be for our honour to refue him.

We brought off three Swords, a mall Trophy compar'd to the los of our Brother, whom we left dead upon the pot; and yet this was not all, for the wound my younger Brother receiv'd, having pierc'd his Vitals, tho the trength of his contitution mater'd it for ome days, I was atoniht to ee him give up the ghot in my arms; I was never o griev'd in my life, eeing my elf the caue of the ruine of two uch hopeful youths, whom I had, as it were, led to be laughter'd on my account: 'Tis eay to be imagin'd the clamour of my Mother-in-law at this news, he aid againt me all that rage and fury could put into her mouth, which I knew not what to ay to, only that if I had known what would have happen'd, I hould have been more cautious of afflicting her. I might have aid omething more for my jutification, but I thought 'twas more proper to let others peak for me, and I flatter'd my elf that there was none but were enible of the innocence of my intention; but among all thee troubles which were not mall, you will ay, I had yet another which rackt me night and day, for tho the Cardinals honour had been the caue of our quarrel, yet Duelling being o trictly forbidden, he would not ee me, and I was oblig'd to abcond as if I had been a Murtherer; they told me at the ame time, that he had order'd earch to be made for me, in order to
deliver me over to the Judges, and that he had ent for the Procurator General about it. La Houdiniere, who was always my Friend, was the firt that advis'd me to keep out of the way, telling me the Cardinal was in uch a paion, that he durt not expoe himelf to peak in my behalf; I durt not deire him to do it neither, for fear his Eminence hould upect he had een me, and I thought he would be more erviceable to me, if without taking notice of any thing, he hould endeavour to ound the intention of the Cardinal. Things continu'd thus three months, which was a long while for a man to lye incognito, and if I had any Enemies, this was their time to ruine me, and 'tis impoible to reckon how many tories they told of me to the Cardinal.

The Count de Maulevriere of Normandy, was one of thee, tho I had laid everal obligations on him, and therefore always lookt upon him as my friend; for 'twas thro my means that he got to be an Enign in the Guards, which he had been refued; and ince that I had introduc'd him to the Count de Harcourt, to go with him to the Army; and I may truly ay, that he how'd him a great deal of favour on my account. This man, who was of a Family of the long Robe, and uch a one as there were a thouand better in that Province, was always cracking, and valuing himelf upon his Nobility, in uch manner, that to hear him talk, one would not quetion but he could derive his Pedigree from St. Lewis: I had told him my opinion of this foolih way of his a little freely, which he pretended to take very friendly; but my digrace coming upon this, he prov'd the greatet Enemy I had; in hort, I was told by everal, that he never had any opportunity to dicoure with the Cardinal, but he us'd it to my diadvantage;
which I reented o ill, that though I was reduc'd to this condition for fighting, I deir'd to be at liberty for nothing more than to demand atisfaction of him. La Houdiniere was one of thoe that gave me account of this, and coming to ee me one day told me, I hould lay aide all thoe thoughts, for the Cardinal himelf had ufficiently reveng'd me of this Norman. I no ooner heard that word, but I was impatient to know the Hitory of it, which was thus. That he being come to his Eminence, and beginning to reflect upon me as he us'd to do, the Cardinal told him, 'twas a trick of a Racal to abue one who was abent, and could not anwer for himelf; that he had known me longer than he had done, but that it was not my practice to peak ill of any body; that I was a fellow who had behav'd my elf well, but was no boater of my own actions, and that perhaps my misfortunes would not lat always. I could not believe this was a dicoure likely to come from the man that proecuted me; however I took it as a good Omen, and it encourag'd me to have patience, till time hould produce omething to my advantage.

'Twas a whole month before I had the leat reaon to hope, but at lat, when I began to depair, La Houdiniere came to me from the Cardinal to tell me, that I hould urrender my elf to Prion, and fear nothing; he told me alo, that his Eminence askt very kindly after me, telling him, that he knew him to be my contant Friend, and further ays La Houdiniere, I am mitaken if you have not as great a hare in the Cardinals favour as ever.

I need not ay, that I was very enible of the kindnes he expret, and that I deir'd La Houdiniere to aure his Eminence, that I had all imaginable ence of his goodnes; o I preently urrender'd my elf to
Prion, without requiring any aurance of my afety, more than the Cardinals word. Thoe who heard what I had done, but knew nothing of what had pat between the Cardinal and me, thought I was out of my wits, and pitty'd my folly: Others, who wiht me ill enough, took this occaion to ollicit againt me, and tho, as the Cardinal did me the jutice to ay, I never did any man any wrong, yet I found a thouand that were glad of the opportunity they thought they had to ruine me, and the wort Enemy I had, was the Count de Maulevriere, who had married to his econd Wife, a Relation of the Preident de Bailleul, and he employ'd her underhand to engage her Unkle againt me; and if that Magitrate had not been an honeter man than he, I had been in great danger; but I found the Information againt me o favourable, that if I had drawn it up my elf, I could not have contriv'd it better. Intead of aggravating the matter, or indeed of telling the very matter of fact, as I have here done, there was a relation, how the man not only abus'd me at Table, but lay in wait for me at the Bois de Boulogue, as I was returning from Verailles with my two Brothers; that e defendendo, I was oblig'd to draw as well as thoe that were with me, and that nevertheles I had firt endeavour'd to tell him, the regard he ought to have had to the Kings Edicts, and the danger of diobeying in uch caes as this; and being fill'd with a great deal of uch tuff, and having o much care taken of me, without my help, my jutification was both hort and eay.

I was till ignorant to whom I ow'd this obligation, and tho I ometimes fancy'd it mut be the Cardinal, yet I could not think o long, when I reflected, that a man who had o much kindnes for me,
hould let me lye o long neglected in my misfortunes; and would rather have told me how it was, than end me a bare meage not to fear: Being however got out of Prion, I went to throw my elf at his Eminence's feet, whom I told I would deal more incerely with, than I had done with the Parliament; that I would honetly confes to him, that I had broken the Kings Order, but if I had been to be a Vagabond twice as long as I had been, or to have lot my head upon a Scaffold, I could never bear to hear him abus'd. Have a care who hears you, aid he, taking me up, 'tis I that have brought you out of this buines, tho no body knows of it; and whereas I did end indeed for the Procurator General to make your Proces, it was only with deign to ave you; if I did not inform you as much, continu'd he, 'twas becaue I make no man Mater of my ecrets: Bouteville and de Chappelle, were executed but t'other day for the ame thing, and what would they have aid of me, aid he, if I had av'd one of my own Servants, when I but jut before had taken off a Relation of one of the firt Princes of the blood, and two Gentlemen allied to the chief Families in France.

So obliging a dicoure as this made me throw my elf again at his feet, and embracing his knees, My Lord, aid I, when hall I be o happy, as to dye for o good a Mater; I mut have liberty to ight againt all that declare themelves his Enemies. He was extreamly pleas'd to ee me o zealous, and he took o much delight in hearing me expres my elf in this manner, that he thought not of raiing me from his foot.

What he had told me of Bouteville and de Chappelle was very true, but he did not tell me how he gratify'd his private grudge in executing the rigour of the Law upon them. Bouteville being Father to the preent Marechal de Luxemburgh, was Couin to the
Prince of Conde, as he told me, but to peak trictly to the Princes his Wife; but that honour was old him very dear: You mut know that the Duke D' Enguien, eldet Son to the Prince of Conde, having marry'd Madamoielle de Bree, the Cardinal's Niece, and his Father having been forc't, againt his Will, to conent to that Match purely to ave his life, or at leat his liberty, his Son, who knew how he was impos'd upon, lookt upon his Marriage as a mark of his bondage to the Cardinals tyranny; and from thence depiing both the Relation and the Wife, he reproacht her daily with a thouand reflections, and not altogether without caue; her Birth was coniderable, and he came of a very Ancient Family; but the Duke D' Enguien, having employ'd a man vert in Heraldry to earch out the Original of her Family, and he, after turning it from ide to ide, made his report, whether 'twas true or no, that the Houe de Maille, of which he was decended, came by Baterdy from an Archbihop of Tours; this was enough for that Duke, not only to inult his Wife, but alo to be very harp in reproaching the Cardinal; and nothing being done but he had his Emiaries to inform him of it, he was o mov'd at this, that he only waited for an opportunity to how his reentment, and 'twas not long before had one Bouteville, who happen'd to fight a Duel, not only againt the Kings Edict, but againt a particular order to himelf, was o cloely purued, that he was apprehended before he could reach into Lorrain, the Count de Chappelle his Couin, who was his Second, and led along with him, was alo taken; and it being to do a depight to the Houe of Conde, the Cardinal caus'd them to be executed by the Hands of the Common Hangman, under pretence of
Jutice, but indeed to atisfy his private revenge.

After I was thus retor'd into favour, the Cardinal, who lov'd me more than ever, made me everal gratifications, and askt me, If I had ne'r another Brother to prefer? I told him I had two, one to whom I had given the lat Abbey, which his Eminence was pleas'd to betow on me; but that for the other, I did not deire to concern my elf for him, for having the misfortune to be accus'd of the death of three others, I was unwilling to expoe my elf to the like reproach: I told him however I had a Siter that pat in the world, for omething handome, and intended to marry her to one of my Friends, a Gentleman of Brettany, and that I only waited for my Father and Mother-in-law's anwer. He hearkned to all this with a ingular goodnes; and a Benefice falling near us, which was in his Gift, he gave it me without asking, and I preented it as freely to my Brother, who was already in Orders; which open'd the mouth of my Mother-in-law afreh, who complain'd now that one mut have all and t'other none; and that I ought rather to have given it to him that had nothing. I e'n let her ay what he wou'd, and only waited for an anwer to the buines about my Siter, which it was three months before they wou'd vouchafe to grant me; at lat, my Father, having a uit at Law that brought him to Paris, and being glad to make ue of ome friends of mine to ollicit for him, he ent me a Note where I might find him; I went to him immediately, and after paying him my repects, I askt him how it came about that I had not heard from him all this while? 'Tis long of your Mother, anwer'd he very ingenuouly, who believes you have a deign to deceive us: But Sir, aid I, what do you believe of it? In troth, aid he, with the
ame freedom, I know not what to think of it, for when the Debate lyes between a Wife that a Man loves, and a Son who has oblig'd him, one has a difficult task to decide it. You have no Obligation at all, Sir, to me, aid I, but methinks you ought at leat to do me a little more Jutice.

I did not care to urge it any farther out of repect to him: His Caue was againt Monieur de la Vieuville, a Man from whom we have een a great many Dukes and Governours of Provinces, and great perons decended; o that it was, as I may ay, the Earthen Pot floating by the Iron Pot, which made me doubtful of the Event, and I told my Father 'twould be bet for him to accommodate the matter; he told me he was willing to do o, upon which I pake to the Cardinal, who had done o many things for me, that he would pleae to concern himelf in this. His Eminence poke of it that very day to Monieur de la Vieuville. But he, who thought that upon the account of his powerful interet, he was able to cruh my Father, as I hinted before; or at leat that he hould tire him out, anwer'd the Cardinal, that he would do any thing he deir'd him, but intreated him rather to leave their Controvery to the deciion of the Law; the Cardinal could not well init upon it after that, o he told me, that my Father mut not expect any accommodation, for Mr. De la Vieuville would not hearken to it; but that for my ake he would epoue the Caue himelf for my Father: I carried this great news to my Father, which at firt he could hardly believe. So the Proces began, and my Father having et forth in his Bill of Complaint, that Monieur de la Vieuville had committed everal Wats, in a Village that we had near Nogent L' Artha • t, which belong'd to him; he had not only the
impudence in his Anwer to give him the Lye, but run on in uch ill language againt our Family, as if we had not been o much as Gentlemen. As no Reproach can offend but what is grounded on truth, o nothing vext me in this but the Lye, tho I was better atisfy'd afterwards, when the Lawyers told me, that thee were but words of coure, which they always put into their Pleas, without any deign of particular affront; and withal being trictly charg'd by the Cardinal not to demand any other atisfaction, I reolv'd to ue the ame Arms againt them, and the next day return'd them the Lye, and prov'd our Nobility. At night the Cardinal askt me how our Caue went on, and I having told him what had happen'd, he wonder'd he aid, that Monieur de la Vieuville hould tand o much upon that Nicety, his Nobility being not o much above ours, and if I knew what Henry IV. had aid one time to his Father, I might have been ufficiently even with him upon that core.

He had no ooner aid thus, but I begg'd his Eminence to tell me what it was, which he made no difficulty to do, but told me, that the Father of this de la Vieuville belong'd to the Duke de Nevers, who to recompence him for ome ervices which he had done him, o often importun'd Henry the Fourth to make him Knight of the Order, that he could not put him off; and it being the Cutom, that when the King puts on the Coller of the Order, the Knight kneeling down ays, Domine non um dignus; Monieur de la Vieuville repeating the ame words, the King reply'd aloud, I know that well enough, but I mut give it you, or my Couin de Nevers won't let me be quiet. The Cardinal could not have pleas'd me o well, if he had given me a hundred thouand Crowns, as he did
with telling me this tory which I carry'd immediately to the Lawyers, and making them put it into
• heir own language in our reply, it was a ingular mortification to our Adverary.

This was good port for the Judges, who are glad to have omething of any ide to laugh at, and Money into the bargain, I had my fill of it, and my Father too, and that which was mot trange, Mr. de la Vieuville could not forbear laughing himelf. The Hitory of Domine non um dig • us, brought him a little to reaon, fearing let thoe that were acquainted with circumtances o very particular, hould alo ranack his Genealogy, and dipute his Original which was from Flanders, and began to be orry that he had refus'd the Cardinals Mediation. In hort, there being everal other things which he was loth we hould enquire into, he came to the Cardinals, and meeting me at the door told me, that he was urpriz'd at what he had heard jut now, for he had never known before, that his Adverary was my Father, which if he had been inform'd of ooner he would never have diputed it. I knew well enough what this meant, and being not of a humour to flatter him, I told him, I had reaon to value my elf extreamly, ince he was pleas'd to grant that to me which he had deny'd to the Cardinal; and tho my Father had been at great charges in the Suit, yet I was ready to move him to an accommodation; and that if he pleas'd to acquaint me with the conditions, I would bring him an anwer; this dicoure vext him, and telling me, that I did not accept his civility as I ought; he flung away without aying a word more.

So our Proceedings went on till, but finding that he treated us with better language, we alo deited reproaching him; our Proces was to be heard
before two Judges, Monieur Turcan was one, a man who having been firt divorced on pretence of Impotence, choe rather to be thought o, than to live with his Wife who was an infamous Woman; he was entirely our Friend, but the Preident, who was the other, was not; o that when he came to um up the matter, as he read a claue that was in our favour, the Preident askt him, if that entence he read was in the writing; Turcan who was very hot, whatever complaints his Wife might make of the contrary, and the Tryal being in the Evening, having two great Wax Candles by his Seat on the Bench, he took one of them and threw it at his head, aying, That a Man who upected uch a thing as that was a Racal, and ought to be us'd accordingly. The Preident by tooping down his head avoided the blow, but asking him what he meant, and at the ame time catching up the other threw it at him, and truck him on the head; this diorder put a top to the Caue which was jut upon deciding. The Preident went out to make his complaint, and Turcan went home to his own houe, where he receiv'd an Order to lay down his Office.

Our Caue by this means lay aleep, and out Friends on both ides took that opportunity to mediate an accommodation, and we being both pretty well tir'd with the Law were the more eaily brought to compliance; they agreed that all reflexions on either part hould be abolutely forgotten, and indeed 'twas the bet coure they could take, for 'twas not poible to enter into the dicoure without recriminating on each other. So the matter being concluded my Father return'd home; but before he went away, I deir'd him to conider of what I had propos'd to him about my Siter, which was o much his interet
to effect; he promis'd to peak to my Mother-in-law about it, and two days after he came home, he ent me word, that they would give their conents to what I propos'd, provided I would do it without their disburing any Money; I admir'd, or rather pity'd the ordid tupidity of thee people, who having no more Children, as one might ay, hould venture the los of uch an opportunity to advance their Daughter, rather than part with about twenty thouand Franks, purely from Covetuounes, to ay no wore of it, for they wanted no Money; the Cardinal having for my ake, to pacifie my Mother-in-law, for the death of my two Brothers, permitted her to ell the Commiion of the eldet, which he had not dipos'd of, thinking I had another Brother to whom he would have given it, by which he got a good um of Money, and more than would have paid the Portion for my Siter: However a little after I receiv'd another Letter which explain'd the former; in which they told me, that ince I thought this o good a Match, they deir'd me that I would not let it lip for want of a little of my aitance; that I was in a condition able to do it, and it would be but a mall matter to me, and for which my Siter would be eternally oblig'd to me.

I was damnably vext at this, and o I gave them to undertand, and my paion appear'd o in my countenance, that notwithtanding all the care I took to conceal it, the Cardinal eaily dicover'd it, and askt me what the reaon of it was, but fearing he hould think it was only an artifice of mine to draw more Money from him I beg'd him to excue me telling him 'twas nothing but ome of my private affairs, not worth diturbing his Eminence with; he was not atisfy'd with thee reaons, but thinking I
equivocated with him, he told me, that he would have me tell him poitively the buines, I defended my elf till with the ame pretence, but the more he aw me unwilling to dicover my elf, the more he pret me, o I was forc't to tell him, but at the ame time told him my fears, let he hould think I had a deign upon him. I thought, aid he preently, 'twas ome buines of vat conequence, and is this all the matter: Go, continu'd he, I give this alo for your ake,
• ut upon condition that you han't call them your Children any more, for methinks they are mine rather, confidering what they cot me every day,

I could with all my oul have run into the fire for him if there had been occaion, I had uch a fence of his bounty and many favours to me, but it being my misfortune to be only a poor ueles fellow, I contented my elf to expres my paion by my zeal for his ervice. Thus my Siter was marry'd at lat to the peron that I had propos'd, and liv'd everal years with the greatet happines in the world, only that it pleas'd God he had no Children; but about ix years after, her Husband was taken with a fit of Devotion, and he, who made it a pleaure to her to uit herelf to his temper, liv'd with him o piouly, that he became an example to the whole Province of Brettagne; but both of them growing zealous to exces, he turns Priet, and he became a Vo • ary; and while he was a kind of a Miionary in his own Country, he retir'd into a Convent near Meulan, to which he had been a Benefactrice.

A few days after the Cardinal had done this lat favour for me, he was eiz'd with o deep a melancholy, that one could not know him almot to be the ame peron; I could not forbear expreing to him my trouble for the condition I aw him in, and
the atisfaction which it would be to me, to be intrumental to his recovery; he poke lightingly of it, but yet I could perceive plainly enough, there was omething more than ordinary in it, notwithtanding all the pains he took to conceal it from me, for I had tudy'd his humour o well, in that long time I had the honour to have belong'd to him, that I knew his temper as perfectly as if I had been himelf; however after uch an anwer 'twas my Duty to be ilent, tho I was enibly afflicted to ee that his dicontent rather encreat every day. To pas away thee troubleom hours, which held for two months at leat, I us'd to go to Luxemburgh to divert my elf with a Lady, who very well deerv'd my acquaintance, and that I might not bring any candal upon her, I always left my men at the Market Gate, and went alone on foot to her Houe. One night as I came back to my Servants, I aw a man go out at the Gate, who I preently remember'd to have een at Bruffels, being a peron whom I knew was employ'd in Intreigues of State; the uneaonable hour of the night, for 'twas pat two a clock, made me imagine, that a man of his character would not be o late abroad for nothing: I preently acquainted the Cardinal, who told me I was mightily to blame I did not follow him, I told him I had a good mind to have done it, but that he perceiv'd I knew him, and I was loth to increae his upicion; he told me I had done well, and pauing a while, he askt me what manner of man he was, enquiring of his age, his tatute, his complexion and the like; I gave him the bet decription of him I could, and he immediately gave orders to all the Pots, Carriers and Coaches, to take notice if any uch like man offer'd to go out of Town, and laid men upon all the Roads, if poible,
to apprehend him if he travell'd any other way

I guet by all this, that this very man was the caue of the Cardinals diturbance; and eeing he intended to place a Centinel near Luxembourg, I told him there was no body could be o proper for that Pot as my elf, for that I knew him, and he hould not ecape me; he told me that was true, but on the other hand he might know me too, and o might mitrut omething and avoid me; to remove this objection, and the thoughts of employing any other peron, I told him no body could know him o well by the bare decription I had given of him, as I could do with my own Eyes, and therefore any other might uffer him to pas and not know him, whereas in a diguie I had in my head, I would defy him to know me, let him be as cunning as he would; he askt how I had contriv'd to diguie my elf? I told him I would dres my elf up like a Beggar-man, and laying my elf down in the treet like a poor Cripple, I hould have the advantage of looking every one that came by in the face; he lik'd my project very well, and would needs have a view of me in my Robes; o I bought very privately a pair of old Crutches, a patch'd ragged Coat, and in hort all the neceary accoutrements of an arrant Beggar; and I plaid my part as well, as if I had been Apprentice to the Trade: The Cardinal bid me go, and told me, that if I ucceeded, I hould do him the greatet piece of ervice that ever I did in my life.

There needed no more to excite me to do my utmot, o having taken my pot at the corner of the Rue de Tournon, I begun to crew up my countenance and make a hideous noie, as if I had been in great pain, beides my poverty; a good many charitable people gave me Money, but everal Coaches happening
