to come by together, I was afraid my man hould pas by in the hurry, o I plac'd my elf as near the Gate as I could get: The Swies that kept guard there were o diturbed with the noie I made, that they would have driven me away, but that I was fain to promie them to be more quiet; I lay in this poture three days and three nights without making any dicovery, which made me fancy he might go in and out by the Port des Carmes, o I chang'd my Pot, and that very night I aw him, to my no little joy, come with a Key in his hand, and open'd the Gate himelf: The Cardinal had plac'd a man that came almot every minute to me, to enquire if I had een any thing, and beides that there was men poted from treet to treet to relieve one another, if there hould be occaion to follow him; things being thus dipos'd they watch'd for his coming out; about an hour after this, I aw another man who came and open'd the Gate jut as the t'other had done before, he was wrapt up in a Cloak o that I could not know him; but order'd the people I mention'd, who attended for that purpoe, that they hould not fail to dog him when he came out again, which they did o dextrouly, that he never had the leat upicion of them, but went trait to his lodging, without o much as offering to look behind him.

This effectually dicover'd the man, who prov'd to be no les a peron than Monieur de Cinqmars, Grand Querry of France, Son of the Marechal d' Effiat; and the Cardinal no ooner knew it, but he told me he was an ungrateful man, and he hould dye for it, or he would know why not. Indeed it was the Cardinal that had advanc'd him at Court, and to requite him he was plotting his ruine, with the Duke d' Orleans, who after having form'd a thouand
Intreigues againt the Cardinal, which always prov'd fatal to thoe that engag'd in them, was now hatching another, that was not like to meet with much better ucces; for the other man was dogg'd in like manner, and the Cardinal being inform'd, that he lodg'd at the Fauxbourg St. Germain, in the Rue de Canetes, he was o well oberv'd, that he could not tir a foot but he knew it; they dicover'd everal of their haunts, where one Fontrailles, a little crooked, but very cunning fellow, us'd to be with them: I pret the Cardinal to apprehend the Conpirators, for it was in his power, and it was needful too, that he might prevent any deign that they might have againt his peron; but as all he yet knew of the buines was but circumtantial, he waited for plainer proofs to convict them; he ent me to lye on the Road to Bayonne, as a Guide to uch as rode Pot, that I might oberve all uch as went to or return'd from Spain; in the mean time they kept a trict eye upon the Conpirators, and the Cardinal having caus'd Fontrailles, to be follow'd to Etampes, he took pot there, with deign as was thought, to go into Spain; the other man of Bruels follow'd him a few days after, and I ent the Cardinal word they were gone, and I had conducted them as far as Bayonne: 'twas a very imple thing of thee people to go two of them the ame way, but God, who infatuates thoe who lye in wait for blood, not only blinded their eyes in this, but uffer'd the Fleming to come back the very ame way, where I had orders to apprehend him; he was very much urpriz'd, and knowing he carry'd enough about him to prove him guilty, and would endanger his life, for he was a Frenchman, whereas I thought he had been a Fleming, he poion'd himelf with omewhat he carry'd about him, without
my perceiving it, which was o trong, that he well'd in les than two hours time; I did what I could to ave him, but having no upicion of it, and no help at hand, the Poion had wrought its effect before a Phyitian could be had.

I found quilted in his Boots, the Original Treaty which Fontrailles had been negotiating with the King of Spain, in the name of the Duke of Orleans, the Duke de Bouillon and de Cinqmars; and taking pot at the ame time to bring it to his Eminence, and give him an account of what I had done, I took the Road to Languedoc whether he was gone, with the King, who was going to the Siege of Perpignan; I found him ditemper'd both in body and mind, but chiefly the latter; for Cinqmars had prepoet the King againt him, and his friends had jut given him notice that he was ruin'd with the King, which oblig'd him to quit Narbonne, to be nearer Provence and Dauphine, the Governors whereof were at his devotion: Cinqmars had taken upon him to aainate him in that Journey, and they ay he had promis'd the Duke of Orleans to do it, who hated him mortally, but having lipt an opportunity which he had one day, being alone with him at leat a quarter of an hour, he could never get the like afterwards. His Eminence receiv'd me as if I had been his good Angel; and being not at all concern'd that the man was dead, ince I had got the Treaty, he ent me with it to the King, after he had taken a Copy of it for himelf.

Having made me the Confident of his preent trouble, I took the liberty to advie him to keep the Original by him, and end only the Copy to the King, ince no body could be anwerable for what might happen, and if they hould chance to get it
from me, he would be at a los to make out what he pretended; but he told me in the condition things were, there was a neceity to undeceive the King immediately, and that if he did not end him the Original, perhaps he would not believe the Copy: Upon this anwer I went away immediately; and the Count de Charot who was in waiting, very civilly introduc'd me to the Kings preence. The King being alone I urpriz'd him extreamly with the preent I made him, he communicated it to no body, and askt very kindly how the Cardinal did: I told him, as I was intructed, that he was very ill, which was the reaon that he had not waited upon his Majety according to his order; for I forgot to tell one thing that was very particular, which was, that before the Cardinal came to Taracon, he had ent to tell the King he was coming to Court, and that the King had anwer'd, he hould not give himelf that trouble, but might tay in the Country for the recovery of his health.

This was the reaon why they told him he was undone, and alo why he retreated towards Provence and Dauphine: In the mean time, as he was the greatet Politician of the age, he knew there was no way o likely to recover him in the Kings favour, as to reduce the King to ome want of him; for the King, who was a timorous irreolute Prince, was not capable of directing himelf in the leat difficulties: The Marechal de Grammont, who was wholly devoted to the Cardinal, play'd this card for him, and uffering himelf to be beaten on purpoe by the Spaniard in the battle of Honnecourt, he left by that means all the Frontier Country of Picardy open to the Enemy; the King upon this news immediately has recoure to the Cardinal, and he having made a fair pretence not to
come to Court, was now not only order'd to come away with all peed, but the King goes part of the way himelf to meet him, uppoing he was not able to make hate enough; o the Siege of Perpignan was broken off.

'Twas in this interim that I brought the King the Treaty that I mention'd; he bid me go back immediately, and let no body know that I had been with him; I met the Cardinal on the way, who was not o ick but he could follow me, and being come to the King, Monieur de Cinqmars was immediately apprehended, and Monieur de Thou to whom he had committed the ecret. The King caret the Cardinal mot paionately at their meeting; but this great man had conceiv'd o much indignation in his mind, at the Kings uage of him after o many ervices, that he fell into a ditemper call'd the Hemorrhoides, which tormented him extreamly; all this however did not eclipe the vigour of his mind, which was not to be equall'd tho under the languihment of a cruel ditemper; he made them pull down the ides of the door to bring him in as he lay in tate upon the Bed; and he was carry'd all the way on mens houlders, the Swis Guards mot commonly performing that ervice.

I was extreamly cat down to ee my Mater in this condition, while the Court generally rejoyc'd at it; for he had ruin'd the fortunes of a great many particular men, tho he had rais'd the Glory of the King, o that every one would have been glad to have een him dead, in hopes to recover themelves again, which the weaknes of the Kings capacity gave them reaon to think would be eay if he were out of the way. The King, like a mot Chritian Prince, hut himelf up often in his Cloet to pray,
but as Prayers without Endeavours are fruitles, the Court was full of caballings in prejudice of his Authority, In the mean time they enter'd proces againt Monieur de Cinqmars, and Monieur de Thou, whom they had ent to Lyonn, and committed to the Catle de Pierre-Encie. The Youth of one, for Monieur de Cinqmars was not above two and twenty, and the Reputation of the other, made them to be univerally pity'd, and open'd the mouths of a multitude againt the Cardinal, for he was not very well belov'd by the Populace, who exclaim'd at his Cruelty, not regarding the Jutice he had now on his ide, nor conidering the crimes they were guilty of; they cry'd out he was merciles and blood-thirty, and ript up the tory of the Marechal de Marillac. His Eminence being told of this, for he lov'd to be told whatever was aid of him, would ay to me ometimes, that he was very unhappy, that 'twas allow'd to private men to purue even to death, one that attempts to aainate them; but that for him, he mut not be allow'd, beides the particular attempts upon his own life, to take notice of thoe made upon the Royal Authority, but Envy would cenure all his proceedings as o many acts of Injutice. I have een him o affected, when he has been talking to me of thee kind of matters, that he could hardly refrain weeping, and when I would reply to him, that he ought not to regard publick fame, which oftentimes aid it knew not what; he reply'd, that 'twas that nevertheles which made a man immortal, and 'twas hard to take o much pains for that ort of immortality, and yet at lat leave the world with the candal of a Tyrant.

He poke thee things with uch enible accents of orrow, that ufficiently tetify'd the greatnes of
his Soul. In the mean time they cut off the heads of Monieur de Cinqmars, and of Monieur de Thou; and Monieur de Bouillon had run the ame fate, having been eiz'd in Italy, had he not bought his life with the los of his Principality of Sedan. People admir'd the Cardinal hould pare him, having had everal Tetimonies of his ill will, for this was not the firt time, that he had attempted to embroil the Kingdom, and epecially to ide in all occaions againt the Cardinal; in hort, 'twas but t'other day that he had been pardon'd for being concern'd in the Rebellion of the Count de Soions, whom he had not only helter'd in his Houe, but had taken up Arms for him; but all that can be aid to this is, that the Cardinal could forget injuries to himelf, when the Honour of the King and Kingdom requir'd it.

Let them ay what they will, this was the man born to lay the Foundations of the preent greatnes of France, and whom all good Frenchmen ought to have wiht had been immortal; but God, who puts an end to all things, having determin'd him to certain limits, which he could not out-live, took him from hence, and he dy'd, to the inexpreible grief of all his Servants. I had foreeen it two or three months before, for his ditemper was attended with viible tokens of death from the beginning, and I was troubled extreamly to ee mot people rejoyce at it: The King himelf was doubtful of his recovery, tho he had thoe about him that ininutated a notion into him, that the Death of the Cardinal would be his happines: This was omething trange, if we reflect, that this great Miniter, who found things in uch a orry condition when he firt came to the Helm of the Government, had reduc'd the rebellious Hugonots, had humbled the Houe of Austria, by
taking from it the Kingdoms of Portugal and Catalonia, and the greatet part of Alace; av'd Italy, and in hort had done o many wonders, that Poterity begins already to acknowledge, that a man who did uch great things, mut have omething in him extraordinary. He told me as he lay a dying, that he had always lov'd me above any of his Servants, and that he was orry he had done no more for me; that if the King would take his advice, it hould be to employ me in affairs of the greatet conequence, for that I had all the Conduct, Courage and Wit that was neceary to accomplih any deign, all which he had experienc'd in everal caes.

If I had ever been enible of the marks of his eteem in his life time, I was much more o now, all his pat favours came at once into my mind, and thinking what I was going to loe, and that in a moment, this man who had made all Europe temble, hould be no more, I was o afflicted, that I am ure if the preent ence of it had continu'd but two days, I hould have been ditracted. His Eyes were no ooner clos'd, but the King made it appear that he dilik'd all he had done, for he immediately recall'd all thoe who had fled for fear of the Cardinals power; this gave me uch an averion to the Court, that I reolv'd not to continue in it a quarter of an hour longer: Several Perons of Quality invited me to their Service; the Duke d' Orleans poke to me by Egremont one of his Gentlemen, who to prevail with me, told me, I needed look no farther for my Encouragement than to him, who had made his fortune in the ervice of that Prince, that he had gotten two hundred thouand Crowns, and that if he hould live but to be fifty years old, he did not quetion but to get twice as much, but he did not tell me that he had
got all this by ways that I hould not care to practice; he plaid at Tables with his Mater, and having a parcel of Sharpers that went halves with him, they made port for the Duke to laugh at, which caus'd him to commit everal errors in play, and gave him opportunity to play fale, or to et up a Game or two more than there was: Thus, as I aid, he came to get o much Money, but as uch gains eldom proper, he grew o litigious, that he pent all that in Law which he had gotten at play.

The Prince of Conde alo poke to me by the Duke de Rochefoucaut, who began now to appear at Cou • t, from whence he had been a long time baniht with the ret; but tho he was a Prince of the greatet Politics, he did not how it in this, to end a peron to me that was one of the greatet Enemies my Mater had. I was jut going to retire my elf when the Queen Mother did me the honour to end me word, that he would have me go to Bruels to do her a mall piece of ervice there; I was amaz'd at this propoal, from one who I knew could not love any of the Creatures of my Mater, from whoe Minitry he had received o much mortification; for beides other things, he remov'd all her Friends from her by one means or another; and had o little repect for her, or rather o much zeal for the public ervice, that upon information that he had receiv'd Letters from Spain, he had caus'd her to be earch'd, without any regard to modety, or the repect due to her Sex: This was an inolence he would never forgive him, and which I thought alo hould make her extend her reentment to any thing that belong'd to his Eminence; I believ'd too, that this was only propos'd to me, that they might have an opportunity to take me off, and that Madam de Chevreue having inform'd them
of my ecape out of Bruels, intended, if he could get me thither, to betow that upon me which ecap'd before; being poet with this opinion, return'd her Majety thanks for the honour he deign'd me; but being not contented with my excues, I was fain to hift it off with telling her, that I was employ'd in the Cardinals time in that Court, where I was o well known, that the way to have an affair effectually micarry, was to put it into my hands.

Thus I conceal'd my fear, and dextrouly put her off with excues; but the Queen, who had, jut as I guet, been inform'd by Madam de Chevreue of what had happen'd to me in that Country, told me, that I hould not trouble my elf, for he knew what I meant, but that going from her I hould be afe, and that he would give me her royal word for my ecurity: Such a continu'd importunity, in pight of all I could ay, made me upect her the more, o I thankt her Majety again, and begg'd her pardon; and he ent in my room Morville, one the Cardinal Mazarin helpt her to, who ince the death of my Mater was become Chief Miniter of State. This errand was to dicoure with la Porte, the Dutches de Chevreue's Confident, and to know from his own mouth, if 'twas poible to gain the Count de ..... who was the Archdukes Favourite; that in cae of the Kings death, which 'twas thought could not be far off, there might be an Army ready upon the frontier to aure the Regency to the Queen; he made no quetion of gaining this Favourite by the help of Madam de Chevreue: But Cardinal Mazarin, who knew already what power he had with the Queen, and was loth he hould increae it by a new ervice o coniderable as this, too readily ininuated
into her, that la Porte would manage this matter by himelf with les noie and more afety; and the Queen who had not o much affection for Madam de Chevreue as he had formerly, was eaily perwaded.

Morville being arriv'd at Bruels, eaily gain'd la Porte, with the hopes of being made firt Page to the King, he charg'd him whatever he did, not to reveal it to the Dutches de Chevreue; and he, who ow'd his fortune to her, who from a Mechanic Taylor, which was his Trade, had been rais'd by her, even to her Bed, readily conented to betray his Mitris and Benefactrice, in hopes of further advancement. The Comte de ..... was more in favour with Madam de Chevreue than la Porte thought of; for he being an amorous Lady had given him unquetionable proofs of her eteem, o that la Porte had no ooner broken the ecret to him, but he dicover'd it all to his Mitris; 'tis impoible to expres the Dutchees reentment, he flew out in all the reproachful language he could think of to la Porte; but he who was a fellow of a very harp wit, imagining that o great a confidence of the Comte de ..... could not proceed but from an affection that had met with ome oft returns from her; intead of appearing urpriz'd at what he aid, return'd her reproaches upon her elf for her Incontancy; telling her, he had purchas'd this dicovery at the price of her honour, and that a man who was abus'd in o enible a part as his Love, ought to revenge himelf by all poible methods. The Dutches, tho he was nettled at this ort of return, epecially from him, and was going to caheer him, yet on econd thoughts he durt not venture to do o, for fear he hould return into France, and give the Queen an account what a life he led, and of a thouand intreagues he had
been concern'd in againt her Majety; and apprehending too, that he would acrifice her to the Marechal de Schomberg's Lady, who after having reited ollicitations from the King himelf, yet as report went, did not tick to admit to her arms o pitiful a Fellow as this.

The Comte de ..... who was jealous of la Porte, was urpriz'd that after all this, the Dutches till carry'd it but coldly to him, and did not throw off la Porte as he expected, and to free himelf from a Rival was reolv'd to poion him; but la Porte, who knew not only the humour of the Spaniards, but was alo enible of the reentment of the Dutches, kept himelf upon his Guard, and would not eat or drink but at his own houe, and continu'd to do thus till he return'd into France; which caution of his, in all probability, was the aving of his life.

During all thee Intreagues the King declin'd o in his health, that 'twas plain to all the world he could not live long, and Madam de Chevreue having o much influence upon the Queen, attended with impatience for the news of his death, not only that he might be recall'd to Court, but not quetioning the raiing of her fortune; wherefore to oblige the Queen, and fix her elf in her Majetys opinion, he reolv'd to effect that by her own interet, which the Queen had attempted to do by an underhand treaty with la Porte; but fearing that as long as la Porte was with her, the Comte de ..... would never heartily engage in her deign, he concerted matters with la Porte, and agreed with him that he hould return into France to manage her part with the Queen; by which means, tho not without regret, he conented to leave her to his Rival, in hopes of advancing his Fortune.

Indeed, the promie they had made him of being Page to the King, had o gain'd upon him, that he lighted every thing for it; o that as oon as ever he came to Paris, he went away to the Queen, whom he told, that not being able to ucceed in his negotiation for her Service, Madam de Chevreue had undertaken it, and would doubtles perform it better than he could have done. The Queen, who had uch confidence in the Cardinal, as we before noted, having acquainted him with this, intead of approving of it, he was exceedingly troubled at it, and told the Queen he was going to ruine her elf, for if the King hould come to dicover what had pat he was undone; his averion to Madam de Chevreue being invincible, that 'twas well enough to entertain la Porte, becaue he was lookt upon as a Peron out of favour, and therefore would not be upected, and might ome time or other be of ue to them; but for Madam de Chevreue, it was neither afe to hold any correpondence with her, nor could he be any way erviceable at this time.

The Queen, who knew this to be very true, was the eaier to be perwaded, o they ent Madam de Chevreue word, that they were very much oblig'd to her for the pains he had taken, but that in the preent poture of affairs, they did not think fit to proceed in thoe meaures any further: In the mean time, the Cardinal et la Porte at work upon the Queen, to leen her eteem for Madam de Chevreue, and made that ervice the further condition of the preferment they had promied him; which nevertheles they delay'd till after the Kings death, and then gave it him as if it had been at the interceion of Madam de Chevreue, who as cunning a Woman as he might be otherways, was made a property
in this cae, to take that for a favour done on her account, that was the reward of his Treaon in betraying her.

In the mean time, 'twas a Mater-piece of Policy in the Cardinal, after having put by the Queen, from thoe methods he had taken o much to her advantage, to find out other ways to ecure the Regency to her. He fear'd Monieur Denoirs mot, who was Secretary for the War, and would have been very glad to have him remov'd, and yet made ue of him to make the propoal to the King, and he had two deigns in o doing: firt, if the King conented to make the Queen Regent, then he had effectually oblig'd her, as being the firt contriver of it; but if the King hould reent it ill and fly ou •
into a paion at it, then 'twould digrace his Adverary: Monieur Denoirs was uch a Fool, as to be prevail'd on to engage in this affair; but knowing that 'twould be a difficult thing, he et upon the Kings weak ide, that is, he engag'd his Confeor in the matter; who repreented to him, that having in probability not long to live, he ought to think of ettling his Concience; that nothing was o much requir'd of us at our going out of this World, as forgiving our Enemies, and that he ought now to forget all the dicontent, that had been between him and the Queen; that he had already recall'd to Court thoe whom he had upected on her account, that nothing remain'd now, but to give her ome Tetimonies of his reconciliation to her: that the preent circumtance offerr'd him one; which was to make her Guardian of her Children, a thing o naturally her right, that the Law excluded all other Relations from pretending to it: That if he did otherwie, 'twould look as if he had till ome reerve on his mind, and that nothing
was o dangerous, as to equivocate with his Concience.

The Confeor was very ready to go upon this foolih Errand, whether that he thought himelf oblig'd to it by his Office, or that he thought to do a piece of Service to Monieur Denoirs; but he was immediately caheer'd for his pains; and the King coming to know afterwards, that this came from Monieur Denoirs, he erv'd him in the ame manner, giving his Office of Secretary to Monieur le Tellier, who is now Chancellour of France. The Fortune of this Monieur le Tellier and the Marquis de Louvois his Son, being o trangely great, that they eem to equal that of Soveraign Princes, if not to exceed them. I hall peak a word to it, to demontrate, that where Merit is really the foundation, there is no tructur can be too great to build upon it.

Monieur le Tellier's Father was one of the Long Robe, and brought up his Son in the ame Profeion, and having made him capable of buines, he had a mind to get him the Office of the Kings Procuret de Chatelet, which is a thing independent from any of the other Courts, and very coniderable. He that old it having everal Cutomers about it, preferr'd him to them all, on condition he hould pay the Money down at a certain time, which was very hort. But wanting 10000 Crowns to make up the um, he had like to have lot it, when Monieur de Pelletier, who had an Office in the ame Court, lent him the Money; o that all obtacles being remov'd, he entred upon the place, and behav'd himelf with o much reputation, that he was lookt upon as a Man, that had not his fellow for widom; but all this did not prevent a very odd accident befalling him. Being one day riding thro the Town,
there happen'd ome Tumult in the Streets, and his Office (being a Magitrate) obliging him to take notice of it: The Grooms of the Kings Hores laid hold of his Bridle, and not knowing who he was, they carry'd him with them into the Great Stable, but the Querrys who knew him well enough made their excue, and made the Grooms ask his Pardon; he was o good humour'd, that he made no complaint of this violence; which if he had, might have brought them into a great deal of trouble. In the mean time, Monieur de Bouillon having ome publick buines with him, and finding him to be a Man of a prodigious capacity, he perwaded him to reign his Office, and to come into the Council.

'Twas by doing this, that he began to make himelf known to my Mater, whom I have often heard peak of him, very much to his advantage; when he appear'd at the Bar, he met with all the marks of eteem that ue to be given to Perons of his Merit, and at lat was preferr'd to be Secretary of State, as I have mentioned before: but it was upon condition, nevertheles, that he hould pay Monieur Denoirs 400000 Franks, which he ent to him accordingly, but he refus'd them, expecting that if any udden Change hould happen at Court, he might get into his place again: So Monieur de Tellier had his Money again, and Monieur Denoirs dying quickly after, the Cardinal Mazarin with the conent of the Queen Mother, gave him this um, excluding the Heirs of Denoirs; this and uch like Obligations fixt him in their Interets, and he gave good marks of his Ability in the nice occaions, which happen'd about that time; the Civil War being jut then broke out, in all which he continu'd firm in the Interet of the Queen Mother and Cardinal
Mazarin, whom he always look'd upon as his Benefactor.

After the Cardinal Mazarin's Death, he o gain'd upon the young King, who had wit enough to ditinguih who erv'd him faithfully and who not; that the ame reaons, which oblig'd him to value Monieur de Tellier, oblig'd him at the ame time, to apprehend Monieur de Ponquet. There had been ome difference between thee two, which made People think, that Monieur de Tellier did contribute underhand to his digrace; but to let the world ee how they were mitaken, he never o much as ollicited the King or meddled with the proces; either of which, if he had done, the other had undoubtedly been lot.

The King had no prime Miniter at all after the Death of Cardinal Mazarin, but if any body could pretend to that place, it was without doubt Monieur de Tellier, he had two Sons and one Daughter. The Daughter is married to the Marquis de Villequier: who is now Duke d' Aumont; for his Sons, he bred up the Eldet, who is the Marquis de Louvois, to Buines, and the younget to the Church, and who is now Coadjutor to the Arch-bihoprick of Rhiems, under Cardinal Antoine; by which means he is certain to be, one time or other, Duke and Peer of France; and the other had the aurance of being Secretary of State after his Father. His great Services are o freh in the memory of all Men, that 'tis needles to mention them; all the great tranactions of Europe were form'd in his head, and he manages the place at this day, with as much reputation as my Mater did in his time, which is enough for any man to ay in his Commendation; only I mut be allow'd to make this difference, between
the preent time, and the days pat, that my Mater was o far from being econded, by a vigorous young King, that he had none oppos'd his directions, more than him who he endeavour'd to erve mot; whereas his preent Majety, is the firt a Horeback, to execute thoe Deigns, that have been projected in his Cabinet.

However it was, the Services both of the Father and the Son, could not be better rewarded than they are now. The Father is Chancellor of France, the greatet honour that can be conferr'd upon the Gown, and who is the leading Man, both at Court and on the Bench: The Son is Secretary of State, chief Miniter, and in a word, the Peron on whom the King relies, in matters of the greatet moment, whether for Peace or War. In the mean time, I mut not forget one Circumtance, which proves the gratitude of both the Father and the Son. Monieur Colbert, who had the Adminitration of the Finances, being dead about two or three years ago, they procur'd his place, for the Son of Mr. Pellitier, whom we have poken of, as a recompence for the favour they had receiv'd from his Father.

I have been a little larger than ordinary upon the rie and fortune of the Chancellor, and the Marquis de Louvois his Son; 'twill be acknowledg'd not to be o remote as may be thought, being to relate in what follows, many great Actions, which have pat under their Minitry, and I ought to give an Idea of thoe, which manag'd the Government, to hew that uch Mater-pieces of Policy, could not proceed from any Perons, but uch as were perfectly vert in the nicet affairs of State.

But to return to my own Cae, ever ince I refus'd the Negotiation at Bruels, I was frown'd upon
every where, and was o lighted by the Queen and the Miniter, that I reolv'd to retire. The King in the mean time, having exil'd Monieur Denoirs, for having but offer'd to peak in favour of the Queen, did not however proceed with the ame vigor againt Cardinal Mazarin, nor Chavigny who had epous'd her Interets: 'Tis true, they did it genteely, and intead of propoing it downright to the King, to make her Regent, they only advis'd him while he was in a condition to do it, to ettle his Affairs as he pleas'd they hould be manag'd after his Death; that the Infancy of his Children requir'd this at his hands; at leat he would have this atisfaction at his Death, to know what hould become of them; whereas, if he omitted it, they would be expos'd to trange unforeeen Accidents.

The King could not deny, but what they aid was highly reaonable, but he met with a great many invincible difficulties, aoon as ever he went about this ettlement; he could think of no body to leave the Government of his Children to, but the Queen or the D. of Orleans his Brother; but the latter appear'd to him, to be of too unettled and unquiet Spirit, and the other too much of a Spaniard: o he took the middle of thee Extreams and joyn'd them both in the Adminitration, hoping they would temper one another, and perform the duty of o great a Charge the better: It happen'd to this Contrivance, as it does to a State that continues Neuter, while its Neighbours are fighting out their Quarrel, neither one nor t'other were pleas'd with what the King had done for them, and new Plots were et at work on both ides, to make him alter his reolution; the Courtiers oberv'd the Contrivances of both Parties, but none knew which would prevail, or who hould
govern the Queen, if he hould happen to get the Power abolutely into her hands, for he carry'd it o fair to all ides, that he had every day new favourites: the Cardinal Mazarin did his utmot to incline the Scale on his ide; and to the end that the Queen might be prevail'd on, by his zeal to her Service, he improv'd every moment of the Kings Life, to endeavour to gain him to do omething more in her favour: He laid it before him, how a Mother had natural Obligations, and would certainly ditinguih the Interet of her own Children, from that of the nearet Relations; that 'twas not the ame thing with repect to the Duke of Orleans, for he who durt everal times take up Arms againt his Majety himelf, would make no cruple to do the like againt a Child; that in the mot flourihing condition of the State, his Birth occaion'd that a Multitude of the Nobility made their Court to him, which they would have more reaon to do, when joyn'd with o great an Authority. The King was not mov'd with all this, but anwer'd that he had taken care of all, by the form of Government, that he had ettled in his Declaration; and o dy'd without making any alteration.

I had been o us'd to the Court, that notwithtanding the reolution I had taken to retreat from it, I could not bring my elf to do it. I follow'd the fortune of the Duke de Richelieu, who was a Peron, to whom my Mater had bequeath'd both his Etate and his Title; ome ay he was his Son by Madam d' Eguillon, but he had not wit enough to be the Son of o great a Man, which makes me give no credit to that report: However it was, finding he did nothing worthy of that Name, I took my leave of the Court, without giving him any reaons for it, being
very melancholly at parting from a place, which I thought was the mot charming in the world. My deign was to engage in the War, which was very hot on all ides on our Frontiers; for tho I had lot a great deal of time, yet I found my elf able and vigorous enough, as I thought, for the hardhip of the Service. This oblig'd me to make my court to Mr. l • Tellier, to whom I was particularly enough known, to give me ground to hope for omething from him: But as he was all policy, he poke to the Cardinal of me, who forbid him giving me any Employment: I knew immediately that he mut have receiv'd ome uch order as this, for Monieur le Tellier did not peak to me as he us'd to do, and intead of giving me poitive aurances, as he had done before, that I hould have what I demanded, he put me off now with telling me, he hould be very glad to do me any Service; This was a word o cutomary with him, when he intended to do nothing at all, that I e'ne took it forgranted: In the mean time, I was vext that he had held me in upence o long, and Monieur de la Chatres having oberv'd, that I was grumbling and fretting, as I came out of his Office, he told me that if I pleas'd he would find me out a Mater, who would make up all my loes and orrow for my old one: I told him I hould be glad of it, provided before hand, that it hould not be the Duke d' Orleans, and he naming to me at the ame time, the Duke de Beaufort, I anwer'd him I had always a great eteem for him, but he being engag'd in Interets contrary to the late Cardinal my Mater, he could not put any Confidence in me; nor indeed could I erve him heartily: he askt me if I thought I did wiely, in talking at that rate, and that after having liv'd o long at Court, I had made o little advantage
of what I had een, as not to know that nothing but Interet rules opinion: that as long as Cardinal Richelieu was alive, I did well not to engage with any of his Enemies; but now at this time when I was lighted by the preent Miniter, I ought to joyn my elf to the Interet and Friendhip, of thoe who had caue to hate him, and if any one was on thoe terms with him, 'twas certainly the Duke de Beaufort, who had been robb'd by him of the Queen Mothers favour, when but for him, he might by his power with her, have done any thing for his Friends; that he was a brisk bold Prince, and knew how to value a man of worth, and one, in hort, whoe Service he was very glad he had entred into; that if I pleas'd he would peak to him for me, and 'twould be enough to etablih his Confidence in me, but to tell him the averion I had to the Cardinal Mazarin.

The difficulty I had to quit the Court, and the eager deire I had alo to revenge my elf of the Cardinal, made me the readier to accept this offer; o he poke to Monieur de Beaufort, who expret a very extraordinary deire to have me. And having told him that I hould find him at Anet, whether he was going, I parted from Paris with one of my acquaintance, who had a houe on that Road, and with whom I had made a Match to play at Longue Paume; o we ent our Men before us, and following our elves, we took the way to Cour la Rein • , o to go from thence by the Bois de Bolog • e to St. Cloud: as we were a little beyond the Marechal de Baompier's Houe, where there is now a Convent, omebody threw a tone at the Gentleman that was with me, and hit him on the Back, and looking behind him to ee who it was, he aw ome People upon
the Leads of the Houe, who nodded their heads at him, and thinking they had been Women, Morbleu, ays he, they laugh at us; as he was aying this, they hollow'd and threw tones at us again; and now we could eaily dicern, that they were not Women as we thought, but Men, who did not conceal themelves, but began to Jeer at us and Banter us, and to over do it too, o as 'twas not to be born: So my Friend drew a Pitol, and a Stone coming at him, and hitting him on the Arm, he made no more ado but fir'd, and narrowly mit killing the peron that he hot at; and was going to draw his other Pitol, when the people of the place told us, that it was the Duke of Orleans, who was there with all his Court. This advice came too late. We took it for granted we hould be immediately puru'd; and having no way left, but to ride for it, we et Spurs to our Hores, and made off as fat as we could: We were hardly got to the top of La Montagne de bons hommes, when 5 or 6 Horemen hew'd themelves coming full peed after us; and tho our Hores were all in a foam, we purr'd on amain, without giving them breath: They had need have been good Hores, to have ecur'd us from thee puruers, for they came on as if they had flown, and were almot up with us, before we got to the Bois de Bologne; o that eeing no way to ecape, we reolv'd to face them; and my Friend who wanted no Courage, was going to fire the Pitol he had left, when one of his Friends being of the Party, and knowing him, call'd him by his Name, and told him ince 'twas he, all was well, and he might put up his Pitol again, at the ame time running to him, he embrac'd him; o the ret put up their Pitols alo: we very civilly told them, that if we had known it had been the Duke de Orleans,
we hould not have behav'd our elves as we did; and they aur'd us on the other hand, that if they had known it had been us, they hould have us'd us better: But I quetion whether they would or not; for a man that would go a Sharping, and catching Cloaks off Peoples backs in the Night, on the Pont Neuf, as the Duke of Orleans us'd to do, would not have been eaily prevail'd on, to be civil to us.

The Quarrel being thus ended, nothing would erve them, but we mut go back with them, which I oppos'd with all my Power; as well for that I would willingly be punctual at the place I was going to, as alo becaue I knew I hould be upected in that Company: but all I could ay was to no purpoe, o I was oblig'd to go with them. We found the Duke d' Orleans, with five or ix others engag'd in a Debauch; he never took notice that I had liv'd with Cardinal Richelieu, or that I had refus'd his Service, but et us down at the Table, where having drank exceive hard, he had a mind to how himelf a Prince; that is, to have a Frolick, that hould have omething in it extraordinary. There was the Collonel of the Regiment of Languedoc there, whoe Name was Wallon, a prodigious fat fellow, and took o little heed to his hape, that intead of Dyetting himelf for it, all his delight was in cramming himelf with good Cheer: This Collonel was to lye down flat upon his back, and the Duke was to eat an Omelette of Eggs upon his Belly; Wallon lay down very readily, and expos'd his bare Belly for their Table, and the Cook clapt the Omelette out of the Pan upon it; while he was o drunk that either he did not feel it burn him, or ele in point of honour he would not confes it.

After every one had eaten of this Ragout, and expret their atisfaction with it, both the Duke and all his Company, they mut needs go all to Paris, to Madam la Neveu, a Lady who was very well known: let my buines be what it would, I was fain to go along with them in pight of my Teeth; They did there all they were capable of doing in the condition they were in, till the woman of the Houe, being enrag'd at their uage of her, and ome other Whores they had ent for: The Duke of Orleans to pacify her, told her he would make her ome port; o he ent for a Commiaire, under pretence of ome diturbance in the Houe: The Commiaire came well guarded, and the Duke d' Orleans having hid us in a Chamber out of ight, there was no body appear'd, but he and Wallon the Collonel; they were both lying on the Bed, with Madam Neveu in the middle; and the Commiaire thinking now he had catcht them in the fact, and not knowing who they were, bid them get up, but they refuing, he bid his followers pull them out by force; and they beginning to lay hands on them, they were urpriz'd to ee us ally out of our Hole, and the more, for that we did not come on as if we intended to attack them, but with our Hats in our hands, making our Repects to the peron they were a going to lug out of the Bed; they were further urpriz'd when they aw the Rich Habit, that was brought to the Duke, when he went to dres him; but when they aw the Blue Ribbon, they were Thunder-truck and perfectly atoniht: The Commiaire began then to ee his Error, and threw himelf at the Dukes Feet to beg his Mercy; the Duke bid him fear nothing, and he hould come off cheap enough: We did not know what he would do, but he was not long a contriving:
he call'd down the other Women, who had not yet appear'd, and et them on the Bed-ide in a row, and taking one at a time, he made the Commiaire and all his Attendants naked in their Shirts, with a wax Candle in their hands, come and do homage to omething he how'd them. thereby to make, as he call'd it, an honourable atisfaction to the Ladies.

After this, we had every one Liberty to go whether we plea'd, and having lot a great deal of time, I was afraid that Monienr de Beaufort would be got to Anet before me, o I Travell'd all night, for fear he hould think I would diappoint him; but when I came there I found he was not yet arriv'd, which I was very glad of; But two days being pat, and not a word of him to be heard, I could not tell what to make of it; Being very impatient and not knowing how to dipoe of my elf, I took my Hore and went out upon the great Road, to ee if I could meet with any body, at lat I aw a man come galopping along, and immediately concluding that it was omebody from him, I would have topt him to have askt what news he brought; but he taking no notice of me, rode on, and went into the Catle: as oon as he was in they hut up the Gates, at which I was urprized, for it wanted a good deal of night; I came, and knockt at the gate to get in but all to no purpoe, tho I waited above an hour; at lat, as I was jut going away, I heard a great many Dole • ul crys within, and at the ame time aw them let down the Drawbridge, I went in, and found that this affliction was occaion'd by that peron who brought them the News, that the Duke de Beaufort was apprehended at Paris.

This Prince had been much in favour with the Queen Mother, who had given him o many marks of her eteem, as left it without quetion; for one day
when they thought the King was jut a dying he put her children into his hands, which was the caue that all the Princes of the Blood were Jealous of him: if the Duke de Beaufort had manag'd himelf wiely after this, there was all the appearance in the world that he would have been made Chief Miniter, at leat he would have been the Favorite: But having plotted with Chateauneuf and others to ruin the Cardinal Mazarin, he no ooner aw himelf ettled above their Power to hake him, but he dipers'd the whole Faction, cauing ome to be apprehended, and others to fly the Kingdom: tho' I knew nothing of all the intrigue, yet I was it eems involv'd in the michiefs of it; for ome body having told Mazarin that I had been een talking with Monieur de la Chatres, he put me down in the black Roll of thoe he intended to ecure, and was urpriz'd with a witnes when at my return from Anet I aw my elf very decently ent to the Batile; de la Chartres came off better than I, but was fain to Surrender his Commiion of Collonel General of the Swis, to purchae his Liberty.

He did not continue o long in Prion as I did, for having none of thoe powerful friends that he had, I was forgotten in my miery, and had not o much as the poor comfort of being Viited; my Father and my Mother in Law, eeing me embroiled in tate affairs, would not expoe themelves to the dipleaure of the Miniter; and for fear my brothers hould be kinder, they forbid them coming at me. I cannot expres how much I was afflicted at the beginning of my Confinement, but as there is nothing o harh but grows familiar by cutom, I made a virtue of Neceity, and bore it very patiently ix whole years without any diverion, but that of a
few books, which they gave me liberty to end for: in the mean time the Duke de Beaufort made his ecape from Vinciennes, where he had been confin'd; and finding all orts of people diatisfied with the management of Cardinal Mazarin, he began his intrigue anew, but with a little better ucces than before; I had been o long in prion, that I began to think that all the world had forgot me or thought I was dead: but when I dreamt of it leat of all, I aw a man come into my Chamber whom I remembred to have belong'd to the Cardinal Mazarin, he told me that he came to offer me my liberty, if I would promie him that after I had recover'd it, I would honetly accquaint him with all that I knew of the Duke de Beaufort's deigns; I made no paue upon his words, but anwer'd him immediately, that I never undertood till now, why I was committed, which it eems was upon upicion that I hould hold intelligence with that Prince, which God knew was no uch matter but tho' I had no concern in the leat with him, nothing was capable of making me accue a man by whom I was but uppos'd to be eteem'd; he would have aid everal things to have made me alter my mind, but giving him no anwer, but that I corn'd to be a py for any man, he left me as he found me; and went to carry his tory to his mater.

I preently concluded from hence, the Duke de Beaufort had made his ecape, and that they were afraid of him, and I long'd now to be at liberty to joyn with him in his Reentment, and after thinking eriouly how I might effect it, I found that there was but one way, and I reolv'd upon that; I brib'd the fellow that brought books to me, who coming o often was not mitruted, and he brought me at everal times, Rope enough to reach down from my
Chamber window to the Ditch; how great oever the danger eem'd, yet I ventur'd one very dark night, and having gotten down with ome difficulty, I made a hift to get through the Ditch, having before taken exact notice of every tep I was to make; o I got off and came into Paris, at the Porte de St. Martin: I lay under a Stall all that Night, it being too late to diturb any of my Friends; but at break of day I went into the Fauxburgh de St. Germaine, where I got me a Lodging: I enquir'd there what News was tirring, and was told that all the Town was in Combution, upon the account of an Edict which the Cardinal had publih'd, by which be Taxt all the Soveraign Courts. The Hatred I bore him, made me forget the Love I bear to my Native Country, which was threatned with great Revolutions; in hort, the Parliament, whom it principally concern'd, gave at the ame time a decree againt Mazarin; and ome of the Members were o violent againt him, that if the ret would have follow'd their Councel, they would have ventur'd once to revenge thoe many attempts, he had made upon their Liberties and Laws, with the price of his Blood.

The People, who aw themelves ruin'd with Edicts one upon the neck of another, joyn'd with the Parliament, and all things eem'd to be in a poture for a revolt: but that which compleated all was, that the Queen Mother clapt ome of their Body up into a P • ion, which erv'd like a ignal for all the ret to take up Arms. In a Moment the Chains were drawn cros the Streets, and all the Lanes and Paages barricadoed, and the Citizens left their Shops and Employment, and form'd themelves into Regiments for the War: So great was the publick
Hatred againt the Cardinal. The Queen Mother thought to appeae this Tumult with good words, but finding it to no purpoe, he brought together ome of the Guards, which erv'd indeed but to enrage the People. I thought now I might venture out without danger, and a Boy that had formerly liv'd with me, knowing me cried out, Here, Here was one would be ure to ide with them, for he had uffer'd deeply by the Tyranny of Mazarin, and coming up to me at the ame time aluted me; but I was o vext to ee he had dicover'd me, that intead of accepting his Compliment, I fell to reprimanding him everely; but the Croud hearing what he aid, flockt about me, and asking me a hundred quetions, which I anwer'd as well as I could. They made me go with them to the Main Guard, telling me I hould be their Captain, if they met with any reitance, for I lookt like a Souldier.

This diturbance would have run further, if the Queen Mother, who had before refus'd to et at liberty thoe he had made Prioners, had not now been better advis'd; but he releat them, and every one went home quickly. I was afraid however, that this matter would be a new Caue of Quarrel at me; and in hort I made no quetion, having been o rudely handled by him already but he would accue me now of having been a Ringleader in the public Tumult; and tho the Queen had promis'd to forget all that was done, yet knowing very well they never wanted pretences, when they had a mind to ruin a man, I thought it my bet way to get ome Protection; that of the Parliament was the ecuret as things then tood, for they had not only the love of the People, who foolihly thought all this had been done on their account, but had alo engag'd everal
Provinces in the Quarrel, who had no les good will to pull down Mazarin. The Parliament received my Petition, which was preented by the Duke de Beaufort, who was a peron very agreeable to the Pariians, principally becaue they thought him irreconcilable to Mazarin, o my requet was granted; and being then afe enough, I adher'd to the Duke de Beaufort's Party, who all of them hated the Cardinal. If I hould mention all the Intrigues and Contrivances laid againt him, 'twould well thee Memoirs into many Volumes: but being reolved to peak of nothing but what I had a hand in my elf, I hall content my elf with telling you that the Parliament having done all they could againt him, he reolv'd to humble them; but 'twas impoible to bring it about, without reducing Paris to Obedience, who having taken part againt him with o much heat, and being till ready to break out into Arms again, upon the leat occaion, the Enterprize did not only eem difficult, but above his trength. There was above a Hundred Thouand fighting Men in the City, to whom the Kings Troops were as good as nothing: Nevertheles the Duke d' Enguien, who was now Prince of Conde, by the Death of his Father, being return'd from Flanders, and having promis'd him to epoue his Quarrel, he drew his Army out of their Quarters; and the Court being withdrawn from Paris, the City was as it were blockt up. Paris being certainly the mot Populous City in the World, the Paages being topt up, brought them into great ditres: every one aid 'twas a hame they hould be tarv'd o, by a handful of People; o they appointed a day for a general Muter. The Forces being all come together, the Captains who were all Counellors (for
the whole was an Army of Burghers) were for drawing them up in Battalia, that the General might take a view of them, but no body knew which way to go about it; This was o pitiful a Buines, that it made thoe People laugh, that knew no more how to do it than they: at lat out teps a fellow from the Ranks all in a heat, and blutring about, aid aloud, that this was not according to the Rules of Dicipline; that he had been ix Months a Soldier in the Guards, and he was very much deceiv'd, if he could not do it better himelf; every body was overjoy'd that they had gotten a Man of Experience among them, and having delegated him the Command by a great hout of God bles the Parliament, and our New Officer: he was made Major General of the Infantry, and as the mark of his Office, he receiv'd the Truncheon, from the hands of Videau de Grammont Counellor aux Enquites; Grammont was jut a going to give him his Corlet, but being afraid of bringing a digrace upon his Family, who had the Reputation of being of a Warlike dipoition, he caus'd them to procure him another: His Son is as chary of his Corlet, to this day, as he is of his Beard, and wears it in Carneval time, which makes him look like an old Corporal, diguis'd like a Counellor.

This new Major was a little out in ordring his Battalia: However all people admir'd what he had done, and the Officers of the Regiment carried him home to Dinner with them in Ceremony, giving him the upper end of the Table; there they conulted of the means to raie the Blockade of the Town, and all that the Major aid was receiv'd like an Oracle; but all this did not hinder the Prince of Conde from attacking Char • nton, where the Pariians
had poted three thouand Men under Command of one Claucleu, and this Pot being of great Conequence, they detach'd a Party of twenty Thouand Men to relieve it; I went among the ret, and had the honour to be one of the Principal Officers among the Cavalry, which was order'd to upport the Infantry; we left them them to take the Front when we went out, but they were not ambitious for that which they they thought was not their due. The Prince of Conde appearing with three or four Hundred Hore, they were very deirous to take the Rear-Guard, but the order of Battle being dipos'd otherwie, we would not allow it, and continu'd to give them the honour of the Van, by retiring our elves full peed back into the Town: they call'd this a Flight, tho we ay, 'twas but our obedience to the Command that order'd us to keep in the Rear; however 'twas, if the Prince of Conde had pleas'd, he might have cut off all our Infantry, but he contented himelf with taking Charenton, where he lot the Duke De Chatillon, his Kinman.

I was aham'd to go into the Town again after uch an action as this, for though, perhaps I was none of the firt that fled, yet it was enough dihonour but to have been in uch bad Company; we would everal times after that try our Fortunes with the Enemy, but being always beaten, though we were ten to one, I aw plainly I hould get but little Honour by fighting at the Head of uch a Militia; in the mean time the Parliament abated nothing of their hatred to the Cardinal, but in their condition the old Proverb would not hold good, Arma cedunt Togae, o they thought of an Accommodation, and the more too, becaue all the People of Quality, though at firt they took part with them, began to hold Correpondence
with the Court; 'twas however, oppos'd by a great many, who were for demanding aitance of the Arch Duke, and the Prince of Conti, who was declared Generaliimo of the Party, was of this opinion, o they nominated the Marques De Noir
• outier and Laicques to go thither, I was alo of this number, not in the quality of a Plenipotenciary, as they were, but in that of a ubaltern Miniter, who was to follow their Orders.

I was not affraid now to how my elf there, going in o good a Character, and did not doubt but we hould be well receiv'd; in hort, the Arch-Duke promis'd us to march his Army to remove our Blockade, and I was left with him, to put him in mind of his Promie; but I was not there above eight days, but I perceiv'd that the Count De—who was till his Favourite, countermin'd all our Deigns. He did not care to have a Man o clearfighted as I to dive into his matters, and ent word to De Laieques, who was his Friend, that they hould recal me immediately; and all that I could undertand from this Conduct was, that Madam De Chevreue, who eem'd to deire the ruin of the Cardinal, was always well with that Count, and endeavour'd to hinder thee Troops entring into the Kingdom to make a more advantageous Treaty for herelf; our Journey had diturb'd the Court, o that he was oblig'd to meet them half way to make up the the Peace, and as the Arch-Duke was too low in his Marches, and the Parliament beginning now to repent of having call'd in Foreign Aid, the thing was immediately concluded.

Every one was for making his advantage in this Accommodation; ome agreed for Money, and others for Places, whilt poor I was the only peron that got
nothing, though the chief of the Party had all along promis'd to take care of my Fortune. I was then enible how little confidence was to be repoed in the aurances of Great Men, who promie largely when we can be erviceable to them, but fail not to forget us when we ceae to be o any longer. In hort, I had been reduc'd to very mean Circumtances, but for my yearly Income at Lyons, which was all I had now to trut to, after I had maintain'd my Brothers all this time at my own Charge. 'Twas not for me then to et up for Quality, yet was it ufficient to maintain me, with good Husbandry, which at lat I practied, having never another Cardinal Richlieu, to whom I could have recoure for what I wanted, and o reduc'd my attendance to a Valet de Chambre, and a Foot-boy, whereas in the Cardinal's days, I never kept les than ix or even Servants in Family. This eem'd omething odd to me, becaue I had ever liv'd great, but I knew not yet what it was to be neceitous, though it was not long before I did to ome purpoe.

Mazarin, who hated me mortally, as well for making my Ecape out of Prion, as for iding againt him in the late diturbances, caus'd my Revenue at Lyons to be topt, and everal Attachments to be made on it under borrow'd Names, though I never heard of it till I went to receive the Money, and then I was urpriz'd indeed to find my elf indebted to People I never knew; but making light of it at firt, I went to my Attorney, who told me the ame tory, and that I mut ign a grant of Poeion to them, till the Caue hould be decided. In the mean time he ask'd me for the Attachments, but I was not o prudent to take them up, and o was forc'd to go back to the peron that us'd to pay
me, and who put me off till the next day; the next Morning I went to his Houe, but they told me there that he was gone to a Siter's of his, who lay a Dying, about ten Leagues from Paris.

'Twas with this Excue they held me in upence for a Fortnight at leat, yet in all this time I never dreamt of this Fellow's holding Correpondence with Mazarin; at lat one told me he had een him in the treet, whereupon, with abundance of Joy for his Return, I went to enquire for him; but when I aw they us'd the ame Pretence as before, I concluded then, there was ome trick in it. I told them roundly that I was inform'd of his being in Town by everal People, who had een him, and vow'd I would not tir till I had poke with him. He was not very far off it eems, for hearing what I aid, he cried out at a ditance, that all was well enough, and they hould let me in. He made me then a thouand Excues for going out of Town without giving me the things I required, telling me, that being but jut come to Town, as I aw, he mut have one Night to look amongt his Papers, and the next day I hould certainly have them at my own Hour. I was uch a Fool as to believe him again, and came next Morning by break of Day, when feigning himelf Sick, he told me in the condition that he was, he could not poibly be as good as his word, and endeavour'd to put me off another day. But my Patience was quite worn out with waiting, o I directed my Attorney to draw me up an Order to make him deliver the things. He no ooner heard what I had done, but never talking any more of the Attachments, he return'd anwer that I mut make application to thoe at Lyons, his Commiion being at an end, and to prove what he aid, he hew'd me the
Sham Copy of an Order to recal it. This was a reference with a Vengeance; however, being oblig'd to write to Lyons, I ent my Contract by the Pot, to the end, that the Peron whom I writ to about this Affair, might as oon as he receiv'd it, proceed with all Expedition. I expected two or three Pots to hear from him, but all in vain, for my Contract was lot it eems, and another Man, to whom I had got one of my Friends to write, ends me this Account.

I lot a great deal of Time in this manner, but 'twas longer yet before I could procure a rough draught of my Contract; at lat they ent me word from Lyons, that the Pay-mater, who was formerly there, was retor'd to that Office, and that I mut addres my elf to him. Accordingly I ent another Summons, to which he anwer'd, That he had the Attachments in his Hands 'twas true, but I could not oblige him to deliver them till they were copy'd: I order'd him then to end me the Copies, which he was content to do, o he gave me in the Names of even of my Creditors, whom, as I aid, I never had o much as heard of in my Life: I deired them to appoint what Court they would proceed in, and after they had appear'd by their Attorney, there was three of them who declin'd the Juridiction of Chatelet. One of them was for removing the Tryal to the Requets du Palais, another to the de L' Hotel, and the third to the Grand Council, where all his Buines was done, as he pretended At lat after our Caue had depended above three Months, and when it was jut going to be decided, they brought it into the Privy-Council for the ake of that Judge's Regulation. 'Twas my ill luck to have a Sollicitor who naturally hated to take Pains, o that I thought our Tryal
was delay'd more out of his Lazines than Malice; but I was mitaken, for having gain'd one of his Servants with a little Money, the Fellow told me as a Secret, that in hort, 'twas to no purpoe for me to wait for any concluion to my Affair, for his Mater was exprely order'd to the contrary. I ask'd him how he came to know that, and he told me, there was a certain Man who came often to his Mater from the Cardinal on this Errand, and by the Decription he gave me of him, I knew it could be no other than Bellinzani, the worthy Servant to uch a Mater.

'Tis impoible to expres the Rage I was in when I heard this: I poke of it with ome Paion to the Mater of Requets, but finding I was not likely to get any Satisfaction from him, I went to make my complaint to the Chancellour Seguier, who promis'd to do me Jutice. He continued but three days in that Mind, for after Mazarin had poke to him, he never regarded his Word, and though I gave my contant Attendance on him every day, I made no Progres in my Buines. In the mean time Money began to grow carce, and I was forc'd to borrow of thoe Friends who were inclin'd to pity my condition. My Father I had often writ to on that account, but receiv'd no anwer, and might have tarv'd, if all the World had been like him. I was advis'd to Petition the Queen-Mother, a Princes of a very compaionate Nature, and who only was not belov'd by the Pariians, becaue they did not know her. I begg'd her therefore that he would be pleas'd to order the Chancellor and Sollicitor to do me Jutice, and to haten the Tryal of my Caue, but 'twas my misfortune that that Princes committed all things to Cardinal Mazarin, from
whom you may be ure, as he was a party concerned, I had little reaon to expect any Favour.

It far'd with me at that time as with all in Miery, I was foraken by thoe I had the mot depended on, and after I had two or three Months longer ollicited in vain, I was reduced to uch extream Poverty that I was ahamed of my elf, and knowing not where to hide my head, my lat Refuge was to go to my Father's, in hopes after what I had done for his Family, he could not deny me ome mall Relief, when he hould ee me uing for it in another manner than what I had done in my Letters. I carce had wherewithal to carry me down, and 'twould certainly have mov'd any one to ee a Man who was lately in uch Splendor, forc'd to tarve himelf for fear of wanting, Money on the Road. When I light at the Door, the old Servants of the Family, who had een my Grandeur, and aw me now, could not believe their own Eyes, but my Father and Mother-in-Law could not help knowing me, or they were willing enough ele to forget me; for though I found them at Table when I came in, they hardly had the civility to make me it down, and when I did, the mot of my Entertainment at Supper was the Reproaches they made me for my extravagance, which had brought me into this condition. How trange a thing is this Miery, that the Mind as well as the Body hould ink under its oppreion! I was o dejected, that I knew not what to ay for my elf, and but I that igh'd at every word they poke, I eemed to have lot both Life and Sence.

After this Welcome the firt day, I would not have tay'd another in the Houe, if I had known whither to have gone; for alas, my old Friend the
Curate had been dead above two Years, and Heaven it elf eem'd to conpire to load me with Mifortunes. Tho I bore them all, as well as I was able, and endeavouring to bring my Father to Reaon, I ounded him to find how he tood affected to lend me ome mall matter to carry me back again to Paris. I told him mine was a plain cae, that they could not always deny me Jutice, and 'twould not be long before Cardinal Mazarin would be weary, and ceae perecuting me, if it were only to be free from the Complaints I hould make againt him. I told him abundance of other things, to make him enible that his Money would not be thrown away, and that I intended to repay him; but • e all in a Fury, interrupting me, Why urely then, ays he, you take me for one that is eaily to be bubbled, but you are mitaken Sir, go banter omebody ele with your ha • Stories, I know the reaon well enough why your Money is topt, and pity the poor Creditors you rail at, as they are not only like to loe their Due, but as they have to do with a Fellow of uch wicked Principles.

Thee words made me o deperate, but that I reflected on the Sin I was going to commit, I had certainly tabb'd my elf at the very intant; yet I could not forbear uing a thouand Reproaches, and though I knew well enough what my Repect oblig'd me to, yet I did, and aid many things which were not o decent to be done to ones Father. He took occaion from this ('twas either he, or my Mother-in-Law) to forbid me their Table: and to put me out of all doubt, there comes up one of the Servants about Ten in the Morning, and preads me a Napkin on the Table in my own Chamber, and acquaints me with their Pleaure; tho' the Cloth was laid o early, it was not till after
they had din'd that I had any thing brought me to eat, and then I had the honour to hare in their Scraps, with the Servants. But what madded me above all was, to ee how great my Brothers liv'd, particularly the Abbot who grew o wealthy, there was none in all the Country, as he fancied, that could compare with him. He kept two or three packs of Dogs, two Huntmen, five or ix good Hores, and yet never was the Man that once invited me to hunt with him, though he ow'd all his Greatnes to my means.

'Tis but meer Railery to ay that any one dies of Grief, for if 'twere true, I could never have outliv'd mine. At lat, after I had liv'd there three Months in this manner, and not being able to endure the ill treatment I met with, I reolved to return to Paris. Much ado I had to queeze from my Father Money enough to bear the Charges of my Journey; but I was not got above two Leagues on my way, before he that was his preent Curate overtook me, and brought me ten Pitoles, telling me that he had a good while intended to preent me with them, but being in the Hands of one of his Friends, he could not have them before, adding, that his Predeceor was oblig'd to me, as he had been to his Predeceor; o begg'd me to accept of them, and wih'd he could have commanded more for my ake.

I had receiv'd in my Life many coniderable Summs from the Cardinal, but I profes I never was o enible of his Liberalities, as of the kindnes of this poor Curate; I told him therefore that I heartily accepted of his Preent, and if Heaven hould favour me with an opportunity, I would give him proof of my Gratitude; for not to diemble
with him, but to tell him plainly how things tood, I was in uch neceity, that without this eaonable relief of his, I mut have certainly tarv'd. After a great many Compliments on both ides we parted, and I kept on my way to Paris: When I came there, I found the Civil War ready to break out again. The Prince de Conde was gone to St. Maur, upon a fale Alarm, with a Troop of Attendants little inferior to the Kings. This Prince, who had done Cardinal Mazarin o much Service, as I have mention'd, was in requital confin'd to a evere imprionment, out of which being ecap'd by meer good fortune, he continu'd o apprehenive of the like uage, that he never reted from the thoughts and contrivances of War, being intigated by a great many People that hated Mazarin: If I had been in the Equipage I cou'd have wiht my elf, 'twou'd not have been long before I wou'd have waited on him, and offer'd him my humble Service; but being now in a condition, o f • r different from what I had appear'd in, I was forc'd to content my elf, only with making Prayers and Wihes for the ucces of his Deigns.

In the mean time the Parliament began again to make Decrees againt Mazarin, o that he was forc' •
to fly the Kingdom to avoid the fury of the common People, who all cry'd out to have him remov'd. Oberving therefore o favourable an opportunity, I preented my Petition to the Court of Judicature, in which I declar'd the tate of my Cae, and what injutice I had uffer'd for a long while; and I had this relief by it, that notwithtanding the Caue was depending in the Council, my Adveraries were order'd to be heard before this Court. Upon this, no body appear'd, and I obtain'd a Judgment againt
the Pay-mater General, who was oblig'd to disburt me the Money, which he had before taken for his own, with giving him a full dicharge for it: He durt do no otherwie, for fear I hould have et an ill name upon him, and have made him pas for another Mazarin, which was a Character at that time, ufficient to have a mans brains knockt out, epecially at Paris, where the Populace hated the very Name of him. I receiv'd then all at once a good Sum, which I had no ooner done, but I ent twenty Pitoles of it to our Curate, ten for the Principal, and as many more for the Interet. The removal of the Cardinal, was all this while nothing but a ham to amue the People; for he had till as much authority in the Council, as if he had been preent there. Every one was diturb'd at this, but epecially the Prince de Conde, who had a trong Party in the Parliament, and was favour'd by the People. For his Reputation, that was founded on o many Glorious Victories which he had obtain'd, gain'd him thoe who had only heard of them, as well as thoe who had been witnees of uch great Actions. He pretended, as I aid, fear of the like uage which he had met with; but the real motive was to advance his own Greatnes, as was evident by his Conduct: For at the ame time that he appear'd irreconcileable to Mazarin, he treated with him under hand; and if he cou'd have brought him to his Demands, he wou'd not only have uffer'd the Cardinal to return, but wou'd have been ready to offer him his Friendhip. 'Tis not known certainly what broke off the Treaty, unles 'twas, that the Ambition of that Prince tormenting him continually, he made new Demands every day, till as the other granted the old ones. But this I am inform'd
from good hands, that the Cardinal ent often to tell him, that he hou'd have whatever he requir'd, and that the Troubles which happen'd preently afterwards, were purely owing to the Prince de Conde.

If I were dipos'd to give a particular account of all the Actions of the War, I cou'd do it as well as another; but that being the buines of an Hitorian more than of one that writes Memoirs, I hall content my elf with telling you only this, that after a great many Meages backwards and forwards to no effect, they both had recoure to Arms. The Prince de Conde, who had everal places of trength in his hands, ent ome of his Creatures to all of them, to provide all things neceary in cae of a Seige, and epecially to Montrond, which was in the Heart of France, and at that time held to be impregnable. My reentment wou'd not let me tand Neuter in this War, o I joyn'd my elf to the Duke de Beaufort, who was now reconcil'd to the Prince de Conde, thro the Interpoition of the Duke of Orleans, after o violent an Enmity, that nothing would erve their turns, but the immediate death of one or the other. Now you mut know that the Duke of Orleans was wholly rul'd by the Cardinal de Retz, the Duke de Rohan and Monieur Chavigny, and thee three perons having their everal Interets to recommend, they had often hinder'd the Peace from being concluded, when the Duke himelf might have done it as he pleas'd, ince the Prince de Conde, who had declar'd for him, durt not have oppos'd him. Cardinal Mazarin, who was come to Court again, eeing himelf on the brink of o many Troubles, was reolv'd to make his lat effort to prevent them, to give the Duke of Orleans and the Prince de Conde all the atisfaction they cou'd deire, provided they did not init too much on the
Terms of their Adherents. He deir'd the Prince de Conde, to end him one of his Friends whom he had a confidence in, but that he hou'd be one who was never known to have been employ'd in any of their former Negotiations, that their Treaty might not be upected, by them whoe Interet it was that they hould not agree. The Prince de Conde choe out one of his own Gentlemen to end on this Errand, to whom he deliver'd his Demands in writing, with order to tell the Cardinal, that it wou'd be to no purpoe to conider a longer time on them, for he wou'd never be brought to any lower conditions. This was a hard Chapter for the Cardinal, who had nothing now to chooe but Peace or War; but one eeming much more eligible than the other, he ign'd the Treaty, telling the Gentleman, that there being everal things in it which requir'd ome time before they cou'd be perform'd; he begg'd the Prince de Conde to deire the Duke of Orleans (whoe Interet was not forgotten) to conceal them from his Lady, becaue the Cardinal de Retis, the Duke de Rohan and Chavigny, who had o great an influence over her, wou'd certainly hear of it, and never ret till they had broke the Treaty.

If the Prince de Conde had follow'd this advice, he had without doubt prevented abundance of michief; but fancying the Cardinal tarted this cruple, only to appear more myterious in his Conduct, he comes publickly with an exces of Joy and Gaity, crying aloud at a good ditance to the Duke of Orleans; We have trapp'd the old Fox at lat, and have got him fat in a Nooe. Here, my Lord, ays he, delivering him the Treaty, is your Demands, and for what concerns me in it, I am very well content. The Duke hewing it to his Lady, he immediately communicates it to the
Cardinal de Rets, the Duke de Rohan and to Chavigny. They all in a urprize come to the Duke of Orleans, and ask him what in the Name of God he deign'd to do, to ign uch an Agreement; telling him, that all the advantage was on the Prince de Conde's ide, who had not only been addret to, to negotiate with, but to whom here were the greatet Conceions made: That he was already poet of Offices enough in the Kingdom, without uffering him thus to ingros all. That his Ambition was inatiate, tho he endeavour'd to palliate it: That the care he took of the Inter • t of his Creatures, p • oceeded not out of any good Nature he had to oblige them, but out of the Neceity which he foreaw, he might one day or other have of their Service: That he himelf was concern'd more than any one, to hinder this increae of the Prince de Conde's power, for after himelf he was next Heir to the Crown: That if he took not ome peedy coure to uppres his greatnes, 'twou'd be oon too late. In hort, That they pray'd him to conider, that on the concluding or breaking off of this Treaty, depended the Properity of the State, the Safety of his own Peron and of the whole Nation.

But it was in other Terms that they poke of this Treaty to the Dutches of Orleans. They repreented to her, that the deign of the Prince of Conde was to poes himelf of the Crown; that in the Reputation he was with the People for his Victories, his Uurpation would be les odious, if not altogether agreeable; that after which, her Husband would certainly be confin'd to a Cloiter, if he were not kept a Prioner all his Life in ome other place; that for her elf, he was not to expect a better fare than to live all her days in a Convent, and it would hardly ecape 'em, but they would dipute the legitimacy
of her Children, becaue her Marriage had never been approv'd of but by force: That the only remedy he had to prevent all thee misfortunes, was to break off the Treaty, while they on their part did all that lay in their power, to diengage the Duke her Husband from a peron he had o much reaon to upect: That he was particularly concern'd to take this care of him, becaue he lov'd her tenderly, of which he had given her ufficient proofs: That they would not pretend to give her Intructions, but if they might urge it without violating their repect to her, they would then ay, that he ought to employ all her Charms to accomplih this deign: That the Bed was the mot proper place to et upon one of her Husbands dipoition; that they had nothing more to ay, but to with her to make ue of it, as they were enible he could do with ucces.

On this occaion thee arguments wrought but too effectually on both of them. They were hardly ever in private together that they had any other dicoure, and the Dutches perceiving her Husband inclinable to receive all the imp • eions, with which he had been prepoet, puht on the affair to that extremity, that the Treaty was broke off, without o much as any tolerable reaon given by the Duke of Orleans. The Prince of Conde than aw his Error in not following the Cardinals advice, but ince 'twas now too late for any remedy, he reolv'd on other meaures, and rais'd new Troops to begin a econd Civil War. The Cardinal having a mind to dipoes him of Montrond, caus'd ome Troops to march that way, every one being in great expectation of what would be the event between the two Parties. They were not long without Skirmihes, and a Collonel of the Prince of Conde's Troops, call'd Concreant being
taken Prioner by the Count de Bougi, who Commanded in Bourges; they were in a dipute how to treat him, whether as a Rebel or as a Prioner of War.
