The Dutches of Longueville, who was in Montrond, fearing let they hould ue him as the latter, writ to the Count de Bougi about it; and having receiv'd an anwer as civil as could be deir'd, it was a very great encouragement to the Officers of both ides to expoe themelves, who before were in no mall apprehenions on that account. However, this was no law to the Cardinal, for he order'd another Officer that was taken to be hang'd; but the Prince erving ome of his in the ame manner, he forbore to ue any more uch Severity.

The Duke of Orleans, for all the jealouy he had entertain'd of the Prince, did not yet eparate from his Interets, to which he was retain'd by many coniderations: he had rais'd ome Troops as well as he, and gave them to the Command of the Duke de Beaufort. I erv • d him in the quality of Aide de Camp all the Campaign, and o contantly attended him, that no body can be better acquainted with all that happen'd to him than my elf. He had been o perecuted by the new Miniter, that the Pariians lookt on him as irreconcileable, and this reemblance of his Sentiments with their own, join'd with ome popular ways, which he had made him o agreeable to them, that they eem'd not content to love him, but omething more, even to adore him. The Fih-Wives above all were thoe that made the mot hew of their kindnes for him. Thee every day were making him Preents, and upon all occaions were the firt to run to get a ight of him in publick. Upon this he was call'd in deriion the King of the Mobb. But all their kindnes was nothing to
that of one of thoe honet Women I am going to tell you of; he comes to him one morning, and brings with her a young Girl of about Seventeen or Eighteen, a weet pretty Creature, and told him that having no more Children in the World, he hould think her elf the happiet body that could be, if his Grace would do her Daughter the honour not only to lye with her, but to get her with Child. The Duke de Beaufort was not like his Father, who was thought to be a greater lover of Men than of Women: So he told her very pleaantly that he was mighty glad to oblige her, and would engage for the one, tho he could not be certain of the other, yet he would do his bet to gratify her in that too; and at the ame time to hew her that he deign'd to be as good as his word, he took and led her Daughter into his Chamber, where after he had lain with her, he ent them both home very well pleas'd with their Entertainment.

This Prince had a Siter married to the Duke de Nemours, a Peron of a thouand good Qualities, with never a bad one. The Prince of Conde having occaions that call'd him into the Province of Guienne, which had declar'd in his Favour, gave the Duke de Nemours the Command of his Troops, with orders to act in Concert with thoe of the Duke de Beaufort. If the Relation of Brothers-in-law could have been ufficient, as one would have thought it hould, to have united two Tempers o vatly different as thee two, then the Prince of Conde did not commit uch a great mitake, to leave 'em together, and go into Guienne: But not foreeeing that his abence would beget a mortal hatred, between thee two Princes, who had been before at variance; he ran the greatet rique
that he ever did in his Life; for hearing on all hands, that their enmity was not only arriv'd to that pitch, that they were ready every moment to cut one anothers Throats, but that all affairs were like to be ruin'd by it; he made a deperate Journey to them from Agen, by his preence to rectify this diorder. The Prince was to pas the Loire, and tho he took all poible care to conceal his departure, by giving out that he was gone to Bourdeaux upon ome pecial occaions, yet the Count de Harcourt, who Commanded the Kings Army on this ide of the River, had notice of it, and preently detach'd a number of mall Parties, to poes themelves of all the Paes both by Land and Water: but he diappointed them, notwithtanding their extream Diligence, for travelling Night and Day, he was gone by, before they could come up to the Paes.

In the mean time, the Marquis de Levi, one of the Prince de Conde's Party, had procur'd of the Count de Harcourt a Paport to retire to his own Houe, peruant to a deign of the Prince's, under the favour of this Paport, to wait on him diguis'd like one of his Retinue. The Marquis tav'd for the Prince till he came at Langres, and from thence they both took the Road of Auvergne, the greatet part of the Marquis's Etate lying thereabouts. While they were there refrehing themelves, the Prince of Conde, who was enible t • e Cardinal had lin'd the River with his Souldiers, ent to Bui Rabutin, who was in la Charite, and obtain'd a promie from him that he would favour his paage; and he was as good as his word, for he drew off the Guard that tood right againt the Ferry of Allier, and the Prince of Conde at the ame time coming up to that place, pas'd over without any manner of oppoition. After this
ecape he made the bet of his way, tho the length of the Journey and the badnes of the Roads had o tir'd their Hores, that they could not make all the hate they deir'd. The King, who was on the ide of Angers, came marching up the Loire; and had ent out Exprees to all places, with orders that they hould apprehend the Prince, and ecure him alive or dead. There was one of thee Scouts came o near him, as to know his Favorite Guitaut, and upecting that the Prince himelf was not far of, inquir'd for him of a Valet de Chambre who tay'd a little behind: If they had had the leat preence of Mind in the World, they would have certainly kill'd that Courtier upon the pot; the Duke de la Rochefaucaut thought of it a moment after, but then the Fellow was gone.

The King, as well as the Cardinal, was inform'd of this Adventure, and immediately detach'd a Party of Hore after him; who taking the Road of Chatillon upon Loin, o cloely peru'd him, that he very narrowly ecap'd falling into their hands: But his good Fortune deliver'd him, and having reach'd Chatillon, he pas'd on to Lori, where his Army than lay. At his arrival there, he found matters infinitely in a wore condition, than what they had been repreented to him. The Dukes of Nemours and Beaufort were at open defiance one with another, for they could not diemble any longer their reentment, after the occaion I am going to tell you of. The Inhabitants of Gergeau, (a Town belonging in Apanage, to the Duke of Orleans) had promis'd the Duke de Nemours to give him notice of the approach of the Kings Army, that o he might have time enough to end them a Garrion. This they did not fail to do, and he accordingly drew out of the Duke of Orleans's Troops five or ix hundred men for that purpoe.
But the Officer that commanded them having receiv'd fale intelligence by the way, that the King had already enter'd the Town, proceeded no further, but came directly back again: Upon which the People of Gergeau ent another Expres, to let them know that if they neglected them in this manner, they hould be oblig'd to open their Gates to the firt that appear'd. Whereupon the ame Troops were remanded thither, but then 'twas too late, and they return'd jut as they had done once before.

The Duke de Nemours was mightily incens'd at this accident, and whether he really did upect ome Treachery in it, or that he was glad of that pretence to vent his Spleen againt the Duke de Beaufort, is uncertain, but he did not tick publickly to accue him of holding Correpondence with the Enemy. The Duke de Beaufort gave him the Lye, and had not the whole Army interpos'd to perwade the Duke of Nemours to upend his reentment, there would have follow'd ome trange diorder upon it. A few days after this had happen'd the Prince de Conde arriv'd, who preently undertook to mediate an Accommodation, but the Duke de Nemours, would by no means hearken to it; yet out of his repect to the Prince, and the Interet of their affairs which would not permit him to attempt any thing at that time, he was content to contrain himelf (he aid) but that afterwards, all the World hould not hinder him when he aw his convenient time. The matter being thus made up for the preent, or rather deferr'd, he march'd againt the Kings Army, commanded by the Vicount de Turenne and the Marechal de Hoequincourt, who took their Quarter eparate one from the other; but the Marechal lying more expos'd, he attackt him, and took four of his
men Prioners, before the ret could be brought to their Arms. The Marechal lot all his Cavalry in this Encounter; and if his Infantry had not av'd themelves by flying at the very beginning, he could not have been more intirely routed. The Vicount de Turenne provided a little better for his ecurity, for poeing himelf of a coniderable Pot, he not only made head againt the victorious Troops of the Prince of Conde, but put them to a tand; and afterwards Night coming on, retir'd to Gien.

One of the Prince of Conde's Gentlemen happen'd to be taken Prioner ome time before this, and it being publickly known that this Marechal was reflected on at Court upon the account of the late Action, the micarriage of which they attributed to his neglect; the Prince found a way to let him know, that if he would engage in his Interets, he hould meet with more gratitude from him. Hocquincourt, who was acquainted of this by ome of his Friends, askt this Gentleman of the Prince's, what advantage it was that he might expect from his Mater, and he engag'd to procure him a hundred thouand Crowns, provided he brought over with him ome of thoe Troops which were at his Command. Hocquincourt joyn'd with the Propoal, and told the Gentleman, that if the Prince of Conde had Money enough to purchae them, there was the Count de Grandpre and two or three German Collonels more at his Service. And indeed they all gave him their words, but the Prince had not a Fund ufficient to do it, and o the buines dropt; which if it had taken effect, would have been of the lat conequence to the Party.

The Prince of Conde, after o glorious an Action, was reolv'd to take a turn to Paris, where he was
receiv'd with an univeral applaue. But the Ladies were thoe that expret the mot eteem for him, ome of them being o forward as to wih they might prove, whether he could acquit himelf as well in an Amorous Engagement, as he had done in the late Battel. Mada ••
Pie, Siter to Concreaut whom I have mention'd, was one of thee longing Ladies: She writ to him, to tell him, that he had ome affairs with him, of that importance that he durt not confide 'em to any, but begg'd that he would give himelf the trouble to let her ee him, and he hould then judge if they were not of conequence. The Letter was writ in terms too preing to admit of any excue; o he waited on her; when intead of ome mighty matter in relation to the State, which he expected, he made him a Confeion of her weaknes, but begg'd him to make ue of it like a Gentleman, and a Man of Honor. The good Prince was toucht with com • aion, and prepar'd intantly to give her the mot enible proof; of it; but being at that time in her Cloet, where unfortunately there was no Bed, he was put to his thifts, yet by taking the Cuhions and placing them one upon another, he did his bet to ob • ige her. I came to Paris the very ame day of this Adventure and having a Letter for him from the D. de Beaufort, I found him at his own Houe, the Hotel de Conde, he would needs make me tay Supper; and while we were at Table, who hould come in but Concreaut: He told Concreaut what a rare Adventure he had had that a certain very fine Lady, tho omething of the tallet and bigget ize, had ent that morning to deire to peak with him; that waiting on her accordingly, he pat thro Apartments very tately furnih'd to her Cloet, which was very rich and magnificent, and hung all round with Looking-glaes;
that the Lady refus'd him nothing, and that in hort, he was extreamly well pleas'd with the Adventure, but for one thing. Concreaut askt him what that could be. He aid, it was becaue he had found all the parts of that Lady's body to bear an exact proportion with her Shapes, and by that bid him gues if he could, who it was. There needed no more to make Concreaut jealous of the truth, nor indeed he did not tick to ay, he believ'd it was his Siter; but was the firt of the Company that fell a laughing, and o prevented the raillery of the ret, who were prepar'd to fall on him. For all that, the Prince, for fear we hould not believe it, and to put it out of all manner of doubt, drew the Letter out of his Pocket, and hew'd it to every one that had had the curioity to ee it.

The Prince of Conde was then in the Vigor of his Youth, and had a great many little fellows about him that were call'd Maters: Thee were mot of them lewd and debauch'd, and led him into abundance of Extravagancies, which not only ruin'd his Health, but his Affairs. For ome time after this, that the Duke of Lorrain had enter'd France, and that the Vicount de Turenne was inclos'd between his Troops, thoe of the Princes, and thoe of the Duke of Wittenberg, the Court Party being in that ditres, that they knew not which way to turn themelves, if their Army was routed, at that juncture. I ay, the Prince of Conde was retain'd at Paris, by a ditemper which it is not decency to mention, but which had nothing of a Fever in it, but the name; by which means he lot his Advantage, and could not dicover the Intelligence which was held between the Court and the Duke of Lorrain; for that Duke having receiv'd a coniderable Sum
of Money on that account, uffer'd the Vicount de Turenne to retire to Melun, which had been impoible for him to do, if the Prince of Conde had been with his Army.

Tho the War eem'd to be carry'd on by both Parties with great vigour, yet there were everal Treaties et on foot, and manag'd under-hand. I was twice or thrice at St. Germains upon uch an account, from the Duke of Beaufort, whom Mazarin had offer'd to make Admiral of France, and to pay him down two hundred thouand Crowns, if he wou'd leave the Princes party, and bring over with him the Duke of Orleans, on whom it was known, that he had a great Influence. My Fortune was to be made effectually too, and I was to have a Company in the Guards for my pains in this affair; the Duke was willing enough to accept of the propoals, and was not wanting in his endeavours on his part, but all our meaures were broke by the means of Madomoielle de Mompenier, who being tark mad to be marry'd, the Prince of Conde had amus'd with the hopes of having his Son, the Duke d' Enguien.

The Army lying jut at the Gates of Paris, we were every day in the City, and there I met with my Siter, who to avoid the effects of the publick diturbances, had left her Convent and was come to Paris. I was urpriz'd to ee he had quitted the Religious Habit, but was much more o, to undertand that he was return'd to her Husband. She, it eems, had met with him when he leat of all expected it, and as true Love is encreas'd by abence, he no ooner aw her, but was tempted to forget the Obligation he lay under by the holy Orders, he had too rahly taken; nor was he behind hand with him, but laid
aide all her thoughts of Devotion. What happen'd on this was omething extraordinary: She, who in five or ix years that they had liv'd together before, had never been with Child, was become in a few months as big as he could tumble. I expret my urprize at thee proceedings, but all the atisfaction I could get from her was this, that he was bound to obey her Husband, and being join'd together by the Holy Sacrament of Marriage, were to be eparated by nothing but Death.

To relate this Affair, which made a great noie in Paris, without breaking off the thread of my dicoure, I mut tell you that my Siter was brought to bed of a Son, in her due time, and that they liv'd together three or four years after, at the end of which my Brother in-law dy'd. My Siter going to enter on the Etate, which was very coniderable, met with oppoition from his Relations, who us'd this as a pretence, that her Son was Illegitimate. Upon which a great Law Suit was commenc'd, which the pretended Heirs had a mind to carry to be try'd in Bretagne, becaue ome part of the Etate lay there; but they having caus'd the Goods which were at Paris to be eiz'd, and the Contract of Marriage being made there, thee two things brought them within the Juridiction of the Jutice of the place; beides that, it olely belongs to the Parliament of Paris to take cognizance of all things relating to the Validity of Marriages.

The pretended Heirs being now oblig'd to come to a Trial here, committed their Caue to one of the ablet Councel to manage, and he in his Plea forgot nothing that the mot artificial Rhetorick could urge, when it intends mot to perwade. He exaggerated what a Reflection it would be on Religion, to tolerate uch an abue as this, which was the very way to authorize what the Hugonots
maintain, that 'tis lawful for a Priet to marry; that not only the Child ought to be declar'd illegitimate, but the Mother ought to be puniht for o black a crime, o h • rrid a Sacrilege: That nothing had forc'd the marry'd Couple to a Separation; but when once they had done o, to devote themelves to God, it was a Vow of that nature, from which none but the Pope himelf could dipence 'em: That the preent Cae was till different; here was a Man who had not imply promis'd to devote himelf to God, but one who was conecrated by all that is mot Holy in Religion: In a word, a Priet, one who had a thouand times offer'd the Sacrifice, by which we all hope for Salvation: One who had receiv'd an infinite Number of Souls to the Sacrament of Pennance; had given the Communion, and in hort, who had done all that o ublime and acred a Character could intitle him to do: That it ought to be conider'd what would be the conequences of allowing uch a Sacrilege; how many Confeions, and how many Sacraments would be render'd ineffectual, and conequently how many Souls eternally damn'd.

'Twould be too tedious to recite all his Plea at length, in which he was not paring of Invectives againt my Siter, who being preent, could not hear them without an extreme Confuion. At lat her Councel began to peak, upon which every one was ilent, and he aid, That he could not but admire, an Action hould be repreented o foul and criminal, which was only a Slip of Weaknes, or Humane Frailty: That he did not conceive the fault lay o much in his Clients living with her Huband after a Separation of 5 or 6 years, as in the uffering him in a foolih fit of zeal to turn Priet. That God had exprely forbid to eparate thoe who were thus join'd, how then could they uffer
one, who had worn Fidelity to his Wie, to violate an Oath he had taken in the Face of the Church? and Marriage being a Sacrament, the other Sacrament, which was ubequent, could not diolve the firt; That the Child had nothing to do with the Indicretions of his Father; that his Legitimacy was confirm'd by his Fathers Contract with his Mother, and by the Marriage Benediction he receiv'd. In hort, if the Parliament, as they had often, in uncertain Caes, adjudg'd the jut Intention of a Marriage ufficient to legitimate the Children; how much more reaon had he to hope for the ame Jutice, in a Caue where the Honour of the Mother was o far from being call'd in quetion, that it was never o much as upected.

The Judges were a long time in upence, during which 'tis no hard matter to imagine mine and my Siters Fears. I was but jut come in, as the lat man had done his Plea. The People that tood by, but did not know me, told me the ubtance of the other Councels Plea, and ome of them were o prejudic'd by his reaons, as to tell us our Detiny; but we were happy, that they were not our Judges. They were mitaken in their opinion, as it prov'd, for we unanimouly carry'd our Caue, and our Adveraries were condemn'd to all the Cots & Charges of the Suit.

This Affair however was the occaion that ome time after, Monieur de Villemontee, being nominated to the Bihoprick of St. Malo, was refus'd his Bulls, becaue he was parted from his Wife; but on another account than that of my Brother. The truth of which was, he had dicover'd ome Intrigues of hers, when he was Intendant of Jutice, and Mater of the Requets; and that with the diappointment put him o out of conceit with the World, that after he had made her retire to a Convent, he gave himelf wholly up to Devotion.

This buines of my Siter's having caus'd me to make ome digreion, 'twill be convenient now to return, and reume my dicoure of thoe matters I was upon before. The Prince of Conde having broken off the Treaty (I mention'd formerly) purely by his own fault, was reolv'd to puh things to the extremity, rather than not compas what he drove at. The other Princes were no les forward, and met every day at Luxemburg, to conult how they might oblige the Queen to relinquih the Cardinal, and to give them a larger h •• e in the government of affairs, which was the caue of all their dicontent. In the me • n time, the Dukes of Beaufort and Nemours, were everal times ready to quarrel about precedency; which the Duke of Orleans and Prince of Conde being willing to prevent, a • judg'd the firt place to him, who came firt to the Council. The Duke of Beaufort complain'd of this regulation; the Batards of France having this Previledge in the Kingdom, to take place of all Foreign Princes; but he was anwer'd that it could not be recall'd, and all his redres would be now, to contrain himelf a little to come omething the ooner. And he did not fail to do o, inomuch that 'twas taken notice of, and aid, that he tood Centinel there every day, to watch till the door hould be open'd.

At length, after they had fully reolv'd the ruine of the Cardinal, and the means to accomplih it, the Prince of Conde, left Paris to go to the aitance of his Tro • ps, which were in no mall apprehenions of thoe of the King, exceeding them much in number. His Preence, with ome other precautions he us'd, made the Count de Mi • ens, who was advanc'd on the ide of St. Cloud, to retire, but not content with that, he turn'd his Forces againt St Denis; in which there was a Royal Garrion. The place being of no trength was eaily carry'd, and for the ame reaon
could not be kept for any time. The Prince, who had experienc'd what kind of Souldiers the Pariians were, when he had to do with them near Charen • on, found them not more brave now they fought for him, for they deerted him before St. Denis, and if he had not had thoe who tood by him, he had been baffl • d before a little paltry Town.

The Prince of Conde was come back to Paris, but in a few days return'd to his Army, perceiving the Kings had taken the Field, on purpoe to dilodge his, which by the means of the Bridge of St. Cloud, was often cover'd by the river of Scine, o as to avoid coming to a Battle. He found the Enemy had made a Bridge of Boats ready on the ide of St. Denis, to pas over part of their Army, while the other marcht on this ide of the River. Being therefore afraid to be inclos'd, he decamp'd, and intended to retire between Charenton and Ville neuve St. Georges, where he hop'd the rivers of Marne and Scine would erve him for a good Re • renchment. The Vicount de Turenne, whom he had to deal with, pe • etrating into his deign, fell upon him from the riing grounds of the Fauxbourg St. Martin, and furiouly charg'd his Rear: The Prince eeing himelf o hotly pret, and depairing of gaining the Bridge of Charenton, which he could not pas neither without defiling, reolv'd to fight, ince he was forc'd to it, and commanded his Van-guard to halt. They were come up as far as the Entrance of the Fauxbourg St. Antoine, where he found everal Retrenchments, the Pariians had cat up, to cover themelves from the Spoil of the Duke of Lorrain, who had ravag'd the Countries all thereabouts. The Prince, as he had the greatet knowledge in Military Affairs of any man in his Age, immediately concluded, that nothing could have happen'd more advantageous, than what Fortune herelf here offer'd him; o he drew his Troops into
thee Retrenchments, and lodg'd them as fat as they came up.

The Kings Army was tronger by half than the Princes; but the Marechal de la Ferte who commanded a part of 'em, being till on the other ide of the Seine, their Forces were pretty equal. The King, who did not imagine that the Prince of Conde could ecape him, poted himelf on the riing grounds about Menilmontunt, from whence being out of danger, he might ee all that pat. He propos'd two advantages to himelf in doing this, one was, by his preence to animate the Souldiers; and the other, that it would hinder the City of Paris from giving the Prince a retreat. And indeed it had this effect, that they did refue to let his Baggage come in, which was for • 't to be left upon the Bulwark.

The Marechal de la Ferte hearing the Vicount de Turenne was going to engage the Prince, made all the hate • e could to repas the Seine; but that was a thing not to be done in a moment, o the Battel begun without him. The Vicount de Turenne advancing to the entrance of the Fauxbourg made a vigorous attack upon it, while at the ame time he ent ome of his Troops, to my to enter ome other part of the City.

I had not been in very many actions, o I could not ay this was hotter than uual, but I heard everal old Officers ay 'twas, and I know very well, ome Squadrons charg'd five times; and tho they had been often broke to pieces, yet they rally'd again as often; here was abundance of men kill'd and wounded, and the Duke de la Rochefaucaut was among the latter; he receiv'd a hurt under his Eye, by which he lot his ight for the preent, but he has recover'd it again ince; they carry'd him into Paris, which Madamoielle oblig'd at lat to declare it elf and thro which the Prince de Conde marcht his Army. The Duke de la Rouchefaucaut, thinking his Wound had been mortal, ent for a Priet to be confet, who told him 'twas to no purpoe,
unles he would count this for one crime, his taking up Arms againt his King, and would promie never to continue in it. 'Twould have been very well if all the Confeors would have acquitted themelves as this fellow did, the diorders would oon have been ended; but they were not all o honet: And the Cardinal de R • tz, who ought to have been an example to others as a Cardinal, and Archbihop of Paris, was o far from that, that he was one of the firt in the Revolt.

It pleas'd God to preerve me in this action, tho I fought in a Tro • p of which above half were kill'd upon the place; but eeing the Duke de Beaufort behave himelf, as I have noted, it very much leen'd my eteem for him, and I reolv'd to leave him; which I did, three days before he fought the Duel with the Duke de Nemours, in which the latter was kill'd. If the Prince of Conde had thought it worth his while he might have prevented this misfortune; but he was not orry that he was thus rid of this Prince, who was his Rival in the Dutches de Chatillon, and as he thought, better receiv'd there than himelf; o that when they told him he was kill'd, he hardly behav'd himelf decently; for hutting himelf up with his Favourites, he gave himelf uch a liberty, that he was heard to laugh o loud, that the People could not but take notice of it.

When I left Monieur de Beaufort, I reolv'd to have no more Maters but the King, that is to erve in the Army, if he would entertain me; and the conj • ncture of aff • irs was uch, that I did not find it o difficult a thing as formerly. I got a Troop of Hore, and orders to wait on the Cardinal; he askt me aoon as ever he aw me, if he might trut me, and anwering him readily, that he needed not to doubt me in the leat, he ent me to Bourdeaux to endeavour to bring over the Prince of Conti from his Brothers Party. I addret my elf to Sarain, the ame whoe Works
have been publiht ince his Death; and Sarain having caution'd me to take care of being dicover'd by the Count de Marin, or by any other Creatures of the Prince de Conde, he gave ear to my Propoitions, which were more advantageous to himelf than to his Mater; for they promis'd him 20000 Crowns ready Money, whereas they offer'd the Prince nothing but a Wife with ome Penions from the Court: Nevertheles his own condition not pleaing him, he was willing enough to change it, and agreed with me to marry Madamoielle Martinoti, the Cardinals Niece. To conceal my elf the better in the Town, I took the Habit of a Francican, being order'd to confer with one Father Faure at the Convent of the Cordeliers, who was one of the Cardinals Friends, being truted with a ecret of no les value than the reducing the City of Bourdeaux to obedience; which he was to do by fomenting certain diviions reigning among the Chief of the Town. He was a famous Preacher, which made him very much repected every where; beides tha • , he was Confeor to the principal Families in the City, o that employing both his talents to bring to pas his deigns, he had the eaier ucces; for which ervice he was preferr'd to the Bihoprick of Amiens, which he enjoys at this time.

The Prince de Conti according to our Treaty dee •• ed his Party, and came to Court, where the Cardinal receiv'd him with great repect, and being marry'd a few days after in the Kings Cloet at Fontainblea • , he very nobly jointur'd his Lady in a Clap. He reign'd all his Benefices to the Cardinal, under the name of one Montreuil, and his Eminence, who made no cruple of the Symony, gave him intead thereof a very large Penion: As for Sarain, they laught at him when the buines was done, and intead of the 20000 Crowns they promis'd him, they put him off with a mall Benefice; he curt and torm'd at the Ingratitude of Mazarin; but
he needed not to have been o concern'd for the reward, having but a hort while to enjoy it. The Prince of Con • i vext to ee himelf lighted by all the Gentry, on account of his Marriage, and enrag'd at a Letter ent him by the Prince of Conde, who abus'd him, both in word and action, he o laid it to heart, that he dy'd in a few days after.

The Cardinal behav'd himelf very well to me after this ucces, but not like my old Mater Cardinal Richelieu, their maxims being far different; this carry'd it civilly to none but his own friends, and that behav'd it alike to all. I went then into the Army which was in Flanders, were we made ome Conquets, which had been greater, but for the diviion that happen'd between the Vicount de Turenne, and the Marechal de Ferte. I erv'd under the latter of thee, who took uch an affection to me, that he could carce live without me. My fortune cating me upon him as it were, I thought my elf oblig'd to how him more repect than the other, tho my eteem was not equal for them both. He was mightily pleas'd to ee me o enible, and this
<> that confidence in me, that he told me all his affairs, even to the private concerns of his Family, and th • rein of the diatisfaction that he had with his firt Wife; when I aw him o hearty, I begg'd him not to think me rude, if I askt him the reaon of it; he told me he would freely inform me for ince the • e • t was dead (thoe were his words) he was not n • w c •• cern'd at her Extravagancies; whereupon he • old me, how he marry'd her againt her inclination, and being d • irous to win her to his humour, he told he • the firt day of their Marriage that if he did not think fit to • i • e as he pleas'd, he mut expect to lead but an uneaie life; that he hould quit all her old Acquaint • nce, and make no new ones; but above all, hould hold no correpondence with any of thoe people whom he had ever any
thoughts of marrying; that he anwer'd very honetly, that he had no deires but to obey him, but he quickly dicover'd the contrary, and • ound her a Jilt in the highet degree, and in a word was oblig'd to dipatch both her and her Gallant a little before their time.

I was extremely urpriz'd at this great Ingenuity, epecially in a man that was not accounted to have over-much; nor indeed did I undertand the d • ift of the matter, which was to inform me downright he was jealous; and that if any was o venturous as to attempt upon the Lady he had now marry'd, there was nothing o deperate but he durt undertake againt them. Now he knew I was very intimate with a certain peron that us'd to viit her very often in his abence, and 'twas reported it was on uch an account; when I undertood what he meant, I took no notice at all, as if I knew nothing, and tho he often run over the ame Chapter, I always turn'd the deaf ear, till at lat he was forc'd to explain himelf, and told me, that he took me to be o much his Friend, that I would keep a ecret; that his Wife kept company with a peron he did not like, who it eems was of my acquaintance; that I hould give him a caution of it, and that 'twas dangerous to give but an umbrage to uch a man as he; that a Letter might micarry, and therefore he choe to have me go my elf; that I hould alo go to his Wife, and tell her as much; and if he took it unkindly • e upected her, I hould tell her that he took it more unkindly he hould give him caue.

It was trange methought that I hould be the peron pick'd out for o great a confidence, and I could not forbear telling him o; to which he return'd, that he had known me a long time, and was not ignorant of the many important affairs I had manag'd for Cardinal Richelieu, and therefore concluded I was fit to
keep a ecret, and he hop'd I would do it for him, and promis'd in requital to ue his interet to get me a Regiment, which he thought the Cardinal would not refue him.

My fate threw me always upon uch Negotiations as thee, and I was forc'd to obey it, o I came to Paris; where I aw my friend, who told me the Marechal was mad; that he had een his Wife indeed, but 'twas as he aw all the ret of the Sex, without any other deign than to pas away the time, and if her Husband would return him all the Money he had lot at play to her, he would go to a Notary, and bind himelf never to come near her any more, but till he had his revenge, he would not promie him. I thought this anwer very weak, and made only to put me off; I told him I wondred he would deal in this manner with a friend; I knew nothing of his Intreague, being never curious to inform my elf of things that did not concern me, but that this buines mut have made ome noie, becaue it had • e • cht the Husbands Ears, who always is the lat inform'd of uch things as thoe; that ometimes indeed 'twas not o great a misfortune, all Husbands being not of a humour to publih their infamy, but if I was not mitaken, the Marechal was none of them; for I had heard ay, that he kill'd his firt Lady upon a bare upicion. I pray'd him to conider what I told him, that he had to do with a violent paionate man, and one beides who was in great favour at Court; that I meant by this, he was able to oppres him without any relief on his part, of which I could how him daily examples; therefore I begg'd him not to tell me, that they coul • n • t • at out a Gentleman and go unpuniht; that it mig • t be true when we had to do with a man of our own quality, but when we talkt of a Marechal of France, there's no having atisfaction of him, unles y • u will downright aainate him.

He heard me quite out with a great deal of patience, and then return'd, I thought, aid he, that you had been one of my Friends, and I am very orry to find my elf deceiv'd. Suppoe I had lov'd Madam de la Ferte, I made no quetion but you would have been the readiet man in the world to have aited me; for you know 'tis a thing that we always undertake freely for one another, but 'tis enough, that you give me the ame liberty you take your elf: However I'll tell you one thing as a Friend, that Monieur the Marechal is jealous without caue; I have had no concern with his Wife, but at Play, and I will have one opportunity more to recover my Money again, and will come no more at her as long as I live.

I aw however there was more Intrigue in this than he would have known, but I reckon'd I had dicharg'd my elf as a Friend, o I went to dicoure with Madam La Ferte, who knew me well enough, but not o well as to imagin I was truted with uch an Errand; for when he undertood it he was mightily concern'd: She told me he was not much urpriz'd at the proceedings of the Marechal, that he went to pick a quarrel with her that he might have a pretence to make her away as he had done his other Wife, but he had ome Friends would revenge it if he did; that if he had given him any occaion to do thus, why had he not told her of it, for he had not aid a word to her of any uch thing; that it was no trange thing to ee a Husband jealous, who had a wanton goiping Cocquette to his Wife; that as for her, all the world knew he never tirr'd abroad, and excepting at play, kept no Company at all; why hould he accue her then of Crimes which were not to be manag'd without much intriguing and aignations afore hand.

She would have talkt all day I believe, if I had not interrupted her; but finding there would be no end of it, I topt her, by telling her that I was not intructed to receive her Jutifications; that as for me
I was perwaded he had more Prudence, but that was not enough, if her Husband was not o; that the way to atisfy him fully, was to avoid the company of the man whom he upected; and ince he did not ee him, except at play, as he aid, he needed not matter it, there being a great many in Paris he might play with as well as with him, and that being done, I did not doubt but her Husband would do her jutice to acknowledge her vertue as well as I; that this was only his nice humour, which was for preventing any candal, tho in the great pot he was, Malice it elf could faten nothing on his conduct; yet if he hould give occaion for it to work on hers, it would be full as bad.

She anwer'd me, I might turn things as I pleas'd, but he mut judge as he aw, that her Husband was a Brute and a jealous-pated Man, that he hould be always unhappy with him, but ince it was her mifortune to be o, I might tell him, he would obey his arbitrary will and would ee the peron no more, there was all this ado about; and if he would too, he would hide her elf from all perons that came to the Houe, even from her own Servants, for one was as reaonable as the other. Thee words did ufficiently demontrate her concern, however as it was not my buines to take any notice of it. I took my leave of her, but with o mean an opinion of her vertue, that I very much doubted he would not keep her word. In the mean time to put a top to this, and to avoid any further upicion, he broke off the Meetings for Play which us'd to be at her houe, and kept in everal days without being een; but having privately entertain'd the peron I mention'd, he made her elf amends for the Pennance he had undergone.

The Marechal being inform'd of this, by Spies which he kept always about her, and reolving to punih both her and her Gallant, he ent three Dragoons of his Regiment to Paris, with order to aainate the
one, and to poion the other; the firt of thee was eaier to be done than the econd: My Friend coming home one night very late from Play, at the Marechal d Estrees, was et upon and kill'd in a moment; the Dragoons would have made their ecape, had not one of them fell into the Common Shore near the Ru • St. Louis; o they took him and clapt him up into Prion, and made him pay for the other; they put him to the torture to make him dicover his Accomplices, and by whom they were et on work to do uch a fact; and • e having dicover'd all that he knew, the Lieutenant Criminel Tardieu went to carry the informations to the Cardinal, and askt him what he pleas'd hould be done with them. Mazarin, who was oblig'd to the Marechal, order'd him to uppres them, and to caue the Dragoon to be trangled in Prion, which was done accordingly. But the Cardinal being afraid, that Madam la Ferte hould fare after the ame manner, he ent her word privately to take care of her elf, and to endeavour to regain the good opinion of her Husband; he had been very much diturb'd at the misfortune of her Gallant, but this Compliment made her very erious. She fled to the Queen Mother for protection, and feigning her elf religious, he began to attend her to her Devotions. The Marechal finding uch an alteration in her at his return, took it very well, and believ'd all the reports he had of her to be candals and fal •• ies; and having been a long time from her, he receiv'd her more like a Mitres than a Wife. However he would not put up all this o eaily, but would have it examin'd into, which prov'd o much to her advantage, that her Husband himelf askt her pardon for his upicion.

All this while the War continu'd, but the heart of France was free from it, and the Prince de Conde after all his great deigns, was oblig'd to retire into Flanders,
and take Sanctuary among the Spaniards; abundance of People of Quality follow'd him, and neither regarded their Fortune nor their Families to tetify their aff •••• on to him: One of whom fell into the hands of the C • urt Party, and there being a dicoure as if they would behead him, the Prince de Conde, who had taken Lancon of their ide, ent word, that he hould have the ame uage that they gave to the other; • eve • the • es for the repect he had for him, he permitted him to end to the Cardinal, to acquaint him of the danger he was in, and to ollicit him to take care of him. This offer was of too great conequence to Lancon to neglect it, o he ent an Expres immediately to Cardinal Mazarin, but he being reolv'd the other hould dye, ent him word, that he mut think of making his Ecape: inomuch that eeing this was no jeting matter, he threw himelf out of a Window three tories high; and tho he was very much bruis'd, and quite crippled with his Fall, yet fear gave him Leg • , and he got off clear.

I was g • ne to Paris to remind the Marechal de la F • rte
• f the promie he had made me, to help me to a Regiment which he till aur'd me of, and made as if he went about it; but the Cardinal told me that this would open the mouths of all the World, and that he had rather give me Money out of his Pocket, and that I mut have patience. I knew there was no great heed to be given to his promies, o I concluded my buines was at an end; but I did not perceive it was a trick of the Marechal's, nor did I know it till above two years afterwards: and indeed, the Cardinal having a buines for me to do, which I am going to mention, told it me himelf; however, as I was even with him, and had no caue to complain, I never troubl'd my head with it. As luck would have it, I fell
in with the Count d' Harcourt, a younger Brother of the preent Duke d' Elbeuf; and being gotten drunk together one day, 'twas reolv'd we hould go and Rob upon the Pont Neuf, a diverion the Duke of Orleans had brought in fahion much about that time: It was in vain for me to oppoe going, all the Company being et upon the frolick, o I was forc'd to go in pight of my teeth: The Chevalier de Rieux, younger Brother to the Marquis de Sourdeac, who was on my ide, was no ooner come to the Pont Neuf, but he whiper'd me, that to avoid being concern'd with the ret, we would get up upon the The Statue of Hen. IV. on the Pont Neuf in bras. Statue of the Hore that tood there, and there we hould ee all that happen'd and be afe our elves; 'twas no ooner aid than done; we made ue of the reins of the Bridle to mount upon the Hores neck, and there we both of us ate very pleaantly: The ret fell to their work, and had preently whiskt off four or five Cloaks; when one of thoe that had been thus erv'd having been to complain, the Officers came and our Sparks finding themelves too weak to encounter with them, camper'd away as fat as they could; we would have done the like, but the reins of the hore catching Monieur de Rieux by the legs, threw him down upon the Pavement,, while I tood pearcht like a •
Owl The Officers had no need of a dark Lanthor •
to dicover us, for Monieur de Rieux, who had hur ••
himelf in his fall, cried out as if he had been going to give up the Ghot; and they coming in at th •
noie, helpt me down againt my will, and carried u •
both to Chatelet. As it is impoible, but that eve ••
one has ome Enemies, ome people took a grea •
deal of pleaure to make their reflections on this adventure;
and Cardinal Mazarin who now had the Soveraign Authority, hearing a great many fale reports of this Action, order'd us to be proecuted with the utmot vigour: o we were examin'd, and that as trictly as if we had been the wort of Malefactors, and I epecially, having had ome words formerly with him that was now our Judge, who fancy'd that I did him an ill Office once with Cardinal de Richlieu. If I had been concious of any guilt, I would without doubt have excepted againt him, as a Party prejudic'd againt me; but knowing my elf clear, I made no cruple of being examind by him, which he was very glad of, thinking now he hould have an opportunity to be even with me: In hort, I perceiv'd that the Clerk, who held correpondence with him, and took my Examination, wrote a great deal more down than I poke, which made me diatisfied with his reading it, o I wou'd not ign it till I had read it my elf; but he told me that was not their cutom, and they would not make a new Law for me. But this made me upect them the more, inomuch that telling them plainly that I would not ign it then, he not only gave me a great deal of ill Language, but committed me to the Dungeon. O God! What a paion was I in, to ee my elf us'd like a Highway-man or a Murtherer for a bare frolick, with no hopes of getting out, and kept o cloe that I could have no Friend admitted to me, nor no body to peak a word to, but the Keepers: I begg'd one of them to convey a Letter for me to a Friend, and to help me to a Pen and Ink to write it, and promis'd him to do him more kindnes than it came to, when I hould get out of Prion; but he was o far from being toucht with my entreaties, that he gave me very
ill Language, enough to have madded a very patient Man. The Chevalier de Rieux far'd not a jot better than I; and being both accus'd of the ame Crime, the Lieutenant Criminel was oblig'd to treat him exactly in the ame manner, let he hould be thought to proecute me, upon a private Picque. The Chevalier was a very lewd peron, and little better than his Brother (who we have known to be a notorious Debauchee) and had like him, the guilt of very many and great Crimes upon him, which now reflecting on a little eriouly, he thought this a judgment on him for his wicked coures; and as Mariners in ditres make vows for their deliverance, o he made olemn promies to reform, if ever he got out of this unhappy buines; but he oon forgot them all when God had heard his Prayers, and intead of reclaiming, grew more vicious than before; till he wated his Etate and left himelf not a bit of bread, and then put himelf into a Monatery, that he might not tarve for want: But this life not agreeing with his inclination, he quitted his Caock, and little Band, and took another turn abroad; when having try'd his Fortune all the ways he could think of, he turn'd Eccleiatick a econd time, more to avoid Humane Jutice, which he was in danger of, than Divine; and taking Orders, is now a Curate in Normandy, where he behaves himelf no better than he did at Paris.

But to return to my own cae. The Cardinal being ollicited every day to make an example of ome body or other, for the terror of thoe that practic'd this way of robbing in the Streets, which indeed was abolutely neceary, to top the inolences contantly committed in the Street, o that 'twas not afe going abroad in the Night, he commanded
the Lieutenant Criminel to bring him the informations; and having een ours, in the manner the Judge had been pleas'd to draw it, he order'd them to proceed againt us. This Order was too publick not to be known at Court, and the Chevalier de Rieux being related to almot all the People of Quality, he made no quetion but they would intercede for him, for fear of uffering a blot upon the Family, which they did; and applying to the Lieutenant Criminel, he told them he hould be very glad to erve them, provided it might be done without my receiving part in the favour; that our Crimes were the ame, but if they who we had aid were with us, would ubmit to be examin'd, which had not yet been done becaue of their Quality, and would tetify that 'twas I that prompted them not only to go on the Pont Neuf, but alo to do all thoe ill things we were accus'd of. Thee were the conditions, and uch did thee Gentlemen accept of; and having propos'd it to the others, they found them very willing; o they purchas'd their own liberty with my ruine, and I was charg'd with a thouand things that I never o much as dreamt of; o I was as it were a Victim deliver'd up to the malice of the Lieutenant Criminel; and had doubtles been acrific'd, had not God ent me deliverance by a way which I leat expected. There came one day into my D • ngeon one of the Keepers Wives, with her Huband, and this woman mov'd with my ditrees, lookt on me, as I could eaily dicern, with a more compaionate Eye than uual: he durt not however peak a word to me while her Husband was by, but coming again a econd time, he took an opportunity to how me, that he had a Letter for me, which I hould take o as her Husband might
not perceive it; but this was impoible to do, this man kept his Eye o continually upon me, which oblig'd the woman to make as if he was looking upon my Straw-bed, and turning it up, he threw the Letter directly into it, where I found it when he was gone: The Contents was, that he perceiv'd the Lieutenant Criminel acted againt me with a Paion, more like an Accuer than a Judge, which had mov'd her compaion; that I was a lot Man, if I did not get ome peron of very great Interet to tand up for me; that he would endeavour to bring me a Pen, Ink, and Paper; that I might write to my Friends, and he would take care to convey it for me.

This was very eaonable for me, my Perecutor being ready to confront me with his Witnees, and waiting immediately upon that to give Sentence upon me, which would alo have oon been confirm'd by the Parliament. Beides, they had made new informations, and whereas in the former, the Officers depos'd that they found me upon the Brazen Hore, they depoed now, that they took me in the fact, Robbing on the Pont Neuf, and catcht me as I was endeavouring to make my ecape. The Keepers Wife was as good as her word, and made ue of the ame device to convey me the Pen and Ink he had promis'd me, as he had to leave me the Letter; o that having wherewith to do it, I wrote two Letters, one to Cardinal Mazarin, the other to Mouieur de Marillac, Son to him that was Keeper of the Seal; I directed both of them to him, and the Keepers Wife having deliver'd them to him, he told her, he wonder'd what I meant; that while I was in favour, his Family, whatever occaion they had of me, never heard from me, but as
oon as I was in Affliction I had recoure to them; however, he would not fail to do me all the ervice he could, and would have done it before if he had known my neceity. This being reported to me by the honet woman, I confet in my mind it was an anwer very true and very generous, for I had given him no caue to have any thoughts of me to my advantage, for they knew nothing, how earnet I was with Cardinal Richlie • , to be excus'd in the cae of the Marechal his Uncle; on the contrary, they very well remembred, that 'twas I that carry'd the Order to have him apprehended; for all which, he delay'd not a moment, but that very day preented a Petition in my name to the Parliament; by which he declar'd that the Lieutenant Criminel was my mortal Enemy, for the reaons I have already given, and as I had intructed him in my Letter, acted againt me with o much private pleen, that he had uppres'd the firt Information to make new ones; and not only o, but had himelf uborn'd Witnees againt me, and the Chevalier de Rieux among the ret, and that he had uppret my Petition to recriminate upon him, not letting it be brought before them that would have done me Jutice, and that without a kind of miracle, I had never had opportunity to preent this Petition; and in hort, that I was o innocent of the Crimes laid to my charge, that tho I was indeed in uch Company as forc' • me againt my Inclination to go, yet I was eparated from them, and not at all concern'd in what they did.

The Credit of Monieur de Marillac (who had a great many Relations and Acquaintance in the Parliament) join'd with the jutice of my caue, procur'd a peedy grant of my Petition, and the Lieutenant
Criminel was forbid to proceed any further in my proces; and the Officers who took me, were order'd to come and depoe before an Officer of the Parliament, but not one of them durt appear; and I obtain'd a peronal Summons for every one of them, which was afterwards turn'd to a decree to take them up; and I took three or four of them, and had them put into the Common Goal: when they were in Cutody they told the truth, and how all had pas'd, o that I was jut a going to have a Judgment, by which the truth of the whole matter would have been extorted from the Lieutenant Criminel, if he had not been advis'd to transfer it to the Counel. The Parliament who had already receiv'd everal reprimands from the King, for having lighted the decrees of the Council, knowing they had given one, by which he was forbidden to proceed any further, durt not go on with it, which pun out my buines to a great length: Nevertheles, Monieur de Marillac having repreented to the Council the injutice that was done me, the Lieutenant Criminel was defeated, and was forbidden to be Judge in the cae, and the Dean of the Counellors du Chatelet was ubtituted in his place, who had order to take new informations; and he be •
having himelf like a Man of honour and honety, the truth was brought to light, and my Enemies were proved to be Lyars: So I came out of Prion, after having been confin'd four Months, whereof I had been two Months and a half in the Dungeon. My firt viit was to Monieur de Marillac, who receiv'd me very kindly, without peaking one word of what he had hinted to the Keepers Wife; he return'd me the Letter I had wrote for the Cardinal Mazarin, not finding it convenient to deliver it.

After having acknowledged this obligation, I thought of dicharging another of no les value, which was to pay my thanks to the good woman, the Keepers wife; to whom having made an offer of a very coniderable Preent, I was urpriz'd to ee her refue it. This affliction gave me leiure enough to reflect upon my elf, and having given my elf up to the Pleaures of the World, like a Man that never coniders he mut one day dye, I had made a reolution to change my coure of Life: Nevertheles, it coming into my head, that this woman could not do all this for no end, or with no deign; and ince he had refus'd my Preent, I concluded it could be no other than that of Love, and thought my elf oblig'd to content her that way too, without conidering that I was going already to break the promie I had made to God in my Troubles. But if I was urpriz'd at her refuing my Preent, I was much more o, at the manner in which he receiv'd my Complement; for without that Preamble, that 'tis o much the fahion for Women to make, who would be thought more vertuous than they really are; he told me roundly, that I did not deerve the Deliverance that God had o wonderfully betow'd on me; that I had more reaon to return him thanks than to pull down his vengeance on me, by an account o criminal, as the Adultery I had compas'd in my Thoughts: That if he had oblig'd me, 'twas only becaue he knew the injutice that was offer'd me, and this was but an ill requital, to propoe o horrid a Crime to her. I was heartily glad to tand corrected by o Chritian a reproof: and as vertue commands our eteem, o I had more real value for her, than I hould have had love, if he had yielded to my olicitation.

I had no ooner lot the thoughts of this crime, but I entertain'd another in my breat; I reolv'd to revenge my elf of my fale Witnees, and begun with the Chevalier de Rieux, whom I forc'd to draw in the treet, having met him by accident: as he naturally was but a Coward, he would endeavour to convince me, that I was under the greatet mitake in the world, to offer that to him who was always one of my bet Friends; but as I knew well enough what I ought to believe, I took no great heed to what he aid, but gave him everal blows with the flat of my Sword, eeing he would not be perwaded to draw; but I was not atisfied with all this: Next I meditated revenge againt the Count d' Harcourt, who I knew had treated me uncivilly behind my back: Tho he was of a mot honourable Family, and tho his Quality exempted him from giving me the common atisfaction in uch caes, yet I was reolv'd one way or other to let him know, that I was not inenible of the affront; and it was not long before I had an occaion put into my hands; there was a Captain in the Marine Regiment call'd Deplanches, who was one of his Neighbours in the Country, to whom he had behav'd himelf very imperiouly, upon pretence that his Ancetors had raied their Etate by being Rent-gatherers, or Stewards to his Family, by which means they had left their Heirs a better Etate than their Mater, intimating as if they had dealt unjutly by him. 'Tis true this Deplanches had been o, and had little les than thirty thouand Livres a year Etate; and having obtain'd Letters Patents for his Nobility, and a Coat of Arms, now he thought he ought not to bear all thoe meannees, which was impos'd upon him by the haughty carriage of the Count:
Beides this, that Prince had a great mind to a peice of Land that belong'd to him call'd Rufflais, which joyning to his Etate at Harcourt, he was always encroaching upon.

I no ooner was inform'd of all this, but I offer'd my Service to Deplanches, whom I had no acquaintance with before; but I found means to let him undertand, that I was like to be very hearty in joyning with him againt one that was o much my Enemy as well as his. This man, who was the greatet Drunkard that ever I knew in my life, never thankt me, nor nothing, but told me, he hould be very glad to drink with me; and not to delay it, dei'rd me to dine with him at the Flower de luce, where he lodged, near the Hotel de Soions. He told me however after his firt Compliment, that he was oblig'd to me, but I did not find him o eager of the thing as I thought he would have been; o that I concluded either that he wanted courage, or that he was afraid of embroiling himelf with a Prince of that interet. I held of this mind till Dinner, when having eaten his Soup, and taken off two or three Bumpers, he began to talk very candalouly of the Count de Harcourt: I told him he mut excue me in aying, this was no • the way he ought to revenge himelf of his Enemy; that I had heard the Count d' Harcourt had offer'd him everal inults, even in his own houe, and if he pleas'd we would go home with him, and ee if we could perwade him, to come and do the like again. Deplanches, whoe paion encreat with his Wine, told me, he lik'd the propoal very well; and having askt two or three Officers of the ame Regiment, that were with us, if they would be of the party, they all agreed immediately they would go: So he order'd
his Hores to be addled, and deir'd us to end for ours. I thought we had nothing to do now, but to put on our Boots and to mount, but 'twas not his way to rie from Table o oon, and 'twas ix a Clock at night before he would tir, and then he was o drunk, that intead of going about what had been agreed, he fell to quarrelling with one of thoe Officers, o that if I had not clapt in between, the quarrel would not have ended without michief; I endeavour'd to make him enible of his error, but he being no more capable of reaon than a Hore, was the more unruly, till the Officer that knew him better than I, was oblig'd to go out of the Room, for fear-of puhing the humour too far: The two others, let I hould think he did o for want of courage, told me at the ame time oftly, that 'twould be bet for us to withdraw too; that when he was drunk he was quite mad, and if we did not, we hould, it may be, find ome of the effects of his diorder: I aw reaon enough to believe them, o we ent back our Hores and went home to our own Lodgings, while Deplanches was fighting with his Men, and quarrelling with his Landlord and Landlady for letting us go.

The next morning before I was up, he comes into my Chamber, and taking no notice of lat nights work, he askt me if I held my reolution, of going with him into the Country as I had promis'd. I told him Yes, and was ready to go when he pleas'd. He told me he would go as oon as ever the other Gentlemen were ready, to whom he had ent that morning, and o deir'd me to rie: and then he took five or ix turns in my Chamber, walking hatily as if he had ome great thing in his head; at lat it came out, and he told me that he was diturb'd in
his thoughts, for fear he hould make a broil with the Count de Harcourt, who wanted nothing but uch an opportunity to out him of his Etate: This made me enible that uch ort of people always retain omething of the meannes of their Nature, in pight of all the Patents of Nobility their Money may procure them; and if the Officers had not come in, in that very moment, I had put off engaging with a fellow of o mean a reolution: I told them what Deplanches had been aying to me, at which they hrunk up their houlders; but being Men of Honor, they told him, he ought rather to dye than to bear the affronts he received every day; that they did not deign to go and quarrel with the Count de Harcourt at his own Houe, but they would only go with him and Hunt upon his Lands, that lay next to the Count's, to let him ee that he was not afraid of him.

And to hearten him up, they gave him leave to go to Breakfat firt, upon condition he hould drink but his hare of two Bottles of Wine; and this having the deir'd effect, we got on Horeback and took the direct way to Normandy: Now tho this Man had nothing to do, but to make hate to our Journeys end, yet all we could do, could not prevent him taying a whole day at Mantes, where he lighting on ome excellent Wine, made them fill a hundred Bottles of it, which we et in the head of our little Troop, and convoy'd to his Houe. And let the Count de Harcourt, who was at home, hould have notice of our coming, we thought it bet to come in in the Night; and having forbid the Servants telling any body how many we were, we went a Hunting the next morning, and rod up even to the very edge of the Count de Harcourt's Land,
which lay next to Rufflais. The Count being immediately inform'd of it, and uppoing it to be only Deplanches and his Men, laid an Ambucade for them as they hould come back. In hort, as we were riding under a Hedge, we were aluted with two hots from the other ide, one of which truck off the Pommel of my Saddle, upon which I turn'd about immediately, and being very well mounted, I came up with one of the Fellows that had hot, before he had time to charge again; I could eaily have kill'd him if I would, but not being willing to do o, I contented my elf with beating him mot unmercifully with my Fuil: The Fellow knowing me, call'd me by my Name, and told me he belong'd to uch a Gentleman, and hop'd that for his Maters ake, whom he thought to be one of my very good Friends, I would be pleas'd to pardon him: 'Tis your Mater Sirrah, aid I, is the caue that I ue you at this tate, but I will let you go, provided you will promie me to tell him o. He made no difficulty of promiing me this, and going another way to ecape Deplanches and the Officers, who were in chae of the others, he got at lat to the Catle de Harcourt, all over batter'd and bruis'd, and his Cloaths torn almot off of his back, o that any body might ee he had fallen into very bad hands: Deplanches and his Friends blam'd me extreamly for letting him go, thinking that I ought rather have eiz'd him and deliver'd him to Jutice; but I who aim'd mot at my private revenge, was very well pleas'd with what I had done. In hort, the Count de Harcourt was o enrag'd at the affront, he had as he thought receiv'd; that he aembled all his Friends, and not conidering that he was the Agreor, he reolves to pull down the very houe at Rufflais, and to bury us all in the
Ruins. This was not to be done o ecretly, but we had notice of it, and the Houe being not defencible, we retre • ted to the Houe of the Count de Crequi Bernieulle, who was no Friend to the Count de Harcourt, and whoe Houe was then the Seat of a little War between him and the Marquis de Sourdeac; for there was not only a Suit at Law depending between them, but 'twas grown to that height, that they made a formal War againt each other; and oftentimes met one another in the field, with fifteen or ixteen hundred men of a ide, as if they would come to a et Battle; o we offer'd our Service to him to engage in his Party againt both the Count de Harcourt, and the Marquis de Sourdeac: There was a great deal of difference between thee Troops and regulated Souldiers, as appeared particularly one day, when the Count de Crequi being advanc'd, the Marquis de Sourdeac had no ooner fired one hot from a Fauconet at the Catle de Nieufborg, but all the Squadron cour'd away as hard as they could drive, every one laying the blame afterwards upon his Hore, who was not us'd to tand fire; but as the digrace was general, thoe that tood were willing enough to take it for an excue. As they made war upon the Marquis de Sourdeac, o did I upon the Count d' Harcourt, upon whoe ground I ventur'd two or three times to kill ome Partridges: The Bayliff came, and deir'd me civilly to forbear, pretending his Mater was gone to Paris, but I knew well enough that was a ham, for the very next night he came with his men, and cut down the Trees, at the very Gates of Rufflais.

I thought however I had done enough to tetify my reentment, and Deplanches being on the other hand oblig'd to return to the Army, I was oblig'd
to bear him company to Paris, for he durt not venture to have gone alone; being arriv'd at Paris, I went preently to Court, and the Cardinal eeing me, askt me whence I came, which made me believe, that he knew all that had pat; nevertheles I durt not tell him the truth, let he hould give me a reprimand for it, and perhaps omething wore; but I was urpriz'd, when intead of that, he told me I had done very well, and he hould like me the better for it as long as he knew me; that one Folleville le Sens, who was a Gentleman of that Country, and who belong'd to him, had told him all, and that I needed not be diturb'd at it; but on the contrary, might depend upon his Protection. I humbly thankt him for this goodnes, but I askt him withal how he would pleae to dipoe of me: For while I was under confinement, he had given away my Company; o that I lookt methought, in my preent condition, little better than a Valet out of Service: he bid me take no care of that, but attend upon him, for he went every year into the Army with the King; who began now, not only to hew himelf great, but alo to give an early proof of what he would one day appear. In hort, he delighted in the War above all things, and tho they caution'd him with regard to his Health, not to expoe his Peron o in the Heats and Rains, yet he eldom mit being on Horeback as long as any Day-light was left.

I had pent more time in the Court than in the Army; and eeing however my Inclination led me to the Profeion, yet that 'twas impoible for me to manage my elf in it, as well as thoe who had been bred to it, I was not orry for the Command the Cardinal laid upon me. I waited upon him therefore
with the greatet aiduity poible; and tho I ay it, omitted nothing that might oblige him. However, there was everal Poeple, who pretended to perwade me that I took wrong meaures, and among the ret one Artignan and Bemau, who complain'd that they had done the ame thing all their lives, without any advancement more than what they were at firt; and indeed they made but a very orry figure, and were in uch a pitiful condition for the mot part, they knew not where to get a Penny to buy a Dinner: This oblig'd them to think of retiring from the Court; but as they were of the furthet part of Gacogne, and that they had not wherewithal to undertake o long a Journey, they try'd all ways poible to raie a little money, but all People were o kind to them as to refue them: for if they had got together but ten Pitoles, we hould never have een one of them Commander of the firt Company of the Grand Muqueteers, nor the other with an Etate of Three Millions of Livres, as he is at this time: However, all they could ay was not capable to dihearten me from following his Eminence to the Frontiers. The Count de Harcourt went the ame time with the King, and looking a little didainfully at me, I ent him word by one of my Friends, that if he was not pleas'd, he had nothing to do but to tell me o. He return'd again, that I did not know my elf, but he hould find a time to make me do it. This was a Bravade which I laught at, and other People laught as well as I; for tho he was a Prince, he ought not to have carried it o high; and everal as good as he, and thoe ome of his own Family too, had not thought it below them to meaure their Sword with a Gentleman; however, my Friend advis'd me to have a care of my
elf, but I lighted it, thinking a Prince of his Quality was incapable of a bae action; but thoe who I thus gave my opinion to, told me, that he who had done his bet to take me off when I was in Prion, might very well be thought to attempt it now I was at liberty: However, I was not deceiv'd in him, and whatever his endeavours had been to revenge himelf, he never attempted any of thoe ways they eem'd to upect: For I do not undertand that any private Ambucade, had been laid at any time for me; and tho I did attribute to him an accident which happen'd to me a few days afterwards, yet I ought always to ay for the honour of the Peron I had to do withal, that he fairly gave me time to draw my Sword; and if I was roughly handl'd, it was by the Fortune of the fight, and not a private aault.

There was one Breaute a Gentleman of Normandy, who was a Man brave enough, and a very handom Peron, but of a behaviour o extraordinary inolent, that it render'd all the other good Qualities he had, not worth taking notice of: He had this ill temper by inheritance, from the Marquis de Breaute his near Relation, who had o good an opinion of himelf, that he challeng'd five and twenty Spaniards, to fight them all one after another; but Monieur de Grobendonc Governour of Boleduc laughing at his inolence, told him, that he hould have enough of one; and to make it good, added, that he hould bring four and twenty French men along with him, and he would end five and twenty Spaniards to meet them. Breaute enrag'd with this anwer, askt leave of the Prince of Orange, under whom he erv'd, to accept of the Challenge, and having obtain'd it, he manag'd the fight o unhappily
that he was kill'd upon the pot, and two and twenty of his Men, and the two other cry'd for Quarter, who being brought Prioners to Boleduc, Grobendonc immediately hang'd them, which action deminih'd his honour, and ullied the Victory his Party had obtain'd; but he gave this reaon for it, That all the Combatants had worn to maintain the fight to the lat drop of their Blood rather than to demand quarter, and 'twas but jut that thee who broke their word, hould expiate the perjury with their lives, for a atisfaction to their Companions that perform'd their vow to the lat. Breaute, tho as you ee, he had no great caue to brag of this action of his Kinman, yet he had the tory always in his mouth, and at every turn would repeat it, to how that his Family had been always men of Courage; and to make himelf more ridiculous, he would bring it out, that if Grobendonc's Men had had to do with him, they hould not have come off o well. I have heard him tell this tory very often, which has made very good port to all the Company: But having been taught by experience, that we hould not always laugh at the follies of others, I was the only Peron that kept my Countenance at thee relations, and conequently was furthet off from the thoughts of a Quarrel; and yet when I leat thought of it, I was oblig'd to fight him, upon pretence that I had been as rude with him as the ret. My honour would not permit me to refue him, but imagining there was omething more in the matter, and being willing to know the bottom of it, I told him that if he had no other caue to quarrel with me than that, he might put up his Sword again, for I had never o much as dreamt of it; and that the Gentlemen that were with me would give me the ame
atisfaction, that I did not ay this out of fear, I believ'd I had given proofs enough of my courage in everal occaions, not to have it call'd in quetion at uch a time: while I was aying this I kept at Swords length off, if poible to have avoided fighting: But he depiing my jutification, or rather being excited on ome other account, threw himelf upon me in a trange fury, and wounded me in the ide. I became raging mad at the ight of the blood, and making a deperate thrut, I ran my Sword to the Hilt thro his Thigh, but he preently reveng'd himelf, for at the next pas he ran me quite through the Body, upon which I dropt immediately, and he diarm'd me.

I had a upicion, that this was done by the procurement of the Count de Harcourt, which was confirm'd by what I heard the next Morning; for they told me, that he carried my Sword to that Prince, and that for joy of the Victory they made uch a Debauche of it, that all the Company that were there, were ent home in a lamentable pickle, and the Count himelf made no cruple to own the fact: 'Twas very dihonorable for him to tell all the world thus, that he could not fight but by Proxy, he had a name bad enough already, after the manner that he liv'd and treated his Lady, he needed not have taken uch pains to encreae it. In hort, he liv'd more like a Bully than a Prince, which was the caue that he treated his Lady after uch a ort as I hinted but now: That 'twas reported that he us'd to beat her, I know not whether this was true at the bottom, or that his being Brother to the Duke d' Elbeuf, who had kill'd his Wi •• with ill uage, got him this Reputation: However 'twas, this is certain, that this Lady, who was a rich Heires, not being able to bear his humours,
retir'd to a Monatery, where he remains to this day.

My wound was too great to be oon cur'd, my Longs having been pierc'd quite through; and you could not hold a Candle to the Orifice, but the wind that came from it would blow out the light. The Cardinal, who hated the Count d' Harcourt and his Family, becaue they were always againt him, upected as well as I that this came from him, and declar'd himelf openly in my favour; and told publickly that if he could get Breaute into his hands, who now abconded, he would teach him how to quarrel in cold blood: Nor did he top there, but to vex the Count de Harcourt more than for any kindnes he had for me, he ent me his own Surgeon, and beides that a Bag with about five hundred Crowns: This was o unuual a thing with him, epecially the Money, and above all to a man that was neither one of his Family, nor indeed one of his Party, that every body was urpris'd, and o was I my elf, and indeed could hardly tell what to think of it, till Deplanches came to ee me, and inform'd me that the Cardinal had ent for him, and told him, that as oon as the Campaign was over he would have him take ome of his Friends with him down to his houe, and do all they could poible to affront that Count; and that his Eminence undertanding I hould quickly be cur'd, would have me be of the Party; and that he would certainly peak to me of it, as oon as ever I was abroad again. In hort, being gone to thank his Eminence after I was well again for his goodnes to me, he told me, he hould be very glad to have me go upon that deign, and then • twas he told me how the Marechal de la Ferte had juggl'd with me, when he pretended to
get a Regiment for me. I thought that this Confidence proceeded from ome dicontent the Cardinal had with him; indeed they aid then that his Eminence had ome upicion that he was not true to him, and that tho the Marechal us'd to ay of himelf, that he never had chang'd his Coat; 'twas becaue they were not o good as their words to him in what they promis'd him, rather than want of Inclination on his part.

The Campaign being ended, Deplanches took four choice Lads of his own Company with a Sergeant, whom he diguis'd like Valets, that his deign might not be known; and we went all of us to his houe, where there came a Gentleman of Perigor, that was a Captain in the ame Regiment. By the way he receiv'd a Letter from his Collonel, who was the Count de Tonecharante, by which he deir'd him very civilly indeed, to give a dicharge to a certain Souldier of his Company: It unluckily happen'd, that the Meenger came in while he was at Table, and the heat of the Wine adding omething to his ugly humor, which was bru • i • h enough of it elf, he told the Expres,
• hat the Count de Tonecharante buied himelf with that he had nothing to do withal; that for his part he would do nothing in it, and if the Collonel did not like it he might take his coure. Seeing him diturb'd, we ask'd him what was the matter, tho he had poke enough already to make us gues what it was; but he how'd us the Letter, which was in the modetet terms that was poible; inomuch, that not being able to ee him o brutih, I told him he was to blame to give uch an anwer to it; •• at I had not the honour to be particularly known to Count de Tonecharante, but he mut give me leave to tell him, 'twas not uual to
deal o by ones Collonel, who was o generous to requet a thing of him which he could have done without him; that 'twas what the Captains could not have done without the Collonel; and if the Collonel choe to go the contrary way, 'twas becaue that they were unwilling to ue their Authority in prejudice of the Captains; that this refual would but put him upon giving the Souldier his dimis without him, and that would not be all neither, for he would eternally loe his friendhip, which he ought to preerve above all things; that 'twas the practice always at Court, as indeed it ought to be every where, that the Captains did all that in them lay to keep a good undertanding with the uperior Officers; that I poke as his Friend, and pray'd him to conider thee things a little; and tho he had an Etate, and o did not value preferment, yet he hould be careful to preerve his Reputation; that infallibly Monieur de Tonecharante would be dioblig'd, and I beought him but to think of that a little.

I know not how he did to have patience while I aid all this; however, 'twas all one, he would have it, that 'twas the Captains Office to give a dimis to a Souldier, and that the Collonel had nothing to do with it: And growing very high becaue I was not of his Opinion, he had o little manners as to give me the Lye in his own Houe; for we were got to Planches near D' Evreux, which was not above Six or Seven Leagues from Rufflais, and belong'd to him. He had no ooner let lip the Word, but I catcht up a Plate and threw it at his head, and the Wine having put Courage into him, he clos'd in wit • me, tho' three or four Perons who were at the Table with us got in between us; by good fortune for us
both we had neither of us our Swords on, o our fight being but with our Fits, 'twas not likely to be very Bloody; however, we were o warm that 'twas not without great difficulty that they parted us.
