There was no great likelihood after this that we hould proceed on our Journey, o I order'd my Men to addle my Hore; the Gentlemen who were there did all they could to accommodate matters: But he tood off, and would do nothing; o I came away, and being pretty late I could reach but to Pai that Night, which was in the Road to Paris. Nothing would erve him but he would follow me, that he would; but his Friends, who aw I aid nothing but what was true, prevented him, that he might ettle his brains. The next morning 'twas quite another thing, and he told the Gentlemen that I left with him, that he was extreamly concern'd for what had happen'd, and that they ought to have kept me, and that he would go and overtake me to ask my pardon. They were all very glad to hear him talk after this manner, and having addl'd their Hores, they came all away with him a gallop. They came up with me at Mantes where I baited, for I had no occaion to be in any hate; when I aw them, and that their Hores were all in a foam, I wonder'd what hould be the matter they were in uch hate, and preently imagining it was to affront me. I plac'd my elf at the top of the Stairs in a poture to receive them with a Pitol in each hand: But Deplanches advancing before them, and offering me his hand in token of friendhip, he pray'd me to forget all that was pat, telling me, that I knew well enough when a man's in drink he is not mater of his reaon.

I could not find in my heart to be angry, hearing him talk at this rate, for beides that, I did not beleive he had acted himelf in that which had happen'd; I had a mind alo to obey the Cardinal, by whoe order, as I have mention'd, I undertook this Journey: So I went back again with him, after we had embrac'd each other, and taying two days at Planches, we came at lat to Rufflais, where we undertood that the Count de Harcourt was at home at his Catle. I courted Deplanches to go abroad that very day, but he pretended he was not well; o I took my Fuil, and with only my own Servants, went out quite to the grounds belonging to the Count de Harcourt; there was no game tirring, but going on more with a deign to be een than to kill any thing, I hot up in the air; one of the Count's Servants came out immediately to ee who 'twas, he knew me aoon as ever he aw me, and run in to carry the news to his Mater: The Count undertanding I had but two men with me, ent out all his men, but took care to tay behind himelf: When I aw I was like to engage nothing but a Mob made up of Plowmen and Footmen, and that I was in a fair way to be devour'd, I thought it was my bet way to retreat; they perued me cloe, but being well mounted I got ground of them, till I came to a lane that was jut in the road: Thee fellows peru'd me till, and made everal hot at me at a ditance; but I ecap'd a greater danger preently after, for I was not gone fifty paces in the lane, when I received a whole volley of hot from another ide, at which, thank God, I was more afraid than hurt, and not without caue, for I had three hots in my Hat, and two in my Cloaths; jut at this juncture I dicover'd Deplanches with his Souldiers, and
not doubting but they were going to et upon me, I had certainly kill'd him, if he had not cry'd out, and told me, that he did not think he had hot at me, but at the Count de Harcourt's men: I was uch a Coxcomb to be perwaded into this; and having told them, that ince it was o, we had nothing to do now but to fall upon them, they charg'd again, and we turn'd upon them, and peru'd them. Being return'd to Rufflais, they all made a great tir about the danger I had been in, and he askt my pardon, with a great many words to convince me, that all that had happen'd was by accident; but my Valet de Chambre, who it eems had at that time more wit than I, told me, as he was undreing me, that I hould not trut my elf there, and that I was with a man that made a practice of uch kind of Villanies; for a Countryman thereabouts had told him, that he had kill'd two or three o baely from behind a Hedge; and that ince I had had a quarrel with him, 'twould be my bet coure to get away aoon as I could: This dicoure made me begin to recollect, what a Blockhead I had been to beleive all he had aid to me, and reolv'd to leave a man with whom there was o little afety; however I wanted an excue to come away, and having ent one of my men to Brione, to ee if there was any Letters for me, I gave him one which I had wrote my elf, wherein 'twas mentioned, that I was wanted immediately at Paris, about ome buines of conequence; o I took my leave of this Traytor, without taking notice of any thing; and it pleaing God, that I hould not continue long uncertain whether my upicion was well or ill grounded, it happen'd that a Souldier whom my Valet had carry'd to drink with him, on purpoe to pump
him, told him, that I was much in the right of it to go away, for I had cap'd a cowring; he could not get a word more out of him, tho he pret him to peak pl • iner; but as this was enough to make me judge of the peron, I was no ooner on Horeback, but I told him, I hould remember him as long as I liv'd, and that at another time I would tell him more; he tood mute at thee words, and not giving him time to jutifie himelf, I clapt Spurs to my Hore, and got o far from him, that if he had aid any thing, 'twas impoible for me to hear him.

In the mean time all that I had told him came to pas. Monieur de Tonecharante having been inform'd of his rudenes, gave the dimis to the Souldier without him, and not content with giving him this affront, he reolv'd to have him caheer'd, the firt minute he could get an opportunity: The thing was difficult to be done at that time, it being not then as 'tis now, that the Collonels were abolute Maters of their Regiments; for on the other hand, the King was in want of Officers, and accordingly was more chary of them, than it has been ince: Indeed they did not come in uch crouds for Commiions in thoe days, nor were not o prodigal either of their Etates, or of their Lives; o that Monieur de Tonecharante, tho he had reolv'd to do his utmot to throw him out, found it impoible to bring it to pas, till the Peace of the Pyrennes; but now the time being come, that there was not o much need of Souldiers, and the King making a reform among his Troops, he manag'd it o, that he got his name into the Lit of thoe that were to be disbanded, tho it was a little out of the order, for he was the fifth or ixth Captain of the Regiment, and the reform
us'd to begin at the younget: Deplanches could not bear this affront without making his complaint, which the Count de Toncherante had foreeen, and had been beforehand with him, having waited upon the King, and given him a large account of his behaviour, which was not only brutih, but omething wore, for he was grown to that height, that acred things were not free from his violence when he was in drink, and he would peak either of God or the the King, in the ame terms, as he did the wort of his Enemies.

For all this he had the Impudence to go to the King, and having pleaded the merit of his ervice, how he had been everal years in the Army, had always kept his Company full, and had never been charg'd with any failure of his duty; that he had an Etate of his own, and did not erve meerly for his Pay, and a thouand things to the ame effect. The King, after he had given him Audience with a great deal of patience, anwer'd him coldly, that he knew all this as well as himelf, and that ince he had been o faithful to him, he had done this to give him leiure to erve God, as regularly as he had erv'd him; and tho he did not expect him to be a Saint, yet he would not have him be impious; that he had been inform'd from very good hands, that he had pit in the Holy Water Pot, in contempt of that acred Element, and of all Religion; that he did not know how it came to pas he was not proecuted for it; and but that he undertood at the ame time he was in drink, he hould perhaps have repented coming to him ele. Deplanches, who knew in his heart, the King had tax'd him with nothing but what was true, inited no more upon it, but went out with hame enough, and retir'd himelf
altogether to the Country, and never tirr'd out of it but once, that he came to Paris to marry the Daughter of Monieur de Brillac, Councellor of the great Chamber; but this Lady neither, being not able to cure him of his Debauchery, he kill'd himelf with drinking in about five or ix years.

I had reolv'd at my lat parting with him to demand atisfaction from him for the Treachery he had us'd towards me; but having given the Cardinal an account of the whole matter, he prohibited me o trictly, that I durt not think of it: In the mean time he ent me to Bruels, upon a ecret affair which I mut not reveal, and in which I could not ucceed. The Prince de Conde was till at the Spanih Court, and it happen'd while I was there, that Monieur de Beauvais was kill'd; he was Father to the Countes de Soions, and Mater of the Hore to the Prince; he was a Man of Courage, but • ad too good a conceit of himelf, which was the caue of his misfortune; for as he was coming down from the Prince de Conde' • Lodging, he met a Gentleman coming up, and takes him by the arm at the top of the tairs with • uch orce, that he threw him down, and walkt over him himelf. The Gentleman would not o much as ask him the meaning of it then, from the repect he ow'd to the Place; but going out immediately, he gets a Friend, and ends him to Beauvais to demand atisfaction of him for this affront. Beauvais was not a man that us'd to refue any body, o having brought a Friend with him to be his Second, they fought it out two and two of a ide; one of his Enemies was quite kill'd upon the place, but he was never the better for this hort liv'd advantage, for he receiv'd a Pitol Bullet in his head, of which he dy'd
in a few days. The Prince of Conde being inform'd of this accident, went to ee him before he dy'd; and as he aw there was no hopes of his life, he told him, that eeing the condition he was in, he ought to leave all other thoughts but thoe of his oul; that he had kept a certain Lady a long time, by whom he had had everal Children, (one of which was the preent Countes de Soions) but was never marry'd to her; that he advis'd him to dicharge his concience, which he might do by making her his Wife; that he knew not how to how his friendhip more to him, than by adviing him for his good; and that if he would be rul'd by him, he would go and end for a Priet immediately. Beauvais had lot all his ences, and had not poke a word in four and twenty hours; but the Prince's voice, or rather the dicoure he made to him, reviving him: No, my Lord, aid he, raiing his voice, I hall not be rul'd by you, I never promis'd her any thing, nor I don't ee, that I am oblig'd to perform any thing. The Prince reply'd, that he knew that bet himelf indeed, and that what he poke was upon the common report that pread it about o; to which the other having again anwer'd the ame thing, he left him to dye in quiet.

All this while the War continu'd with great fury, not only on the Frontiers with the Spaniards, but alo in the heart of the Kingdom; and the weaknes of the Chief Miniter encourag'd uch as were dipos'd to diminih, if not to overthrow the regal Authority, and the preent form of Government in the Kingdom: I don't pretend to reflect, in aying this, upon what the Parliament did, but upon the Impudence of ome particular perons, who thou •• t themelves at liberty in thee times of publick ••• traction
to etablih the pe • ty Tyrannies they exercis'd in their own limits. Indeed they had in every Province two or three of thee little Princes, for uch they were in effect, for the Kings orders were but laught at among them, if they were not agreeable to their deigns. This was a great trouble to the Cardinal, but more to the King, who had a thouand times more courage, and who was more nearly toucht in thee practices than others; but 'twas his time to wink at all this, and as young as he was, he was extraordinary politick, and choe rather not to reform an abue, tho he knew it to be o, than to let it appear that it was too great for him to attempt, in uch an uncertain condition as things then tood. In the mean time, never was there uch a prank play'd as was done now, by a certain Coxcomb that had married one of my Relations, and in whoe cae I had like to have been involv'd. This Man call'd himelf the Marquis de Pranac, he was a huge hulky fellow of himelf, but his pride well'd him beyond all dimenions; if he had any Nobility in his blood, 'twas only that he was Grandon to a Preident of Bourdeaux; but ince I am fallen upon his Genealogy, I mut give you a hort hitory of his Great Grand-father. He kept a Brandy-hop at Bourdeaux, and made a figure o mean, that no body reckon'd him to be worth above two thouand Franks. In hort, he not only dwelt in a little naty houe, but bought and old privately in other Peoples names. He had but one only Son, who he had bred up well enough and above what 'twas thought he could afford; for not intending to make him a Brandy Merchant, he ent him to the Univerity. This young fellow was a meer Thomas Diaforus, that is jut uch another Blockhead,
as Moelier calls by that name inMalade Maginaje. his Comedy, or as we may ay a veryBen. Johnon. Bartholomew Cokes. However, he happens to ee one day at Church, one of the Preidents Daughters, and falls deperately in love with her, inomuch, that but one ight of her brought him into the yellow Jaundice His Father, who as I aid, had no more Children, and knew himelf to be richer than anybody thought, was almot ditracted to ee him in uch a condition: And after a deal of pother to know what ail'd him, at lat with much ado got the Secret out of him. Phaw! ays the old man, is that all? Ne're trouble thy elf, I'll warrant you I'll get her for you; and with that away he goes to her Father, and demands her of him for his Son. The Preident thought the little old fellow was mad, and askt him who he was, that he hould come with uch a compliment to him; and gueing at the man by the figure he made, which was very indifferent, he was going to bid his Footmen kick him down Stairs. The little man, not at all daunted at the cornful treatment of the Preident, and to come to the point, askt him how much he could give his Daughter, for let it be as much as it would, he would give his Son three times as much in ready Money, beides the refual of uch a place as his was, which he had ecur'd for him when he hould be capable to manage it. The Preident hearing him talk at this rate, could not tell what to make of it; and eeing nothing in him that lookt as if he were craz • d, began not only to treat him civilly, but to ask him as civilly, if he was able to make good what he talk'd of. The old man told him he was not very likely to be deceiv'd, unles his Money would not go, for 'twas all in pecie;
and taking him home with him, he how'd him a great Iron Chet, and in it above eight hundred thouand Franks all in Gold.

The Match was oon made up after uch a ight as this, and from this Conjunction prung the Father of our Coxcomb; I leave any one to judge whether I have done him wrong in giving him uch a Title, when they have heard his Story. Firt, tho he knew his own Original well enough, yet his Coach would not pleae him unles it was adorn'd with a great many Coats of Arms; o without any regard to the Coat that his Grand-father had taken up, and which erv'd his Father well enough, he picks out uch Coats as he lik'd bet, and orders the Herald to quarter them with his own, and to divide them into ixteen quarters, the leat of which belong'd to ome Prince or other, and withal gives a mot glorious Livery, that made all the Town tare at him. The City of Paris, like other great Cities, never wants Sharpers, who live by their wits, at the price of other peoples follies. One of thee oberving our Gallant, and finding him ruuning tark mad after the vanity of Grandeur, preents him with a very formal Genealogy, by which he made it out as clear as the Sun, that he was decended in a direct male-line from the Family De Dreux, a younger branch of the Blood Royal; and that as uch, he had a right to bear in his firt and fourth quarter the arms of France, and in the econd and third thoe of Dreux: He was overjoy'd with his dicovery, and I happening to be then at his Houe, he askt me what I thought of it: I found he was too well pleas'd with it for me to contradict it, for I had no mind to dioblige him: So I having given my opinion in his own ence, I made him o compleat a Fool, as that he immediately
ends for his Coach-maker • , bepeaks a new rich Coach, giving him the Arms that he would have et upon it; he chang'd alo his Plate, and made the ame Coat of Arms be engraven upon that; and to omit nothing that might add to the Lutre of his Family, in ome Writings he had making, he caus'd himelf to be til'd, The mot Serene Prince L. ... de Dreux, adding however the Surname of Rhedon, which was his true name, but which he intended to drop in proces of time, or to attribute it to ome accidental imaginary entail, as a great many other Families in France do; who, if they were to tell the truth, would be very much at a los to make out their Original.

Beides this, the new Marquis de Pranac chang'd his Livery again, and took up the ame with Madamoielle de Montpenier's, the Lining only excepted, one being green, and the other blue; and encreaing his Attendants with four Pages and ome Footmen he went beyond everal Princes in his Equipage: He took care in all his greatnes not to forget a Canopy of State, and wanting nothing but the name of his Highnes to make him a compleat Prince, ince he now began to beleive himelf to be really one; I was the firt, that to carry on the jet, betowed that title upon him; he took this o extream kindly of me, that I mut eat always at his own Table, and if I would beleive him, he could not part with me. He that firt et him up for a Prince, was alo very liberally rewarded, and being reolv'd to outdo me, made one addition more to his title, and til'd him his Royal Highnes, telling him, that ince he was decended from o many Kings, he did not ee any reaon, why he hould content himelf with the bare title of his Serenity. Our Marquis
thought this very rational, and giving his aent by nodding of his wie head, he how'd how well pleas'd he was with it; but being reolv'd to manage this humour, I began a little to contradict this, and his Highnes was to be Judge between us; I told him then, that was the way to call the ret of his Titles in quetion, to give him one that did not belong to him; that none but the immediate Children of Kings took this Title upon them, and that was but lately neither, and that the very next remove was that of Serenity, as in the Prince of Conde, and the Prince de Conti his Brother, to mention no more: This dicoure allay'd a little the vanity of his Highnes de Pranac. But the other Gentleman, to engratiate himelf further, told him, that the Title of Royal Highnes was well enough, for the Prince of Orange had aum'd it; I reply'd, that he never knew any body give it him but the Dutch Gazetteers; and if it was due to the Princes of Orange, as he was a Daughter, and Siter of a King of England, it did not follow, that her Husband hould be til'd o upon that account; that the Princes of the Blood Royal of England, as well as thoe of France, never lot their quality, tho they did marry Husbands inferiour to themelves, and therefore 'twas a mitake of his, to give the Husband the Title, which was due only to the Wie.

His Highnes of Pranac was pleas'd to think me in the right, and to be content with the character that was his due, o he told us with a very grave, tho a very foolih manner, that time would bring every thing to pas. All People were amaz'd to ee him et up uch an Echutcheon, and to appear in uch an Equipage: But he having not an Etate to anwer uch a prodigious expence, it hrunk his
Revenue, o that to leen his charge he was fain to retire into the Country, till his Exchequer hould be in a condition again to upport his Pageantry.

This piece of Fopery pat well enough o long as the War held, but when the Court, (the Peace being ettled) had leiure to look into civil affairs, the King gave order to the Procurator General of the Parliament to enquire, how the Marquis de Pranac came to be a Prince of the Blood: Whereupon the Procurator General goes with his Officers to make him a viit, and finding how the cae tood, he caus'd them to break in pieces all the Coaches where the Flower de Lis were quarter'd in the Ecutcheons, and calling for his Plate, they caus'd that alo to be bruis'd, and the Arms to be beaten out; beides they gave him a Summons, to anwer to a Complaint which was preented to the Parliament upon this ubject. Never was man o perplext as his Highnes appear'd upon this occaion; he ent for him that had wheedled him up in this fancy, but he knew well enough, 'twas no time for him to be een; then he ent for me, and I went, for I had a mind to ee how he carry'd it under his mortification. Really the man deerv'd Pity rather than Envy; for he was o great a Fool, that he would till be call'd his Highnes; for having fail'd in howing him that repect, he told me with a great deal of gravity, that I hould have a care of being too familiar with him; that his Caue was not yet lot, and that before long he might be in a condition to make me repent affronting a Prince of the Blood: But he abated much of his Pride hortly after, when the Procurator General, who proecuted him vigorouly, condemn'd him in a Fine of fifty thouand Crowns, and declar'd him and his Poterity uncapable
of the Priviledge of the Nobility; and everal other claues in the entence to degrade him of his Honour. Beides all this, the Lawyers advis'd him to drop his pretenions, and with much ado prevail'd with him to do it; but that which was wort of all, he was forc'd to draw up the urrender of his claim himelf, no body caring to meddle in uch a buines; in which he et forth, that the man I mention'd and my elf, were the perons who ininuated into him, that he was a Prince of the Blood; and that he, meaning no harm, verily beleiv'd it had been o; but that ince it appear'd otherwie, the ame incerity oblig'd him to relinquih the thoughts of it; that he begg'd his Majety's Pardon, and hop'd, that having not intended any way to offend him, he would be pleas'd to extend his Royal Mercy to him, and not proecute him with the utmot rigour. I was ummon'd to anwer upon this Depoition, and my Friends thought I hould have been ecur'd; but being examin'd, I made it appear, that I was far from prompting him to that folly, and only made my elf port at it; that 'twas not my fault, if he had not more wit to take a thing eriouly, which was poken only to banter him; that I knew his Original too well to beleive it my elf; but that in hort, 'twas impoible to make a Fool a Wie Man let one do what one could: My Examination did him more ervice than I had foreeen, for there being other circumtances, that made him appear a very weak peron, the Parliament us'd him gently, and he got clear with asking the Court's Pardon, and paying a thouand Crowns Fine.

After this buines he was oblig'd to change his Name and his Arms; as for his Name, he reum • d his own, but for his Arms, 'twas four or five years
before he could reolve upon it; o he bare upon his Coach nothing but his own Cypher with a Coronet, and nothing at all upon his Plate; at lat he gave for his Arms a Lyon Sable in a Field Or, but as he could not forget the Flower de Lis, he put a great many in the alliances which he quarter'd with his own, which was as much as to tell the world, once a Fool and always a Fool. After this, tho he was threecore and ten years of age, he thought himelf young enough to fall in Love, and to begin his Amours, he makes Love to Madam the Dutches de Saux, but in o very a repectful manner, that he never poke a word to her, but contented himelf to go to the Fauxbourg Saint Germaine, where he tays all the while the Mas was celebrating at the Convent des Minims, only to have the honour to ee her go by, and returns the happiet Man in the world, if he vouchaf'd to take the Holy Water from his Hands, and takes but o much notice of him, as to bow when he gives it her. The Dutches was a good while before he imagin'd any thing, but ome body having told her Husband, the Duke de Saux, he was reolv'd to oberve the humour himelf, which having een, he order'd his Lady to look a little favourably upon him; which put the good man o beides himelf, that if it continu'd a month or two longer, he mut certainly have been ent to a Mad-houe.

Becaue I would not break off this tory, I have run on thro the tranactions of everal years, which I mut look back again to, for what relates to my own affairs. I was pretty well with the Cardinal, and tho I had not ucceeded in my Voyage to Bruels, he employ'd me again in a ecret buines he had on foot on that ide, which was to get off
the Count de Marcin from the Intrets of the Prince de Conde, for whoe ake he had acrific'd his fortune; for had he continu'd in his duty, he had not fail'd being made a Marechal of France: Indeed there was few men undertood military affairs better, nor that was fitter for any great enterprize; and yet for all this, the Prince de Conde quarrell'd with him, for not having punctually oberv'd ome Orders he gave: The Count de Marcin excus'd himelf, and how'd him how the occaion requir'd him to make ome little alterations. But the Prince, who was the paionatet man alive, turning hatily from him towards the fire, would not hear him peak, but in a fury, Ah Marcin, aid he, who would have thought, that you would have us'd me as you do; repeating the ame words over and over five or ix times with o much heat, that he bit the Chimney-peice with his teeth for madnes. Marcin, eeing what a rage he was in, thought it his bet way to retire, for fear of omething wore. The Cardinal was, by his Spies, immediately inform'd of this miundertanding, which was the occaion of his ending me on this Errand. The Rique was great in this adventure, for it had been as much as my life had been worth, if I had been dicover'd; but going for a Merchant of Leige, I lodg'd in a private treet, and feigning my elf ick aoon as I came into my Lodgings, I told my Landlord, I had a Letter of great conequence to be deliver'd to the Count de Marcin; I wrought o well with my Hot, that he offer'd me freely to go and carry it to him for me. I charg'd him to deliver it to his own hands, which he carefully perform'd. The Count de Marcin, who gueing at the thing, carry'd on the diguie, bad him take care of me, and that if I wanted for any thing, he hould tell me, I
hould not cruple ending to him; that he could not come to ee me till the next day, becaue he was jut taking Hore to ride out of Town, but that he would be with me at Eight a Clock in the morning without fail. My Landlord, coming back with this good news, did not quetion but I was at home, but I had poted my elf in Ambucade, about ten or a dozen doors off to ee, if intead of an anwer, he did not bring a Party of Souldiers with him to apprehend me; and I tay'd out upon the cout, at leat an hour after I aw him come back; but finding the coat was clear I return'd home; he askt me whence I came, who he had left in no condition to go out, and if I intended to increae my illnes. I told him, that I had a mind to be at the Mas, tho I was o weak, I was hardly able to get back again. This dicoure being over, he told me what Monieur de Marcin had aid to him, which I was overjoy'd to hear, hoping that ince he had lent an ear to the beginning of my me • ge, ome good iue might probably be made of it. I waited that night with great impatience, and Monieur de Marcin being come at the hour appointed, he ask'd me what Propoals I had to make to him, and what Credentials I could how to atisfy him, if he hould treat with me. I told him for that matter I had ufficient; and not to give him any reaon to doubt it, I how'd him my Letters from the Cardinal. He told me this was omething indeed, but it was not enough however; that I ought to have had a Letter of Credence from the King himelf; that tho the Cardinal did govern the Kingdom as Chief Miniter, yet he diengag'd himelf oftentimes from very trict Obligations and Treaties, on pretence that the King did not approve of them; and that this was his method,
only to try people how they were affected, or to make them upected to their own Party; but however I might tell him, what advantages they propos'd to him; that if they were uch as he hould think worth while to conider of, I might then return and get a larger Commiion; and if not, that then 'twould be needles to give me o much trouble. He had ome reaon indeed in the bottom for what he aid of the Cardinal; for he had everal times in that manner, hifted his head out of entangling Caes, while the Civil Wars lated: As for example, in the Cae between the Prince of Conde and the City of Paris, where he render'd the Prince upected by the Pariians; who doubting the Prince would not perform his Engagements, he broke off everal times with him, when the Prince of Conde thought all things were concluded of: However, being deir'd to declare my elf, I told Monieur de Marcin, that if he would quit the Interets of the Prince, and break off his Treaties with the Spaniards, the King hould give him fifty thouand Crowns in Money, a Government of a Province in the Heart of the Kingdom, with an aurance of being made a Knight of the Order at the firt Promotion. I had everal other offers to make to him, but I was like our Shopkeepers, who never how the bet of their Commodities till the lat. I conceal'd what I had more to ay, till I had heard him peak, t • at I might know what his intention was. He told me the Cardinal banter'd him ure, to make him uch offers as thee at this time of day, for he had offer'd him more than all this long ago; that either he mut beleive him to be extreamly outrag'd at the Prince of Conde, or that he was reduc'd to great neceity, to fancy he was to be tempted
with uch a little matter as this was; that he did not offer him half the value of the los he had receiv'd in his own Etate in France; that this was far from making amends for the ill treatment he had met withal; that if he had quitted Catalonia, in a time when his preence was mot neceary there, the Cardinal ought only to blame himelf for it; for that after having put him in Prion, at the ame time when the Prince de Conde, the Prince de Conti, and the Duke de Longeville had been apprehended, tho he had never been concern'd in any thing, that might give the leat caue of upicion; he ought to have kept his Orders more ecret, which he had given to treat him in a different manner from them, after the Prince de Conde was gone out of the Kingdom; that there was nothing which a man would not venture upon to gain his Liberty, and that he remembred every day what the los of his had cot him; that he was fain to purchae his Ecape, at the price of throwing himelf out at Window, from the top of a Houe, which broke one of his Legs, and that to avoid the like treatment, there was nothing o acred in the world, that he would not violate; that the Cardinal hould not then accue him, as he did every day, of the blacket crimes that ever were committed; that if there was any one could be tax'd with uch crimes, 'twas he who had caus'd him to be apprehended, once already, without caue, and would have done it a econd time, if he had not taken care to prevent him; that bare upicion ought not to be ufficient ground, to ue extremities with men of Honety and Honour; but they hould have plain Matter of Fact to charge and prove upon them. He made a long Oration of this ort, full of complaints, too many to be
incerted here; and I would not interrupt him, becaue I knew, that when a man has dicharg'd his paion, he is the more tractable to an accommodation. In the mean time, finding that he began to be cool, I told him, that I did not pretend to jutify the Cardinal, but that I would tell him this, tho by the by, that a man who is in uch a Pot as his Eminence, is often at a los, and that too much confidence would have ruin'd him; and that 'tis the contant Maxim of Politicians, to ecure always the perons of them whom they upect, and then to examine whether they were guilty or no; and that if he had been in his place, he would have done no les himelf: That his falling in o violently with the Prince of Conde, was what the Cardinal could not be pleas'd with, who aw that Prince, in the deigns laid for his ruin, uffer'd himelf to be carry'd to all manner of extremities; that 'twas too late to recall thoe things now, therefore 'twas better to drown the remembrance of them in a hearty reconciliation, which he might make very much to his advantage; that ince the Offers I had made him were not atisfactory, I begg'd him to tell me what it was he expected, and that I would ue my endeavours with the Cardinal, that he hould have full content. He told me that he would think of it, and that this Convera • ion having already been too long, and the Spaniards being naturally jealous, to take away from them all caue of upicion, he would not come to me any more there, but pray'd me to go to Liege, and to come to him to his Catle de Modave, where he would be in eight days time: but he could not tell what I would do to pas thro the Spanih Towns upon the Road, which I could not avoid; that he would have given me a Pas-port
himelf, if the Prince de Conde had been abent; but as it belong'd to him, he durt not encroach upon his authority, and that it might do me more harm than good if it hould be dicover'd; that 'twould be better for me to apply my elf to the Governour's Secretary, as if I was of Liege; that thoe ort of People would do any thing for money, without much troubling themelves to examine into it. I thankt him for his Counel, but I had no occaion to make ue of it; for that I was provided with all thoe things before I came to Bruels; and intead of coming by the great Paris Road, I came down the Meue in a Luggage Boat, which had a Pas-port for Liege. The Marechal de Fubert who was Governour of Sedan, having notice from the Cardinal, that I went from him about affairs of Conequence, had intructed the Mater of the Boat, and that I might pas afely at Charlemont and Namur, I diguis'd my elf and went for one of his Boys; at Liege I was directed to a man the Cardinal employ'd there for a Spy, and he got me a Pas-port under the name of a Burgher of that Town, o that having nothing to fear I went not from Bruels till the day before I was to be at Modave: I lay that Night at Lovain, and leaving Loo on the left hand, I went on and enter'd into the Country of Liege about a League further. I tay'd ix days in the chief Town thereabout for News of Monieur de Marcin, for the Country People, who came every day into the Town, would preently have brought the News if he was come home; at lat undertanding that ome of the Servants that he ent before him were come, I went away and met him there the very day he arriv'd: I was diguis'd like a Maon, as was agreed on before, between him and I, for uch people were not
upected coming to him, becaue he was a great lover of Building, o that there was no notice taken, tho we were lock'd up together for a great while: he knew me as oon as he aw me, and asking me if I had brought him the Draught that I had promis'd him, I anwer'd him yes, and taking a Paper out of my Pocket I made as if I would give it him, but he bid me keep it; and when he had view'd a thing, which he was treating with ome Workmen about, we hould then go into his Cloet and dicoure of it.

To avoid all upicion, when he aw me at a ditance that I could not hear him, he aid to them near him, that he did not believe I could do his buines; that I came on purpoe from Cologne; but that he had been told by ome people that I was not uch an Artit as I pretended. He told me all this a few Minutes after, and how well it had taken; that ome of the Workmen had envy'd me, becaue they thought I came to take the work out of their hands; at lat h • ving taken everal turns, and done ome little buines about the Houe he took me into his Cloet with him where I askt him for an Anwer, to what I concluded my lat dicoure with: He told me, that was eaie to do, and o going on with it, explain'd himelf upon the matter: That they hould make him Marechal of France, Governour of a Province, Knight of the Order at the firt promotion, General of the Army either in Italy or Catalonia, and hould pay him two hundred thouand Crowns in Money. Thee demands being o extravagant, I was amaz'd; however, as my Intructions reach'd further than I had yet dicover'd to him; I told him, I had wrote to the Cardinal about it, ince I had the honour to ee him, and had receiv'd this anwer: That intead of the Government of a Province, he hould be made
a Marechal of France, which he did not quetion would pleae him better; and that he hould receive one hundred thouand Crowns in ready Money, and withal that he hould be aur'd of the dignity of the Order, whenever there was a vacancy: he was in a rage at this, and asking me if the Cardinal made no difference between him, and the Marechal de Fouca • t, to whom beides that dignity, they had given fifty thouand Lovis Dor's. I told him yes, I believ'd they did, but that he was not mater of a trong place as 'tother was, when he took the opportunity of making uch a bargain for himelf; and that when the Cardinal granted him thoe Conditions, 'twas becaue he aw plainly 'twould cot much more to recover uch a place out of his hands; that regard mut be had to the Circumtances, and all things were to be conider'd; that he was but a private Captain among the Spaniards, and could not do them much more hurt than the Prince of Conde would do without him, who was left till behind.

I aid a great many uch things to perwade him, but he would not abate a jot of his demands; upon which I deir'd him to give it me in writing, that I might how it to the Cardinal, to whom I was reolv'd to return. I meant honetly; nor did I intend any thing but to jutify my elf to his Eminence, that I had done my bet; who knowing o well what had happen'd between Monieur de Marcin and the Prince of Conde, made no doubt but I hould ucceed in my deign; and therefore order'd me not to come up to the offer of a hundred thouand Crowns, but with a great deal of difficulty; o that I doubted he might blame me for mimanagement, and I was willing to have omething to clear my elf: But Monieur de Marcin, taking it quite otherwie, roe up in
a rage, and told me, he could find in his heart to acrifice me that moment to his jut reentment: For what did I ee in his face to propoe uch a thing to him; and if this was the Cardinals method, to involve a man in Negotiotions on purpoe to dicover it to his own Party, he hould have a care of him; that if he hould have been uch a Fool to give it under his own hand, he made no quetion but they would take care to have it publih'd both in Spain and at Bruels, and at all the Confederate Towns in Europe; that he perceiv'd I was only ent to ruin the confidence that had been put in him by the Spaniards; that however, he would be o generous as to let me go, provided I went about my buines immediately, for he had nothing more to ay to me. I was quite confounded with the Paion he was in at me; however, commanding my elf, I let him go on without any interruption, and finding that his fury was over, I told him, that if the Cardinal had any uch deign, 'twas more than I knew; but for my elf I could give him an account of mine, and I would ingeniouly tell him the reaon why I made uch a propoal to him. That I had to do with a Peron that was very difficult, and that expected every thing hould come to pas to his own fancy; that I had een him o prepoet with an opinion, that my negotiations could not fail, that I was very careful to atisfy him at my return, that I had done my bet; that I acknowledg'd to him, that I was to blame to make him uch a Propoal, having not the honour to be known to him, and the deire I had to ee him return into France, where his merit would meet with another ort of recompence than what he found from the Spaniard, made me willing to give him an unuual atisfaction, which I would do by howing him my
Intructions which I had kept by me, tho I run the greatet danger in the World, if it hould be found out.

This dicoure cool'd him a little, but not at all prevail'd with him to leen his demands; o eeing there was no good to be done with him, I took my leave, and came back to France, by the ame way that I went; and being arriv'd at Charleville, I was forc'd to tay for a Convoy to go as far as Rhetel, for the Prince De Conde who held Rocroy, and Montal, who was Governour of it, made uch excurions as hindred the Communications between thoe Towns. The Duke De Normouteir who was Governour of Charleville, and to whom I was particularly known, askt me were I had been; but having no order to communicate to him any of my Buines, I told him, I came from the Spaw, where I had been ordered by the Phiicians to go to drink the Waters: He took this for an Anwer, and having ent out his Cavalry into the Country of Luxembourg for a Military execution, the People having refued to pay their Contributions, I was oblig'd to attend till their return; and there being a great many other people, who waited as well as I, he granted us a Convoy of the firt that arriv'd, but we were but little the afer for them, for they were but thirty Troopers, and thoe o fatigu'd with the duty they had been upon, that both Hore and Man were ready to fall every tep they took: If the ret of the Company would have been rul'd by me, we would not have taid for them at all, for we were enough of us to have ventur'd; but the majority was againt me, and over-rul'd me, whether I would or no: which we had all of us caue enough to repent of. In hort, Montal, the Governour
of Rocroy for the Prince de Conde, knowing well enough that there was a great many people waited for the return of the Convoy, et one to give him an account what time they came back, and beet the ways with everal parties; o 'twould have been a miracle if we had ecap'd them. When we were come within a mile and half of Pierre-Pont, the Enemy, who were hid in a Wood, dicover'd us; and having divided themelves into two Bodies, one attackt us in the Front, and the other in the Flank; our Guard made but little reitance, and would have run away if they could, but their Hores, as I aid, being harras'd, they were taken immediately; for us, we made a body by our elves, and made a how to defend our elves, and at the firt charge we kill'd two of their Officers; but being overpowr'd by numbers, we were forc'd to eek our afety from the wiftnes of our Hores; and o made away to get back to Charleville. In the mean time, having oberv'd, that the Dragoons had gotten before us, and had poted themelves in a Defile, by which we mut of neceity pas, I got into a Wood, and tho I was peru'd by three Horemen yet I lot them, and coming out on the other ide I aw no body appear, which made me conclude I was out of danger; and I travell'd two Leagues without any oppoition, and was jut rejoycing to my elf that I had ecap'd, when four Horemen very well mounted dicover'd me; and one of them coming up to me with the uual quetion of Qui vive, or who are you for? I had no ooner anwer'd, Vive France, but he bid me urrender my elf, or I was a dead man: In the mean time, the other, who were coming towards me, and were not above ten paces off, rendring it impoible for me
to ecape them, I was oblig'd to give place to my ill fortune, and to yield my elf their Prioner; o I was carry'd into a Neighbouring Wood where the ret of the Troop lay in Ambucade; and he that commanded them, having ask'd who I was, and whence I came: I told him that I was a Frenchman, and that I came from Charleville. It happen'd that this was a Gentleman that liv'd but two Leagues from my Fathers, o making my elf known to him, he would not uffer me to be earcht, or any way roughly dealt with, but us'd me very civilly.

I taid there with him till Evening that they broke up their Ambucade, which I thought very trange, knowing 'twas not cutomary to do o till Sun rie: But he told me 'twould ignify nothing to tay there any longer, for they only waited for any Perons they could find that had got away from the others;
• ut ince they had met with no body but me, 'twas very probable the ret were all taken; and indeed o it prov'd for I found them all got to Rocroy before me, which was ome Comfort to me in my Affliction; yet till I mut ay, that I was better treated than any of them, for there was not one of them but had lot his Money, whereas I kept mine, of which, to my great comfort, I was very well provided. In the mean time I was in great perplexity, whether I hould end to the Cardinal or no; for on one hand I conider'd if I did o, he might perhaps get me out, but then on the other hand my applying my elf to the firt Miniter of State, might give them caue to upect, I was not the Peron I pretended to be; for I had told Monieur de Montal that I was a Lieutenant of Foot in the Regiment of Grancy; of which Regiment I was throughly acquainted with all the Officers; Inomuch that when he quetion'd me, I
gave him an exact account of the State of the whole Regiment: At lat, having well conider'd what I had to do, I thought 'twas bet to let it alone, and to dicover my elf to the firt peron that hould get his liberty upon Parol, or till the general exchange of Prioners, which was expected would not be long; I had alo another reerve, which was ince I had Money, to offer my ranom, but Monieur de Montal would not accept of it, o I found my elf frutrated of that deign. Tho we were not far from the Capital City of the Kingdom, where every one generally has ome acquaintance, yet 'twas not to be imagin'd, how few there was that receiv'd any aitance from their friends; I could not however ee o many worthy Gentlemen uffer, without haring with them omething of what I had left, which uneaonable bounty oon hew'd me the bottom of my Pure; but till I comforted my elf, that I had half a years Arrears due to me at Lyons; but when the time was come, the quetion how I hould endore a Receipt on the back of the Order was another perplexity, and I mut ign my own name, which I had conceal'd from Monieur de Montal, and call'd my elf by the name of one of the Lieutenants of Grancy; o becaue I would not expoe my elf to appear a Lier, I choe to continue in that miery, which I had begun to be enible of ince my Money had fail'd me. In the mean time, many of thoe to whom I had • ent my Money, having received recruits from their friends, conceal'd it from me, for fear they hould be askt to repay me, and I that aited every body, was deerted in uch a manner, that my condition was mierable beyond expreion. I was oblig'd to live above three months upon the Basket; and to compleat my misfortune, my Linnen was
tolen from me, and I had but one Shirt and one Crevat left me in the whole world, o that I was fain to lie a bed all day to have it waht; for my part, when I call to mind how 'twas with me at that time, I cannot imagin how I was able to bear it; and above all to find thoe whom I had aited in their ditres, hun me as if I had the Plague, tho they knew in their own Conciences, that I had never been reduc'd to this condition, but for my compaion to them. All this while there was no appearance of the General Exchange, which we had o long lookt for, altho the Campagne was ready to begin; that was all the news that I enquir'd after, for I was, jut as it were, inking under my mieries, my Cloaths, and epecially my Shirt, hung all in rags; and for Beer or Wine I had almot forgot the tate of them. In hort, I, who had compaion of every body, found all the world cold and indifferent to me, they would wih me better fortune indeed, but no body would do any thing to procure it.

'Tis eay to judge, that my mind was perplext under all this affliction almot to ditraction, and was a thouand times jut upon the point of dicovering my elf to Monieur de Montal, chooing rather to dye at once, than to linger out my life by little and little; however reolving with my elf to have a little more patience, at lat the Exchange o long wiht for arriv'd, but 'twas no help to me, for the Marechal de Grancy having given in the names of the Officers of his Regiment who were Prioners, left my name out, as he very well might, for that he whoe true name it was, remain'd with the body; o I had the unhappines to ee all my fellow Prioners go free, and my elf left behind. I remain'd o
overwhelm'd with trouble, that Nature it elf unk under it, and I fell into a Fever which held me two months at leat, and being carry'd to the Hopital, all my hopes depended upon an Officer of Picardy, whom I thought to be an honet man, and to whom I had dicover'd my elf; I had deir'd two things of him before he went away, one was that he would convey a Letter for me which I had writ to the Cardinal, in which I had given him an account of the ad accident that had befallen me; the other was to end me the half years revenue that was due to me of my rent at Lyons, which I dei • 'd him to receive, and to that end gave him a Blank Receipt igned with my hand, for the Pay-mater to fill up as uual in that cae; but intead of doing me this kindnes, he not only run away with my Money, but was o barbarous as to keep my Letter which I had written to the Cardinal. I waited with impatience for an anwer from him, and from his Eminence, but I heard from both of them alike; yet I was uch a credulous Coxcomb as to flatter my elf for three months, that there was ome extraordinary thing had fallen out to hinder him; at lat, eeing I was foraken both of Heaven and Earth, if I may dare to peak o, my depair was o great, that I was ready to lay violent hands upon my elf; in the mean time I relaps'd into my ditemper, and was come to that extremity, that they began to tell me I ought to think of ettling my Concience; I askt then for a Confeor, and having, as it happened, fallen into the hands of an honet man, I made him my Confident in ome part of my orrows; I told him of the fale name I had taken up, and how it depriv'd me of that relief which otherwie I might have had. I durt not tell him any more, let out of
a fale zeal he hould reveal my Confeion. The good man, after he had given me what Conolation he could, offer'd himelf very freely, to go for me to Paris; and having gladly accepted his pro •• er, I gave him a Blank ign'd, as I had done the Officer of Picardy, that he might receive whatever there was due to me from Lyons; I did not tell him how much, for I was afraid that Officer had p • aid me ome nick, and indeed he found that he had receiv'd five hundred Crowns, which he was gone away with, but there being by this time another half year due, he brought me likewie the like um of five hundred Crowns, excepting a mall matter for the Charges of his Journey. If I durt have truted him, as I aid, with my affair to the Cardinal, he would without doubt have acquitted himelf honetly, ince he was a Frenchman both by Birth and Inclination; but Providence having order'd things otherwie, I reolv'd with my elf, being reliev'd from that horrible neceity I was in, to have a little longer patience, and the rather, becaue they began now to talk of the General Peace, which the Spaniards, who had always rejected it, eem'd now more inclinable to, ince the ill ucces they had in the lat Campagnes; but it all depended upon this Summers Expediti • n, and if the Spaniards hould happen to beat us, all our hopes would be lot again. The Kings Army was commanded by the Vicount de Turenne, who had with him join'd in Commiion the Marechal de la Ferte, but the latter uff • ing himelf to be beaten by an overight before Valenciennes, the Vicount de Turenne manag'd it o, that he had no longer a Collegue, and affairs were never the wore for it; for before, the Jealouy which aroe between thee two, ruin'd the bet of their deigns, but now thoe
diorders being prevented, we got the better of the Enemy on all ides; but as we could not be atisfy'd with any Conquets, till we had added that of Dunkirk, which nevertheles was to be deliver'd up to the Englih, by virtue of a Treaty with them, the Vicount de Turenne marcht thither with his Army. Monieur de Montal, who apprehended nothing o much as a Peace, aid openly, that it all depended upon the ucces of this Enterprize; and I, aoon as I heard how it was, pray'd heartily it might come to pas, as I had reaon to do, for I aw plainly enough, that this was the only hope I had left for the recovery of my liberty; but the place being of the greatet conequence to both Parties, the Spaniards were not les vigilant in the defence of it, than we were vigorous in our attacks; and they who had always before hun'd giving Battle with a great deal of caution, now drew all their Forces together into the Field, and the Prince of Conde having join'd them with his Forces, advanc'd together within Cannon-hot of our Trenches. The Vicount de Turenne, who did not expect to take uch a place as this without blows, had dipos'd all things for their reception, like a great Souldier; and the Enemy knowing who they had to deal with, reolv'd to make a dicovery of his Lines, before they advanced any further. Don Juan of Autria, who commanded the Spaniards, would trut no body for this ervice, but advanc'd himelf with the Prince of Conde to take the view; and the Marechal de Hoquincourt who was with them, having with more courage than wit, adventur'd too far before the ret, was kill'd with a Muquet-hot; this made the ret retire, but did not put by their deign of attacking
us in our Trenches. The Vicount de Turenne having notice of this by his Scouts, was reolv'd to be before-hand with them, and coming boldly out of his Trenches drew up in a poture to receive them; he did not tand to encourage them by amuing them with a long Speech, but riding thro the Ranks to ee that all things were in order, he how'd a countenance o full of aurance, that put uch an opinion into the minds of his Souldiers, as was a good Omen of a certain Victory.

If I had been in this Engagement my elf 'twould have pleas'd me to have given you the particulars, the account being o much to our advantage, but I know too well the errors they are ubject to, who write of uch things from the mouths of others, and hall therefore, to avoid the ame mitakes, content my elf with telling you in general, that the Vicount de Turenne having broken the whole body of the Enemies Army, at down immediately before Dunkirk, which he oblig'd in a few days to capitulate; and from thence he march'd his Army along the Sea Coat, and took in all the mall Towns thereabouts, for having gain'd o great a Battle, and taken o trong a Town in o hort a time, they thought there was no reiting him; and he would have over-run all Flanders, if the Spaniards had not taken their meaures very peedily to obtain a Peace. I was too much concern'd in the iue of thee affairs, not to be very inquiitive about them, my Liberty depending upon them; and therefore I was always teazing my friend the Eccleiatick to end me word how things went: Firt, he ent me word of the Battle, and how the ucces of that put the Spaniards upon uing their utmot endeavours for a Peace; this overjoy'd me, but I waited in expectation
eighteen months longer before 'twas brought to perfection. I can't imagine what the Cardinal thought of me all that while, for 'twas three years before he had any news of me. Without quetion he tho ••• I was dead, or ele I hould have let him know what was become of me, but being always in hopes of getting out, I defer • 'd writing to him from one day to another till at lat 'twas o long, I thought 'twas to no purpoe to write at all; I was blam'd for it by many, but I think with very little reaon, conidering my circumtances.

At lat the happy hour arriv'd, the General Peace was made, and I was deliver'd: aoon as ever I got out I went to wait on the Cardinal, whom I found at Vincennes; he took me for an Apparition at firt, but recovering his urprize, he askt me whence I came, and how I had the Impudence to ee his face, after I had erv'd him o. I told him, I thought I had reaon enough, conidering what had befallen me, and I would make himelf my Judge, if he would pleae to give me a hearing; I told him then the reaons that prevented my writing, and repeated the particulars I have jut now related; he made light of it, and hrinking up his houlders, as if he thought me craz'd, he told me for anwer, he was orry for me, but if I talkt at that rate, God help me, he thought the bet he could do for me, was to end me to theBedlam. Petites Maion • . I was mad indeed at this dicoure, and o candaliz'd at it I was, that I went out all in a rage, and meeting with la Cordonniere, who is now Lieutenant General, but then belong'd to him, I told him, that his Mater was o haughty with his good fortune, that 'twas intollerable; that 'twas all one to him who he affronted, and a Gentleman
hould have no better uage from him than a Slave, but I hop't the time would come, that I hould revenge my elf of him for the language he had given me. I thought I had poken this to one of my friends, when I aid it to la Cordonniere, who I had oblig'd, and lent him Money everal times, when he was but a mean fellow, and wanted it enough; but forgetting all thoe obligations, I had no ooner opened my mind to him with all this freedom, but he began to take his Maters part, and one word bringing in another, we both drew, and were both of us wounded, and if we had not been parted by the Marquis de Rennel, we had not left off without ome michief or other; and it being impoible for us to proecute the heat after this dicovery, we went off each of us as our occaions directed: Mine was to hide my elf, the Cardinal having publickly worn, if ever I fell into his hands, I hould come horter by the head. I made my retreat into a Convent, the Prior whereof was my true friend; while la Cardonniere was viited by a crowd of the Grandees, who to make their Court to the Cardinal, could ubmit to any mean Recal that had but his favour. This affair of mine making a great noie in Paris, the Religious where I was began to be afraid of me, which the Prior perceiving, was fain to give out, that I was deirous of taking the Habit, and to that purpoe was to pas the Probation; o he directed me to go every night to the Office, and to make great hew of my Devotion, for being to ave the life of a friend, he made no cruple to make ue of any tratagem to effect it. 'Tis not for me to dipute whether he did well or ill in it; I am ure the obligation's mine, for without his aitance I had run a great rique of a Scaffold; for the Cardinal, who
was a true Italian, revengeful as the Devil, when he could not come at my body eiz'd my rent, and had reduc'd me to a very mierable condition, if my friend the Prior had not tuck cloe to me; but he differ'd in that, epecially from his Brethren of the Order, who tudy nothing but their own interet, for the more mierable he aw me, the more he trove to comfort me; for my part I knew not what to think of my elf, but in my opinion it was my evil detiny rather than any fault of mine: I made a trict examination of my elf, as if I had been to make my own Proces, but whether elf love was predominant in me, or that indeed I was rather unhappy than guilty, I could find no atisfactory reaon to condemn my elf.

I tay'd in this Convent till the Death of the Cardinal, which tho it happen'd quickly after, yet 'twas not ooner than I deir'd, for as godly as I was grown, I could not heartily wih well to a man that had done me o much injury, and who, after he had been the caue of my lying three years in Prion, oblig'd me now to another Confinement, in a place not one jot more agreeable to me than the place I came out of; if I had been any thing eriouly dipos'd, I had certainly become a Religious, and I oftentimes ecretly wiht, Heaven would have given me the Grace to attempt it; but being not cut out for that Vocation, I was fain to have Patience with all my Fury. The Count de Charoft whom I have formerly mentioned, and who was pleas'd till to retain a kindnes for me, poke to the King in my favour before I drut appear, and having given him an account of my adventure, of which his Majety was wholly ignorant, he was pleas'd with a great deal of goodnes to give me his Pardon, provided the Scuffle I had
had with la Cardonniere could not be prov'd to be a Duel; for he had olemnly wore at his Coronation upon the holy Evangelits, that he would never pardon any one that was guilty of that crime, an Oath which we ee he hath never yet dipens'd with; and if we may judge by what happen'd oon after I ecap'd, we may conclude he never will; I mean the affair of Meieurs de la Frette, and of Monieur de Chalais, in which I was very happy that I was not engag'd, as you will ee by the following tory.

You mut undertand, that about a fortnight or three weeks before, I happen'd to be playing at Tennis with a Gentleman of Poictou, call'd la Verie an Officer of the Guard; we play'd at the Tennis Court in la Rue de Vangirard, near Luxembourg; there was a great many better Tennis Courts in Paris than that, but we went thither, becaue our Lodgings being both near it, we had the convenience of going in our Morning Gowns; we plaid everal Games, and when we were jut a going to give over, the Chevalier de la Frette came in, and tanding by the Ball Basket, as if he had a mind to quarrel, began to tos the Balls into the lower Hazard of the Tennis Court. La Verie lot the Game, and being a little out of humour upon it, becaue at that time we did not play by the Set, but paid for the Balls we hould looe, deir'd him, that he would pleae to divert himelf with omething ele; I know not whether he poke it urlily or not, or whether the Chevelier de la Frette, who to ay the truth was a ort of a Bully, took it for an affront on purpoe to make a broil, but without any more ado he takes the whole Baket up, and throws the Balls all about the Tennis Court, this occaion'd ome hot words between them, and the Chevelier de la Frette was in uch a
rage, that not conidering that the other was not only without a Sword, but as a man may ay, quite naked, he drew and made a pas at him: The People that tood by ran in between them, and prevented him doing any michief, o we left off the Play, and went into the dreing-room to put on our Cloths. There was no Gentlemen there o that having parted us, they apprehended nothing of any further michief, and we went away without any notice being taken. La Verie told me, if he was ruin'd by it, he would have atisfaction. I durt not diwade him, tho 'twas againt my judgment, let he hould think 'twas for want of Courage, and o I, that was but jut got out of one nare, fell into an other, that was ten times more dangerous. I was fain to be the Meenger to go and carry the Challenge to the Chevalier, who liv'd in the ame treet, at a great Houe, now belonging to the Duke d' Elbeuf. I had nothing to do to make him a long Compliment: He told me preently he knew my buines, and preventing me told me, that we mut get another man; for that two of his Friends who had heard of the quarrel, had made him promie that he would not engage without them: Upon this we went to ee if we could find the Count de Beaumont, younget Son of the Marquis d' Entragues, who has ince taken upon him the Title of Marquis d' Illiers, and was made under Lieutenant in the Light Hore of the Guards, and lot his life at the battle of Seneff. But happy enough for him, we could not find him; but as we • ought for him at his Fathers houe, L' Hotel d' Entragues, we met with a Gentleman who was his Neighbour in the Country, one Chilvant, who made up our Party; o we fought behind the Convent of the Carmelites, where I was
wounded, and our ide had the wort of the day, but no body was kill'd. We every one hifted for our elves, knowing we were lot men if we were dicoverd'; but as good luck would have it the thing was never known: La Verie return'd to his Pot as if nothing had been done, and none of us had the leat diturbance about it. For my part, I had taken anctuary at the Marquis de Noirmoutier, Eldet Son to the Governour of Charleville, of whom I made mention before, but he oon inform'd me there was no need to be afraid, o I appear'd again too as well as the others.

About a fortnight or three weeks after this, as I hinted before, happen'd the quarrel of the Meieurs de la Frette, which did not come off o well: The Eldet was at a Ball at the Palace Royal, where was a great appearance of Courtiers: when all was over and every one preparing to go out, this de la Frette who reented omething from Monieur de Chalais, about a Mitres, and had a mind to let him know it, rudely jutled him everal times as he went out. Monieur de Chalais looking about to ee who jutled him, preently knew la Frette, and gave him ome words about it that were diobliging enough. If they had had Swords there would have been ome diorder about it in the Palace, tho that was a very improper place to quarrel in, but every one being dret for the Ball, la Frette would take no notice of it there, but waited without for him to demand atisfaction. They oon agreed upon it, to fight three to three, and fixt the place, where they hould meet the next day, it being too late for that night. This was in too publick a place to quarrel, and make a ecret of it; the King was made acquainted with it, and immediately ent away the Chevelier de St. Agnan,
to tell Monieur de la Frette, that he poitively forbid him fighting, and that if he hould dare to do it, he hould certainly dye for it. St. Agnan, who was his Couin German, found him out preently, and made him this compliment. De la Frette told him, that he hop'd he had more regard to his honour than to make him forfeit his word; that the hour was at hand, and 'twas in vain to think of diappointing them; and beides being his Friend too, he hould rather expect, that he would make one in their number, and that they would end to Chalais to provide himelf with another man. The Chevalier de St. Agnan, never conidering that he was ent by the King with o evere a meage to prevent it, nor how trictly all orts of Duels were forbid, rahly embarques in an affair, which he could never hope to get clear of; and join'd with them in it, o they immediately ent to Chalais to provide a fourth man. The Marquis de Noirmoutier his Brother-in-law, who was already engag'd, knowing of the affair I had lately had with the Chevalier de la Frette, immediately thought upon me, and ent about to look for me; but very happily for me, I was engag'd that night at play at a Friends houe; and tho it is not the cutom at Paris, upon any occaion, to tay from ones Lodging, yet it being very late, and that the treets were at that time very full of Rogues, I was oblig'd to take a Bed with them. This odd tep av'd me from all the michiefs of this affair, and was the only time that I could ay, I was oblig'd to fortune for my deliverance; and that tho he had always crot my advancement, yet he had not reolv'd my ruine. The eight Gentlemen who fought, were the Chevalier de la Frette, Ovarti his Brother, ince called by the name of d' Amilly, and is
now Lieutenant in the Guards, the Chevalier de St. Agnan and the Marquis de Flammarin, on the one ide. The Prince de Chalais, the Marquis de Noirmoustier, the Marquis d' Antin, Brother to Monieur de Montepan, and the Vicount de Argenliece on the other. The ucces of the buines was not fatal, only to the Marquis d' Antin, who was kill'd upon the pot; but the ret got off cheaper, yet their condition was bad enough. The King was in a great rage when he heard of it, but above all at the Chevalier de St. Agnan, who indeed was more to blame than all of them. In the mean time their danger was equal, there was a neceity for them to think of getting out of the Kingdom, and that very privately too; for the King had given evere orders at all the Ports, and all the Paes on the Confines to top them. However they got off, ome into Spain, ome into Portugal, ome one way, and ome another, as their own good fortune guided them. But as whatever a man enjoys in a foreign Country has a ort of banihment in it, while he is kept out of his own; o with all the joy of their ecape, they had every one time to repent of his folly: No body pittied the Chevalier de Agnan, all the world aid he had no more than he deerv'd; the Brothers de la Frette were as little as he, for they were o very quarrelom upon every light occaion, that they were very well compar'd to a vicious Hore, that will let no other Hore come into the Stable. For the ret, every body was concern'd for them, and would have been very glad, if it had been poible, that the King would have a little wink'd at it on their accounts: Indeed they were all very honet Gentlemen, and deerv'd better fortune; but not one peron durt peak to the King for them, and tho the Duke de
Agnan was very near to his Peron, yet he was one of the firt that told to the King, his Sons Crime was of a nature too gros to be forgiven, and that if he knew where he was, he would be the firt hould bring him to jutice; that therefore he would not trouble his head to ask any • avour for him, and he believ'd that all People would be of his mind. This was a dicoure well enough for a Court Paraite, that uited all he aid to the temper of his Prince, but very ill became a Father, who at leat ought to have extenuated the Crime of his Son, not agravated it. The Relations of the Meieurs de la Frette took other Meaures. If they durt not expoe themelves to peak to the King, they et all their wits at work to prevail with him: The Dutches de Cha • lnes, whoe Husband was Ambaador at Rome, oblidg'd him to peak to the Pope; and tho the Holy Father at the ame time ought to jutify the Kings everity in thee matters, yet that did not hinder him from promiing his aitance in this occaion. In hort, having a Legate reiding at Paris, on ome Affairs needles for me to repeat, he order'd him to peak to the King in his name on their behalf: The Dutches could not have employ'd any whoe Interet was more likely to prevail, the Pope having power to dipence with the Oath, which 'twas uppos'd was the chief caue, that made the King o inflexible to all orts of Application. But he anwer'd the Legate, that he hould be glad to oblige his Holines in any thing, but that in this his hands were ty'd, and that none but God himelf could dicharge him of an Oath o olemnly taken: Not that he call'd in quetion the Authority of the Holy See, but that 'twas for the Honour of God who made him a King, that he hould be a Prince of his word,
and he did not quetion but the Pope himelf would forbear preing him any farther, if he pleas'd but to conider the conequence of it.

The People ador'd the King when they came to know the anwer he had made the Pope; and his Holines himelf, who indeed concern'd himelf in it, but at the Importunity of the Duke de Chaulnes was overjoy'd at the contancy of the King; and if one may credit what I heard from a Peron of Quality ecretly, thankt the King for the refual: On the other hand, the Duke de St. Agnan coming to be in extraordinary Favour oon after, no body doubted but he would employ it in behalf of his Son, but he was very cautious; whether 'twas that he aw it would be to no purpoe, or as others thought, that he was without natural affections.

This affair having made a great noie, as it is generally with things at firt, People began now to forget it, another publick accident happening to divert their dicoure. Monieur Fouquet Superintendant of the Finances was eiz'd and committed to Prion; indeed he had uch powerful Enemies that 'twas a miracle how he ecap'd the Scaffold. About the time he was Arreted they gave out everal things againt him to render him more odious to the People; but I owe this Tetimony to the Truth, to ay that many of them were really fale, which I can more eaily jutify, than ay that I had not a hand in ome of them my elf. Monieur Fouquet was a man of a large Soul, and a very generous Spirit, and 'twould have appear'd more had he been of any Profeion but of the Long Robe. Cardinal Mazarin had taken an averion to him, for that he being Procurer General to the Parliament, he could not bear to hear the Cardinal reflect upon that great Body, of which
he had the honour to be a principal Member: He had however often told the Cardinal that he would not deny, but there were everal Perons in that Aembly that he could wih were not: But this was not atisfaction enough for an Italian, who made nothing to retain a grudge againt a man all the days of his life, tho being of an effeminate cowardly nature, he durt never dicover his malice, but jut when he was a dying, and then he told the King, that he was a man, who not only profuely wated the publick Treaure, but alo apply'd great ums of it to his private ue; that he lived in greater plendor than the King himelf; that his Houes were finer than the Royal Palaces, both for the Buildings, and the Magnificence of the Furniture; that he gave private Penions to everal perons about the Court, a hrewd ign that he had ome dangerous things in his head; that he had caus'd Belle Ile to be fortify'd, a place which he had bought of the Houe of Gondi, which had the Englih, the antient Enemies of the Kingdom, behind it, With whom, ays the Cardinal, I will not aure your Majesty he doth not hold correpondence; that the only way to prevent uch a michief, was to trike at the root, and to make ure of uch a dangerous man that nevertheles this was to be done very cautiouly, and to be ure not while he was Procurer General, becaue then the Parliament would be his Judges, and he would certainly get off; that therefore he hould take his meaures accordingly, and above all, that it hould be done with uch ecrey, that he might be ure to have no upicion of it.

This was jut at the time of the Cardinal's Death, who that he might hew himelf a true Italian to the lat, ent for this very Monieur Fouquet,
and embrac'd him, calling him one of his bet friends, mentioning to him the many obligations he had receiv'd from him during the Civil Wars, and particularly how he had ent him fifty thouand Crowns, when he was oblig'd to fly, and retire to Leige, which he had not paid him till a long time after: But as this was his manner to wheadle with thoe he had a deign to betray, o his being upon the brink of the next world, did not one jot alter his meaures; for he left the King prepoet with all thoe fine tories he had made of this Miniter. His Majety, who was perfectly form'd for all thoe great things we have ince een him execute, was abolute Mater of his own ecrets, which is one of the mot eential qualities of a great man; and having dicover'd his intentions to no oul but Monieur le Tellier, whoe fidelity he had try'd in too many occaions of the lat moment, to have any caue to upect; and to Monieur Colbert, who the Cardinal had recommended at his death, as a fit peron to manage the Finances, and thee he made exactly perue the method the Cardinal had aid down, which was not to attempt Monieur Fouquet till they had got him out of the Office of Procurer General.

And now, ince we have occaion to peak of this Monienr Colbert, who had been one of the mot profligate wicked fellows of the Age, I'll tell one tory of him, concerning ome buines that happen'd between him and I: It was a great many years ago, and in thoe days he was counted a very honet man. My Siter, whom I told you of, had a great Trial about the birth of her Son, had by her Husband a certain rent charge upon the Hotel de Ville, and the Writings were left in the hands of this Monieur
Colbert's Father, who as every body knows was Paymater of thoe Rents: Her Husband, however it happen'd, knew nothing of it; but my Siter having found a little Memorandum among his Papers after his death, by which it appear'd that he had a demand of five hundred Livres a year on the Townhoue, and in whoe hands the Writings were al • o. I apply'd my •• f to this Monieur Colbert, who I uppo •• d being the eldet Son, had all his Fathers Papers, and p • ke to him about it: 'Twas not a very pleaan •
piece of News to him, who ince he began to come into favour had et up for a man of quality, which appear'd chiefly in his Retinue, epecially after his pretenion to be decended from the Royal Family of Scotland: However, he demanded to ee the Memorandum I mention'd, and I being uch a Coxcomb, as I may well be aham'd to mention, how'd it him; as oon as ever he lookt on it, and py'd this defect in it, that it wanted a Date; knowing that 'twould therefore be very difficult for us to make any proof of the matter; he told me lightly, that he had never heard of the thing before, neverthel • s he would earch among his Papers, and deir'd me to call on him again in about weeks a time. I went to him again at the time appointed, and in the mean time my Siter caus'd the Regiter to be e • rch'd if poibly he might find any thing there to <…> the time. When I came, he told me, he could not yet find any thing; and thus he led me on from <> day to another, for above two months. They that my Siter apply'd to, aid the ame thing to her, o that I began to think there was nothing in it; when there comes a man to me one day, and tol • me, that if my Siter would allow him one half of the rent, he would procure her the Writings: I
told him, I could not give him an anwer, till I had poke with my Siter, becaue I did not k • ow her mind; but if he would let me ee him to morrow I would dicoure with her, and give him a poitive anwer. 'Twas a brisk offer, and I could not imagin who it hould come from unles 'twas from ome of them my Siter had been with, or ele from Monieur Colbert himelf; but I reolv'd to have the man dogg'd when he came again, which was effectually done, and he was found to go directly back to Monieur Colbert's: Tho 'twas but a preumption of mine at bet, yet I found it o probable, that I thought 'twould be no great damage to go again, and peak a l • t • le more poitively to him about it; o I went again, and telling him bluntly I came to know if he had yet found our Writi • gs, he anwer'd me, No. This is bae, aid I, not only to get Peoples effects into your hands, but to keep them by force. Come, come, Sir, continu'd I, don't think to put your tricks upon us, we know well enough that you ent a fell • w to me to make a racally Propoal; I had your Man follow'd, and I'll prove he came in hither beides I have other proofs enough to convict you. Monieur Colbert, amaz'd to hear me talk thus, chang'd colour, but oon recovering himelf, whether that he was u •• d to uch tricks, or that he knew me to be a Man of Hon • u •
and would not ue him ill, and that he had better venture upon my Generoity, reply'd, 'Twas he indeed that had the Writings, ince I would have it o, but not with o much injutice neither as I pre ••• ded, that my Brother-in-laws Father ow'd his ••• her a coniderable um of money, and left this in his hands for his ecurity, as he found in his Regiter. I askt him, if he would how me what he aid and t • at I would be atisfy'd, if I aw it in the Regiter; • e
told me, 'twas not proper to expoe the affairs of his Family to other peoples knowledge, that he was an honet man, and I ought to believe him upon his word.
