This was all the reaon I could ever undertand why the Advocates, to whom my Siter went for advice, directed her to have recoure to the Regiter, and to take out a Duplicate of the firt Deed, which nevertheles could not be, till we had made him wear that he had not the Original: So we caus'd a Summons to be given him, and while we attended the ealing of it, we made them look over all the Regiters of the Hotel de Ville; but the Father and Son, being one as honet as t' other, had alter'd that which only could give us any information of what we lookt for; and our Contract had gone under the names of o many people on one ide, and t' other, that neither his name nor ours was to be een in it: The only refuge we had left, was the Oath he was to take, but our friends having very well oberv'd to us, that he that was Knave enough to cheat us, would alo be Villain enough to forwear himelf, we were advis'd to make up the matter; o we gave him a dicharge for all the Arrears which he had receiv'd under borrowed names, and alo for the year then going on, and o had her Writings deliver'd.

I leave any one to judge, if a man whoe Concience was o well manag'd, could be thought to tick at the upplanting poor Monieur Fouquet, who held a place which he had o great a deire to dipoes him of, and in which he might o eaily rob both the King and the People: So he et all his wits at work to get him out of his place, that he might then attack him as was concluded; and as it
was neceary to find out a pretence for this, they made a fine tory to him, that now he would be o much encumbred with affairs in the Council, the weight of all buines there lying wholly upon him, ince the Cardinal was gone, and not able to ait him, that 'twould be impoible for him to dicharge the buines of the Parliament too, and therefore 'twould be better for him to lay it down; to carry this on, the King how'd himelf kinder and mo • e obliging to him than ever; in • much that the good man being abolutely deceiv'd, fell blindly into the nare, and laid out for a Chapman for his place in the Parliament, which being pat all quetion the bet in the Parliament, there was great truggling amongt the mony'd men who hould have the opportunity to buy it; Monieur de Fieubet bid mot for it, for he offer'd boldly ixteen hundred thouand Franks for it; but Mr. Fouquet choe rather to let Mr. de Harlai, one of his particular friends, have it, tho he got not o much of him by two hundred thouand Franks. This was a piece of generoity few, but himelf, were capable of, and for which he was admired both by his friends and his enemies; but the latter, to • ully an action that got him o much honor, reported preently, that he had robb'd the King of uch Sums, that o mall a matter was not worth his taking notice of; and as nothing is ooner credited than an ill report, every body believ'd it, till by the iue of his affairs it appear'd, that he was o far from having made himelf rich, that he was above two Millions in debt. Being thus out of that Pot, which was his Protection, the King thought it bet to make a Tour into Bretagne, before he uffer'd him to be arreted, that if he had any intelligence either within or without the Kingdom, he
might eize upon Belle Ile, where they apprehended a Rebellion. And this was manag'd with a great deal of prudence, had there been need of o much caution; for before Monieur Fouquet upected any thing Souldiers were planted o near to Belle Ile, that if any of his friends would have attempted any thing for him, it had been impoible; his Imprionment tartled abundance of people, nor were they les orry for him, for tho it happen'd at a time when the publick Miniters were odious to the people, by reaon of the great Taxes, yet the people oberving, he was always a generous man, and did not • oard up what he got, as Statemen do, but pent it freely amongt them, they ditinguiht him from the ret, who they had markt out as the publick grievance of the people; others were mov'd chiefly by their interet, for he had oblig'd the affections of abundance by uffering them to get by him, and thee could not ee him carry'd to Prion without regret, who had done every body rather good than harm; and if he had been guilty of any thing, 'twas only under the Minitry of Cardinal Mazarin, and in executing his orders too punctually. But that which mov'd them mot to compaion, was to ee the King put Colbert in his place, one who under the Cloak of Moderation nouriht an intollerable ambition, always deceitful, tho he pretended to be fair, preaching honety in all his dicoures, while under-hand he robb'd every one with impunity, making himelf an Enemy to Mankind by enriching himelf with their poils; barbarouly cruel, and yet at the ame time preing and recommending nothing but Clemency and Compaion; being mater of not one good quality, but that he knew how with an exquiite art to hide his own faults. People
thought him a man wholly given up to buines, one that had no time for Softnees and Pleaures, and yet no man was more Debaucht than he; he had his hours for his Amours and his hours for his Publick Affairs, only with this difference, that in the latter he always put on a tarcht formal gravity; but in the other appear'd with a free humour, and an air of Gallantry.

If it was a great unhappines to Monieur Fo • quet to have dipleas'd the King, 'twas no les a misfortune to have uch a ecret Enemy as Monieur Colbert; for tho he had premeditated his overthrow long before with the Cardinal, and had plaid a thouand Tricks to render it inevitable; yet, let Monieur Foquet hould at lat jutify himelf, he made ure of all the Officers that depended upon him for fale Witnees; and o order'd it by le Berrier, that all his Papers were tole from him, by which he hould have clear'd his innocence: and not atisfy'd yet, he pread abroad all the horriblet reports of him that 'twas poible for him to invent; as that he had Debaucht the greatet part of the Women of the Court, by means of his money; and his end in this was, that their Relations and Friends, who would perhaps have aited him in his misfortunes, hould be provoked rather to ait in his Ruine: And in this cae perhaps I can give a better account than mot People; as for intance, they had rais'd a report when the Queen Mother expell'd Madamoielle de la Motthe Agencourt, that it was on his core, when I am aur'd upon very good grounds, that it was for entertaining the Marquis de Richelieu againt her Majeties expres Command: This Lady, who was one of her Maids of Honour, was a peron whom I was particularly
acquainted with, and that o much, as I was uppos'd to have a Paion for her: he was co •• ted one of the finet women in the Court, and therefore I was not at all dipleas'd to have it thought o, for except Madamoiel de Meneville (who had her Admirers) there was none that would pretend to dipute it. 'Twas not for me to decide the cae between thee two Beauties, being upected to be partial, from what I have aid before. But to come to the Story, One day as I was at Fountain Bleau, where both the Queens continued while the King was in Bretagne, he came to me in a great concern, and with tears in her Eyes told me, he was ruin'd if I I did not erve her in one affair, which was immediately to convey into her Chamber a Suit of Mens Cloaths; but that I hould be ure not to be dicover'd, for he had a great many Eyes upon her: I askt her what the occaion was, and if he was o much concern'd in the digrace of Monieur Fouquet, as to oblige her to fly for it? No, ays he, 'tis nothing of that, I never was intimate enough with him to be o very much concern'd for his misfortune; but this I'll confes to you, they will have it, that Love has caus'd me to commit ome faults, foolih enough to be punih'd for: That impertinent old Jade de Beauvais has been buzzing in the Ears of the Queen Mother, that I have een her Son in Law; and her Majety, who uffers her elf to be govern'd by that Wretch, reents it o highly, that he has order'd one of my Relations to dipoe of me into a Cloyter; I mean the Countes de Maulevrier, the ame whoe Husband you had formerly a quarrel with; therefore for Gods ake deliver me out of her hands, and do as I have deir'd you; and then be o kind as to get me a Hore, and place him at the Kings Wine
Prees on t' other ide the Ferry de Velvins, that I may be gone.

If I had been in Love, as the World would have me be thought, I leave any one to judge how this Compliment would have pleas'd me; but having really never pretended any thing of that nature to her, I was very ready to ait her, without any concern at the occaion: o I ent one of my Hores to the place he had directed, and went my elf to her Chamber with a Suit of my own Cloths; but there being no body there to take it, I put it under the Bed as he had order'd me; and the Chambers or Lodgings of the Maids of Honour being always open to the Gallery, I went and fell into a chat with the good old Lady, Madam du Tilleul under Governante of the Ladies: who was one of my old acquaintance, and walking up and down with her, I aw lying upon the Toilet everal Combs, and a Powder Box, and all the neceary Impliments of the Dreing Box, and amongt the ret there tood a little Pot of Pomatum, o I mut needs take a little to rub upon my hands becaue they were a little rough; I found it quite of another colour than the ordinary ort, which made me fancy it might be good for the Lips too, and o without any conideration, apply'd ome to mine, they being a little chopt; but I oon paid for my curioity, for immediately my Lips were all on fire, my Mouth was contracted, my Gums hrivl'd up, and when I went about to peak, I made Madam du Tilleul laugh at that rate, that I might eaily ee I had very finely expos'd my elf; and which was wort of all, I was not able to bring out one word ditinctly; and running directly to the Looking-glas to take a view of my elf, I was o damnably aham'd of the figure I made,
that I run away to hide my elf; but jut as I wa •
going out I met the Duke de Roquelaire who was coming to make his Court to one of the Ladies, and being car'd to ee me in that condition, he askt me what the Devil ail'd me? I told him very imply my misfortune, but intead of pittying he fe • l a laughing at me, and told me I was but rightly erv'd; that at my Age I ought to know that there are everal orts of Pomatum; that the ort I had meddl'd with was not either for the Hands or for the Hair, but was deign'd for another ort of ue; after he had had his fill of this rallying, he left me, and went to the Apartments of the Queen Mother, where he made his Court at the expence of my misfortune. Immediately all the Town came to ee me, and finding that I had really furnih'd them with ufficient matter for their mirth, I would have been one of the firt to have laught at the Jet, if I could but have open'd my Mouth. This adventure was the entertainment of the whole Court, for at leat a Week, they were o taken with it, that they ent an account of it to Nants where the King was, who as erious as he was, could not forbear miling at it; for my part, I had as much inclination to laugh as any body, when I thought of this accident, but though I wah'd my Mouth often with freh Water, and ometimes with warm Wine, yet nothing but time would bring me to rights again.

This little digrace however hindred me from howing my elf for ome days, o that till I came abroad again, I could not hear any tidings of Madamoielle De la Motthe, but then I was preently inform'd, that the Countes de Maulevriere had put her into a Cloiter at C • aliot, and that this confinement, which was a true Prion to her, was accompanied
with a very evere reprimand made her by the Queen Mother: I was inform'd alo, that this Lady who was blindly in love with the Marquis de Richlieu, had given her elf a great deal of liberty, in reflecting upon la Beauvais, notwithtanding the repect which he ought to have had for the Queen; and reproacht her among other things, that he took occaion to wait upon the King when he was but very young, and to make him this civil requet, that his Majety would be pleas'd to lye with her. I could not eaily believe Madam la Motthe could be guilty of o great a folly, but the thing being confirm'd to me by every one, I askt them if what he reproacht the little old Lady with one Eye for, was true, and if his Majety had been o charitable as to oblige her? They told me, that was not a thing to be quetion'd, and askt me where I had liv'd, that I hould be the only man in France that was o ignorant.

Tho this was the true Hitory of Madamoielle de la Motthe, yet Monieur Colbert had maliciouly nam'd her amongt thoe, whom as he aid, Monieur Fouquet had been intriguing withal; but this was a mall matter compar'd to the other methods he us'd for his ruine. He pickt out uch Members of the everal Parliaments as he thought were the mot needy, and who watcht for an occaion to oblige the Court, to be his Judges: Thee he fed with hopes, and made them large promies of Preferment, if they would give their voices as he directed, and upon this account was o confident of his detruction, that he gave order to have a Scaffold made privately ready for the occaion. In the mean time he had o firmly poet the King, that Monieur Fouquet could not poibly clear himelf, that his Majety had ordred his Hore Guards to attend him to Chartres; a
journey which he had contriv'd, not for any Devotion, as was pretended, but to be out of the way of any Applications, which he foreaw would be made to him on behalf of Monieur Fouquet; for tho he was of no extraordinary Family himelf, he had marry'd one of his Daughters to the eldet Son of the Count de Charot, and the King was enible he would throw herelf at his feet for her Father. Thus the King tood ready to be gone, the very moment they hould b •• ng him news that the poor man was condemned; when one of the Judges (a Councellor of the Parliament of Aix) tood up and poke for the Prioner; He told them he was atoniht to find uch prejudice in that Court againt a man, as to eem reolv'd on any terms, right or wrong, to hurry him out of the world; that at firt view indeed there might be ome appearance of guilt; there had been found, 'twas true, among his papers, a rough cheme of a Rebellion, with everal methods how to raie it, and other projects for his conduct in uch an affair, when it hould be brought to pas; and many uch things for which Monieur Fouquet might eem to deerve no les than death: But when one came to examine into the the proofs of thee Crimes, there was caue enough at leat to upend ones Judgment againt him; this was found among a parcel of old wate Papers, thrown by, not only into a corner of the Room, but into the Chimny, and deign'd for nothing but the Fire, as Monieur Fouquet had very well oberv'd in his defence; that there was no other marks of it, but as of a thing form'd in his mind, provokt to it by the barbarous uage of Cardinal Mazarin, who upon all occaions had not fail'd to tetifie his malice againt him; that, 'twas a general maxime in the Law, that no man could be
punih'd for thinking Treaon, nor for intending, unles he proceed to ome Overt-act; that here was nothing like it in this cae, but on the contrary, very evident tokens that he had laid aide o much as the thoughts of it; that Kings ought not to be more rigorous than God himelf, who o graciouly paes by the inadvertency of our conceptions; but beides there was omething of more conequence than all this that had been aid, that Monieur de Fouquet affirm'd exprely that he had wherewithal to prove beyond contradiction, his repentance of that very intention, if they had not inhumantly tole away his Papers; that 'twas true thoe words might be poken only to excue himelf, but 'twas alo true, that it might be really o; this was certain, and not to be denyed, that they had found among his Papers everal Petitions adres'd to Mon. Colbert, with the title of my Lord, which was never given to him till ince the imprionment of Monieur Fouquet; that this was a proof, they had come into his Houe without his knowledge, and earcht there at their own pleaure; and 'twas an infallible conequence, that they did o with a deign to ruin him, becaue, that under pretence of earching in that manner, they had carried away all the Papers which he hould ue for his Jutification; that notwithtanding all this, he had clear'd himelf of the great Crime; his enemies made uch a tir about, of wating the Revenues of the Crown; that he had laid before them an account of his etate, what he had when he entered upon the Minitry, and what he had with his Wife; (which rogether amounted to above a million) what Penions he had received, and what had ell to him upon other occaions. And though thee were very coniderable, yet he had not only pent all this in the
ervice of his Majety, but was run into Debt above two Millions: that his extravagance ought not to be reckon'd criminal, ince he had means enough of his own to do it, without wrong to the King, and he had done no injury to any body, but himelf, poor man, and his Family.

The greatet part of the Judges were amaz'd, not o much at the dicoure of this man, tho' that had a great deal of force with it, but to ee how little he valu •• the great Men, whom he knew he hould dioblige • t the highet rate. Now, as we cannot do our Neighbour a better ervice than by a good example to et him in the right way, all thoe that poke after him, were of the ame mind, and thoe who had before given their Voices for his Condemnation, being aham'd of o unjut a Sentence; retracted their judgment, o that in a moment, there was een uch a change in the Court, as if ome influence from above, had wrought a miracle upon them: However, as there was caue enough to inflict ome punihment upon Monieur Fouquet, either for that project of a revolt I mention'd, or that he had fortifyed Bell Ile on his own account, they thought fit to condemn him to Banihment. They were very much urprized at Court, at a Sentence o little expected; and it quite broke off their journey to Chartres, and Monieur Colbert fearing that if Monieur Fouquet hould ever be at liberty, he would find an occaion, ome time or other, to let the King know certain things which i • concern'd him to have kept ecret, prevail'd upon the King, to change the Sentence of Banihment, to a perpetual Prion. After then he had laid I kn •• not how long in the Dungeon at Vincennes, they carryed him to Pignerol, where he continued at leat ixteen or eventeen years: But
this was the Pennance for his faults, for they who knew him in that place of Perecution, ay he made o good ue of it, that nothing could have happen'd more to his advantage. And ince I have nam'd this, I cannot forbear telling you a tory, that happen'd upon the occaion of his meeting with Monieur De Lauun, who was committed to the ame Prion about ten years after, and from whom I receiv'd this account. Upon the firt meeting they aluted one another, and Monieur Fouquet not recollecting immediately where he had een him, askt him his Name? Whether or no he had forgot him in the time of his Digrace: Or that, as 'twas mot likely, Monieur De Lauun was not o coniderable in his time, as to be known to him? But Monieur De Lauun having given him atisfaction who he was, goes on to make himelf known to him, with the common vanity of telling ones own Hitory, by acquainting him with the particulars of his life.

Monieur Fouquet heard him very intently, for he was extreamly urpriz'd at ome dicoure he pretended to have had with the King, about Madam de Monaco; How he had told his Majety he was no better than a Tyrant, in offering to take away his Mitres from him, and how he refus'd to erve in his Office of Collonel General of the Dragoons, in the Army which marcht into Italy; how he had askt the King to be made General, and upon the refual had thrown up his Commiion. In hort, how his Majety had ent him to the Batile, from whence nevertheles he was releas'd in four and twenty hours to rie the greater in his favour: Monieur Fouquet gave him the hearing, but oberving the man, and taking notice of the very mean figure he made, he could not perwade himelf, the King, who was a
Prince of the nicet judgment, and known to be of a fierce and violent temper, hould uffer himelf to be Nos'd at that rate; and hould o far forget his Character, as to bear thoe Inults from a Subject, epecially one o depicable as he appear'd; however Monieur Fouquet conceal'd his entiments, and would by no means interrupt him, but when he came to relate his Marriage with Madamoielle de Montpenier, how the King had given his conent to it, and afterwards recall'd it, and the concern that Princes was in at the diappointment, and all the conequences of that affair; he could not forbear turning to another Prioner of State, that had join'd them jut before, and making a ign to his Forehead, as we do when we would ignifie a man is craz'd, he gave him to undertand that he thought no better of this Gentleman. Monieur De Lauun perceiv'd it, but made as if he took no notice of it, and went on with other trange paages of his life, which did but confirm Monieur Fouquet in his former opinion.

But to return to Monieur Colbert, who was now by the digrace of this Miniter become o powerful at Court, and had the Kings ear o entirely, that he grew uneay to Monieur Tellier; this latter had been an old Courtier, and having done very great ervices to the State, it was but jut he hould expect ome marks of ditinction. The firt method that Colbert took to fix his Reputation, was to change the whole form, and etablih a new exact order in the Chamber of the Finances, reforming the number of Offices, and uppre •• ing the Under-Treaurers and their Dependencies, who were all clapt up in Prion upon pretence of having cheated the King; o that thoe, who pretended to have vat Sums due to them, were o far from recovering their Debts, that they were
forc'd to part with all they had to atisfie his extravagant Demands: Indeed to ay the truth, there was very gros abues practic'd in the Finances, and 'twas no more than neceary they hould be redret But here were everal great perons touch'd by this Affair, for thee fellows being rich, had ally'd themelves to everal coniderable Houes, as the Duke de St. Agnan for one, whoe eldet Son the Count de Seri, was to marry Madamoielle de Monero, the Daughter of one of thee Officers, with whom he was to have two Millions of Livres. This Duke being very much in favour, as we have formerly aid, and Monieur Colbert apprehending ome ill Offices from him, who was alo a very riing man, he appeaed him by promiing him his eldet Daughter for his Son, intead of Madamoielle de Monero. 'Twas thought he made this promie againt his inclination, the Duke being not very rich, and he had a propect of marrying her more advantageouly; but whatever his thoughts were, he durt not have gone back from his word, if the Count de Seri had liv'd to accept of it: Wherefore to preerve his friendhip with the Duke, he told him, that tho it had pleas'd God to dipoe of his Son, yet that he had another left, and tho he was young, that hould not hinder their alliance, ince he had a younger Daughter of a uitable age, and he would give him his word he hould be reerv'd for him. The Duke de St. Agnan, who had occaion for money, and knew no where to get a greater fortune for his Son, eaily conented to this offer; when they were grown up, Monieur Colbert was as good as his word to him, and they were marry'd accordingly.

The reaon which induc'd Monieur Colbert to be o fond of this alliance, was becaue the Duke de
St. Agnan, as we mention'd before, grew every day more and more in • avour; for the King, who was now fallen in love with Madamoielle de la Valliere, one of the Dutches of Orleans's Maids of Honour, a Lady of no extraordinary beauty, but one who was more agreeable than thoe that were infinitely more handom, and had a mind to conceal it from the Queen, committed the management of that intrigue to the Duke. This young Lady was but of an indifferent Family, he was the Daugh • er of one of the principal Burghers of Tours, which tho they pretended to • ome Nobility, 'twas only that Henry 3d, when he retir'd to Tours in the time of the Civil Wars, had enobled her Great Uncle, which decended but to his Heirs, if he had any, and which he could lay no claim to; but her Father indeed having got a coniderable Pot in the Army, marry'd a Lady of Q • ality, which gave his Children ome pretences to it. However it was, he was entertain'd by the Dutches of O • leans, without crupling her Gentility; and before the King had any thoughts of her, there was a Gentleman o in love with her, that he intended to marry her; he was of a very good family near Chartres, and Heir to an Etate of twenty thouand Livres a year, which was counted an advantageous Match to her, his Name was Estourville, and was a Lieutenant in the Guards; he had but one misfortune, which was, that his Etate lay o much in the power of his Father, that he durt not marry without his conent: So he was oblig'd to leave his Mitres for a while, to ollicit the old Gentleman upon that account. It was gone o far on her ide, that he deir'd him to make as hort a tay from her as was poible; and 'twas gone o far on his ide, that he needed no uch importunity, but
he had a Father to deal with, that requir'd more time to conider of it than he was aware of, for the meannes of her Birth, and epecially of her Etate, were difficulties which were not o oon over with him, but took up o much time, that when he had reconcil'd things, and return'd at lat with his Fathers conent, he found things were trangely alter'd in his abence, for the King had not only appear'd to be in love with his Mitres, but he had prevented his Addrees by making a dicovery of her paion for him. He met with this News for his firt welcome to Paris, but being loth to believe it from any mouth but her own, • he went to the Palace Royal to wait on her; he did not find his acces to her o eay as formerly, the King having plac'd thoe about her whoe obervation made it neceary for her to be cautious who he convert with; which he undertood o well, and withal being full of her new Grandeur, that when he ent up his name to her, he made trange of it, and return'd that he knew no uch peron. Etourville knew how to interpret this anwer, and tho he made no more doubt of the truth of his misfortune, her ingratitude o overcame him, that he kept his Bed upon it. His Friends, who knew the particulars, accus'd him of folly, in being concern'd for o perfidious a creature; but being uncapable of impreion by all their reaons, he left them an example, that 'tis not impoible for a true Lover to break his heart, for indeed he languih'd about three weeks, and then died exclaiming on the Ingratitude of Madamoielle de la Valliere to the lat, charging one of his F • iends, jut as he was expiring, to tell her, that he was the only caue of his Death.

Monieur Colbert engag'd in all the interets of Madamoielle de la Valliere, from the firt moment that he found he had an influence upon the King, and this gave him the advantage of all pretenders to the Kings favour. In the mean time, I, who had liv'd all my days among the Grandees, found my elf now as it were alone, and forgotten of all the world, and if it had not been for my little Income, I have o often mention'd, I hould have been in but an ordinary condition. My Father was yet living, and tho he was very eay on account of his family, mot of them being provided for by the good Offices I had done them, yet I could never have the benefit of the leat upply from him; on the contrary, if a Glas of Water would have av'd my life, I verily believe, he would have uffer'd me to perih for want of that relief: This was a enible grief to me when I reflected on it; but as it pleas'd God I was not quite reduc'd, I bore it with the more patience, epecially when I conider'd, that it was not from any fault of mine. At lat, about the latter end of the year 1663. I receiv'd a Letter from his Curate to come down with all peed, if I had any deire to ee him before he dy'd. I had no buines to hinder me, o I took Pot immediately, and in ix hours time I was at his Houe; he was urpriz'd to ee me, and imagin'd preently that I had been privately ent for, but however he made as if he was glad to ee me, and told me I had prevented him, for his deign was to have ent for me; that he being weak, and his great age making it improbable that he hould recover, he was willing to ettle his affairs, and as there was nothing he deir'd to prevent more, than Law Suits among Relations, he did not uppoe I would refue, conidering the condition in
which I aw him, to agree matters now with his Wife and my Brothers; and he pretended to oblige me in doing it. For this purpoe he • old me, he intended his Etate hould be equally divided, his Wife coming in for a part, beides her Joynture; that this was for my advantage, for he had brought a great fortune to him, and which his Etate was engag'd for; o that if he hould come to demand it, as is cutomary in like caes, he would carry away above half the Etate. I made no anwer at all to a Propoal o unjut, he having no regard in that dicoure to the Joynture of my own Mother, which was my Birthright, and which he ought to have reerv'd for me, when he marry'd again. He took my ilence in this cae for an aent to his Propoal, and without preing me to any reply, ent away for a Notary. I uffer'd all this without giving him the trouble of any contradiction, in repect to his indipoition; but when I aw the Notary was come, and he began to dictate thee things to him. I beg'd him to defer it, till I hould take ome advice about it; that I deir'd him to remember, that I was his Son as well as the ret, that they had always enjoy'd the priviledges of his houe, which I had been depriv'd of. That his eldet Son by this econd Wife was already provided with two good Benefices, o that he might not only very well bate his Legacy, but was in a good condition to ait his younger Brother; that I had dipos'd of his Daughter, who was rich enough alo to have no need of it; that I did not ay this with any thought of depriving her of the Inheritance, nor to take that from them which Nature had given them a right to, but that he ought to conider me upon the ame account; that I would conent, if he pleas'd, that he hould
give my Mother-in-law a Penion as large as he thought fit, which I was ready to con • irm, and alo another to my younget Brother, that o, if his Brother hould not be kind to him, he might have wherewithal to ubit; but for the ret he mut permit me to advie upon it, as I had aid before.

There was nothing could be more fair than my Propoal, and indeed it was a meer impoverihing my elf to enrich others: But my Father was o bewitcht to my Mother-in-law and her Children, that he would certainly have got up and truck me, if he had been able to lift himelf up in the Bed; he told me, that now he aw all that had been aid to him of me confirm'd; that I was an unnatural Dog, and one that would horten his days by my Diobedience; that he had made me a Propoal too much to my advantage, but that I would deprive my elf of it purely in malice to diturb the Family; that he did not wonder I had o many broils with my Maters, who were better acquainted with my humours than him; that another in my place would have made his fortune, but that God had dealt with me as I had dee • v'd; that I hould get out of his ight, that he might not be dicompos'd at his departing out of the world; that if I continu'd in that reolution, he would leave me his hearty Cure, and that I hould conider of it, whether I was willing he hould dye in that opinion.

I mut confes to you, I wiht my elf a thouand miles off when I heard him talk at this rate; I endeavour'd to pacify him by the mot profound Submiions, and labouring to make him enible, that what I demanded was nothing but jutice. I told him once more, that if he did not pleae to let things go in the ordinary way of Jutice, for fear they
hould be too much to the prejudice of my Mother-in-law, I was willing they hould have the Etate who wanted; that I had as much occaion of it as any of them, epecially ince there was a talk of uppreing the Bank of Lyon, or at leat of retrenchments upon the particular rents of it; that my Brother the Abbot was like to be richer than all of us together, from whom I had reaon to expect nothing, ince, tho he ow'd all his fortunes to my procurement, he never offer'd me a farthing when he aw me in o much neceity.

My Paion perhaps might make me think this the mot reaonable dicoure in the world; I thought o indeed, but my Father it eems was of another opinion, and I had the unhappines that he dy'd without being reconci • 'd to me; 'twas none of my fault, and o I believe his Cure had not the effect he deir'd upon me. At his Death I enter'd upon the Etate, and et my Seal upon the Goods, which you may be ure put my Mother-in-law into a great rage: She, who, when I did all I could to oblige her, perecuted me with o much cruelty, would not fail to exclaim againt me upon this proceeding; I did now as I us'd to do formerly, let her ay what he pleas'd, and the rather, becaue he never had more occaion; however that he might have nothing jutly to reproach me with, and not out of any ditrut of my own Title, I offer'd her a thouand Crowns a year, provided he would relinquih her other pretenions: this was a Preent he ought to have look'd upon as very civil in me, for in jutice he could hope for nothing but her own Fortune, of which the bet part was never paid; but he having taken ome meaures which I knew nothing of, ent me word, that I ought to have accepted the offers
my Father had made me, if I had been well advis'd; but that ince I had not, I hould ee in a hort time whether I was in the right or no.

This ort of talk did not trouble me, having no apprehenions of the trick they were going to play me, but I went on to make out my Title, and was buie with the Advocates, who according to their rules, declar'd, I ought to have the whole Etate, if it was never o great: So I concluded to take off the Seals which I had put on, which I did in the cutomary form, and found among the papers, that my Mother-in-law was a Feme ole by the Contract of Marriage: I uppos'd my Cae was the better for that, becaue that then if there had been any payments made out of her money, the Etate was not anwerable for them; and imagining, that ince he had hown o much ill nature, he might have forgotten this particular, I was uch a Fool to tell her of it; but all the anwer he made me was, that the end of the matter would dicover the truth, and perhaps it might poil my mirth I could not comprehend for the oul of me what he had in her head, till at lat it dicover'd it elf in a moment, to my no mall diturbance. The peron that made the Inventory brought me a bag of papers ty'd together, with a Ballet or Ticket upon it, in which was written with my Mothers own hand as follows, Diburements paid of my Money out of the everal parts of my allowance, due to me from my Husband, for which I have the Preference of Demand upon his Etate, before all other Debts. I was not much urpriz'd at this, till I had look'd a little further; but taking the papers out of the bag, I aw ome contracts of Settlements, made by my Grandfather to ome particular perons in trut, for payment of Debts, one of which was for no
les than fifty thouand Crowns; o that if what my Mother pretended had been jut, he might well ay, I had no caue to laugh, he would poil my Mirth; for I was remov'd out of the Family when I was but a Child, and had never any account of their affairs, o that I could ay nothing to this till I was better inform'd: I aw well enough there was a juggle in it, and the mot favourable contruction I could pas on it, as to my Mother-in-law was, that he had imploy'd the Revenue of her Sons Benefices to her own ue; that which confirm'd me in this thought was, that tho my Brother the Abbot left all his affairs to the management of his Father and Mother, yet I found but eight Livres and a half of ready Money in the Houe when my Father dy'd, a fine um for a Family that made uch a figure in the Country; or rather a very good mark of my Mothers extraordinary management. However, after I had mus'd upon this Cae a while, I began to conider, that 'twas impoible my Grandfather hould leave o many Debts, ince the whole Etate did not amount to more, and my Father had marry'd two of his Siters, and had paid them five and twenty thouand Livres each for their Portions; and from hence I thought this was an infallible conequence, that my Father was far enough from having his Etate o much encumber'd; but that they were old Contracts that they had reviv'd by ome clandetine methods, to make pretenions upon the Etate; the chief of thoe Creditors being all Relations of one kind or another to my Mother-in-law.

I acquainted ome very judicious perons with my upicions, who were preently of my opinion, and after them the Lawyers, who advis'd me however, before I made any tir about it, or commenc'd any
Suit at Law in the cae, which could not but be very inconvenient to me, that I hould try if I could any way underhand dicover the Cheat. I try'd all the ways that I could poibly think of, having et everal Perons of Quality of that Province to work for me, who knew what I had done for the Family, and were mov'd to compaion to ee me us'd in uch a manner: But tho they us'd their utmot skill and very heartily too, the Agents my Mother-in-law had employ'd, had plaid their game too ure to be dicover'd, and no doubt had been well enough paid, o that all our endeavours were to no purpoe, and I was forc'd at lat to begin a tedious Suit at Law. Then I charg'd them with Forgery concerning thoe pretended Reinburements, and having obtain'd the liberty to publih a Monitory thereof, I caus'd it to be read in the Churches of thoe Parihes where they liv'd, whom I upected had a hand in the f • aud, hoping that the time of Chritmas being at hand, when every one was to pas for Abolution, 'twould oblige them to conult eriouly with their Conciences. My Siter how'd me at this time a particular mark of her Gratitude; he came to me and told me, that tho he knew what he was going to ay would embroil her with her Mother, if ever he hould come to hear of it, he would nevertheles witnes the truth o far as to tell me, that he had heard my Father often ay, in dicouring of everal things with my Mother-in-law, that his Father had not left him one Farthing in debt, but that on the other hand he found eight thouand Franks of ready money in the houe at his death: She told me he remember'd this, as perfectly as if it had not been above a quarter of an hour ago, and that if it would do me any ervice, he would make
affidavit of it before a Judge: I gave her a thouand thanks for her good will, but not being willing he hould incur the hatred of her Mother for her affection to me, I told her it hould uffice me to ee uch a proof of her Love, without making her a acrifice; that I was orry I was in no better a condition for her ake; that I had reolv'd he hould be my Heir to that little I had, for I lov'd uch an honet principle; in hort, he did all I could deire, for he gave me a Declaration two or three days after, whereby he relinquiht any claim for her part in any thing her Mother might pretend upon my Fathers Etate, acknowledging that it all belong'd to me, and charging her Son, in cae of her Death, not to meddle with it, but to make me retitution: She forc'd the paper of this into my hands, and made me take it, but I laught at her, and having torn it in her ight, I told her we hould eaily accommodate the cae between her and I, if there was no body ele concern'd; that I took this as kindly of her, which he had now done, as if he had given me a hundred thouand Crowns; and that all my trouble was, that I was not in a condition to requite her kindnes.

Our Caue, which had at firt been commenc'd in the Country, was quickly brought to Paris, by the means of one of my Mother-in-laws pretended Creditors, who uppoing he hould erve her the better there, where he had a great interet, made her remove it to Paris, where he did all his buines. I was o far from being orry for this, that they could not have pleas'd me better, having perhaps as many friends there as he, and hop'd they would not abandon me in a Caue o very jut. In hort, every one proffer'd me his ervice, and I that had always hated
Law Suits above all things, carry'd on this with o much vigour, that I minded nothing ele. When I think of this ometimes, I wonder what it was wrought o great a change in me, unles it was, that my Mother having on all occaions exaperated me, I was very willing to have my turn in vexing her too, and plague her as much as I could. In the mean time however, the Caue was againt me, and every body told me, that when it came to a hearing I hould be cat, unles I could produce ome Deeds to make out the Cheat I pretended was put upon me. I had brought the Contracts of my two Aunts, whereby it appear'd they had receiv'd fifty thouand Franks, and that 'twas likely my Father had a great deal more, becaue we liv'd in a Country where 'twas the cutom to be favourable to the Male Children; but the Lawyers laught at this, and told me, that in matters of Law they did not ue to judge by uppoition.

I was to be ure trangely embarrat at this ort of dicoure, and aw my elf at the point to be cat for the charges; when a certain Councellor of the Great Chamber ent to me to tell me, that if I would promie to marry his Daughter, he would engage I hould carry my Caue. I askt of the Meenger who this Councellor was, but he told me, he was not to tell me, unles I accepted the propoition; but that aoon as I had given him my word, I hould ee both my Father-in-law and his Daughter. I reply'd, that folks did not ue to marry they know not who, and before I promis'd any thing, I hould be very willing to know who I had to do with; that in the firt place the propoition eem'd a little freakih, or to peak eriouly, it eem'd to come from a man that was not very crupulous;
that my Father-in-law pretended belike to ell me Jutice, ince it might chance I hould buy it with the los of my Liberty, and perhaps of my Honour; and in the econd place, this caution he us'd to get my promie before I hould be uffer'd to know him, lookt as if he had no great confidence of his own reputation; that I could not imagin who it hould be, and could gues but two or three perons, whom I would not name; but if it was any one of them, I defy'd them, and would rather run the hazard of being mierable all my life, than to buy my Etate with o dihonourable a Match: The man let me go on without the leat interruption, till I had quite done, and then hrugging up his houlders he told me, this dicoure from a man of twenty year old would be well enough, but for one that had een almot fifty, 'twas an inexcuable folly, that I call'd it then elling of Jutice; that he would help me with his credit and interet; what obligation had a man to prefer my interet before my Mother-in-laws, who in all appearance had the right on her ide; that thoe Gentlemen who I talkt o candalouly of, were at the ame time the chief men in the Parliament; that all perons were at their beck, and that if I hould have o little wit and o much boldnes, to offer them any ill language, I hould certainly loe my Caue, which if I hould be o much a Fool to do, I hould oon alo be made to pay the cots; and that if he hould hear the News, that all this was come to pas, he hould be the firt to ay I was erv'd as I deerv'd.

I confes I was enibly touch'd with this threat, and endeavouring in my elf to excue the proceedings of this pretended Father-in-law, I told the Meenger, perhaps he was not o much to be reflected
on as I imagin'd; that perhaps the methods he would ue to ait me might be only interets, not unjut; that uch men as they aw further into a Caue than other People, and doubtles it was upon that core, that he pretended to be able to help me in mine; on the other hand, 'twas not o trange, he hould demand for his recompence, that I hould marry his Daughter; for 'tis fair every man hould ask what wages he pleaes for his pains; that in this cae, to ay the truth, 'twould not be my giving his Daughter a portion, but his Daughter giving me an Etate, ince without her I was jut a going to be not worth a groat. In hort, to ay the truth, the averion I had for my Mother-in-law, reconcil'd me to all the difficulties of this affair, more than I thought 'twas poible for me; o I told the man I would venture, provided my Father-in-Law that was to be was not Monieur Genou, and that the Woman was not infamous. I had an implacable enmity in my mind againt Monieur Genou, for a piece of Injutice that he did to ome very honet Gentlemen of my acquaintance, which I could not forgive him; and he run o much in my head for a notorious fellow, I would be ure to avoid, that it put others out of my memory, who were every jot as bad as himelf; the man taking it for granted the buines was done, names to me Monieur de Canae, who was uch another Villain as Genou, if not a wore; the very name made me cry out as if ome udden diater had urpriz'd me: The fellow perceiving his mitake, and that no good was like to come of it, bid me have a care what I did, that the los of my Suit at Law depended upon my managing this affair; that the young Lady was a dicreet peron, and agreeable enough; that to refue it now would make her Father outrageous,
and he would certainly be my Enemy, and o I might only thank my elf, if my Caue micarry'd. I reply'd, the thing mut be as it pleas'd God, but I could never conent to be Son-in-Law to Monieur de Canae; that he might indeed make me loe my Suit, without blackening his Concience, ince he had been guilty before of o many Villanies, as had already brought it to the colour of the Chimney; that I could not but wonder he had not found the means, of marrying his Daughter, who by this time began to grow omething tale; ince without doubt he had many uch affairs as mine in his way; and might find ome Client or other to make a Cully of; but it would not pas upon me.

I aid too much indeed, conidering I had a Suit depending, and that he was one of the Judges, and epecially before a peron he particularly employ'd in uch under-hand practices; who having given him an exact account of what I had aid, my Mother-in-Law herelf did not ollicit her Caue, with o much eagernes againt me in publick, as he did in private. However 'twas to his advantage, that I refus'd his Daughter, for he married her to Monieur Montigni, Son to the Governor of Diep, who was richer than I hould have been, if I had recover'd my Etate; and this cot him nothing, but doing a little injutice for him, jut as he offer'd to me.

However, I never repented that this Gentleman carry'd away the Prize, for he wears the Breeches manfully, and all that her Husband can do to hew that he is Lord and Mater, is that, when he pleaes he will go to Chartres and get drunk, becaue he won't uffer him to have a drop of Wine at home. I uppoe I may be allow'd to mention this tory, that reflects on his Son-in-Law, becaue I have o much reaon to hate the Father. In hort, he was the occaion that about a Fortnight after I lot my Caue, and was condemn'd to pay the charges, and ince that I have not had an Enemy, has done me half the michief which he has endeavour'd to do.

The charges amounted to a huge umm, and my Mother-in-Law who had no thoughts of favouring me, took out Execution againt me, at the perwaion of Monieur de Canae, and clapt me into Prion, at the time when I leat of all expected it: The umm was no les than two thouand livres, and money being very carce then, as well as now, I could meet with never a friend, would help me to uch a umm: However abundance of them came to ee me, and exclaimed with me at the ingratitude of this woman, but that was a mall relief to me, o I was forced to take it as patiently as I could: I found in the Prion, a great many honet Gentlemen, whoe misfortunes had brought them into the ame condition, but they were not o much concerned at their afflictions, as I was at mine, for I aw them eek all manner of ways to divert themelves, as if they had been at Liberty; but not being of their humor, I pent my time in curing of my Judges, and railing at the times, in which there was o little Jutice to be had; and there being Spies there, as well as in other places, they inform'd againt me, o from a Debtor, I was made a Criminal, and was carried away to Pierre Encie. I was a long time before I could gues what they were going to do with me, and what I had done to deerve this ort of uage; but recollecting that I had poken a little too freely of a certain Miniter, I troubled my elf no further for a caue of my removal; but the Crime being of no great conequence, they gave me liberty to walk abroad. The other prioners eeing a new comer, were very eager to hear my tory; I made no difficulty of telling them all the particulars, and proteting my innocence, but I found this was o common a tale in uch a place, that they were all as innocent, as by their own accounts. Among the ret I found the Marquis de Frene, whom I had known well enough to give him more particular repect, than the others, and on that account, I told him my cae ingenuouly, and askt his advice what co •• e I hould take, to make atisfaction for my imprudence; he told me, he knew not what to advie me
to, in o nice an affair, and that he tood in as much need himelf, his misfortune coming from a like caue: He urpriz'd me in aying o, having always been told 'twas for endeavouring to • ell away his Wife to ome Pyrates, and I could not forbear telling him what I had heard; he anwer'd, that ince I had been o ill inform'd, he would acquaint me in a few words, with his true Hitory. Having no great matter of buines in uch a place, I was as willing to hear this adventure, knowing it mut be extraordinary, as he could be to relate it: So we at down on a bank, upon the Platform where we was walking, and he told me, That before he was married, he was paionately in love with her, who was now his Wife, that tho 'twas his contant maxim, that Daughters took always after their Mothers, and that he knew well enough what was the manner of her Mother, yet it pite of his own-notions, he was uch a fool to fall into the nare, and after having try'd all poible means to enjoy her, and finding them ineffectual but by marrying her, reolv'd to atisfy his inclination at any rate; o he ask'd her Mothers conent, which the old woman, not caring to part with her money, had refus'd him; that this repule had but encreaed their paion on both ides, o that they reolv'd to do it without her; upon which he had taken her away, and having goten a Priet ready to marry them, this oblig'd the old Gentlewoman to give her conent; that upon this he thought himelf the happiet man in the World. But this happines lated no longer than three months, when Monieur de Ecuilli, his Brother, fell in love with his Wife, and he with him, and that they manag'd this with o little prudence, that he cou'd not but perceive it preently, and was o enrag'd at it, that he was everal times tempted to dipatch 'em both; but conidering what a noie uch an action wou'd make in the World, he thought of ome other method, and the more, becaue, as fale as he was, he cou'd not bring himelf to that degree of hatred againt his Wife; but having not the ame tendernes for his Brother, reolv'd to fight him, upon pretence of ome Etate that was to
be divided, and about which they had formerly had ome words, and to urge him to it, he had frequently taken occaion to dicoure about that concern; but that the love he had privately for his Wife, caus'd him to take all the reproaches he made him without any reply. It madded him o much the more to ee his Brothers policy, in avoiding all occaions of quarrel, and he was loth to fight him without ome apparent caue; but a circumtance which he happened to be an Eye-witnes to, made him change his deign of fighting him, into a reolution of dipatching him by a urer way; for one day coming unexpectedly into her Chamber, he had urpriz'd them in the fact, and before he entred the Room had overheard them plotting together to aainate him: that his Brother eeing him coming in, made as if he had been only toying with her, and he on his part made as if he believ'd it, that he might not give them any caue of mitrut; and o they parted from one another, without any words of the matter, but with the more reentment in their Hearts: For in hort, he for his part had appointed one of his Servants whom he knew he could trut, to hoot him as he was a Hunting, and his Brother at the ame time, had hir'd ome Souldiers to do as much for him. However, it fell out o, that neither part was perform'd, and yet the deign on both ides became publick, and made a great noie in the World. His Servant in particular had taken uch gros meaures, that he had as good have betray'd his Mate • , for he made him be upected, and that perfectly lot him the favour of the King, and alo was taken to be done upon account of private interet, and not from his jealouy; that after this his Brother having not opportunity as formerly with his Wife, and he being not of an inclination to be content without a Gallant, e'n entertain'd them, where he could find them, according to the cutom of her Family; that among others he happen'd upon one who was a Peron of great Credit at Court, who being in his young Blood, gave himelf up to his pleaures, tho at the ame time, he had great employments, in the
State. He told me, that their behaviour was alo o notorious, that he could not refrain taking notice of it, and reflecting upon the Peron, which oon came to his Ears, and there began his ruin. The Peron however deferr'd his revenge, becaue the World would ay, 'twas too hard to kis the Wife, and quarrel with the Husband; and waited only for an opportunity, which he was not long without. De Frene could not bear the mocks and reproaches he met with in all Companies on this occaion, and therefore reolv'd when this Courtier hould be abent, he would take an opportunity to convey his Wife away. To prevent all upicion of this, he made as if he would be reconcil'd to her, and became o kind to her, that he was perfectly deluded, and was as forward for going as he; finding her in o good a humour, he took her at her word, and taking the Road to Lyons, he carry'd her into Provence, with a deign to have hipt her on board ome of the Levant Pyrates, and o to have old her, having bargain'd with a Captain of uch a Veel for that purpoe: But he had been o unfortunate, that his Wife had ecap'd as it were by a miracle, and that intead of ridding himelf of a Whore, he had got the name of a Villain, and a Racal, for attempting it; upon which her Gallant, who, as has been aid, waited for a pretence to ruin him, has laid hold of this, and had effectually lodg'd him in that place, which was hardly o grievous to him as the candal; that his Wife having procur'd a Merchant to furnih her with money to carry her back to Paris, he had been o bae, as to force him to go to Law with her for it, before he would reimbure, and this came before the Parliament, where the aid Merchant was oblig'd to tell the whole tory, to et forth the neceity he was in of the money, and to aggravate the ingratitude of it; for indeed he had a great deal of reaon to complain of her uage, after having done her uch a remarkable kindnes; and tho, as he told me, he ow'd this Merchant a great deal of ill will, for not leaving his Wife where he found her, yet he could not but acknowledge, he was very ungrateful to cheat him
of his Money, upon pretence, as he pleaded, that he was under the Covert of a Husband, and o had no power to make an Obligation.

Tho I knew a great part of this Hitory before, yet I would not interrupt him; and he told me ome circumtances that I did not know before, as that he was in Prion for having dioblig'd his Wives Gallant. This tory made me reflect on my condition, as not altogether o unhappy as ome perons, ince I had never been marry'd; and gave me o great an averion to that Sex, that I made a Vow never to have to do with any of them. I liv'd three years in this Pierre Encie, without o much as hearing either of Friend or Foe, and believing my elf confin'd for term of Life, I grew o melancholy, and it o alter'd me, that people did not know me; and the more I reflected upon my miery, the more it afflicted me: Sometimes calling to mind my old Mater, the Cardinal de Richlieu, I more paionately bewail'd that los, than ever Lover did that of his Mitres. In hort, having pat my time in this condition, with how much atisfaction you may eaily imagin, the Archbihop of Lyons, Brother to the Marechal de Villeroy, who acted as Lieutenant of the Province, ent me word, that I might go abroad when I pleas'd, for his Majety had given me the bounds of the City, only for my Prion. I return'd him my thanks, as if the favour had come immediately from himelf; and he was vain enough to accept my Complement, as if it had been his due. I had been maintain'd at the King's charge all the while I continu'd at Pierre Encie, and by that means had a little Arrears of my Rent due to me, with which I made hift to pay my Mother-in-law, and had a little in my Pocket; and now I began to reolve upon being a good Husband, eeing to what I had been expos'd for want of two hundred Pitoles, to pay thoe pitiful Charges. But whatever Reolutions a Man may make, it is impoible to avoid one's Detiny. The Archbihop, having taken me with him a hunting, to his Houe at Nimis, which he had lately call'd Neuvilli, notwithtanding he had told me, I hould not go
out of the City; when we came back we mut needs go to play, and my Complaiance there cot me all the Money I had in the World. Being in a rage at uch a misfortune, it made me reflect upon the Life of this Man, whoe Practice was o wide of his Profeion. Indeed he was a Military Archbihop, and was urrounded with Guards, intead of Priets; following the Stag at the he • ls of fifty couple of Hounds, rather than following the Cros; making good Chear, intead of Fating; boating of, and magnifying the Grandeurs of the Court, rather than practicing, or preaching Humility; and in hort, he governed the City of Lyons at uch a rate, that he eemed rather a Tyrant than an Archbihop. I aw before my Eyes a thing no les trange than true: He would end every now and then for the Magitrates of the Town, upon pretence of having received ome Orders from Court; and if he told them, that his Brother the Marechal had ent him word he had lot a umm of Money, they durt do no les than make him a Preent of as much the next morning; this was the Price of his Protection, and this cot me, as well as others, who had Demands upon the Bank, one quarter part of my Rent; for having thus exhauted the Town by this ort of Contribution, if I may be allowed that term, he was oblig'd to ollicit a Warrant from the Council, which reduc'd the Rents to three quarters the value.

Having lot all my Money, the Archbihop ent me word, he had Orders from Court to dicharge me; o I was at my liberty to go whither I pleas'd; this was the unhappiet piece of good news to me that could be, now I might go about my buines, I had no Money left; o I was fain to continue in my old quarters till I had recruited a little, and pas'd away my time there as well as I could. I had accidental convere with abundance of Strangers, for my Lodging being at a Publick Houe, and that City tanding on a very great Road into many Provinces, we had new faces came every day to quarter there as they travell'd, and their ort of Converation I found very diverting; and that for a man who had no great, but a hort allowance,
uch a ort of life was not very diagreeable: Among the ret, there came to lodge there one Monieur St. Sylvetre, an Officer of ome Note in the Army, I did not know him, but his humour, as well as mine, being free and eay to be acquainted, we oon fell into Company together; he came from his Regiment, which I think was quarter'd in Garrions in Franche Comte; and having fallen into the Company of a Gentleman of that City, call'd Servietes, (Father to him who has the fine Cabinet) This Gentleman came to him to invite him to Supper; St. Sylvetre asking him leave to bring me along with him, he was too much a Gentleman to refue; and I went very freely. After Supper he askt us if we would play a Game at Tric-Trac; I took him at firt word, being pretty well acquainted with that Game. We playd but for half a Pitole an end, and Fortune tood o neuter among us, that we play'd above four hours before any one of us had lot a whole one, and they both crying out we mut not part o, truly we play'd on till eight a clock the next morning, and by that time I had the good luck to have won an hundred Pitoles; the Cornet being quite overcome with leep, told me, he demanded quarter, for he could hold up no longer: I told him, it was for him to order that as he pleas'd; for that tho I had every jot as much an inclination to leep as he, yet I would not leave off firt, becaue I had gain'd; o being both agreed we left off play, under an agreement to go to it again after Dinner; o we lay down on the Bed, and having lept about four or five hours, they brought us ome Soup, and then we went to play more vigorouly than before, and Fortune continuing to favour me, I won five hundred Pitoles; at lat, conidering he could never recover o great a umm, and that we hould be likely to play all night again, he deir'd me to play him three hundred Pitoles a et, for three times running: I agreed to it immediately, and won the two firt currently, but then fortune turning upon me, I lot two more as quick; o that being jut where we began, we agreed to our three Sets again; thee Games were more tedious
than the other, both ides playing with more caution; but I had the wort of it at lat, o that I was come to two hundred Pitoles, which was all I had left, and o we gave over play. This was no inconiderable umm for the mall Game we began at, nevertheles he had once lot eight hundred Pitoles, by which we may ee there is nothing o dangerous as play.

This comforted me for my los with the Archbihop, and having got Money enough to carry me to Paris, I took my leave of him. It was a good while before I durt how my elf at Court, for I took it for granted, I hould not be lookt upon very well, after this lat affair of mine. Indeed we were got into an age, where the Miniters expected as much reverence as if they had been Petty Gods, and tho they could pretend to no more merit than uual, yet they pretended to make private Gentlemen how them as much repect, as Princes of the Blood: I went nevertheles to viit Mr. de Surenne, who I knew carry'd himelf after another manner; for as he came of a better Family, than any of them could pretend to, o he was much the more courteous and affable. I had the honour to know him at Cardinal Richlieu's, and had een him everal times ince that; he receiv'd me indeed with all that Civility which is o natural to him, and telling me that he was better pleas'd to ee me there than at Pierre Encie, ask'd me the particulars of that affair, I told him I had a great deal of trouble in it indeed: That the Cardinal had done by me as the Ape does by her young ones; for by loving me too much, he had been the caue of the ruine of my fortune; for if he had left me to follow the Profeion of Arms which I had choen, I had in all probability been in a better condition; that the War was my Inclination, and that had made me fall into it again under Cardinal Mazarine; that Fortune had however eem'd to cros my Undertakings, yet I was reolv'd to try her again; that on the other hand, I was now of an age which eem'd more to require Eae than a New Apprenticehip; yet
I could not but tell him, if he had occaion for an old Aid du Camp, or ome uch thing, I hould think my elf very well accommodated; that my young blood was ufficiently temper'd by my afflictions, he need not be afraid I hould ruine things by my rahnes; that I thankt God my mind was tay'd and ettled now; and yet when I was once a Horeback, I was as capable of undertaking the fatigues of the War, as I was at five and twenty, which he hould find if he pleas'd to make ue of me.

I made him laugh with the manner in which I offer'd him my ervice; and taking me at my w • rd, he told me, he would appoint me a Comrade, who, tho he was not o old as I, hould have no need of intructions; he meant one Clodore, who had been Captain in an old Regiment, and was one that I knew very well, which pleas'd me o much the better. This Man, tho he was very well known for his Merits in everal occaions, yet he was more known by omething ele, not o much to his advantage; he had the misfortune to have a Jilt to his Wife, and one time as he was coming from the Army, one of his Friends having oblig'd him to bear him company to a Houe of ill repute, his Wife, who in his abence took occaion to divert herelf that way, happen • d to be one of the perons produc'd for their Entertainment. You may judge how diturbing an Adventure of this nature mut be to a man of his Spirit; he did not only handle her very roughly upon the place, but ecur'd her, and put her into a Convent; and yet quickly after, by a urprizing turn of his reolution, epecially for one who had always been lookt upon as a Man of Honour, he chang'd his mind, took her back again, and now actually lives with her. This had been a great Diadvantage to him, for he was extreamly banter'd for it among the Souldiers; o that if I had been a marry'd man, I hould not have car'd to have joyn'd with him, for fear they hould have aid we were Comrades in every thing; he was overjoy'd, as he aid, to ee that I would erve again; o we prepar'd our Equipage together, in order to make the
Campaign in Holland, which prov'd o glorious.

Since the King had been marry'd we had everal hort Campaigns on every ide, but the Forces of the Kingdom were never all of them employ'd, except it were in that of Lile; the King had never engag'd any Commander of great Reputation in thoe little Expeditions, o that their failures made thoe great men to be the more eteem'd. But having now to do with the mot flourihing Republick, and whoe Wealth went beyond mot of the greatet Monarchs, he made choice of the two greatet Captains of Chritendom, the Prince of Conde, and the Marechal de Turenne. The Prince of Conde undertook this charge with a great deal of atifaction, having receiv'd everal Mortifications ince his return from the Spanih interet; for except it was in the year 1668, when they made ue of him for the Conquet of the Franche Comte, they made no Eteem of him; and this great Employment happen'd to him, more from the Marquis de Lovoys Jealouy of the Vicount de Turenne, than any repect to the Prince, notwithtanding all the great Actions he had done. The occaion of this Jealouy in the Marquis de Lovoys was, that during the Campaign of Lile, he thought the Vicount had the Kings Ear to his prejudice; and o to remove this great man he brought the other into play, who had been as it were, confin'd to his Houe at Chantilli, and had receiv'd everal affronts. Indeed this was to be taken notice of, that when the King ent ome Troops into Hungary, the command of them was given to his Couin, the Count de Coligny, only to pight him, becaue they two were at Enmity, and becaue every body does not know this circumtance, it may not be improper to relate it.

In the year 1660, as I take it, the King being to make everal Knights of the Order, the Prince of Conde had the Nomination of one, and the Count de Coligny made no quetion, but he hould be the man, becaue of the many obligations the Prince had to him, or at leat it hould have been the Duke of Luxemburg, who was then call'd the Count de Bouteville; and indeed
'twas thought the Prince would have certainly have preferr'd one of thoe two, as well upon the account of their quality, as that they both belong'd to him; but he having nam'd his Favourite Guitaut to that Honour, as it were over their Heads, the Count de Coligny was o candaliz'd at it, that he went to him immediately, and threw up his Commiion of Captain Lieutenant of his Gens d' Arms, and the ame time told him, that he did not deerve what he had done for him; that he had left one of the bet Offices in the Kings Houhold to follow his fortune, and in return of all, he had preferr'd before him a man that he could not o much as call a Gentleman; that he had Children, and if ever he hould live to ee them grown up, he would ooner pitol them with his own hand, than they hould ever engage in any ervice but the King's. 'Twas the Prince of Conde's character, that he was not the mot patient man in the world, but whether 'twas that he conider'd he had wrong'd the Count, or that he was willing to regain him by any means, he treated him very civilly, and told him, he had no reaon to be in uch a paion; ince if he had nam'd Guitaut, in prejudice of the Duke of Luxemburg and himelf, 'twas becaue, he believ'd their quality would, ome time or other, procure it for themelves, which Guitaut could not hope for from the meannes of his; that if he had known they would have taken it o ill, he hould perhaps have taken other meaures; that they hould therefore be atisfy'd, and it hould be no fault of his, if they were not better pleas'd for the future. Tho this was a great deal to come from the Prince of Conde, who did not ue to be o complaiant, yet the Count de Coligny withdrew from him in a paion, and was far enough from any reconciliation.

This was the chief reaon, as I noted before, for which they gave him the command of the Troops that were ent into Hungary; which o madded the Prince of Conde, that if he had not retir'd to Chantilli, where he had leiure to give vent to his paion, he had certainly dy'd with the Grief of it: Here he continu'd a long
time, under pretence of being troubled with the Gout.

But when the King aw himelf entring upon a dangerous War, he chang'd his carriage to him, and treated him with all the Carees imaginable; and hutting up himelf in the Cabinet with him and the Vicount de Turenne, he pent everal whole days with thoe two great men, to take his meaures for the enuing War from their known Experience. I hall not take upon me to relate the ucces of that Campaign, it would be too affected for Memoirs; beides the whole World is full with the remarkable Hitory of it: Only this I hall ay, that the Enemy being at a ditance, we took our own time, and made but very low footteps at the beginning of this War. The Vicount de Turenne, who foreaw what would happen, told the King, that 'twould not be always thus, and that if he did not proceed more vigorouly, he would find himelf in an error. The King had a great confidence in Monieur de Turenne, but the Marquis de Louvois, who, to peak properly, had indeed the direction of the Army, had no ooner dicourt the King about it, but his Majety quite alter'd his mind; o that Turenne finding he could do nothing with the King by his advices, having not the good fortune to be believ'd, let them take their own coure without troubling himelf about them. In the mean time I had my Office of Aid du Camp, which was eay enough to me; and when I thought leat of it, they were pleas'd to change my quality, and mitake me for a General, coming to me for Certificates. The Duke de Longueville had a great many Gentlemen in his Retinue, and amongt the ret the Chevalier de Monchevreuil, Brother to him who is now Colonel of the King's Regiment; he was a very compleat Gentleman, and had been very fortunate with the Ladies; for the Duke's Mother lov'd him at that rate, that one day when he came back from the Army, he her elf helpt to pull off his Boots, which was uppos'd to be, that he might the ooner be ready to erve her in another way; beides this, he was very much in the favour of everal other Ladies; inomuch, that if he had not ruin'd himelf
by gaming, he might have been in a very good condition; but he would play away all that ever came near him, whether 'twas his own or no; and one time he lot all the Advance Money of the Regiment of Normandy, which was put into his hands for Recruits. He had often practis'd thee tricks, o that he had not only lot his Reputation, but in ome meaure his ences; for he aw himelf reduc'd at lat, to uch extremities, that even ditracted him; yet for all this he could not leave off Play. He was no ooner gotten into Holland, but he begun afreh, and his old ill fortune continuing, he lot every penny he had; which bringing his old ditemper upon him, he became perfectly mad, and a Fever eizing him with it, in few days carry'd him out of the world. The Duke, his Mater, did not urvive him long, for getting ome Wine in his head, in the Prince of Conde's Camp, jut before he pat the Rhine, he made that foolih tep which cot his own life, and the lives of a great many brave Gentlemen. There being but a little time between both their Deaths, the Relations of the Chevalier de Monchevreuil came to me, to deire me to write to my Acquaintance in their Country, that he dy'd for Grief at the los of o good a Mater. 'Twas a very pleaant Requet, when I knew that they carry'd him to Nuits the day after we entred Rhineberg, which was at leat four or five days before we pat the Rhine; but feigning my elf ignorant, I told them I would do o to oblige them, tho I had been inform'd that he was ick before. I could not imagin, what hould make them deire this piece of ervice of me, except it was, that they had a mind to conceal the nature of his Death, to avoid a blemih upon the Family; but they had another reaon, for he having play'd away a great many peoples money, they had rather make them believe they had receiv'd it again, after his Death, than that he dy'd for Grief at the loing of it; and after all, 'twas a finenes that I could never undertand, for let it be which way 'twould, 'twas of no great conequence; and on the other hand, they might be ure to expect, that thoe perons would demand
their money; but the eldet Sons Etate was entail'd, who was the only peron they could expect it of; and if Madam de Maintenon had delay'd much longer to take care of that Family, they had been o far from paying Debts, that they had been reduc'd into very bad circumtances. I can't be thought to peak this enviouly to leen his quality, if you will but conider what I have aid of my elf, they may ee I do not flatter; and if it hould ever come to pas, that I hould be as rich as the greatet, I hould never be for boating of it. I did not indeed inquire of thoe Gentlemen what their end was, but thoe people to whom I wrote, wonder'd what the meaning of it hould be; for coming preently after to undertand that he dy'd ditracted, his Relations immediately concluded that I was the caue of it, and upon that account ow'd me all the ill will poible; however not one of them had the impudence to charge me with it; but as they were near Neighbours to Normandy, and Normandy is famous for Treachery, they did their utmot to ruin me; and if Madam de Maintenon had been in as much favour as he is now, they might eaily have done it, and the bet I could have hop'd for, had been to have pent my life in the Batile; but to my great good fortune her credit was not o great at that time, and o all they could do was to make Grimaces at me. The truth of it was, I never ought to diabue them, but taking not a word of notice, either good or bad, I let them alone to do their wort.

In the mean time our Army gain'd ground in Holland, and having pat the Rhine, we came to the Iyel, and paing alo that River, laid iege to Doesbourg. The Duke de Orleans, the King's Brother, was in the Army, and his Birth requiring, that he hould have the principal command, next to his Majety, he march'd on one ide the River, and the King on the other. He had nothing of the Air and Mein of the King; as much as one was majetick, o much the other had of meannes in his Countenance, and in his Manners; he had the very Looks of a Woman, and painted like the Sex,
which he did, becaue 'twas aid he had a Tetter upon his Cheek, and he would have been very much disfigur'd without it, which might be; but if he was excuable on that account, yet he was inexcuable in another, for he wore a Cornet in bed, like a Woman, intead of a Night Cap, not forgetting a Scarlet Knot, and a Riband of the ame to tye it under his Chin. 'Tis true, he was o aham'd of it himelf, that he would make all withdraw when he went to put it on; but as always there was ome Valet, or ome Favourite, that had acces to him, the tory became o publick over Paris, that all people knew it, and 'twas neceary he hould be very brave to have all thee failings, and yet pleae the French, who are very nice and cenorious; but indeed he wanted not that quality, for he who avoided the Sun, for fear of his Complexion, would at the ame time expoe himelf to Fire, fearles of Death. In hort, he laid hold of all occaions to ignalize himelf, which was not very pleaing to his Favourite the Chevalier de Lorrain, not o much out of tendernes of his Mater, as of that hare he was oblig'd to take in the danger; for tho he had acquir'd ome reputation at Sea, ome years ince, when with the Count de Guiche, and another, they ventur'd in a mall Shallop to burn a great Ship of the Enemies; they will have it, that he did it rather by the excitement of others, than any inclinations he had to uch actions: This was omething trange for one, that was Son to one of the greatet Captains, and one of the bravet Souldiers we have had a great while; this made me believe, that all the reports pread abroad of him, was nothing but Lies; but tho I was o charitable, the truth was too plain to be conceal'd, for the next year at the Siege of Maetricht, he behav'd himelf o in the ight of the whole Army, that there was no more quetion to be made of his Cowardice. But to return to the Siege of Doesbourg; Monieur Martinet, Marechal de Camp, and Collonel of the Kings Regiment, was very unhappily kill'd in the Trenches, by a Cannon-hot which came from the Duke of Orleans's quarter. The King was
exceedingly troubled at it, for he had indeed been very erviceable in the Army, • eing the firt that put the Infantry into that Order and Dicipline which we now ee among them; but the Souldiers, who like Brutes, that know not what is good for themelves, dilik'd him for his Severity, and were o far from regretting his misfortune, that they rather rejoyc'd at it. I may ay too, that a great many of the Officers were not orry for it, attributing the innovations in their Dicipline to him; which tho they depriv'd them of ome advantages they us'd to make, yet were really very much for the ervice of the King: However their Joy did them no ervice, for things did not return to their old condition again at the Death of Martinet; the Court too well approv'd of his Maxims not to continue the practice. The King, deiring to give the command of his own Regiment to one who hould be capable of following his teps, refus'd it to everal perons of great quality, who made their Court to him for it, and gave it to the Count de Montbron, who was but a private Gentleman, but who was already at the Head of the econd Company of the Grand Muqueteers, and whoe fortune had rais'd him to that Pot, againt the expectations even of all the world, as well as his own.
