Indeed tho he had merit, yet that was a place which was not to be obtain'd without favour too, and both little enough to gain it: He had erv'd at firt in the Regiment of Picardy, where he was a Captain; after which he was made Under-Lieutenant in Cardinal Mazarine's Company of Muqueteers. The Cardinal dying, the King took that Company, which was then called les Petits Mouquetairs, till uch time as Colbert Maulivriere bought them of Monieur de Marac, who then had the command of them; the name of the Company was then chang'd again, and call'd the Second Company of the Grand Muqueteers, which was done by the favour of Monieur Colbert his Brother; in the mean time Monieur de Caau, who dy'd Governor of Bergues, was before Mr. de Montbron, having always commanded this Company under Mr. de Marac; he eeing Mr. de Montbron
put in over him, thought he had injutice done him, and o gave up his Commiion, at the ame time that Mr. de Montbron had the guard of Madam De Pleis Belliere, who was confin'd upon the account of Monieur de Fouquett; this was the beginning of his good fortune, which afterwards was enc • eas'd by the affair of Monieur Colbert Maulivriere, who welling with Pride to ee his Brother o near the King, reign'd his Pot, becaue they refus'd him a coniderable Government which he would have bought; and Monieur de Montbron, who had wiely made his Court to the Marquis de Louvois, got leave to treat with him about it, and having marry'd a rich Wife he was the better able to compas it.

By thee degrees he came to be what we now ee him, and the King having given him his Regiment, and at the ame time having made him Brigadier of Foot, he quitted the Muqueteers to erve at the Head of thoe Troops. I was overjoy'd that the King had made choice of him for a Pot o coniderable, and having been always one of his friends, I was one of the firt to congratulate him; he receiv'd me very kindly, and told me he had formerly been oblig'd to me, and hould be very glad of an opportunity to erve me; I told him that 'twas now in his power to do it, if he pleas'd, that I had a Nephew, my Siters Son, who was in the firt Company of Muqueteers, for whom I would beg a Lieutenants place of him, if he had a Vacancy in his Regiment; or if not, the next that hould happen; he granted it me immediately, and the gentile manner of his doing it, oblig'd me more than the Gift it elf; for he went himelf to Mr. de Louvois, making the affair his own, and telling him a thouand things in favour of my Nephew, tho he had never een him in his Life. That which made him o very hearty to me was, that formerly, while he was not o great, I did him a very good p • ice of ervice. He had een a certain Lady call'd the M • rchiones de Courvaudo • , who was reported to have an
•• tate of 17 or 18 thouand Livres a year; and believing that he had indeed uch a Fortune, he had
propos'd to marry her. I happen'd once to go and ee this Lady, but without any deign in the world but to divert my elf in the Company, which was generally of the bet; he having put a little confidence in me more than ordinary, deir'd me one time very eriouly, to give her my opinion of the Count de Montbron, and of his Etate; I told her, that for his peron I could atisfy her preently, but for the other I deir'd a little time; that he was a Man of Honour, and deerv'd extraordinarily well, and that in general I knew he had a good Etate, but in two or three days I would tell her more particularly. I went preently to the Count himelf, and inform'd him of this converation, and deir'd him to intruct me what I hould ay; and he giving me my Leon in Writing, I did all I could to bring about the buines; but we had to deal with a Fool, who was yet not o eay to be manag'd as we thought for. She had amus'd a dozen people at leat at this rate, and while thus he talkt of Marriage with all the world, there were ome certain Sparks, who without troubling themelves with thoe things, had found out a way to come directly to the point, and conummate without Matrimony. She was both old and ugly, and but that he was a good Pay-mitres, would have had but few Cutomers; yet by the help of her Money he found ome who had tomach enough to be concern'd with her, and they had o drein'd her, that now, if he could find a fair motion to a Husband, there would be no great difficulty in the bargain.

The Siege of Doesbourg was fatal not only toA Swallow. Martinet, but alo to two more, who bore, as he did, the name of an Animal, which was oberv'd by the whole Army, one was Monieur de A Worm. Ciron, Governor of Mene • ou, and the other MonieurA Moue. Souris, Major of a Regiment of Suis. As for me, I was quite on another ide with my General, he being oblig'd to command in the room of the Prince of Conde, who acted with a eparate Army, and was wounded in paing the Rhine. We took Towns fater than we could march to them, for we no
ooner came before a Town but we found the Gates open, or at leat they made us no reitance, o that we took an infinite number of places, and excepting a little oppoition we met with at Nimeguen, we could hardly perceive there was any War; the reaon why the Enemies were in uch trange confuion was, the Diviions which were amongt themelves, beides that, they had no aitance at all from their Confederates, who eeing the Kings Army o powerful, durt not give him the leat hadow of digut, for fear he hould fall upon them; 'twas in hort a very lamentable thing to ee the condition they were reduc'd to, and not eaily to be expret, but you may gues at omething of it by this, their State was o perplext, that they entertain'd any thing that offer'd to erve, if there were but the bare looks of a man. Upon which I have heard a very pleaant tory of an Italian, who offer'd his ervice to the Penioner of Holland to raie a Company, who being examin'd if he had been a Soldier, and whence he was, and the like, after giving anwer to thoe quetions, he draws out his Sword, and tilting at the Wall, how'd them that he was a brisk fellow; but the jet of the cae lay here, the Penioner having objected, that he was an Italian, and conequently a Papit: Yes, ays he, I am o, ince you mut know it, but this Sword is a Protetant, and ready to erve the States and your Lordhip. The Penioner lik'd his blunt way of anwering o well, that intead of a Company, which he askt, he made him Lieutenant Collonel of a Regiment; but he had no ooner finger'd the Money than he ran away, and never rais'd a Man.

The Enemy being often thus cheated, and the diorder of their affairs encreaing daily, began to think that a Peace, however diadvantageous it might be, would be les o than the War; by which in les than a month, they had lot three whole Provinces: This was the opinion of ome of the more timerous people, but the Prince of Orange was of another mind, and to that end dipatcht his Courriers to his Uncle, the Marquis of Brandenburg, to remontrate the tate of affairs to him,
• nd how it was his interet to joyn his Forces with the
States; that we took indifferently his Towns and theirs, all was alike to us. Tho the King was erv'd the bet, and mot exactly in the world, yet his Spies, who he kept in that Country, gave him no account of this, till eight days at leat, after the Vicount de Turenne had advis'd him of it. I know not by what means he got this news, but he came himelf to the King about it, and informing his Majety of what he had heard, told him, Now was the time for him to make a Peace, infinitely to his advantage; by which, at leat, he might demolih the greatet part of the Towns he had taken, and keep his Army entire to oppoe his Enemies. The King would have the opinion of the Prince of Conde upon this affair; and having ent a Courrier to Arnheim, whether he was carry'd to be cur'd of the Hurt he had received, the Prince immediately gave the ame advice. The King aw of himelf the neceity of their advice, yet could not take their Counel; for having left all things to the management of the Marquis de Louvois, who thought he knew more than both of them, he let lip the opportunity, being lull'd aleep by that Miniter, with the hopes of eaily defeating all the Contrivances of the Germans: And as generally one error draws on another, epecially with thoe that will never acknowledge themelves in the wrong, they taid till th • e Succors appear'd in the Field, and more from other parts, and never follow'd that advice, till it came to the lat extremity. The Prince of Conde, and the Vicount de Turenne were very much dioblig'd to ee the Marquis de Louvois harken'd to, o much to their Dihonour, and the Damage of the King's Affairs; and if Louvois had not made up this Micarriage by extraordinary Services, perhaps the King had not been o well atisfy'd with him, as we now ee him.

Monieur de Turenne being come before Arnheim, ent to compliment the Prince of Conde, and to know how he did, as to his Wounds; and tho the Meage eem'd to belong rather to a Dometick, than an Aid du Camp, yet he was pleas'd to confer that honour upon me, as well to how that Civility to me, as that I might dicoure
of ome other affaairs. I found him very much out of order with the hurt he had receiv'd, inomuch that in peaking to me, he was fain to interrupt his dicoure by the pain of his Wound, which occaio • 'd me to cut hort my dicoure as much as was poible; and jut as I took my leave of him, the Duke of Mecklenburgh came into his Chamber; they had told him in the Anti-chamber how bad he was, at which he put on an air of concern and orrow, and entering the Chamber in a fantatick manner, or rather like a Fool, Fructus Belli, Monieur, begins he, Fructus Belli, and repeating thoe words at leat a dozen times, he comes up to the Bed, without making him any other Compliment. I would have taid a little longer in the Chamber to ee the end of this Comedy, but my repect to the Prince oblig'd me, againt my will, to withdraw; all I could do, was to tay in the Anti-chamber with Deroches, the Captain of his Guards, and deire him to go in and ee what became of that Maggot; but he told me, I would take him for a Coxcomb, if he troubled himelf to go in for uch a thing, that I did not know the Duke of Mecklenburgh, if I expected he hould ay any thing which was not very illy.

In the mean time the Marquis of Brandenburgh, drawn by the force of the Dutch Money, more than the Prince of Orange's Arguments, had given his word to march to their relief, upon which they not only broke the Treaty of Peace which was then on foot, but maacred their Chief Miniter, who they upected to hold intelligence with us. Many others were ruin'd in the ame fury, and amongt the ret Mombas, one with whom I had had everal affairs for a Gentleman, one of my Relations, nam'd Brinon, whom he had notoriouly cheated. Mombas had lent his Mother ten thouand Crowns, and had taken the ale of a peice of Land worth 40 thouand Crowns for his ecurity, upon promie of repaying the overplus of the Money, but the Contract was no ooner made, but he began to put a great many ham tricks upon him; o that the poor young man, who undertood nothing at all of the Law, had
ignorantly given him a Dicharge for 40 thouand Francs, hoping thereby to facilitate the payment of the remainder; but intead of that, Mombas procures everal pretended Creditors, who made Demands upon him; and tho Brinon, before he engag'd the Land, had ummon'd all his Creditors to make their Claims, more or les, as was owing to them, and to receive their Money; yet did he make this a new obtacle, and reduc'd the poor Gentleman to uch an Extremity, that in a great deal of trouble he came to me. I poke to Mombas about it, who pretending to be honet, promis'd me to end the affair in fifteen days; but telling me that he had not Money at Paris, he would give it him in Holland, if he would go thither with him; the unhappy Gentleman went with him, but when he had him o far off, he forc'd him to lit himelf a Soldier in his Company, and then made him ign to what he pleas'd. I was in a rage when I heard of it, but the thing was pat remedy, the Notary having ign'd it, o <> 'twas forc'd to be let alone, and the more, becaue 'twas at leat ix years before he came back again; and for my young Kinman, he let him perih in miery, not giving him one penny beides his Pay.

This thing lying always upon my thoughts, made me malicious enough to rejoyce at his digrace; for it was almot as great as that of the Penioner of Holland, aving that he did not loe his life; for he lot at leat 20 thouand Livres a year, and underwent a evere Imprionment. During this, the Vicount de Turenne was commanded to march againt the Marquis of Brandenburgh, who approacht at the head of 24000 men; and being about to pas the Rhine, the Sui • e made ome difficulty of it, upon pretence that, by the Treaty with the King, they were not to be oblig'd to go into Germany: Monieur de Turenne told them, that thoe were old tories, which they ought not to credit, and their principal Officers having diown'd it, they oblig'd the Souldiers to follow the Orders of M de Turenne; he had given order to conult the Elector Palatine, and having ent me to him upon ome •• ines
of conequence, the Elector would make me dine with him, he was pleas'd to let us be very cheary together, and I was not the firt Frenchman that he had invited to dinner; he did his bet to make us all drunk, and if we had been as willing as he, he had ent us home in a very fine pickle. There was a comical ort of a fellow at the Table, who had introduc'd himelf into favour by inventing a trange kind of Intrument, I know not what to call it, but by clapping it to another man's ear, you might peak to him at a ditance, and yet no body hear you; this fellow was one that put himelf forward upon all occaions, but had not wherewith to anwer it. He had a Woman whom he maintain'd at a orry rate, and often at the Electors cot; for when he thought no body aw him, he would lip the Wing of a Fowl, or any other good bit, underneath his Plate, and afterwards very dexterouly into his Pocket. We had not taken notice of his Ingen • ity, but the Steward, to his great misfortune, happen'd to ee him pocketing up a young Turky; o he came and whiper'd the Elector in the ear, and told him, that if he would give him leave, he would make him ome port; the Prince, who lov'd nothing better, would fain know how; t'other excus'd himelf, and aid, the tory was too long to give him an account of, but if he pleas'd to give a hint to the French Officers, as they roe from Table, that they hould not take any thing amis, whatever was done: The Prince was very well pleas'd, and did as he deir'd him; and they had hardly aid Grace, before the Steward came, and told him, there was certainly a Knave in the Company, for ome body had taken off a piece of Gilt Plate from the Side-board; and if he pleas'd, he deir'd that every body might be earcht, to ee who had got it; we being told, as I aid, that there was ome Frolick in hand, was not concern'd at this, but cry'd out, by all means, and that the Steward had reaon for what he aid; o putting our elves all in a row, the fellow was oblig'd to do o too, and after the Steward had pretended to earch ome of us, he came to him, and found the young Turky in his
Pocket; he aid not a word till he had hold • n't, and then lugging it out by the Legs, he how'd it to the Elector, crying out, that in looking for one Thief he had found out another. The Elector laught ready to kill himelf at this Farce, and o did we too; without doubt this would have put any man but him out of countenance, all the Company taring at him; but he, who was as impudent as a Court Page, laught as fat as any of us, and peaking to the Elector; Tis true, my Lord, aid he, I took a little orry Turky, here, to carry home to my Dog, that is a little indipos'd, and has a weak tomach; but this Gentleman here, Mr. Steward, methinks hould have let it alone, who is o us'd • o cheat your Highnes, at leat of a whole Ox a day. The Repartee took extreamly, and the more, becaue 'twas o harp upon one who ue to pretend very much to that Talent himelf. And the Elector was o pleas'd, that for the future he order'd he hould have a dih of meat always provided for him.

After I had done my buines with the Elector I took my leave, and return'd to give an account of my meage to Mr. de Turenne. I told him alo the tory of the Turky, which gave him diverion enough. In the mean time the Army marcht along the Banks of the Neckar, and when we were within a league of Wimphem, all the Officers came and made a complaint to him, that they were paid in Money that would not go; that 'twas a trick of the Paymater, who no doubt receiv'd good Money, but put them off with this Money for the advantage of the Exchange. The Paymater was my friend, and I reolv'd to let him know, aoon as poible, what was doing, I found him o perplext, that I could eaily dicern he was guilty; but eeing him o cat down, I told him there was a remedy for all things, and therefore he hould not be o much concern'd; and ince it was o, if he would be rul'd by me, I would tell him what he hould do: Hearing me talk thus, he told me in the greatet paion imaginable, he hould owe his Life to me; confeing ingenuouly, that the deire of aving omewhat by it had put him
upon doing it; I found him o troubled, that I was afraid, if I did not tell him what I had to ay quickly he would dye with the fright. So I askt him how much the lat Remittance was which he had receiv'd, and if he had ince that, paid any other Money than that bae Coin; he told me no, for he had receiv'd it from Strabourg, intead of the Louis d' Ors which he had from the Treaury; that the lat Remittance was of 200000 Francs, but as he had told me, he had turn'd it all into this bad ort of Money: When he had told me this, I bid him go and draw out a particular of all the Money, as well what was paid, as what he had in Cah, but to diguie his hand o, that no body might know it to be his writing; that when Monieur de Turenne hould end to earch, as he would not fail to do, he hould tand in it, that he had receiv'd no other but uch Money, and offer to produce the account to make it out; but in the mean time to appeae the Officers, he hould pas his word to them, that if they had any of that Money left at the end of the Campaign, he would give them other Money, or good Bills for it; and to make them eay, to deire Mr. de Turenne to make an Order, by which all the Suttlers were commanded to take it, upon the penalty of ten Crowns a man; he found my advice very much for his advantage, for Mr. de Turenne ending immediately after, and eeing the account I mention'd, he told the Officers, the Paymater had paid them no Money but what he had receiv'd, that they ought therefore to be atisfy'd with his Offer, and making at the ame time an Order to the Suttlers, there never was any more aid of it. By this means the Treaurer, not only ecap'd the Punihment he fear'd, but alo made a very great Advantage to himelf; for the Suttlers bringing back the Money to him to change, he got three or four Sous a Crown out of them too. He was o oblig'd to me, that he offer'd to lend me any Money I wanted, but I having no occaion thankt him, and refus'd it.

Monieur de Turenne, not contenting himelf to have pat the Rhi • e, as I aid before, and after that the
Neckar, oblig'd the Marquis of Brandenburgh to retire beyond the Mein, which he alo pat after him. I cannot imagin why he avoided the • ight o, having more men than we by one third, unles it was, that if he hould hazard a Battel, and have the wort, he knew he hould leave his own Country too much expos'd; however it was, tho he was Agreor in this War, yet he was the firt that deir'd a Treaty of Accommodation, and we promis'd to retire out of his Country, provided for the future he hould meddle with no body's affairs but his own. The buines of Brandenburgh being thus at an end, Mr. de Turenne return'd to the Rhine, but the Troops were o fatigu'd with thoe Marches, that 'twas even pity to ee them; and yet they were o far from allowing them time to refreh them, that they were immediately forc'd to begin a new Campaign, the King being then jut going to undertake the Siege of Maetricht: He durt not attack it the year before, and tho he had always an Army about it, yet the Garrion fail'd not to brave them in their Camp; and the Officers were o bold, that they would come pickeering, and challenge ours to exchange a Pitol with them, and 'twas none of their fault, if we did not try our force with them; among the ret, there was none who expos'd himelf more than Somerdike, who not only came out as the ret did, but in particular was continually inulting the whole Army, and no body could hoot him, which made people believe, he had fortify'd himelf with ome Charm; and a Trooper telling me o very eriouly, and that he had known everal perons that had done o; I laught at him, upon which he told me, I needed not go far to be convinc'd, for that he himelf had one; and if I doubted it, I hould fire a Pitol at him, and tand but three paces off, and that he had try'd everal. He et me in a great fit of laughter at thee words; and he finding me till of the ame mind, pret me to try him with my Pitol, whether he aid true or no; which I refuing, he was o mad, that he told me if I would not make the experiment my elf, I hould ee him make it before my face: Upon which
he immediately goes from me till he came within Pitol hot of the Countercarp of the Town. I not imagining his deign, perceiv'd that he endeavour'd to fetch off a Cow, of which there was a Herd grazing, as big as a good Flock of Sheep; there was above 200 hot made at him, before he came at them; and certainly 'twas a very pleaant ight to ee a man run taring after a Cow (having eparated one from the Herd) in the midt of the Muquet hot, which in an infinite number were fir'd at him from the Town. At lat, after having thus diverted the whole Army, and me in particular, who knew the occaion, he brings the Cow to me, and askt me if I believ'd him now? I protet, I could not tell what to ay to it, but I put it off with telling him, that this was all by good fortune, which words were unhappily the caue of his attempting the ame the next day, when he was kill'd for his pains.

During the time that all things were preparing for the Siege of Maetricht, I went to into Alace and Lorrain, by Orders from the Marechal de Turenne. Going to Beffort I aw the Governor there, who was but a young Soldier, to command in a place of uch conequence, which I could not forbear taking notice of to the General, to which he very wiely gave no anwer at all; but the Count de Florenac, younger Son of the Duke D'es, who had not o much command of himelf, askt me what Country I came out of, and if I did not know, that the Women rul'd all now adays? that that Gentleman I poke of, was the Brother of Madam de Maintenon, the faithful Confident of Madam de Mont • pan, and he might be allow'd a place or two, provided he made his Court, as he ought to do, to the Kings Mitres; by this dicoure he eem'd to reflect on the conduct of the Prime Miniter, as if it had been him that had made o bad a choice: In hort, to explain himelf, he aid, that by the example of Monieur Colbert, who triumpht in the Reign of Madam la Valliere, o Monieur de Louvois was reolv'd to triumph in that of Madam de Montepan; that it was for that reaon he o much epous'd her interet, and if we might credit
reports, he was none of the leat concern'd in her preent advancement. We were all of us urpriz'd to hear him reaon o gravely, who came of a Family that never was fam'd for any tore of Undertanding; but Nature had been kinder to him than to his Family, for he had ometimes very happy allies of Wit; and he had added another miracle in his favour, that he was the firt of his Name that could pas for brave. In hort, there was nothing o trange as to ee any of the Houe D'es in the Army; which caus'd that Satyr upon him in the Scandalous Chronicle, that he was not the true Son of his Father.

For all this Monieur, the Governor, undertood one part of his Office well enough, for he had made the Town preent him with everal coniderable Summs of Money; and had it not been that they knew what power upported his interet, they had complain'd of him at Court. I told this to the Count de Florinac, who continuing his Vein of Wit, anwer'd, that I needed not wonder at that, for he had an excellent Schoolmater, having been documented by the Ma • echal de la Ferte, who tho he had got the Gout in his feet, had not lot the ue of his hands; that one hours intructions from uch a Man as he, was better than a months teaching by another; and then related to me the practices of the Marechal during his Government of Lorrain, and told me o many paages, as would take me two days time to relate; but amongt the ret, he told me one thing I hall never forget as long as I live, and which I'll give you an account of, as a ample to judge of the ret by. He told me, that the Marechal being come to Nancy, the Magitrates came to wait upon him, brought him everal Preents, and among others a Pure of Gold Counters, every one weighing two Louis d' Ors, having on one ide the City of Nancy, and on the revere ix Fue • s in a Fee, which are the Arms of the Houe de la Ferte. That when they were gone out, he lookt upon them again, and liking them very well, more for the Metal than the Device, he would have been glad of uch another parcel at the ame price; and to that end
ends for the Townmen again, he pretends he did not know what Town that was which they had repreented, and they returning that it was Nancy: You are mitaken, certainly, ays he, why this does not look like it, for 'tis too little for it; if you had made the Model bigger, one might have gue • it to be Nancy, but this does not how it all. I would have you go and make another, and let the Town be decrib'd at large upon it, that the fine Towers and Steeples may be ditinguiht, one can ee nothing here. The Magitrates undertood him well enough, and being unwilling to quarrel with him for a matter of 100 Pitoles, they went and brought him a preent of Counters as big as Medals, the ize of which pleaing him, he never examin'd the figure.

This was no tory to tell the Vicount de Turenne, tho I had made it publick enough to others; for 'twas not the way to make ones court to him, by telling him any thing that lookt like a reflection upon another peron; he was crupulous in things of this nature to an exces, and our young Sparks, who were of different entiments, us'd to banter him with it, and ay he was not a man fit to live in this world; but all this could never alter his temper, nor make any impreion upon him. Tho ometimes it might be aid of thee people, as it was aid of the Father of the preent Duke de Lude, who tho 'twas at the expence of his fortunes, could not forbear breaking a jet upon Marie de Medicis the Queen Mother, who asking him for her Vail, ( Le Voile in the
• rench Tongue ignifying • Vail, or a Sail of a Ship. Le Voile) anwer'd her, there was no occaion for a Sail for a Ship that lay at Anchor, alluding to the Marechal d' Ancre, who they aid was her humble Servant. Indeed thee young Blades gave him a great deal of ditate by their foolih carriage; and I having the opportunity of eeing what notice he took of it, when they were abent, and ometimes to their faces, knew the better how to govern my elf. In the mean time, tho we had made Peace with the Duke of Brandenburgh, yet the Fire was now kindled in Germauy, of which we oon felt the
conequence. 'Twas the Emperors interet not to uffer the Kings Forces to come o near the Rhine, epecially conidering the Leagues he had made with everal Princes of the Empire, which the Emperor lookt upon as o many Marks of his Ambition, and therefore ollicited alo the Princes of the Empire to confederate with him. The Dukes of Lunenburgh were very fond of it, as being afraid to have o dangerous a Neighbour as the French; and everal other Princes being united, the King was not only oblig'd to end an Army into Alace, but alo to make a hort appearance there himelf. After the taking of Maetricht, Monieur de Tur • nne was particularly commanded to guard this Frontier, and having marcht into the three Bihopricks I was quarter'd at Metz, near a Houe which was taken up for the Count D' Ile, Collonel of Hore, who was there with his Regiment. I was not very well, and therefore went to Bed betimes, and being jut got to leep, I was wak'd of a udden with a great Out-cry, as if the Houe had been on fire. I roe immediately, and lipt on my Gown to ee what the matter was, and perceiving the noie was in the treet, I lookt out of Window, where I aw the Count d' Ile's Landlord crying out for help after a hideous manner; I was not acquainted with the Count d' Ile, but jut knew him, he being a Catalonian, and their Cutoms were a little too rough for me, who without boating, I may ay had learnt how to behave my elf well enough, by living with the Cardinal de Richlieu; however being oblig'd to take the Souldiers parts, as I was one my elf, I dret me immediately, and having taken my Sword, I was no ooner got down, but going up to the man that cry'd out o, I askt him, if there was no way to quiet this tumult? By good fortune he knew me, we having lodg'd together once in an Inn at Verdun, and making ome compliment to me, Yes, Sir, ays he, I will be judg'd by you, you are a Soldier, and you hall ay whether this hould be o or no? This Gentleman, who is quarter'd at my Houe, after having eat and drank what he pleas'd, will needs have me let him lye with the Cook; now what would he have me
to do? Or what does he take me for? Don't you know me to be a Man of Honour? I profes to you, tho I came down tairs mighty eriouly, this tory made me laugh, and eeing the man had got a great Rabble about the Houe already, I deir'd him to quiet them, and I would go and accommodate every thing for him. I had much ado to perwade him, he telling me, I had to do with a Devil, that would but laugh at me; but bidding him not fear, I made him go into his Houe, where we found the Count, who had lockt himelf in with one of the Kitchen Wenches, and would force her to lye with him: I call'd to him to open the door, and told him my Name, but 'twas to no purpoe; at lat I was forc'd to tell him, that I came by Orders from Mr. de Turenne, which he would know better when he aw me. I took all this care, that he might not upect me to deceive him, and when he heard that, he durt not make any farther reitance; I told him Monieur de Turenne knew nothing of what had happen'd, yet, but he would oon, if the uproar continu'd, and I would leave it to him to imagine, how he would reent uch a diorder; he, who we knew was a worn enemy to all uch irregularities; that they aid he would needs have a Cook Wench; why he might have twenty by to morrow, if he was put to uch hard hift; but to force a Man of Honour to furnih him for his Debauch, was a thing no man would take, and the bet contruction the World could put on uch an action, mut be to ay he was drunk, and that it was an ill extremity to be forc'd to excue one folly by another: I deir'd him to reflect on thee things, now while he had time for it, let, when 'twas too late, he hould come to repent it.

The Count d' Ile hearing me dicoure at this rate, grew a little mild; however it being the humour of thoe people, that tho they are in an error will never acknowledge it, he told me, that for my ake, he would relinquih his right, but that I knew well enough it was his due. This dicoure was o ridiculous, it had like to have renew'd the quarrel, if I had not topt
his Hot, who was jut riing up again, and having pray'd them both to be peaceable, and live quietly, ince it was but for o hort a time, I made them hake hands, and promie to drink a Glas together the next day: His Hot, who was an honet man, told us with all his Heart, and he would give us a Breakfat; and the Count d' Ile, who pretended to tand upon his honour again, told us he would conent, provided he might treat us again at Night. Thee civilities between them, left me no room to quetion, but they were both thoroughly reconcil'd, o I e'en went to Bed again, and there had never been a word made of it, if ome body had not foolihly told the tory among the Souldiers, which made the poor Count be mot horribly banter'd in the Army; and when he went by they would ay, There goes our Friend that would have kit the Cookmaid: Would it not have madded any body to have been o diappointed? And for me, they told me, that truly I had done very ill to poil port in that manner, and to prevent me for the future, they would have a Law made, that I hould mind my own affairs, and not meddle with them. The Count d' Ile aw himelf o rally'd with this ort of talk, that there being Troops to be detach'd to Catalonia, he procur'd an Order from Monieur de Louvois to be ent thither, out of the way. The Spaniard was by this time come into the Confederacy, and to prevent the ruine of Holland, attempted to give us ome diverion, and in order to that, had form'd a deign upon Charleroy, in which they were aited by all the Dutch Forces, but they fail'd in the attempt; which might have led them to conider, how unfit a match they were for o powerful an Enemy. The Count d' Ile thought by this means to have avoided the raillery of the tory we have told, but intead of that, he carry'd into his own Country, a character which perhaps would not have reacht o far, had he continu'd where he was: In the mean time we were preparing for the War in Germany, the Emperor having now effectually declar'd upon us; and as Alatia was like to be the Scene, on which the firt appearances
were to be acted, Mr. de Turenne gave orders for the fortifying Saverne and Hagenaw, beides Briac, where everal new works were made to trengthen the place. The Souldiers rejoyc'd at thee great preparations, and they were in the right of it, for they were afe now from being disbanded, which otherwie would certainly have follow'd, if the Peace had been made with Holland; for me, I was too old to expect making my fortune by the War, and therefore was far enough from pleaing my elf at the news; but on the contrary, was really griev • d for the People, who had been deliver'd from the calamity of a ruinous Campaign, if they had pleas'd to have us'd the Hollanders a little gentler upon the Propoitions of Peace; but they carry'd it o high with them, that contrary to the Genius of that Nation, they joyn'd with the Inclination of the Prince of Orange, who pret them to the War, and was reolv'd to proecute it, whatoever it cot him, having built all his hopes upon the ucces of it.

The King, who knew very well, he had no General o fit to command in Germany as the Vicount de Turenne, continu'd him there, tho he wanted him elewhere, having great affairs upon his hands: For the Englih, who at the beginning of the War was on our ide, had left us in the lurch, the King of England having deerted us, and pretended he could not help it, on ome reaons of State which had oblig'd him to it. In the mean time our Coats were expos'd to the Decents of the Hollanders; and we, who being all along aited by the whole Naval Force of England, and durt do nothing to them at Sea, were not uch Fools to tand in their way now. In this extremity the King was forc'd to ummon the Ban and Arriereban of the Kingdom, of whom he ent a Party into Lorrain, let the Duke, who the King had long ago deveted of his Principality, hould take this opportunity to recover the Poeion. Seeing uch a bloody War at hand, I was orry I was no younger; and whatever obligation I had to the Memory of the Cardinal de Richlieu, I reflected a little on him for taking me from a Profeion,
that, as old as I was, I lov'd o entirely; however I would not be thought o old as I was, nor I would not keep company with people of equal years, let they hould make me eem older than I was indeed; but affecting not only the Company and Manner of the younger Men, but a certain ridiculous Air of Gaiety, I mut needs put on a flaxen Perriwig, when my Beard and my Hair was as grey as a Gooe. Mr. de Turenne had a certain Gentleman call'd Roiguiot, a Man that fancy'd mightily to wear a long grey Beard, and to look always like an old man; this fellow was my courge, and as if he had a mind to plague me, he would be always telling me of Locates, and of my being ent for by the Cardinal Richlieu. This was certainly the mot glorious action of all my life, and yet I could not bear his telling me of it, becaue he would be always aying too, that he was but a Child at that time, and that his Uncle us'd to cure him with that tory, telling him, that Vertue never went without a Recompence: For by this tory people begun to look upon me, and wonder'd at me, that being o old, I would appear o young, telling me that I could not be much les than fourcore. I was made at this dicoure, and bluht oftner for anger than hame; yet others that were but lately come into the Army told me, that I lookt very well, in which they did not know how they pleas'd me; yet this did not top the other dicoure, but every day one Blockhead or another would be raiing of it again, inomuch that nothing was more welcome to me, than when ome Order came to get on Horeback, and there I was as young as any of them. I have often been aham'd of my elf in my own thoughts, that I hould be uch a Fool, and that I hould be the firt that hould condemn it in another; how hard a matter is it for us not to be opinionate of our elves; for after having experienc'd this in my elf, I never reflected upon other perons for the like.

'Twas a very fine ight to ee the Nobility when they entred Lorrain; if one had not known they had been
Gentlemen, one hould rather have taken them for Hog Drivers; and tho mot of them were arm'd with Plumes of Feathers, it became them jut as well as it did me to make my elf a young man. However this was only the appearance, for they did their duty, only that they could not pretend to keep them in order, epecially with uch people as commanded them, who knew no better than themelves, and made greater mitakes than the Soldiers; and yet as ignorant as they were, they thought they knew o much they needed no teaching: They endeavour'd indeed, to find out ome old Soldiers among them to make Captains, but either they had forgot the Service, or indeed never undertood
<> and o were all one with raw and undiciplin'd M •• . The Duke of Lorrain, an old experienc'd Commander, falling in upon thee people, made no g •• at difficulty of routing them; and knowing that the Marquis de Sable, who commanded the Nobility of A • jo • , lov • d a oft Lodging, after the French Mode, and took no manner of care, he beat up his Quarters, pill • g'd them, and took him Prioner. If this Sable had been • Man of any Spirit, this digrace would have enrag'd him; but he was o very debaucht, that if he did come into the Army, 'twas purely by force, he had no tomach to it, nor had never made a Campaign but once at Lile; and that was becaue the Duke de Sulli his Brother-in-law, committed his Troop of Hore to him, being as much uch another Soldier as himelf. I may ay this without reflection, for all the World knows what happen • d to that Duke in Hungary; that at the Battel of St. God • art he had got o much Wine in his Head, that he •• uld not get a Horeback, but laid himelf down <> a Couch in his Tent, whilt his Men were <> engag'd with the Turks; which being kn • wn at Court, was o reented by the King, that he immediately order'd a Party of Soldiers to be quarter'd upon his Etate. For my part I was willing to believe, with the ret of his friends, that this was only a misfortune which happen • d to him, and that he was really brave enough. But to have convinc'd all the World of
this, he ought to have done, as the Duke de Villeroy did, who, in the Campaign of Lile, having quitted his Pot in the Trenches, and perceiving that people laught at him for it, brav'd Death it elf, the next Winter, in the Franche Comte, where he expos'd himelf more than the meanet Soldier in the Army.

But to return to the Marquis de Sable, he was carry'd to Strasburgh, where the Duke of Lorrain reti •• d, having his ordinary reidence in that City with his new Dutches, who was of the Family of Apremont; who tho he was a very fine Woman, having not had the Small Pox, which has ince ruin'd her Beauty, yet this old Duke marry'd her more for his Interet, than for her Peron: There had been a Suit at Law between him and her Father a long time, in which the Duke was cat, and to avoid paying the Debt, he made up the buines by marrying his Daughter. The Marquis de Sable, who was a very compleat Gentleman, beli •
ving that this circumtance, together with the great diproportion of Age between the Duke and the Dutches, might be a ufficient ground to form an Averion between them, was reolv'd to make a tryal, and having more inclination to an Amour than to the War; thought 'twould make him ome amends for his Imprionment, if he could gain o delicate a peron to be favorable to his Addrees. 'Tis hard to ay, whether he ucceeded in his deign or not; but if I hould be as forward to cenure, as the people that liv'd in the place, I hould make no quetion of it, but take it for granted, as they do: But as I am not apt to judge o lightly, and epecially in caes of uch moment, where the Honour of a Peron of uch Quality is concern'd, I hould rather chooe to ay, that tho 'twas probable it might be o, yet 'tis not afe judging by probabilities; however it was, the old Duke was not altogether without upicion, and to be ure of him, he haten'd him away, and ent him back into France. Any Man, but Sable, would have been more enible of the Glory of an Intrigue with uch a Princes, than of his Liberty; but he, who took his own way, was glad to be gone, and
o return'd to Paris, where he oon comforted himelf for the los of his Mitres.

As for the Duke of Lorrain, having nothing to diturb him, he pent his time when he was not in the Field in ome Employments, which were very particular to himelf. He would go and viit the meanet Burghers, and would take more pleaure in their company, than that of Perons of the greatet Quality. I have een him play trange pranks when I was at Bruels. I have een him dance in the open treet among the Mob, to the common Tunes of thoe people; and he took that opportunity once to make a coniderable Preent to a Lawyers Daughter, who he had an Intrigue with. It was the fahion in Bruels, to give the young Ladies Garlands of Flowers for the Head; he gave her one, where there was Flowers indeed, but 'twas et with Diamonds beides. They judg'd from thence, that he was extreamly taken with her, for Liberality was not his character, but rather the contrary; but this was not the only proof he gave her of his Paion for her. She had a Mother who had an averion to any thing of a Soldiers coming near her Daughter, therefore he diguis'd himelf like one of the Long Robe, that he might come to ee her, and the young one perwaded her Mother, 'twas a Preident of Nancy, and the good Woman very honetly believ'd her. This ort of diguie was very common, but he had a great many others, in which no man took o much pleaure as himelf: He lodg'd in the Rue de Fripiere, call'd o from the Pawn-brokers who liv'd there; and I aw him one day dret like one of thoe people, and he had lain all the Door and Window of his Lodging with old Cloaths; o that one that did not know him, would have taken him for one of that Trade; and he himelf itting without, in a great Chair, with an Apron before him, colding with his next Neighbour, all one as if he had been his fellow. In hort, unles 'twas they who had known him very well, every body took him for a Broker. One day a Trooper came and cheapned a Buff Coat which hung up among other old Cloaths; the Duke told him
he hould try it on before he made him any price; and o taking it down, he put it on for him, which the other let him do, not imagining 'twas the Duke of Lorrain; but the Duke d' Archot coming by with a great many other Officers, could not conceal their knowledge of him, eeing him in uch a figure; by which means the Horeman finding his error, and not knowing what would become of him, got up a Horeback, while they were a making their Compliments to one another, and not daring to tay to pull off the Coat, rid away with it. The Duke, who had no mind to loe it, runs after him in the treet as hard as he could drive, but the other having ix Legs to his two, 'twas all to no purpoe. They rally'd him very heartily upon this accident, which they thought might have made him leave off thoe ort of diverions, but 'twas all one with him, he was at it again in two or three days, having a temper o naturally inclin'd to omething odd and unuual, that he was never better pleas'd than when he was thus expoing himelf: This was the caue he was o very much belov'd by all the common people where ever he came. In hort, he was always familiar with them, and would go to Dinner with a poor man, aoon as with a rich; he would tand Godfather to any of their Children, and would have all uch whoe Children he had o tood for call him Brother, he would at leat call them by no other name, and often has been een to top in his Coach at a poor Trademan's Door to ask how his Goip did, and all the Family.

But to return to the War: The Enemy was o trong, that Monieur de Turenne was oblig'd to give ground, and they took up their Winter Quarters on this ide the Rhine. Our Troops however being canton'd in the Neighbouring Villages, with order to keep trict guard, having apprehenions from everal quarters Mr. de Turenne had poted perons of great experience at every quarter, that if any thing happen'd, they needed not come to him for Orders, not he needed not be oblig'd to march in peron, it being impoible he hould be in all places; and he had choe to pot himelf about Phillipsburg,
where the Enemy eem'd to bend their greatet force: As for me, I had been o extreamly fatigu'd with making two Campaigns in one year, that I was left behind ick in the Quarters of Monieur Pillois, Brigadier of Hore, where, when I verily believ'd I hould dye, I was cur'd by a kind of miracle; for when every body had given me over, a Trooper that was taken Prioner by one of our Parties, and was put into a Houe next Door to where I lodg'd, told me, he would undertake to cure me, if I would give him as much as wou • d pay his Ranom. The price was o mall, that I made no difficulty of bargaining with him, • he gave me a Doe made up with Brandy, Sugar, Ci ••• mon, Pepper, and a certain Powder which he had in a Tobacco B • x. This Compoition o trengthned my Stomach, that in eight days time I was able to get on Horeback. Aoon as I was well, I reolv'd to go to Mr. de Turenne, who everal times in my Sicknes had the goodnes to end to the Quarter, to know how it went with me; but Mr. Pillois would by no means let me go yet, for fear of a relape. During the time he kept me thus, I had an opportunity to do him a piece of ervice, which very much oblig'd him, and which, without vanity I may ay, was very much for my Reputation, tho I took no great pains in it neither; the Enemy had beieg'd a little Town near Homburg, and he having Orders to relieve it, drew together what Troops were at hand, which making not above 2500 Hore, he found 'twould be a difficult thing, the Beiegers having receiv'd a great Reinforcement, o that they were at leat even or eight thouand Men; he call'd a Counel of War about it, and every body was of the opinion, that 'twas not a thing practicable, without expoing the Troops to manifet ruine. I aw him o extreamly afflicted with it, that made me try if I could find any way to comfort him: I had heard ay, that ometimes Policy goes beyond Strength, and being reolv'd to tudy upon it, I put my invention to the rack, and at lat a thought came into my head, which afterwards had a ucces as happy as I could deire.
This was nothing but to write a Letter to the Governor, that it not being proper to attempt the relief of the place with les than ten thouand Men, Monieur Pillois could not get ready before, but that now he was marching to his uccor, and by two a Clock the next day he would give the Enemy a Viit, and that he hould only hold out the place o long, and he hould be an Eyewitnes of the Sport. This Letter was to be carry'd, directed to the Governor, but o to be contriv'd, that it might fall into the Hands of the Enemy; and alo it was to be order'd, that he who carry'd it hould not be privy to the deign neither. Having laid all thee meaures, I deir'd Mr. de Pillois, that he hould get the richet Man in thoe parts he could meet with, and threaten him, that if he did not carry that Letter afe, he would not only burn his Houe down, and all that was in it, but he would certainly hang him, if ever he came home again; he had confidence enough in me to do all this for me, without inquiring upon what account; and having got a Man, he would fain have excus'd himelf upon the account of the difficulty of paing the Enemies Lines, but he had as good have aid nothing. Mr. Pillois told him, in hort, he hould either go of this Errand, or of another into the next World; o eeing there was no remedy, he prepar'd to go on the Meage: But while he was getting ready, my Hot, who I had gain'd with a promie of a great reward, got before him, and taying by the way, met him, and made him believe he was going about ome buines the ame way. Thus jogging on together, and falling into dicoure, he who had the Letter to carry told him, what a trait he was in, adding that he was undone both ways, that if he hould perform his Meage, he hould be taken in the Camp, and hang'd for a Spy; and on the other hand, if he did not, he hould leave his Wife and Children to the mercy of Monieur de Pillois, who beides the plundering and burning of his Houe, would treat him in the wort manner that could be imagin'd; that he had told him what would be his fate, o that there was no room to flatter himelf;
that he had thrown himelf upon Providence, being unable to make a choice, when it lay between his own Life and theirs, who were as dear to him as his life.

My Hot pretended to pity his Misfortune, and to gain more upon his belief, accus'd Monieur de Pillois of Cruelty; however after a great deal of talk, and expreing his concern for him, he told him, that if he was in his place, he would e'n go and urrender himelf into the hands of the Enemies, and tell them by what Threatnings he was oblig'd to carry the Letter; that they would let him carry it into the place, or they would not let him, but either way he would ave his Life, and his Wife, and Children, Mr. de Pillois believing he was taken, endeavouring to execute his Orders, could have nothing to ay to him; and the Enemy on t'other hand, would do him no hurt, eeing he had put himelf voluntarily into their hands. The Man thought this was an admirable expedient, and reolving to take that coure, gave him a thouand thanks. My Hot eeing him in o good a mind, had done his buines, and feigning that he was to go no farther that way, left him, and coming back the ame way, he met Mr. de Pillois, who marcht at a venture with his 2500 Hore; he gave us an account of what reolution he had left the Man in, and we taking it for a good Omen, made no quetion, but the Enemy would take it all for truth, and the rather, for that the Man himelf had been really made believe, there was a very great force ready to march to raie the Siege; in hort, what with the Man's Report, and the Letter together, they were o frighted, that they immediately reolv'd to raie the Siege, and retreat.

We receiv'd this News when we were come within three leagues of the Enemy; and Monieur de Pillois having then no buines to go any further, marcht back to his own Quarter, where in a little time he receiv'd Letters from the Court, which complimented him extremely on this happy ucces; not but that it was known by abundance of people, that I had a great hare in the action, but as he was the General, and they bear
the Reproach of ill ucces, and o ought to have the Credit of the good; o alo it was jut he hould have the Privilege his place afforded him. And indeed I ought to ay this in his praie, that he was a Man that perfectly undertood the Cavalry, and perhaps there was none in the Army went beyond him, of which he gave an undeniable evidence a little while after; when in the Fight at Eineim, he refus'd to charge at the command of Monieur de Vaubrun; for eeing that the Enemy kept their advantage, he choe rather to tay till he drew them out of their Pot, than to obey and be beaten. I do not ay he did well in diobeying, and he that had erv'd o long, ought to have known, that nothing can dipence with our obeying the Order of our uperior Officer; and he found the effects of it afterward, being cahier'd for doing it; but yet he how'd by that action, that he undertood his buines better than Monieur Vaubrun who commanded him; and the Court was o enible of it, that tho they could not allow the fact on account of the example, yet they allow'd him a Penion of a thouand Crowns a year, that it might not be aid he had erv'd o long, and o well, for nothing.

Jut as I was come back from this Adventure with Mr. de Pillois, there came an Officer to me and made me a very pleaant Compliment, which was, that having been pleas'd to quarrel with Mr. de Montperoux, Maitre du Camp of the Regiment de Rovergne, he had occaion to cut his Throat a little, and deir'd me to be his Second. I told him I was very much his humble Servant, and I how'd my elf o mot effectually, for intead of going to fight, as he imagin'd, I took care to have us dicover'd, by which I prevented him from fooling away his Life. This Monieur de Montperoux, was a very tout Man, but o very hy, that 'twas difficult to conform to his temper; he had his Sallies of Humour, which made him very ridiculous; but of all his Whims that was the pleaantet, when the King gave him the Regiment; for after the King had told him, he granted the Regiment to him, he begg'd his Majety to give it
the Name of ome of the Provinces of the Kingdom; tho it was not the cutom then, except for the old Troops; telling the King, that he was o little known in his own Country, that if the Regiment hould be call'd by his Name, no body would lit themelves in it. The King thought this was omewhat trange in a Gacon too, who generally value themelves extreamly, and don't ue to fail o in their own character; however the King would not deny him, and he behav'd himelf with a great deal of Bravery, till at lat, as it often falls out with thoe who erve a long time in the Armies, he was knockt on the Head.

As for me, I was till Aid de Camp, and tho the King had everal in the Army who wore long Beards as well as I, as the Marquis de Angeau, and the Marquis d' Arcy, yet none of them would pretend to dipute the Seniority with me; however I was till very vigorous, and Monieur de Turenne would ay of me ometimes, that 'twas pity I began o late, and that, if I had as good a contitution of body to the War, as I had of mind, I hould have been able to do any thing. Indeed I us'd to tire two or three Hores a day; I was o contantly riding about in every corner, that they call'd me the Petty General of the Army. I did not do this to make people believe great things of me, but 'twas my delight; and I always choe rather to pleae all the world, if 'twas poible, than to give offence to any; and I know but one man in the whole Army, that complain'd of me, and I leave the world to judge, whither that was my fault or no. In the Regiment of Hore de Harcourt there was a Gentleman of Vexin, call'd Bellebuine, whoe Father having been one of my acquaintance, a Captain in the Guards, I thought my elf oblig'd now and then, to give his Son a hint of my obervations of his conduct, and I had told him of everal things which I thought were not very much for his reputation; indeed he was very debaucht, and tho he had a very honet Woman to his Wife, yet he run away from her, and follow'd a Gang of naty common Whores: This could not but produce ill effects on him, and all that I had foretold him came to pas; he was lookt upon in the Regiment, as one who 'twas candalous to be een with, and beides he had done two or three very dihonourable actions, and to compleat all, he brought the fould dieae with him from Paris; and whether he wanted Courage, or was unable to erve on thee accounts, I know not, but he came to me one day, and deir'd me to ask leave of Monieur de Turenne, for him to go omewhere to be cur'd: We had then the Enemies Army jut at our Trenches, and thnking it was not a proper time for any Man to leave the Army, I gave him my opinion, that Mr. de Turenne would not
grant it him; he would not take my word for it, but eeing I refus'd to peak for him, he went to Monieur de Turenne, and askt him himelf, but he told him the very ame thing as I had aid, which not atisfying him, he went away without leave. In hort, I had good reaon for what I aid, for the Armies engag'd in a day or two after, and had he taid till then, I hould have made no difficulty to have poke to Monieur de Turenne for him; and Monieur de Turenne who was very civil to him, told him, if he would have patience two or three days he hould go; but going his own way to work, he was cahier'd, as he well deerv'd. God knows I never accus'd him to Mr. de Turenne, but aid all I could in his favour, when they told him of it; nevertheles, he took all the digrace that was done him to be my doing, and they wrote to me from Paris, that he threatned me trangely; I made a trifle of it, and indeed I knew him too well to be afraid of him, but I was oon taught, that the bravet Men are not always the mot dangerous Enemies; but on the other hand, a Man has nothing to ecure himelf againt Malice and Treachery. In hort, I was no ooner come back from •• e Campagne, but one night as I was going along the Fauxbourg St. Germaine very late, three Men et upon me with naked Swords in their hands, and I knew him to be at the head of them. I was not o much urpriz'd, but that I had time to ask him in cold blood, if it was poible for a Gentleman to be concern'd in uch a piece of Villany. I confes he had been in a great many ill actions, as I have before oberv'd; and now, having reduc'd himelf to the lat extremity, he had lited in the Gens d' Arms, where, tho I do not ay but there may be ome honet Gentlemen, yet I hall not fear to ay alo, there are others, who will tick at no manner of crime; here it was that he furnih'd himelf for all ort of Villany, and I believe 'twas by concert with thee people, he that undertook an action o horrid: I was in the more danger from thee Rogues, becaue 'twas very late, and I could hope for no help from the Watch, for they were gone, it
being near day: But I had not o much work with them as I expected; and taking care to et my back againt a Shop, that they might not come behind me, I tood upon my Defence; I have wondred a thouand times, reflecting on the paage, how it came to pas, ince they had Villany enough to contrive uch an action, that they had not arm'd themelves in another manner; but o it pleas'd God to order it, I kept them off in that fahion with the point of my Sword, till at lat a Coach was heard, which was the Duke Lediguieres; aoon as ever the Villains aw the Flambeaus they fled; and the Duke, who was in his Coach, knowing me by the light, made his Coach top, and askt me what was the matter? I would not tell him the name of him I had o much reaon to have expos'd, out of my repect to his Relations, who were very honet people: I only told him, I had been attacqu'd by three fellows, I knew not who, and if his Grace had not come by in the minute, I did not know how it might have far'd with me. He tept out of his Coach immediately, for fear of a urprize, and we walkt along together two or three whole treets, but could ee no body. But this was a day of trange adventures; coming to a new Houe, which was not above half finiht, we heard a grievous groaning, which was like a Woman's Voice: Mr. de Lediguieres order'd his Footmen to go into the Houe, and ee what was the matter, and we follow'd them; but I was trangely urpriz'd when I aw what it was: 'Twas a Young Woman extraordinarily well dret, and to appearance of ome Quality, with a Maque on her Face; he was fallen in Labour in that place, and without any manner of help but a ort of a Girl, that was not like to be capable of doing her any ervice; I was extremely mov'd at her circumtance, and aid omething to her to make her enible of it; but Mr. de Lediguieres, who was a hard-hearted Man, fell a laughing at her, and was a going to make her pull her Maque off, and if it had not been for me, I believe he would have done it, for he aid a great many hard things to her which I did not approve
of: I had a great deal of difficulty to get him away, but having at lat perwaded him, I did her a great kindnes, for I aw he had almot tifled herelf with her Mask for fear of being known; and if he had been to keep it on much longer there had been no aving her. I had the Curioity the next day to go and inqure about her, making all the decription I could of her Dres and Shape, and the like, I got o much information, that I undertood 'twas a Councellors Daughter, that pat for a young Saint: However, tho he was of no mean Family, yet the Child was expos'd to the Parih, and the Commiary was jut taking it away as I came by: If I had thought fit, I could have given him ome light into the matter; but conidering that I ought not to ruine a poor Girl, who without doubt had been drawn in, I never poke a word of it.

However this affair of Bellebrunne that befel me, made me bethink my elf, and I was jut a going to his Captain, the Prince de Soubize, who I had the honour to be particularly known to, and I knew he would do me jutice; but then conidering 'twas a orry Wretch I had to do with, I thought 'twas not worth my while, only I would look to my elf a little better; o I took care to come home betimes at night, and if I was out late, I always took ome of the Watch, who for a mall matter would guard me to my Lodging; by which means I avoided him in the night, and he had not Courage enough to attack me by day light.

I had follow'd the War now three years, in which time I had plaid the good Husband o well, that I had three years Rent in Bank, which I think was extraordinary for my Pot, where 'twas not the Cutom to be aving; for my pay was 100 Crowns every ix weeks, and truly I made bold to live upon Monieur de Turenne for my Diet; o that I never was in a better condition in my life. But knowing not well what to do with my Money, I enquir'd after an opportunity to put it out; and peaking to a Friend of mine about it, he told me, he could accommodate me himelf without my eeking any further; that he had lent 20 thouand
Francs to a Gentleman of Provence to buy a place with, and had taken a Mortgage of him for it, and he would enteret me in it if I pleas'd; and that, tho it was not uual, yet he had a Counter Security alo upon the place to the value of 20 thouand Crowns, between him and the Marechal d' Humieres, who had lent 40 thouand Francs on the ame account; o that I hould run no hazard in it, and hould oblige him too. This lookt o fair that I had nothing to object, and being alo very willing to erve him, I fetcht him my Money, tho I had intended to have put it into the Fund for Annuities, or at leat into the Town-houe. Indeed I had better have done o, but I was born to be a Beggar. I receiv'd the interet but a very little while; and the Gentleman dying, the King gave the place to Monieur de Briac, Major of the Guard du Corps, without any regard to the Obligation the other had made: I had laid my meaures o foolihly, that intead of taking an Aignment of the Deed from the peron I lent the Money to, with his Security for the payment, I let him be quit, and my elf be contituted in his place; o that all the hopes I had, was upon the ucceion of Monieur d' Arboute, who held the aid Government; but then undertanding that he owed already more than he was worth, that thought was at an end; but •• en we reckon'd, that if the King had an account of the Cae, he would caue Monieur de Briac to pay us; and the rather becaue the Marechal d' Humieres was concern'd, who we thought had interet enough to appear for us; the peron I had done this withal had great Friends too, it was Mr. de Saillant, Brother to Mr. de Montauban, Lieutenant General in the King's Army; but tho this Man did his endeavour, the other did not tir in it, telling us 'twas to no purpoe, for that Mr. de Briac not being able to pay us, to trouble the King about it, would but be to ask him to give us o much Money out of his own Coffer: But this did not atisfie Mr. de Saillant and me; and as I did not care neither to appear too publickly in it, all the care of the matter lay upon Mr. de Saillant, who to ay the truth, par'd no pains in
the buines; but 'twas three months before he could have a word of anwer, tho he had given abundance of Petitions to the King with his own hand; at lat Monieur de Louvois told him, that if he would not offend the King, he hould deit his pretenions in this affair, and think of omething ele to ask of the King to make him atisfaction. This was enough to let us know our Money was lot. But Monieur de Saillaut thinking himelf oblig'd on my account, but chiefly on account of his own Family, not to be put off o, preented till everal other Petitions to the King, to one of which the King anwer'd him himelf, that he might know of the Marechal d' Humieres how that affair tood. Mr. de Saillant having told me this, I troubled my elf no further, thinking that Mr. d' Humieres having already told us his mind, he had made his Court at the expence of our Caue, but I did him wrong; for very generouly he had told the King, that if he had not importun'd him, 'twas becaue his Majety had already been o bountiful to him, and that in his Majeties favour he could not be the poorer for the los of 40 thouand Francs; but that it was otherwie with Mr. de Saillant, who, beides that he was not very rich, had alo a very great Family; as for me he aid nothing, for as I aid I did not appear, and I aw alo that Mr. de Saillant did what • as poible. One would have thought o handome a Declaration as this of the Marechal d' Humieres hould have done us ome ervice, and that the King, or Mr. de Briac would have paid us; but they thought no more of that, let they hould be oblig'd to pay the Marechal d' Humieres too: o that Mr. de Saillant had for his lat anwer, that he hould not pres it any farther, but rather eek for omething ele to ask of the King; he car'd not for all this neither, but till continued olliciting, tho to no purpoe at all.

But to return to my other affairs, which this tory has too much diverted. The year 1675 being begun, I prepar'd again in the Campagne with Mr. de Turenne: He had finihed the lat o gloriouly, that there was nothing known like it; he had fought four Battels in
one Summer, with uch unequal Forces, as any body, but he, would have been overthrown; but his Conduct, or his Courage, always upply'd his Want of Numbers; and in the lat fight, with not above 25000 Men, he drove the Germans back over the Rhine, tho they were at leat 70000 trong. In other places where the War was more dipers'd, it was till proportionably uccesful on our ide, the King having taken the Franche Comte; and the Prince of Conde, who made head againt the Prince of Orange, having taken his Baggage at the Battel of Seneff, and made him raie the Siege of Oudenard. In all thee places there fell a world of Men, and a Peace eem'd equally needful to both parties, but one thing rendred it impoible to be effected. The Marquis de Grana had been too cunning for Prince William of Furtemberg, now Bihop of Strasbourg, and had urpriz'd him in the City of Cologne, and taken him Prioner; and this had quite broken off all the Treaties then on foot for the Peace of Chritendom. He was carry'd to Neutadt under a trong Guard; and the Emperor, who knew he was deep in the interets of his Enemies, and afraid too of his capacity, reolv'd to detain him, tho the action was condemn'd by all the world, as againt the Laws of Nations; the Prince being at the Aembly at Cologne, on the part of the Elector of that name; and the violence offer'd him there was enough, without any further deign upon him: and people were the more concern'd at this too, becaue of all things the Emperor himelf was a Prince far from any uch ill deigns; but ome of his States-men perwading him, that he could not be afe without it, and that this Prince William had as much credit in the Empire as himelf, he made his Judgment toop to his Interet, and o his ruine was concluded on; and if the Emperor had been les religious he had not liv'd long. In hort, they aembled the next day, more indeed to make a formal Judgment, than to examine much into his Affair; but the Emperor would have but three of his Miniters there, of whom the Prince de Lokowits was one. They condemn'd him to loe his Head, and
the Execution was appointed to be in private, and not to be known till it was over. But the Prince de Lokowits, who ign'd the aid Sentence much againt his Will, whither it was that he was a Penioner to France, as his Enemies gave out, or that he thought that manner of proceeding would reflect upon the honour of the Emperor his Mater, ent word to the Popes Nuncio, and deir'd him to go to the Emperor, and to threaten him with the Cenure of the Church, if he uffer'd this Sentence to be executed. The Nuncio, who had already Orders from the Pope to interceed for the Princes Liberty, was very ready to forward the matter, and ent immediately to demand Audience of the Emperor; who being urpriz'd, when he undertood he was acquainted with an affair which he had committed to o few perons: the Emperor did all he could to find out how he came by the information; but the Nuncio told him, his Majety knew well enough what he told him was true, and begg'd his Majety to conider what might be the effect of uch a proceeding. The Emperor, who is a mighty religious Prince, and whoe Concience would not permit him to contradict the Pope, uffer'd himelf to be bluter'd out of his intentions, by the high words of this Church-man, and o chang'd the Sentence from that of Death to cloe Imprionment. It was alo a great tep to his Deliverance, that he had taken up the Habit of an Eccleiatick, for that was the Nuncio's great Argument to the Emperor, that he had nothing to do to put to death a Man who was conecrated to the Church; and that if he was guilty of any crime, the Pope ought to take cognizance of it.

But if the Prince de Lokowits found means thus to ave the Prince of Furtemberg, he ruin'd himelf by it; for the Emperor preently upecting that this Intelligence mut come from him, caus'd him to be arreted, and eized upon his Secretary at the ame time, who they put to the torture. It is hardly to be imagin'd the barbarous uage they both receiv'd; for beides this affair for which they were reolv'd to plague him, the Empres, that then was, ow'd him a pleen, for oppoing
her Marriage, which he could never forgive him; he had indeed puht on the Match with the preent Empres, and had the other dy'd ooner, perhaps he might have made hift to have got off clear; but the Empres hating him, every one made their Court to her by puhing at him, till at lat he was ent to one of his own Catles, where they found means to poion him, and o ent him out of the way.

Thee things had rais'd uch a ferment on both ides, that intead of Peace, or the hopes of it, the Flame of War was kindled more violent than ever. All the preparations imaginable were made on every ide; but after all, fortune till declar'd for us, and every year before the Enemy could be got together, the King had taken two or three of their bet places; by this means the Low Countries grew weaker and weaker, tho indeed 'twas chiefly by the negligence of the Court of Spain; for intead of committing the Government of thoe Countries to an experienc'd Soldier, that undertood things, the Duke de Villa Hermoa was then Governor, who had never erv'd in any degree above a Captain of Hore, and was no way a match for the old politick Commanders in the King's Army. The Spaniard had another failing too, which was that they wanted Money to make Magazines for their Forces; whereas the King could take the Field in the middle of Winter, and his Men had no neceities to encounter, but the everity of the eaon; all thee things ought to have inclin'd them to a Peace, and mot people thought it would have done o; but the Miniters of State eeing with other Eyes, they reolv'd upon the continuance of the War, to the great regret of all Europe, who was quite weary of uch a long and bloody contention.

I had till my old pot, and being of o ill an age for action, I ought for no other; and finding that Monieur de Turenne was almot ready to go into the Field, I got away before with my little Equipage: As I went by Courtenai, I found a Spanih Officer of the Regiment of Grana, call'd Cueillette, who had been taken Prioner at the Battel of Seneff, and was returning into Germany
with ome private Soldiers, who had run the ame fate with himelf; they had an Order for Quarters, paying for what they took; but the Sheriffs were forc'd to put them all into a Barn with Straw for their Lodging; the Officer was lodg'd in an Inn, and I becoming acquainted with him there, we lodg'd together for three or four times; I found him a very civil Gentleman, he told me he was a Lorrainer, and that he had been Page to the Prince Charles, now Duke of Lorrain. His company was very agreeable to me, epecially ince I travell'd no fater than he, only it cot me a little dearer; for when we came to Bar Sur Scine, he told me his Money was all gone, and that Monieur Louvois having made him attend everal days for his Pasports, he had pent his Money, and knew not how to get more till he hould reach to Mets; that if I would defray his Charges o far, and his Men, I hould extreamly oblige him, and he would certainly reimbure me when he came there. I believ'd all he aid, and did more for him than I hould have been perwaded to do for one of my own Countrymen; at leat unles I had known him very well: I told him he hould not be diturb'd, I would let him have what he had occaion for. When we came to Mets, he told me, the Man who he was directed to, was gone out of Town, o that intead of paying me what he had promis'd me, he mut beg me to continue my aitance to him, and upply him till he came to Strasburg, that there he had abundance of Acquaintance; and that aoon as ever he came there, he would punctually repay me all I had laid out for him: I did not mitrut him yet, but upply'd him with whatever he wanted; but from that day to this I could never ee one penny of my Money; and 'tis the leat that I can do, to give this caution to uch as read thee Memoirs, to take heed who they trut in that manner: I have been ince told he is become a Capuchin, but he might have paid his Debts firt; for I do not undertand they have any more priviledge than other people to rob their Neighbours.

In hort, Monieur de Turenne oon after being come to the Army, he had about as much caue to be pleas'd with the Inhabitants of Strasburg, as I had with Monieur Cueillette; they promis'd him a thouand things which they never perform'd, but he might have known them, for they had us'd him jut in the ame manner the year before; this oblig'd him to pas the Rhine, to prevent their giving up their Bridge to the Enemy; but all the Country being ruin'd, it is impoible to tell you what difficulties we were put to for want of Forrage, and for fifteen days together our Hores eat nothing but Weeds we pickt up and down near the Camp. The Quarter Mater General of the Hore, gave Monieur de Turenne an account of this every night when he went for Orders, telling him the Cavalry could not ubit any longer, if they were not permitted to Forrage, for it had been a long time ince he would uffer them to go out for that upply; but Monieur de Turenne anwer'd him, that they would never dye with hunger, as long as there was Leaves upon the Trees, and if they wanted they might go and gather them if they pleas'd. The Enemies far'd no better than we did, and we did nothing on neither ide but watch to ee which would break up firt, o as the other might make ome advantage of it; for if we had a great Captain at the head of our Army, the Germans had no fool with them, being Commanded by no les a Man than Montecuculli, who had hown us a piece of his skill at the beginning of the War in the firt Campaign, when feigning to march way, he countermarcht immediately, and went directly the contrary, and on a udden urrounded Bon in uch a manner, as we could by no means relieve it. Thus the two Armies lay and both uffer'd great inconveniences, till at lat they came o near, as 'twas thought they could not part without coming to a Battle, and every one was overjoy'd at the hopes of being deliver'd at once from all thee mieries; but jut at the very moment, when Monieur de Turenne thought the hour of Victory was come, he was kill'd with a Cannon Bullet, by the fault, in part, of Monieur de St. Hillaire, Lieutenant
General of the Artillery; I ay by his fault, becaue Monieur de Turenne having poke to him to go along with him, to view where he might place a Battery, he mut needs tay to put on a Red Cloak, by which they were known to be Officers, and that made the Enemy fire at them; and the ame Ball that kill'd the one, hot off the Arm of the other, as he was pointing at omething they were taking notice of together.

If another was to tell this tory, you might expect ome account of the trange conternation which eiz'd the whole Army upon this unhappy accident; but I can give no ditinct relation, for the confuion I was in my elf was o great, that I minded no body ele, nor took no obervations of other matters; this I know, that every body gave themelves over for lot; and the more, becaue the Marquis de Vaubrun, and the Count de Lorges, without conidering that the condition we were in requir'd a common unity for our general afety, fell to making Factions and Parties, and to draw the great Officers to their ides, about the principal Command. This had certainly been the ruine of the whole Army, if it had continued but two days, but ome of the graver heads remontrating to them, that this was not a time for them to dipute Punctilio's of Honour, and point of Command, but to conider the Honour of the King, and that they would be call'd to an account for it if things micarry'd upon this core: At lat they perwaded them to refer their pretenions to ome of the principal Officers, choen by the ret to decide it between them; and o the differences being compos'd, we began to retreat towards the Rhine, where we had a Bridge of Boats. But we had taken everal advanc'd Pots very near the Enemy, and 'twas neceary to draw our Men out of them before we decampt, which we did without any los, etting fire to our works, and principally at Willeat, where all the Mills were burnt. The Enemy, aoon as ever they had notice of the Death of our General, imagining we would reolve to retreat, as we did indeed, prepar'd to fall upon us; and decamping the very moment that we began
