to retire, they attackt us at a Pas of a little River; the Fight was very obtinate on both ides, ours being enrag'd at the los of their General, and the other in hopes to make their advantage of our Confuion, knowing we had lot our principal dependance; but neither Party had their ends, for the Germans being oblig'd to repas the River with the los of a great many men, we had the honour of the Action; yet however we were forc'd to proceed on our Retreat, and that with all the caution imaginable; and the Enemy having waited upon us to the Rhine, we pat that River in ight of their Army.

My Commiion being void by the Death of Monieur de Turenne, I reolv'd to leave the War; and there being a great many more in the ame circumtances, we form'd our elves into a little Troop, that we might be able to defend our elves if we hould be attackt; for beides that the Country was full of Schepepans, a ort of people as dangerous as the Enemy, the Germans alo had pat the Rhine after us, and fill'd the Country with their Parties, and we met with one of them preently, with whom we engag'd, and had the good fortune utterly to defeat them by plain force: We took the Officer that commanded them Prioner, and they that took him having earcht him, they found a Pasport in his Pocket, which they brought to me, for they had made choice of me to command them, till we hould be pat danger. This Pasport eem'd omething particular to me, for among us there was no body took Pasports, but uch as belong'd to ome Garrions; but they told me they did not belong to the Body of the Army, but to certain Troops which the Enemy had poted in everal places in Alace. While he was talking with me, I perceiv'd ome Blood to run down his Coat, upon which I told him, I doubted he was wounded; he told us he was not, for he knew nothing of it; but when he aw his Blood he chang'd colour immediately, and which was very trange, in a moment more he dropt down dead; whether 'twas really from the greatnes of the Wound, or the urprize of it that eiz'd him, which I
am more apt to believe; for certainly Fear is capable of producing more extraordinary effects than that: And the Marquis d' xelles, Collonel of the Dauphin's Regiment, told me a tory a few days ago, that at the Battel of Cael, one of the Soldiers fell down dead in the Ranks, before one hot was fir'd, jut as they were going to charge. 'Twas a great good fortune to us however, that this Man dy'd thus, without which, I, and all my Troop, had been taken Prioners, for we were hardly got a League farther, before we met with another Party of the Enemies Hore, who were at leat three hundred trong. I was a little urpriz'd, for our Scouts had not had time to come to ask them who they were for? But ome of their body came up to me, and askt me who we were? It came trangely into my Head, at the very moment, to make ue of the Pasport, I told you of, and with a greater preence of mind than was uual to me in uch caes, I told them, we belong'd to uch a Garrion, naming the place the dead Officer had belong'd to, and to confirm it I how'd them my Pasport, which they taking for granted, let us all go. 'Twas a great happines to me, that I was pretty well Mater of the German language, o that they never imagin'd me to be a Frenchman, for that indeed was what deluded them mot. Being thus happily got out of their Clutches we purued our Journey, and arriv'd afely in France, where they had given over all for lot upon the Death of Mr. de Turenne. The King himelf indeed expected ome diater to fall out, and therefore had ent an Expres to the Prince of Conde, who was then in Flanders, to put himelf at the Head of the Army in Germany, with all the Expedition imaginable. The Germans were et down before H • genau, but the Prince of Conde advancing with a reolution to fight them, they rais'd the Siege: They had alo appear'd before Sa • erne, and rais'd ome Batteries, and for three days together had fir'd upon the Town, and thrown in a great many Bombs; but this only erv'd to encourage us again, eeing they made no better ue of the advantage they had. I was jut arriv'd
at Paris, when the news of thee things came thither; but nothing urpriz • d me like the tory they told of ome Jews in thoe Towns, who had got a way to put out the Fue of the Bombs, jut as they were going to break. They threw themelves deperately upon them with the Hide of an Ox jut kill'd in their hands, and topping the Mouth of the Fue o that no Air could get in, they put the Fue quite out. It had been a brave contrivance for the Genoees to have had ome of thee people with them, upon the late recounter we had with them; which if they had their City, which was the mot magnificent in the world, had not been reduc'd to that condition we are told it now lyes in.

The death of Monieur de Turenne was daily in my thoughts, and if I had had the leat inclination to a olitude, I believe this alone would have caus'd me to have retir'd to a Cloiter; but that ort of life having been always my averion, I made no advantage of the example that great man left me, who had reolv'd to retire himelf among the Fathers of the Oratory if ever he had out-liv'd the War. I peak this to my own hame, that an old Fellow as I was of above threecore and ten, hould be o fond of the World at that Age; that I could not be perwaded to forake it. To peak the truth, I did not eem o old as I was, as I have aid before, for tho I might have been truted afely enough with Women, yet my Age it eems did not appear o much, but that I was capable of making ome people jealous: Indeed I was the occaion that a Gentleman of Picardy, whoe name I hall conceal, made a pretty ort of an eay upon his Wife, which might have been a fine Hitory if it had been publick, for being become extraordinary jealous of his Wife, he gets him a Fryers habit, one of the ame ort he knew his Wife went to Confeion to, and having brib'd her Page to be true to him, he order'd it o that when he ent the boy for her Confeor, he hould bring her word that he was not well, but that he had ent one of his Fellows of the Order. In the mean time her Husband dret himelf in the habit, and went to her Chamber, which being a dark Room, he
did not fear being dicover'd; being there, he began to make trange work with her, for he intead of acting the Confeor, examin'd her particularly if he had not entertain'd me, and he could not imagine why after all he could ay to him, till he repeated the ame quetion to her over and over, which he did alo to inform himelf of ome other upicion which he had in his head, if I might believe what he told me the next day; he got nothing from her but what he did not care if all the World knew: But the truth was he knew him by his voice which made her be cautious, and he had Wit enough not to let him perceive it; but both made a jet of their Religion, one to atisfy his jealouy, and to find out, if it had been poible, the Intrigues of his Wife, and the t'other, to cure his Jealouy if he could, which only made him ill natur'd.

While I pent my time thus, the Kings Army had enough to do to repule the Germans, and hardly cou'd keep them from preing into France it elf; for the death of Monieur de Turenne was not the only misfortune that befel us, for there happen'd a wore at Treves, were the Marechal de Crequi was o intirely beaten, that we have very rarely heard of uch a defeat; mot people, epecially thoe that did not know how things were carry'd, thought the accident which befel M. Vignori, the Governour of Treves, was the occaion; they thought I ay that he having agreed with Mr. de Crequi to ally out and fall upon the Enemies Rear, and being kill'd in the march, which the General knew nothing of, was the caue of the diater, it being impoible to provide againt all things, but I mut explain this; for Mr. de Crequi knew well enough before that his Hore had thrown him and broke his Neck, the Kings Lieutenant of Treves having ent him word of it by an Expres: the real occaion of the misfortune was, that intead of 200 Hore, which he had ordered to go out to forrage, the order was mitaken, and all the Hore went out, o that when the Enemy appear'd, there was no Hore to receive the Charge or to cover the Foot. However 'twas, this affair
perplext the Court very much, if the Enemy cou'd have made the bet of their advantage, but the differences among themelves were the occaion, that it all ended with the taking the City of Treves.

I had followed a coure of Life for four years pat which was very agreeable to me, and tho one would have thought I hould have lov'd my eae better, yet I could not be quiet but I mut return to the Wars, but I could find no opportunity, for every body knew me, and I was aham'd at my years to go and beg an employ, o I was forc't to it till whether I would or no; I know not whether my diquiet at this or any other caue brought me to it, but at lat I began to be out of order, and in even or eight days I was o bad, that I was given over by all people; my Ditemper was a Dyentery, and tho they could find no way to top it, yet I was of o trong a contitution, that I do not think I was ounder at 25 years of Age; from whence I could not believe I was o ill as they aid I was, and no body would tell me of it, but eeing my Valet de Chambre cry, I would know what was the matter with him, and he told me it was becaue the Chyrurgeon had told him I was a dead man; I ay the Chyrurgeon becaue you mut know I fell ick in the Country, and having no Doctor at hand, I would not let them end for one: I was not frighted at what the Boy aid, but finding my ditemper increae, I ent to Paris for a Hore Litter to carry me thither, being about 12 miles off; being brought thither I ent for a Doctor that us'd to come to me, one Jonquet, and the firt thing he askt me was, if I had not had a debauch; I askt him what he meant by it, for there was everal orts of debauches; that if he meant of women, I had not been a hater of the Sex in my time, but he told me he meant as to Wine, adding withal that if it was from that, he would not undertake me, for it would be impoible to recover me; I aur'd him there was no uch thing, upon which he told me then there was hope, however he would promie me nothing, for I was ancient and therefore he advis'd me to end for a Priet, and make
ters even for another World, I believ'd him, and commited my elf wholly to Gods mercy and the Doctors art; he took me into his management, and kept me in his hands five Months intire, in which time I took ome Phyick or other of him every other day: This is a tory every one may not believe, that one of eventy years old hould hold out o long in a Ditemper, that often dipatches younger men in half the time; at lat, my Phyitian coming to ee me told me, 'twould be a digrace to him to take any more of my Money, and do me no more good; that all that he could think of to give me, or all that he could be inform'd of in conultation with others, erv'd indeed to keep me alive, but not at all to recover me, and therefore he would come and ee me as a Friend but not as a Phyitian. This was in hort to tell me had given me over, however, tho both from my Ditemper and my Age I had reaon enough to fear, yet I had no apprehenion on me, I only deir'd him, to continue his good Offices, and come to ee me as he us'd to do, but he like a very honet man, would not take any more Money; and tho my ditemper held me four Months longer, he never fail'd coming to ee me: I hould tell you a lye if I hould ay, I was in as much pain all that time as I was before, for I had a great deal of eae to what I us'd to have, but being not at all cur'd, and reolv'd if 'twere poible, whate re it cot, to get rid of the Ditemper, I had recoure to a thouand Quacks and Mountebanks to relieve me, and I took a world of Slops and Drugs, but finding all was to no more purpoe, than what Mr. Jonquet had done already, I ent for one Father Ange, a Capuchin, who was accounted an admirable man for thee ort of things; when he came in, I told him a long tory of what I had uffer'd by this Ditemper, and that I hop'd he could tell me of omething to cure me, he reply'd in a doleful Air, that he had known everal that had languih'd a longer time under the ame Ditemper than I, that the Duke of Luxemburgh had had it four years together, and perhaps this might hold me as long; if I had been able I believe I hould have beaten him to hear him talk in
uch a manner; but I was grown o weak that the leat puff would have blown me down almot; o I was forc'd to take it patiently, and only askt him if he could tell me of any thing to do me good, at leat that I might get ome ret, for I had not lept, as I may ay, in 8 months, and 'twas that which weaken'd me o extreamly. The good Man to pacify me, brought me the next morning a miraculous Syrup, which beides its Vertue, was o pleaant to the tate, that I thought when I took it, I was drinking Rasberry-water. I lept after it 12 hours without waking; and when he came to ee what effect it had on me, I embrac'd him, and aur'd him, that I hould be bound to acknowledge the remainder of my life was owing to him. But I began to rejoyce a little too oon, for all the other remedies he gave me, were o far from having the ame effect, that they only put Nature into a ferment; and all the benefit I had, was that I found it eay to take his Medicines, for they were all as pleaant as the firt; o I dimit Father Ange, as I had done all the ret: And I believe this unhappy Ditemper had till been my Companion, if Madam d' Ort, Siter to the Marquis de Feuquieres, had not happen'd to come to Paris. I was acquainted with her, but more particularly with her Husband, who was a very brave Gentleman; he enquiring after her old Friends and hearing what a pitiful condition I was reduc'd to, came to ee me, and brought with her a certain ort of Bread, which he had made up like a Cake, which I had no ooner eaten of, but I found my elf perfectly cur'd: I have carry'd ome of it about me ever ince, and I think I may ay it has been the preerver of my life.

'Twas impoible to be brought lower than I was; yet this good effect my affliction had, that it made me more enible of the things of another world than I had been formerly; I went to Church a little oftner than I us'd; and in hort, I began to remember, that I was ome time or other to dye: On this account having heard of a certain Capuchin, call'd Father Marc d' Avano, who was reported to work Miracles, I had the curioity to go and ee him. I took Pot from Paris to Flanders,
where I heard he was; but being told he was newly gone from thence for Germany, I follow'd him, and overtook him in the Country of Gueldres. I had no occaion to make much enquiry after him, for all the Road was crowded with people, who came, as I did, from all parts to ee him. But tho every one told me with great earnetnes, that they had een him cure everal Dieaes, and particularly the lame; yet tho I look'd with all the Eyes I had, I could ee nothing of it, only that the vogue was got o into the heads of people, that he had never les than an hundred thouand people about him, where-ever he quartred, and made a figure like the Entry of ome great Prince; they built Scaffolds, and paid for tanding at Windows to ee him go by. My zeal having made me as much a Fool as the ret, it was not long before I repented it, for the Scaffold I was got upon to ee him, breaking with the weight of the people, I fell down from a place even or eight foot high, and broke one of my Arms; everal others had the like misfortune, or were as much hurt; but tho they ay 'tis a comfort to have companions in affliction, I found none from it now, and the rather, becaue I was in a Country, where 'twas a rare thing to get a good Surgeon. I ent about for one of the bet, but they brought me one that undertood no more than one of our Apprentices in France; and after he had very roughly handled me for about three weeks, I found it was o ill et, that 'twas all to be done over again. I repented a thouand times of my Devotion, and curs'd the people that put this tory of Father Aviano into my head; but all this did not cure me, I found my • elf reduc'd to the neceity of carrying my Arm to Paris, in the condition 'twas then in; or ele to put my elf into the hand of the Hangman of Ruremond. This man undertood etting of bones, as well as breaking them, and had got uch a name for it, that everal Gentlemen told me, all people who thought themelves ill cur'd by others, went to him. It eem'd an odd thing to me, to apply my elf to the Hangman; but conidering, I was but in an ill condition to be carry'd
to Paris, I e'en deliver'd my elf over to him, like a condemn'd peron in depair: Being come to his Houe, I told him what had happen'd to me, and askt him if he could do me any good; to which he urlily reply'd, with the true air of a Hangman, that he had cur'd thoe that had been wore than I; he took hold of my Arm and tretcht it out; and whether it was that he handled me a little rudely, or the averion I had to the Man, I know not, but I thought he had done me a prejudice, and I gave him uch a look as would not have pleas'd him, if he had een it: However, after telling me, that he who had had me in hand was a orry ignorant fellow, and making it out by a great many terms of Art, which I have forgot, he askt me if I had any body to hold me, while he perform'd his Operation; I told him no, and I thought there would be no need, I hop'd I had courage enough to bear it; and I uppos'd all the pain he would put me to, would not force me to cry out. He hook his head at that, which was as much as to ay he believ'd ne'r a word of it, and told me he was not uch a Coxcomb to attempt it upon that uppoition; but ince I had no body with me, he would have ome of his own people for that purpoe, and that he mut tay for them, for they were gone upon a mall Execution about a league or two off. This little Execution he talkt of was; they had been breaking a Man upon the Wheel that had kill'd his Wife by and by they came home, and with their hands all bloody, lay'd hold of me, jut methought as they had been doing to that Murtherer. The Mater took hold of my Arm, and broke it again in an intant, without any engine but his hands, but not without uch exquiite pain to me, that he had good reaon to tell me I mut be held. However I was very well atisfy'd in going to him, or I was well again in a few days, and never felt any weaknes in that Arm ince, any more than if it had never been hurt.

At lat this War ended, after it had held three years, and all was concluded by the Peace of Nimeguen, as much to the Kings advantage, as the
Campaign had been; for he had found out the way to divide his Enemies in uch a manner, that intead of uniting their common interets, they fell into private Treaties with him, and every one made their Peace as well as they could. This was uch a fale tep as the like was never known, and they oon found their error. Aoon as ever the King had eparated them, he lays hold of the opportunity with his uual policy; and as he had een by the War, that his Kingdom would never be perfectly at eae, while Luxemburg continued in the hands of the Spaniard, he reolv'd therefore to have it in exchange for Alot, which he had pretenions to of another ort. This was not uch a Chimera neither as ome people pretend • d. The King having taken Alot, among everal other Towns, in the coure of this War, and the Treaty of Peace expreing, that all uch Conquet hould remain to him, as were not mention'd particularly in the Treaty, this was doubtles his own, there being not the leat notice of it taken in the aid Treaty; all the Objection was, that he had kept no Garrion in it, and o the Spaniards aid it was actually put into their power again, aoon as ever we had abandon'd it. But the King return'd, that he had left it to the keeping of the Inhabitants, who had always been their own Maters, and therefore he would tand by the Letter of the Treaty. In hort, there was no remedy but to decide the matter by the Sword, or to refer it to the King of Great Britain, who had been Mediat • r of the Treaty, and was Guarantee of the Peace. But the Spaniards upecting, that Prince not to be o much their friend as that requir'd, choe rather to name Commiioners to accommodate the matter; the King did the like, and they appointed the Town of Courtrai for their meeting; which having produc'd nothing but arguments Pro and Con, and no concluion appearing likely to be made, the King order'd Luxemburg to be inveted.

Every body thought this would kindle the fire again, and that the War would break out hotter than ever. The neighbouring Princes were o alarm'd, that
they dipatcht Orders to their Envoys at both Courts, to try if 'twere poible to often the matter, and prevent the mieries that threatned upon a rupture But it was impoible to adjut it, the King would have Luxemburg or Alot; and the Spaniards aw, 'twas equally inconvenient to them to part with either; if they gave up Luxemburg they hut out their Succors from Germany, from whence they mut come; if they granted Alot, it was to give away one of the bet Revenues in all Flanders, the income from that Bailliage bringing in a Revenue of 1600000 Livres a year; and beides, the juridiction of it extended even to the Gates of Bruels on one ide, and Ghent on the other: o that it would be to block up both thoe Cities. And to ay all in a word, in the neceity they had brought themelves to, the King taught them which to chooe; for his Majety having more mind to Luxemburg than to Alot, ent them word that was better for his turn than the t'other: But he had not the gift of perwaion neither, if they could have helpt it; but Luxemburg in the mean time continu'd blockt up, which if it had not, he mut have made ue of ome force to have open'd his paage on that ide the Country. The King of Spain, who aw himelf in no condition to reit uch powerful forces by himelf, had ent orders to avoid the quarrel if poible; o that the Souldiers were wholly unprovided when they hould have come to fight. Thee things will hardly be believ'd in times to come, but ince there is no other Hitory, I believe, will mention them, I hope the mot incredulous will take my Tetimony of them; and if I have given an account of thee things, 'twas not that I was really preent there, or that I am troubled with that itch of cribbling, to write of thoe things which has already employ'd the Pens of o many worthy men I hould have aid les of this affair, had I not been oblig'd to mention it upon the account of my Nephew, whom I hall peak of preently, and of an accident which happen'd to him, which had certainly been his utter ruine, if he had not found very good friends to appear for him.

He had quitted the Kings Regiment, where, as I aid before, I had plac'd him, and had put himelf into the Cavalry, where his inclinations led him to erve, and was made a Captain meerly on the account of merit, for a very gallant action which he had perform'd; and tho it be not proper for an Unkle to praie one of his near Relations, yet I mut not omit, that he had a very good reputation in the Regiment; but o it hapned, that in one day he lot all that eteem he had obtain'd, which nevertheles was not o much his fault, as that by his action, Luxemburg was prevented falling into our hands at that time. We had been already a good while before the Town, and the Garrion began to feel the want of many things, and above all of Money, for want of which the Governor could not ubit his Men; wherefore he reolv'd to end ome body to Bruels to get ome in if poible. He fixt upon three perons for this enterprize, the Count de Walatine, and two other Officers, and he order'd Capt. Gregorie, an old Soldier, for their guard, who knew all the by-ways round the Town for twenty miles together. Gregorie found means to get them clear well enough, but we having ome people in the Town, who gave us an account of every thing that pat, we had advice not only of their going out, but of their errand to Bruels, and could have trac'd them thither if it had been needful; but we contented our elves to watch them o exactly, as to be ure of them as they came back. Our Spies look'd out o well, that we had certain advice when Gregorie and his Companions were come within a days journey of the Town, whereupon everal Parties were ent out, one of which was commanded by my Nephew; it happen'd that Gregorie fell into his Ambucade in particular, and they being but about eventeen Hore, and my Nephew above ixty, they thought it their bet coure to retreat, and o made off towards Treves: My Nephew peruing him kept o cloe to him, that he was forced to take into the Town, and appear'd at the Gates almot aoon as he; but the Germans not favouring our party, deny'd him entrance, on pretence that they
mut firt go and ask leave of the Governour, my Nephew told them, in hort, the King would have a evere atisfaction for this falenes; but 'twas all one, they made them tay a full hour at the Ports; in which time Captain Gregorie and the Count de Walatine conulted together what to do, whether they hould tay in the Town, or go out another way, but at lat they reelv'd to tay in the Town; o they took up in an Inn which had a private back door, againt which they threw a g • eat heap of Hore-dung. The Governor of Treves, uppoing by this time they had ecur'd themelves, orders the Troop to be let in; and my Nephew being in •• rm'd, that the Spaniards were in that Inn, he quarter'd his people all thereabouts, and having viited all the Avenues, he plac'd Centinels at every place which he thought proper; but eeing the Dunghil which I mention'd, he never imagin'd there hould be a door the •• . In the mean time, Gregorie, to amue him, and that he might not imagin he would be tirring that night, made a trange revelling in the Inn, and uch a noie as if they had been all drunk, and appear'd at the Windows with Glaes of Wine in their hands, and this they got ome Germans to continue all night. The Centinels made no quetion but 'twas the Spaniards all the night; while in the mean time they open'd the fale door I told you of, and threw aide the Dung, and went about their buines. My Nephew knew nothing of their going till twas quite day, when finding how 'twas, and undertanding they were gone towards Coblentz, he follow'd them. Tho Gregorie was a great way before them, yet his Hores were o fatigu'd, that he was afraid of being overtaken before he got to the Town; wherefore eeing a little Chapel upon the road, he reolv'd to take poeion of that, and to defend it if my Nephew hould attack him; but his ill fate would not put it into his head to look there. So that paing by without dicovering them, Gregorie came out, and advis'd the Count de Walatine, and the two others, who carry'd the Money, to venture with it alone. It was the bet counel that could poibly be given, for our Parties were
very vigilant, and upon the cout on every ide; the Count de Walatine took his directions, and with the two Officers betook themelves to the Woods; but they taid three days before they could get along, and had taid longer, but that they were forc'd to venture for meer hunger; Fortune favour'd their Vigilance, for they pat undicover'd in the night, jut between two Squadrons of our Troops. They got into Luxemburg in very good time, where the want of Money was o great, that the Governour would not have known what to do if they had taid any longer.

As for Captain Gregorie, he wandred a long time in the Woods, before he could get in; but all the Country being Spanih, he found means to ubit, and o was not in uch neceity but that he might wait for a favourable occaion, which at lat offer'd it elf, and he got afe into the Town; the Governor, who had been in great pain for him, was overjoy'd to ee him return without the los of a Man. We had News every moment from ths Town, and when the Hitory of this Ecape came to the Army, all were enrag • d at my Nephew, for letting him ecape o; they wrote the account of it to the Court, and very luckily for him, I was gone that very day to St. Germains. I had ome Friends in the Secretary's Office, and among the ret Monieur de Charpentier, under Mr. de Louvois, a very civil obliging Gentleman, and always ready to do offices of kindnes to every body; he eeing me coming from Mas at the King's Chapel, deir'd me to come and dine with him. I was going to excue my elf, for that I had promis'd to dine with a Friend: I don't ask you, aid he, whipering in my ear, for the good chear you hall find there, but to inform you of omething which concerns you. He aid no more to me then, having another man in his Company, who he was not willing hould know what he had to tell me; but this was enough for me to put off any other appointment. So I went to him, and there I had the whole tory; after thanking him for his information, I ask'd him what I had bet to do in it; he told me I hould go to Monieur de Louvois, and not
eem to be urpriz'd at what he hould ay to me; that I hould let him ru • on and ay what he would, and only tell him, that this was a michance might have happen'd to any body as well as my Nephew, and that he had never had the misfortune to dipleae him before; and that if he would pleae to pardon him this, it would oblige him to greater circumpection; he told me everal other things I hould ay, which I oberv'd exactly, but I found Monieur de Louvois in uch a paion, that intead of hearing me peak, he told me, that he thought he ought to make out a proces againt uch a man as he; that if he had taken the Count de Walatine, he had taken Luxemburgh; and he was going to inform the King, how much he was beholding to him; I begg'd of him not to do o with all the ubmiion imaginable, but he was not a man to be mov'd with pitiful words, and he had certainly done as he aid, had not a Courier very happily arriv'd at the intant, who going with him into his Cloet, gave me time to go and eek ome friends to peak to him: Monieur the Grand Mater did me the mot ervice, for he would not leave him till he had promis'd his favour to my Nephew; having thus happily made his peace, I ent him word who he ow'd the obligation to, that he might not be ungrateful, but above all I order'd him to thank Monieur Charpentier, without whom it had been impoible to have hindred his ruine.

I came acquainted with the Grand Mater by the means of the Dutches de Vitri, who was I think one of the bet of Women, and of whom I hall always have a good opinion, for all that has been aid of her Conduct in the World. I had very great obligations to that Lord, yet eeing him one time when I was making him a viit; take a great deal of pleaure to reflect on her, I deired him to do me the favour to refrain from uch dicoure, auring him if he did not, I mut go out of the Room; he told me he was glad to ee me take my friends part o vigorouly, but he hop'd I did think that which he then poke was not out of malice, and that he only talkt o to ee if I could make any excue
for her; for all the world could tell him, that he kept a certain young German, whom he had rais'd from a Lackey to be her Valet de Chambre, and from that to be Mater of her Hore, but he would ay no more becaue he was a friend of mine; the bet could be aid tho was this, that he had hewn affection enough for him to marry him; and for his part he believ'd, they either were already contracted, or marry'd upon Honor. I know not how he came by thee particulars, but the truth was, that Lady manag'd her elf o unhappily with that fellow, that every body reflected on her for it; but while we were talking about it, came in Monieur de la Tonr, who had marry'd Madamoielle de Vitri, and I preently guet 'twas all from him, and that he did it in revenge becaue he had oppos'd his Marriage. His coming interrupted our dicoure, but I reolv'd to inform Madam de Vitri of it; but that he might not take ill my freedom with her, I us'd a great deal of precaution in it: I told her, if he would promie not to take unkindly one thing I had to ay to her, I would inform her omething that hould not be to her diadvantage; he told me I hould not cruple aying any thing to her; and after having made a great many protetations, that I hould extremely oblige her, I told her, that being in company with a certain Duke, I heard her o everely reflected on concerning her converation with one of her Servants, that tho I was very much concern'd for her, yet I was carce able to jutifie her conduct. I aur'd her however, that I had not the leat upicion of her Vertue, and would anwer for her to all the world body for body; but if he would permit me to peak eriouly to her, this Groom was a fellow that deerv'd to be handomly chatis'd, ince, when he knew what notice the world took of it, intead of behaving himelf cautiouly to prevent the preading of uch a noie, he had encreas'd it by his impudence, and had made people believe what really never was; that I knew he had pull'd out handfuls of Money among his Comrades, which was as much as to ay, that he who had the priviledge of omething o extraordinary, could want for
nothing; that this I had taken notice of in particular, but there were a multitude of uch like paages; tho without troubling her with uch trifles, I left it to her elf to judge, if this was to be uffer'd in uch a fellow.

Tho he had aid a thouand things to urge me to be very free with her, yet I perceiv'd he was very uneaie at my dicoure, her colour came, and he bluht like fire when I touch'd ome particular points; and when I had done, intead of flying out on the Racal I had o plainly detected before her, he exclaim'd violently on her Son-in-law, who he aid was the Author of all thee Calumnies. It was to no purpoe in the world for me to wear and deny it, he did not believe me, or at leat he pretended not to believe me; but at the ame time threatned what he would do to him; and he gave proofs of her good will in a few days, in attempting to ell a fine Etate he had about Nemours, that it might not come to him: The umm being at leat four hundred thouand Francs, he could not oon find a Chapman; and Mr. de la Tour did all he could to prejudice people againt it, when he aw them inclin'd to it. Indeed her conduct in this affair was inexcuable, not only on that account, but as he had o little dicretion, as to tell the fellow all I had aid to her. He, who, tho he had chang'd his habit, had till the ervile pirit of a Foot-boy, durt not expres his reentment to me; but he had uch an influence upon his Mitres, that he let me ee it in her countenance, which was enough to have taught me to deit, and if he had a mind to ruine herelf, to give her liberty: Indeed 'tis o with all the world, and a man ought not to attempt doing people good againt their will; but as I did every thing different from other people, I went to her again as I us'd to do, and told her, that for all her dipleaure at me, I was reolv'd to let her ee how entirely I was devoted to her, and therefore came to tell her, that in endeavouring to ell her Etate, he made the world talk of her more than ever: That now
they aid, for Money to give the Groom, he would ell the Inheritance of her Family, and ruine her only Daughter; that he might eaily gues what the conequence of this would be, ince a peron of her quality mut needs be more enibly touch'd with uch reports than other people; that her Family, and that of her Husbands too, were concern'd and at take; and if I might venture to tell her what I had been told, there were not wanting thoe that had reolv'd, by ome means or other, to dipatch the Racal that had expos'd her, and made her the common talk and jet of the Town.

Nothing that I could ever ay to this Lady, made uch an impreion upon her as this lat circumtance; he enquir'd who it was that told me o, but finding me unwilling to name any names, he pret me to it by all the intreaties and good words poible; but I begg'd her pardon for not proceeding any further, which made her imagin I had made the tory my elf. I told her he was at liberty to believe what he pleas'd, but perhaps time would make it appear too true, that I was wholly incapable either of adding to, or diminihing from the truth: Upon which I left her without any more ceremony. The next day, paing thro the treet where he liv'd, I met Mr. Theodore, (that was the name of the Groom) who thinking he had to do with one of his own ort, comes up to me, and tells me, I was well et a work to go and tell uch a parcel of impertinent tories to his Mitris. He had no ooner poke the words, but without any other reply, I gave him his reward with two or three good rubs over the Shoulders with my Cane, at which he was o urpriz'd, that he did not o much as offer to put his hand to his Sword. In the mean time he took another method to revenge himelf, and gets an order to have me before the Marechals of France, and did not quetion, I uppoe, but according to their uual everity, I hould have been ent to Prion. But I having acquainted the Marechal de Villeroy of the matter, before whom that Court was held; and alo that uch a fellow as he had not a right to
ummon before them; he could have no Audience there, but was referred back to the common coure of Jutice, and there I had been before hand with him, by the advice of a cunning fellow I employ'd, o that he was urpriz'd, when coming to get a Warrant for me, he found himelf arreted by vertue of a Judgment I had obtain'd againt him in the ame Cae. Madam de Vitri was but ill pleas'd with me on this account, and had told ome of my Friends, that I had o little repect for her as to abue one of her Servants; that he had always had a great repect for me, but he would never forgive me this as long as he liv'd. I deir'd them to inform her that I was provok'd to it by his awcy language; that it was true I might have conider'd that I ought not to have been provok'd by any thing uch a fellow could ay, but one is not always Mater of ones paion; beides a Man ought always to have regard to his own honour; and if I had fail'd in that, yet I deir'd her to conider, that having a Sword by my ide, I ought o much the les to bear uch affronts as thoe. Another would perhaps have thought thee excues reaonable, but Monieur Theodore having a greater influence upon her than I, he was not at all moderated, but continued as furious as ever. I did not much trouble my head with it, having the atisfaction of the general approbation in what I had done. Indeed I dare ay he govern'd herelf more by her humour than her reaon, as appear'd oon after in her elling her Land for half the value, to Monieur de Boisfranc, Intendant of the houhold to the Duke of Orleans; this enrag'd all her Relations againt her, and the report went that to make Mr. Theodore amends, for the affront I had put upon him, he gave him good part of the Money; Monieur de la Tour who had the greatet concern, finding things went thus, thought he ought not any longer to uffer this Wretch; however before he did any thing, he thought 'twould be bet to theaten him, to ee if he could make him run away of his own accord; the deign ucceeded, for Monieur Theodore eeing that all the world was bent againt him, marcht
off with his Money, without o much as taking leave of his Dutches, and if we may give any heed to the Scandalous Chronicle, he laid it o to heart, that it was the caue of her death. This is true tho, that he liv'd not long after his departure, and it had been better for Mr. de la Tour that he had gone 4 or 5 years before, •• e had not then quandred away the bet part of her Etate, nor lot her Reputation, which before was o great, that no Lady could have a better.

But to return to the Blockade of Luxemburgh; it continu'd all this while inveted, and tho the arrival of the Count de Walatine gave new courage to the Garrion, yet the relief he brought could not lat always, and that being wated they were reduc'd to the ame condition they were in before; this made the Governor very thoughtful, but at lat he committed one error, for which, if he had been a Subject of France, he would at leat have lot his Government, if not his Head. When our Forces firt approach'd, he brings a noie of Muick to the Ramparts, as much as to ay, he was very glad to ee us, and that we had oblig'd him in giving him an opportunity to how his Courage, and upon that made everal Balls and Rejoycings in the Town; but he never conider'd that he had to do with Enemies, who knew how to dance to other orts of Intruments, and whoe Courage had been too well hown in the late War, to be upected; and if I may be allowed to make a little digre • ion, I would ay if they had been attackt by plain force, it might, for ought I know, have fared with them as it did with the Prince of Conde at the Siege of Lerida. He being fluht with a multitude of Victories, which he had gain'd in Flanders, and imagining that fortune was bound to follow him into Catalonia or where he pleas'd, not at all concern'd at the misfortune that had befallen the Count d' Harcourt the year before, he brings his Violins to play in the Trenches, and not content with this, he ends to tell the Governour, that he would give him every day uch Serenades; to which the Governour anwer'd, he would endeavour to return his civilities, but begg'd his pardon till the next
day, his Violins being out of order, but he would take care they hould be in a readines by that time; his Violins were a peal from his Cannon, which he caus'd to fire without any intermiion, and in the heat of it he ally'd out and fell upon the Trenches with a deperate fury: The Prince of Conde tood him gallantly, and there • as no Courage wanting in him to beat him back into the Town, but being not o well econded as he ought, he was forc'd to give ground, leaving at leat even or eight hundred of his men upon the pot.

Now if I might be uffer'd to give my opinion of o great a Captain, I think he was very much to blame, for where is the jet of thee ort of Bravado's? are not there a thouand other ways for a man to ignalize himelf, and if one comes to be baulk't, as it happen'd here to the Prince, how foolih does it look? but I won't run too much on this ubject. To go on with the buines of Luxemburgh; the Governour was a man of great bravery, and he mut have degenerated from his family if he had been otherwie, for it has been a houe which has produc'd a great many Gentlemen of extraordinary worth; and the action which I am blaming him for, proceeded indeed rather from an exces than a want of Courage; however he ought to conider that even too much Courage is an inexcuable fault in a General or Governour of a Town, tho it may be allow'd in a Souldier; however there was les reflection made on him, for this affair, than for another of a different nature which happen'd oon after, and 'twas this I meant, when I aid he had been very everely puniht for it, had he been in our ervice; being one Night at a Ball within the Town, he happen'd to have ome words with a Collonel of the Garrion call'd Cantelmo, who thinking himelf affronted, whiper'd him in the Ear, that if it would oblige him he would give him atisfaction immediately: The Governour took him at his word, and without o much as conidering that he had an Enemy under his Walls, he withdrew from the Ball without any noie, and was immediately at the place
appointed, in a by Street of the Town; the Governours Second was the Count de Walatine, and Cantelmo's an under Officer of his Regiment; their Footmen had Flambeaus to light them, and tho the buines held but a little while, yet there was ome blood hed; the Governour gave Cantelmo a thrut in the ide, which glanc'd along upon his Ribs, and whether it was that the Collonel thought himelf wounded wore than he was, or that his feet lipt, it was not known, but he fell down, and the Governour coming up to him, he askt his life, and was going to deliver his Sword; when the Officer who was his Second eeing the danger his Coll. was in, flew to his recue with uch fury, that he had run the Governour thro and thro if the Footmen had not tept in and kept him off with their Flambeaus, which they run jut in his face, and o the battel ended, for they knockt him down jut by his Coll. and the Count de Walatine being come up to the Governour, they eaily mater'd the other two who were down before. If the Marechal de Crequi, who lay before the Town, had had orders to have attackt it, no doubt he might have made but hort work of it, while the Governour that commanded it had o little dicretion, but tho we had forces enough yet we durt not attempt it, as otherwie we would have done, for we had meaures to keep with the King of England, who was the more troubleome to us, the more he was himelf diturb'd by his own people that hated us, upon which account he concerted all matters with us. Let not the Englih think the better of themelves for what I have mention'd; I dont ay we were o afraid of them, as that we were bound to do every thing they order'd; if they had declar'd againt us it had not been much the wore for ou • affairs, but 'twas not prudence for us to create our elves new Enemies, when there was o many jealouies already of the progres of our Arms. I allow they are a brave people, but I dont doubt we have convinc'd the World we are o too; one thing we excel them in, and that is, in having abundance of experienc'd Souldiers and Officers, bred to the War; and above all
a King, who if he abandons himelf to his pleaures, yet abandons all thoe pleaures, to perue the coure of an immortal fame.

I hall not give any other account why the Blockade of Luxemburg was rais'd, than what went currant in the World; 'tis an action o lately done and o well known, that all the world mut remember it: There were ome reflections upon my Nephew on the occaion of this deign failing, which he laid o much to heart, that I perceiv'd he was grown melancholy; I advis'd him to lay down his Commiion, but he would not do that neither, but being overcome with dicontent, at lat he fell deperately ick: I lov'd him very tenderly, and indeed above all the ret of my Family, and therefore I no ooner heard of it, but I took Pot to go and ee him; 'twas no difficulty for me notwithtanding my Age, for that ort of Coach which is an invention we have from the Germans, carries one o very eay, that it is not the leat inconvenience; at my arrival at Dunkirk, for there was his Quarters, I found him omething better, and very glad he was to ee me, for as I lov'd him, as I aid before, o he had the ame affection for me; and it appear'd preently; for Company o reviv'd him, that he began to recover apace, and I never left him till he was quite well: And as nothing contributes to our recovery from any ditemper, more than a proper divertiement; I endeavour'd to bring it about for him, by inviting ome Ladies to come and play at his Chamber. This did not continue long, for in a little while he was well enough to viit them. There were at that time a Poppet-how in the Town, and all the people went to ee it, the famous Punchinello doing trange things; tho my Nephew, nor I, did not much fancy thoe things, yet I carry'd him to ee it; we were exceedingly diverted, and o were a great many more beides us, by ome extraordinary paages in this adventure. Some may think it very impertinent in writing thee Memoirs, to trouble the World with uch a mean tory as this of the Poppet-players; yet if they pleae to have patience till they have heard it out,
they will be better atisfy'd; the reaon I mention uch a trifle as this, is becaue ome Hitory depends upon it, at wort; it may make 'em laugh, as it hath done many more beides my elf.

Brioche the famous Poppet-player of Paris, finding people began to be weary of his fooleries in the City, took his opportunity when mot people were out of Town, to make a turn in the Country; firt he went into Champagn, thence into Lorrain, o into Alace, and at lat he came to Stratsbourg, where abundance of people having never een Punchinello, run after him; finding o good ucces there, he takes a march into Swierland, I can not poitively remember into what Canton he went, tho I have been told that too; but in hort, 'twas in one where they were o perfectly unacquainted with thoe hows, that when he came to play his tricks among them, they took him for a Conjurer and thought he dealt with the Devil; away they go to the Magitrates, who it eems were jut as wie as themelves, and in hort they were going to give entence againt him; but as it happend, before they would go o far they bethought themelves of one Monieur Du Mont Colonel of a Regiment of Swie, which was in the French ervice, and who happen'd to be then in the Country he laught heartily at their implicity, and aur'd them that there was no witchcraft at all in the matter, and that in France they were o frequent, that they were to be een in every Market Town; but Monieur Du Mont being a jocoe ort of a man, and the Magitrates thinking he only bantred them, they were reolv'd not to take their meaures wholly from what he aid, but to be better inform'd, they order'd Witnees to be examind, and there having tetify'd that they heard little figures in the hape of Men and Women to peak, they concluded they could be nothing but Devils, and therefore without any more ado pat their decree againt Biroche: They carry'd the entence to Monieur Du Mont, who told them in hort, they were going to make themelves ridiculous, and he was heartily orry that his C • untrymen hould be uch abominable Fools. Being
not able with this freedom to undeceive them, he reolv'd to play 'em a Trick; he turn'd his tone immediately and told them, that if he had not confet the whole matter at firt, 'twas becaue he aw they would engage him in an ugly piece of buines; that Biroche was a French man, and the French were now o great, that people ought to conider well what they did before they quarrell'd with them; but beides that, he had a great many perons of Quality among his Poppets, with Princes and Princees of everal Countries, that he did not know what relation he might have to thoe great Perons, but to be ure his interet was very great, ince they hould give him leave to bring them upon the Stage in that manner, and that in a word, he found they were going upon a buines which might embroil the whole Canton; but he would ay no more, 'twas their part to conider of it; but in caes where Princes and Princees were concern'd they could not be too cautious.

This dicoure poken mighty gravely, took with the Magitrates extreamly: They told Monieur Du Mont, that what he had told them was of conequence and deerv'd conideration, indeed, that they would therefore call an Aembly to advie what was to be done, before they proceeded any further, and pray'd him to continue his good Offices to them on this occaion; in hort, they call'd their Aembly to conult of the matter, and they oon agreed, which was, that they hould have a care of bringing a troubleome buines upon themelves, and therefore they ent to Monieur Du Mont to tell him, that they would not proceed to extremity, but content themelves with banihing Biroche out of the Canton, on condition that he paid the charges of his proecution; Monieur Du Mont took upon him to carry this meage himelf; but Biroche would not hear a word of it, o Mr. Du Mont told the Magitrates, that ince Biroche would not ubmit to their entence, 'twas his opinion they hould caue his Poppets to be tript of their fine Habiliments, for what ever relation they might be to perons of Quality, Princes and Princees, they would have him do jutice to be ure, and when
they undertood he had refus'd it, they would blame him: They thought this was the mot reaonable propoal in the World; and ince they could have no atisfaction from him, they ent and plundred all his Poppets, and carry'd away all their fine Cloaths in Triumph, and poor Biroche was fain to dres them all in new Cloaths, before he could appear in Flanders, whether he went next in his way to Paris.

Tho Monieur Du Mont had done this fellow no mean ervice, as you may judge by the tory, yet he thought otherwie, and made him a very ill return for it, of which I can give a particular account, having been an eye-witnes of it my elf. Monieur Du Mont had been a long time in Garrion at Bruges in Flanders, and having got a Mit • is at Dunkirk had a fancy one time to go thither to ee her; he went Incognito, and having conceal'd himelf there ome time, his Mitres would needs have him go with her to the Poppet-how, and promis'd him he would o diguie him, that no body hould know him; he had much ado to perwade him: But as 'tis a hard matter to refue any thing to a peron a man loves, he agreed to go with her; he dret him up like a Burgher, and they at in a corner by themelves, the young Lady having told her acquaintance it was one of her Fathers friends; Biroche coming upon the Stage with his Punchinello, and looking about him, pies out the Colonel, and knew him, tho he did all he could to conceal himelf; o he makes his Punchinello cry out Treaon, Treaon, Treaon in Spain, Treaon in Germany, Treaon in England, Treaon in Portugal, Treaon in Italy, and at lat, Treaon in Flanders. Biroche tells him he hould hold his Tongue and look he did not trouble his head with what was done in the everal kingdoms of Europe; but Punchinello run on and names all the other States of Chritendom; people wondred what this meant, becaue it was different from what they us'd to hear, none of the Plays beginning like this; but it all came out in an intant, for Biroche turns to Punchinello and tells him, that ince he had a mind to talk and prate, he would give
him leave, only on this condition, that he hould not ay a word that Monieur Du Mont, Colonel of a Regiment of Suie at there in that corner, dret up like a Burgher and his Mitres with him; as there was a great many Officers there who knew the Colonel well enough, they all tood up and lookt on every ide, to ee if what Biroche aid was true; in the mean time Monieur Du Mont helpt to dicover himelf, for being in a trange confuion to find himelf urpriz'd in uch a condition, he made a great deal to do to hide himelf; but one who knew him a little more particularly than the ret, made him pull away his Hat from before his face; o then it ignify'd nothing to endeavour to conceal himelf any longer; if he was in confuion enough, his Mitres was in more, and 'twas well for her that he pull'd her Hoods over her face, by which he prevented her being known. But the Comedy was quite put by on this occaion: Monieur Du Mont wore he would be reveng'd on Biroche; but he left the Town the ame day to get out of his way, and went to Paris, where he was fain to lye hid too, for fear of the Colonels reentment.

I have been the longer on this tory, becaue I fancy every body will be pleas'd with it, for of all things that have been aid of the Suie, I believe no one ever heard uch a imple buines as this. By this time my Nephew was quite recovered, and I came back to Paris, where telling this tory, I had pat for a great Lier, had not Biroche been by to jutifie it; and I deire all that read thee Memoirs and doubt of the truth of it, to inform themelves from him. He tells a great many particulars diverting enough, which I omit here on purpoe becaue I would not make the tory too long.

Being come back to Paris, I found I had got a little tock of Money again aforehand; and tho I ought to have learnt the wit to know what to do with it, having paid o dear for my experience in the cae of Monieur de Saillant, yet I mut till be conidering forooth how to improve my Money; this good husbandry was a humour came upon me a little too late; had I been o wie when I liv'd with Cardinal Richlieu, I had had no need
of it now; but it was my lot to be ruin'd, whoever I dealt with.

Monieur De Saillant mut excue me if I ay o, 'twas a word lipt out by chance, and may well be forgiven a man whom it cot eight thouand Francs beides Interet, only to do him a kindnes; however my deign is not to do him any harm, for he did his bet, and o did he that I am going to peak of, and I forgive them both; I had 2000 Crowns by me in good Gold, and as old age has this particular quality to love hoards, I enquired of every body if they knew one to whom I might afely put out this Money; they propoed everal to me, and I choe out one of them, to my misfortune: No body pleas'd me o well as one Monieur Joeier de la Jonchiere, becaue he made a good figure, and I thought him a rich man: Any body wou'd have been cheated as well as I, for he had a place of eight hundred thouand Francs a year, a fine Houe of his own at Paris, Rents on the Town-houe, Lands in the Country, and if one had had a hundred thouand Crowns to put out, he had ix times enough to anwer it; in hort, I gave him my Money, and thought my elf very much oblig'd to him that he would take it; but about ix months after, going along the treet where he liv'd, I aw a croud of people at his door, and enquiring what was the matter, they told me they did not know the particulars, but the Kings Souldiers had taken poeion of his Houe; which was enough to tell me my Money was in danger, and I was too true a Prophet, for tho he appear'd everal days after, yet his affairs and mine were not much better than one another; he call'd his Creditors together, and I coming among the ret, he told us he had enough to pay us all, if we would have patience, and the King would have any compaion of him, that he had had everal loes, which the wiet man alive could not foreee. Firt, that one of his Factors had run away with a hundred thouand Crowns. Secondly that upon calling in the Money the pieces of four Sous, and giving out the markt pieces, he had not above eight days warning, and having a vat quantity
by him, at leat ix Millions, ix hundred thouand Livres, he lot above eight thouand Francs by them; do whatever he could; that tho Monieur de Louvois was inform'd of his los, he being a Publick Notary himelf, yet he had not par'd him in the Tax, but had rated him, as he did the two other Treaurers General Extraordinary of the War, at five hundred thouand Livres; that nothing was o unjut as that Tax which was laid on them, on pretence that they had hared with ome of the Under-Treaurers in their Cheats; that he would not anwer for other folks, but for himelf he could afely wear he had nothing to do with them; that all his loes amounted to fourteen hundred thouand Francs, which had all befallen him in a year or two; that however he had this to comfort him, that no body needed to loe a farthing by him.

He could not ay this to us without ome tears, reflecting on his pat fortune, which indeed compar'd to his preent condition, was enough to move compaion, who but a few days ago liv'd in plendor equal to a Prince, and was now in a moment reduc'd to uch a condition, as not to have a Bed to lye on: His Wife, who was a Colbert, and marry'd him but for his Etate, deerted him now he found he was like to be mierable; and his friends, at leat uch as call'd themelves o before his diater, erv'd him in the ame manner; and to compleat his miery, his Brother-in-law, one Brebier, who had marry'd his Siter, put him in Prion for a Bill of Exchange he had paid for him. In hort, every one run upon him, and did him all the michief they could, and no body, but I, regarded the incontancy of fortune; but I thought myelf oblig'd, rather to help him than to cruh him in this condition; I had rather, that he hould ay this than I, becaue it is of my elf; however, tho I was in no condition to make large gifts, yet I frankly gave him my two thouand Crowns; and if all his Creditors had been of my mind, he would ne'r have periht in Prion, as now he is in great danger to do. Perhaps God ent him this affliction, to punih him for being a little too ure of his properity; for there
was nothing rich enough, or fine enough, neither for him or his Wife. They would not give themelves the trouble of going to the Play, but the Actors mut come and play at their own houe. Their Diet was extravagantly nice, and every thing ele anwerable, tho at the ame time they thought, that they had a fortune proportionable. He had a place which in time of War never brought him in les than a Million a year in his turn, and was at other times worth an hundred thouand Crowns a year, and there were but three of them, who had every one a year in their turn; a rare example of the viciitude of humane affairs, from whence one may learn, that there is nothing o mortifying in a poor condition, as to reflect upon our former properity.

A little after this happen'd, my Nephew came to Paris, and as he went out after dinner from one of his acquaintances houes, he was et upon by four Ruffians, who after having tab'd him in three everal places with their Swords, made off, uppoing they had kill'd him. The Citizens are commanded, when any uch accident happens, or when two draw their Swords to fight in the treets, to diarm them, and ecure their perons; but this is an Ordonance which is but very little regarded, and 'tis with jutice enough that the Pariians are accus'd of Cowardize; the Trademen being always very little fond of parting a Fray in the treet; by which means thee fellows got away: And tho I made great earch after them, I could never hear a word of them. My Nephews wounds were very bad, but yet not o dangerous as I was afraid they were, and o were cur'd in les time than I expected, which I was very glad of; but however we were atisfied from this, that he had ome Enemies underhand, and uch as were the more dangerous, becaue they were not to be known, tho we did our utmot to dicover them. I enquir'd of him who he had given any occaion to, and on what affair he could affront any body to deerve uch uage; and after having tudy'd a little on the matter he told me, he could not tell who to upect, except it was one Bletterie, who was in his Winter-quarters in the Country, near
the Loire; he had been acquainted with his Wife, who had carry'd it o very obligingly to him, that he had a very great eteem for her; that her Husband who was always by, was o far from hewing any dilike at it, that he was always the forwardet to invite him to his houe: However ince men are not always of the ame mind, o he would not ay 'twas not on his account: That this man having been oblig'd to go to Paris, about the latter end of January, he had left ome Money with his Wife, with order to give it to one that was concern'd with him in the Farms; but that he happening at the ame time, very unfortunately, to loe all his Money, he let him have two thouand Crowns, without any repect to the order her Husband had left with her; that thereupon great diturbance follow'd, and the Farmer General eiz'd his Goods for want of payment; that he had wrote everal Letters to his Wife, but receiving no anwer, he was forc'd to come himelf; where he finding herelf unable to atisfy him, was fain to pretend he had been rob'd; but that upon enquiry the man was inform'd, that there was omething ele lot beides his Money.

My Nephew having made this ingenuous confeion, I troubled my elf no more at what had happen'd, but on the other hand told him, he had but his due; for a man that could not be content to kis his friends Wife, but mut bilk her of his Money too, deerv'd no fair play, but ought to expect to dye in the treet, as he had like to have done. However, this did not hinder my making all the enquiries I could poible, to find out whether this happen'd to him on that account or no. I made one of my Servants I had tutor'd, hire himelf to le Bletteire, who was to ay, he came from the ame Town where my Nephew liv'd, and had been injur'd by him; which was to draw omething from him, by which he might gues how he tood affected to my Nephew; but he came away with a parcel of illy tories, without making any coniderable dicovery. Another would have been dicourag'd after o many fruitles attempts, epecially too, after having pent more Money about it than
can be imagin'd; for 'tis a cutom at Paris, when they fancy you are eager to revenge your elf, to have a number of harping fellows come about you, all pretending, ome this way, and ome that way, to give you information; and if you hearken to them a little, they oon find the depth of your Pocket.

I was the Cully to thee ort of people for two or three months; at lat, one that had erv'd me like the ret, came and told me, he had found one of the Ruffians: I thought this was only a trick to get more Money, and o I told him, if he did not get him about his buines, I hould have him oundly kick'd; but he auring me the thing was true, told me, he askt me for nothing till he had deliver'd the fellow into my hands; and provided I would then give him ten Pitoles, he would bring me to the place where he was; that in the mean time my Nephew hould go before, where he hould appoint, to ee that he would not deceive me, and that he would order it o, as to help him to a ight of the man, and if it was he, he hould be provided with people ready to ecure him This Propoal was o fair, that I could not refue it, but I agreed to all his conditions, and promis'd him more than he demanded. So taking my Nephew along with him, he plac'd him in a Chamber up four pair of tairs in la Rue de la Mortelliere, where on the other ide of the treet, jut over againt him, the peron lodg'd whom he meant; he plac'd my Nephew in ambucade behind the Window, telling him he hould oon ee him come to his Window, and that he hould not have time to ecape. In hort, in a moments time he came to the Window, as he had aid, with a Woman who betray'd him; and my Nephew having view • d him very exactly, was o well atisfy'd, that this was one of the perons that aaulted him, that he ent to me to come on with the Officers, which I immediately did with all expedition. Firt, I poted three or four men at the corner of the treet, and follow'd my Nephew with the ret, who would needs be in the action himelf, as being mot concern'd. We preently en • red the Chamber he had taken notice of,
but found no body there; for he being at the Window when we came to the door, fled to a back room; the Woman whom we had et to watch, made a ign to us where he was hid, and there we found him; but he having fatned all the Bolts we were forc'd to break the door open: He put himelf at firt into a poture of defence, and fir • d a Pitol among us, but hurt no body; but throwing our elves in upon him, we took him, and carry'd him into the Chatelet. My Nephew appear'd to proecute him, and we had very good proof of the aault, for it was made in the open day, and in one of the mot publick treets of Paris; but when they came to be brought face to face with the Prioner, truly there was but one would be poitive that he was the man, the other aying, 'twas too long ago to remember particular faces: However, this was half a proof, and I did not doubt but they would put him to the torture upon that, as is uual; and I hop'd o the rather, becaue he eem'd a coundrel kind of a fellow, that had not above two years ago run away from his Colours. But as orry a Wretch as he was, he had good friends who ollicited for him very hard, under-hand; among whom, Monieur Genou was one, who having a great interet in the Parliament, all we could obtain was, that he hould remain in Prion three months longer, to ee if we could bring any further witnes to inform them more fully; o it lay upon us to ue our endeavour, for after that time, if none appear'd, he would be at liberty: But what could we do more than we had done? So the three months run out, and we being not able to make any further dicovery, had the pleaure, after a great deal of Money pent in the proecution, to have our Proces dimit out of the Court.

I attribute this diappointment to the ollicitation of Mr. Genou, and I believe I am in the right. In the mean time, it was no very hard matter to find out, what made him o willing to appear againt us; for I had done jut the ame thing in an affair that he had (or at leat Vedeau de Grammont his Kinman) againt a certain Lady, whoe Father was my very good friend; but
here lay the difference between my management and his, that he av'd a man that deerv'd to be broken on the Wheel, and I did nothing but what every honet man ought to do; and to the end, the Reader may not think, I ay more of my elf than is my due, I will be judg'd by all that hear the tory, which was as follows. The eaon inviting me to take the air in the Country, I left Paris with an intent to go and ee a Gentleman, one of my Relations, call'd Mere, for whom I had lately done a particular piece of ervice, in a difference he had with one Domanchin, who had been a Notary, but now was become a noted Uurer. In hort, this ubtile old Fox had cheated him, at leat of fifty thouand Crowns: The Gentleman having been put to great charges on account of other people, particularly being to pay for hunting Equipage for Mr. de Vendome, he had been quite ruin'd, if he had been forc'd to pay all that this fellow demanded of him; he apply'd himelf to me to help him to adjut this affair; and having found out his Adverary, I got him a Dicharge for a very mall um more than what was really owing, and abundantly hort of the vat um he pretended to. This peron, thinking himelf under great obligation to me, had a long time invited me to come and ee him; and the weather being o pleaant as I aid, I had a mind to divert my elf, I got on Horeback by break of day, and arriv'd the ame night at his houe; he made me extraordinary welcome, and I believe I hould have been o if I had taid longer; but as I never lov'd the Country for any long time together, and alo having a mind to make another viit not far from his Houe, I took my leave of him. My other viit was to Monieur Herve, Counellor of the Great Chamber, and one of my very good friends, who I was told was at Monieur Salle's Houe, who had marry'd his Daughter; o I went directly to his Houe, but when I came to the Catle, I undertood that they were neither of them at home, and that no body was within but Madam Salle. I having had the honour of acquaintance with her at her Father's, alighted to go and pay my repects to her. I had not been with her
above half an hour, but they brought her word, that ome of Monieur de Vedeau de Grammont's Footmen, whoe Lands adjoyn'd to theirs, were a fihing in the Motes. Aoon as he heard it he chang'd colour, and turning to me, Sir, aid he, you are too much a friend to my Father to uffer them to put uch an affront upon me; and with thoe words he ries up in a heat, and going out of the room, he runs herelf to defend her right. I had no thoughts of leaving her in a cae o plain; but tho the fellows were ent on purpoe to offer her that affront, yet they durt not tay, epecially aoon as they aw 'twas the Lady herelf, and he natching away their Lines, they were in uch a conternation, that if he had pleas'd, he might eaily have bang'd them. Vedeau, who was not far off, was urpriz'd when he undertood how things were, and epecially when he heard that a ingle Woman had by herelf return'd the affront he deign'd, he was ready to burt with anger. He was a Man of War as you might gues by his Habit, of which I hall peak preently; and in particular of a certain blue Coat which he had uch a kindnes for, that he had wore it at leat ten or twelve years. Away he goes, raies the Ban and Arrierban of his Etate, and having made a fine Speech to them, to encourage them to ome bold action, he tells them, that they mut march againt Madam Salle, to recover the Booty he had made of his Mens fihing Tackle; and he would have led them on himelf, but that it was not proper for o coniderable a Captain as himelf, to go on o mall an Expedition. If I would ay any more to give you his character, I might eaily do it; but I need only ay, that this was becaue it eems people which have uch affairs as thee, ought not to be of the Party themelves; and as 'tis with thoe that are out of love with their own occupations, they won't trouble themelves to know o much as the terms of art; o he left all thoe things to the Men of War.

I was newly gone from Madam Salle when this Rabble came there, or ele I am ure I hould ooner have been cut in pieces than have uffer'd them to offer her
uch violence: But they having found her all alone, neither her Sex, her Quality, no nor her Face, which as it was all charming, o was at the ame time very majetick, could not put any top to their outrage; but eeing that he had plac'd herelf ingle at the door of the Hall to dipute their paage, they ruht in upon her, and he making what reitance he could, they threw her down upon the ground, and I know not what other inolencies they offer'd her; they drag'd her about the houe from place to place, as if he had been a Criminal, and they had authority for what they did; at lat having found what they came for, they went away, after having aid all the beatly things to her they could devie, and which they deerv'd to be everely puniht for. The Lady was a peron of too much pirit, to bear all this without taking ome coure to revenge it. She ent a Man immediately expres to her Father, to inform him of what had pat, and he having overtaken me upon the road, and telling me what had happen'd, immediately upon my going away, I thought my elf oblig'd in honour to go back, and offer her my ervice. I found her perfectly diconolate, and it ignify'd nothing to tell her, her Father had credit, and friends enough to revenge this affront, this gave her no atisfaction; and I believe, if I had not proffer'd her my ervice, to go immedietely out and perue them, he had dy'd under the violence of the oppreion; and this dicover'd to me the Greatnes of her Spirit, more than ever I had oberv'd in my life. She told me it was not reaonable I hould expoe my elf on her account, and he tay at home out of the danger; but if I would needs undertake her defence, he was reolv'd to run the rique with me; that 'twas true he was but a Woman, but as much a Woman as he was, he believ'd he was able to beat Mr. Vedeau. I told her, I hop'd there was no need of that, I would only have her look to her elf after o much violence as had been offer'd her; and beides, ince he was the Party o much abus'd, he hould keep the right of her ide; and therefore I only deir'd her to let me have one of
her Servants with me in a deign I had thought of. In hort, I ent to everal friends I had in the Neighbourhood to lend me the help of their Footmen; upon which meage they came away themelves, thinking I had ome quarrel upon my hands; but I ent them all back again, let I hould embroil them, they being all marry • d men, or otherwie ettled in the Country; o they were forc'd to oblige me, or ele nothing would have been done. Having 5 or 6 jolly fellows with me, who did not value Monieur Vedeau, epecially not being known, neither to him nor his Servants; We put our elves into a hunting poture, and follow'd the Chae jut to his very Gate: He was chief Ranger of that part of the Country, and had Men for that purpoe in mot of the Villages about there; one of which coming out, upon the firt hot we made, to know if we had leave from his Mater; we complimented him with a good cudgelling, and bid him go and tell Monieur Vedeau, that if he would pleae to come out himelf, we would be as civil to him; there came three one after another on the ame errand, which put us to the trouble of erving them all in the ame kind, and they all run to the Catle; where tho they all told the Errand, Monieur Vedeau did not think fit to venture abroad; however he thought, if he could raie the Country, he hould eaily urround us; o he order'd the Church Bell to ring out for an alarm, and gets himelf up to a Garret Window to ee, by the help of his Propective, if any of the Country people came to his relief. All this did not hinder, but I kept beating about the Fields for game, and made one hot jut at the Gate of his outer Court; and his blue Coat dicovering him to me, I made as if I would hoot at him, which he perceiving by the help of his Glas, for he was naturally pur-blind, he popt in his head in a great deal of hate, which I could not but laugh to ee; for indeed he was o far from being in danger, that a Fuee could not carry above half o far; but all that did not prevent the fright he was in; by which I learnt, that a man is never the les a Coward for big Looks and great
Whiskers. All this while the Alarm rung, and at lat the neighbouring Parihes beginning to make the ame jangling with their Bells, I thought it was time to retreat. Indeed, I found already the Peaants began to pot themelves at the Lanes ends, and Defiles; but none of them daring to tay my coming, I retir'd very well pleas'd with my little Expedition.

Vedeau preently guet this was ome of Madam Salle's friends, but having no proof, he was enrag'd at the affront he had receiv'd; he endeavour'd to get ome information, and ome pretended to tell him who it was, but it was all uncertain, for it was impoible to have contriv'd it better; none of us were known, and if any had een me at Madam Salle's, they had not ventur'd to come o near me, as to know me again. This affront was oon follow'd with another. Monieur Herve having been inform'd of what had happen'd to his Daughter, he made out a Decree againt his Men; and having given it to one of the Prevot's Officers, he gave him power alo to put it in execution. The people all fled, and when the Officer came, all he could do was to make earch in their Houes, where they made trange havock, and earcht every hole and corner. Monieur Genou, eeing his Kinman had o many
•• oils, and that, without his aitance, it would be impoible to extricate him out of them all, advies him to a very ubtile trick. He made him preent a Petition in the name of thee Runaways, in which he et forth, that under pretence of earching for their perons, they had plunder'd their Houes, and took away all they had This they had leave given them to prove, and there was no want of ham evidence to wear it. Upon which M. Vedeau got a Decree againt the Officer and his Aitants; who mitruting nothing all the while, and no body being o kind to tell him what had pat, was taken as he was itting peaceably in his own Houe, and carry'd Prioner to Chatau-neuf in Thimerais; this was jut in the Neighbourhood of Vedeau, where the Ma •• liv'd in very good credit: From whence he cat him, not only into a loathome Prion, but alo immediately
order'd him to be proecuted. 'Twas trange that a Man who was oblig'd in concience, and above all by the obligation of his Office, to do jutice to all men, hould uffer himelf to be led into uch a paion, th • s to oppres an innocent man, and that purely for revenge; for all the crime they could lay on this unfortunate man was, that according to his Office, he was at his Houe to earch for thoe againt whom there was a lawful Decree; and the pretence of his tealing things was o frivolous, they might as well have charg'd me with it who was not there. In the mean time the poor man was ready to perih, and the baenes of Vedeau was uch, that let he hould be reliev'd, by any body that he thought might ait him, he order'd it o, that neither Monieur Herve, nor Madam Salle heard a word of it; all people who had any repect for him, and that knew not how he had contriv'd it, wonder'd they hould forake the Man in uch a manner, epecially ince he had brought himelf to this ruine on their accounts, and they had promis'd to bear him harmles.
