At lat, ome one of his friends, being apprehenive of ome further danger deign'd, went to Paris, and acquainted Mr. Herve of the matter, who was extreamly urpriz'd at the News, that being the firt word he had ever heard of it: He was too much a Gentleman not to do his bet for the poor man, the very moment he knew of it; wherefore putting all his Irons in the fire immediately, he manag'd it o well, that he obtain'd an Arret, by which the Court of Jutice of Chatea •• e • f was prohibited to proceed againt the Prioner, and that he hould be remov'd to the Conciergerie; and one of the Officers of the Parliament was immediately dipatcht to carry this News to him; and indeed he arriv'd in good time, for the King's Sollicitor was jut upon paing the Sentence to have him hang'd; the bet he was to expect, was to be branded with the Flower de Lis, and whipt, or be ent to the Gallies. Vedeau was very much troubled, that jut when he was going to make himelf o famous in the Country, by uch a piece of injutice he mut now go and give an account of his
reaons to the Parliament, where the Father of his Adverary had at leat as much credit, as he and all his Family; but being contrain'd by neceity, he came to Paris, and finding that it was neceary to have all the parties up, the thing being proecuted in other names, they try'd all ways poible to make it up. Indeed, it was a very dihonourable trife, for both parties had recoure to all the tricks and hifts of the Law, not to ay injutices, they could devie; and the paion and pleen with which it was carry'd on, having made them hut their Ears to all orts of Propoals, this was the occaion of opening the whole cene of the affair, and why Vedeau ent his Servants to fih in the Motes of Madam Salle's Catle. Monieur Salle it eems, had refus'd de Vedeau the ue of the Water of a River, that belong'd to him, to water a Meadow of his, for which he was reolv'd to be even with him; and to that end he purchaes a Fief of about 5 or 6 thouand Francks, in right whereof he pretended, that the River was not only his, but that Monieur Salle had no authority to draw the Water thro his Motes. This affair could not but require a long deciion, conidering alo what happen'd between, and the obtinacy of both parties; being on both ides throughly acquainted with all the nice tricks of the Law. In the mean time the poor Officer was the Sufferer; and tho he was no longer in the Dungeon, yet he was to remain in Prion till the truth was made out; and to make his misfortune more compleat, the Parliament would not be Judges in a Cae that repected uch coniderable perons of their own Members; and it took up a long time before they could agree to name other Judges: At lat, they referr'd the Cae to the Determination of the Requetes de l' Hotel, and I having very good friends there, I joyn'd my interet with Monieur Herve, which very much dipleas'd Monieur Genou and his Son-in-law; not that they thought I had more credit there than their party, but that they thought it was a bold thing in me, that was but a mean peron to them, to oppoe my elf o publickly againt them. Monieur Genou, who was a hot
Man, poke to a friend of mine to diwade me from it; but I told him I had always been Monieur Herve's humble Servant, and beides happening to be at Madam Salle's Houe when the firt inult was given, I could not avoid being of their ide. I let fall thee lat words, without conidering that his Son-in-law might upect me by that, to be the peron that had hot at his outer gate. It had been excuable in a young man to have poken thus hatily, but I was of an age to have had more wit: I aw immediately that I had committed a fault, but it being too late to remedy it, I let it alone to take its own coure, and never troubled my elf about it. My friend having told Monieur Genou what anwer I had given him, without thinking of doing me any hurt, they preently concluded, it could be no body but me, that had offer'd him that affront; and to be more certain of it, Mr. Genou meeting me next day at the entrance to the Requetes de Hotel, where I was olliciting, told me, Madam Salle was very much oblig'd to me; that after I had expos'd my elf, as I had done, in coming to inult his Son-in-law at his very doors, I hould till be o hot upon the buines, as at all hours in the day to be olliciting for her: When he had aid thus he eem'd to expect my anwer, and that he might catch me at my words, I perceiv'd he had plac'd two fellows ready, who making as if they took notice of nothing, hearkned to what we aid, but they all lot their labour, for I was not to be catcht o; for being aware of them, I aid nothing they could lay any hold of; o they went away as wie as they came. However, Monieur Genou ow'd me a grudge in his heart, and having found an occaion to how me his good will, as I have related, he did it with a great deal of pleaure.

But to return to the tory, the Hotel having again attempted to accommodate the matter with Mr. Herve, but finding their inveteracy o great, that they would hear of nothing, they dipos'd themelves to do jutice and to pas Sentence: For the affair of the Officer who was till in Prion, they adjudg'd that he hould
have liberty to follow the buines in the Court till the end of the Caue, for they had not dimit his Proces, tho they thought fit to allow him his liberty. In the mean time this affair was like a heap of Snow, which grows bigger and bigger by rowling to and fro. There were o many Proceedings, that they had, at leat, forty or fifty bags of papers; and it cot Mr. Herve an infinite deal of Money to carry it on, for he bore all the charge of it, as well as the ubitence of the Officer; whom in this cae 'twas but reaonable to provide for. However, at lat the Proces, after having held, I know not how long, was concluded by a Sentence in favour of my friends; and Vedeau was o vext, and aham'd at it, that for fear he hould be laught at in the Country where the quarrel began, he would not go there for a long time. This was the end of an affair o much talkt of in the world, and in which they might have av'd a great deal of Labour and Money, if they would have been rul'd by the advice of their Friends; for tho Monieur Salle cat his Adverary in the Charges of the Suit, yet it cot him at leat two thouand Crowns in other expences.

The Proces being at an end, I was at liberty to dipoe of my elf as I pleas'd, for I was not willing to leave Paris till I had een the concluion of it. There was a Gentleman who liv'd near Melun, had oft times invited me to his Houe, I ent him word it hould now be in a few days: Beides, I had a great mind to go into that ide of the Country for more reaons than one. In hort, beides that, I had a mind to divert my elf in hunting with him; I had alo a great deire to viit Monieur de Charot, who was at Vaux le Vicomte, where, as 'twas aid, he went to take the Air; but that was a report given out, to hide a mall accident that befel him. The poor man was become a meer Child again, and tho he was not o very old, his Spirits, which ue to die lat in us, had o much foraken him, that to ee him in the preent condition, one would never have thought him o perfect a Courtier as he had been:
what I have aid of him before, is more than ufficient to make one believe him uch. There were few that rally'd more agreeably than he; I was witnes of this once in my life, and tho it was on a ubject not very pleaant to me, yet it did not hinder me, but I laught as well as other people; this happen'd a little after the Death of Cardinal de Richelieu, my very good Mater. I have aid, how it was reported that he was pretty great with the Dutches of Aiguillon, his Niece, and that they would needs have it at the ame time, that the Duke de Richelieu was her Son. This Report which was common enough while he was alive, was more publickly dicourt of after his death, till at lat it became o common, that not only the ordinary people, but the perons of the firt quality believ'd it: So that a Court Lady, upon a quarrel with the Dutches de Aiguillon, reproacht her publickly, that he had been the Mitres of a Priet, by whom he had had everal Children. 'Tis without quetion, that ome things are better conceal'd than divulg'd; but the Dutches being of the humour of mot Women, to regard nothing o he gratify'd her paion, comes all in a fury, and cating her elf at the Queen's feet, demanded Jutice; the Queen bid her rie, and let her know what was the matter. I was jut then peaking with Monieur Charot, with whom I was going to the Houe of this Princes; but he, who had no kindnes for that Lady, with whom he had had ome pique, left me, to go and inform himelf of the particulars. She told the Queen, that Madam de St. Chaumout had call'd her Whore, (for he nam'd the word at length) and had openly told her, he had had five or ix Children by her Uncle: When he had aid this, it was thought the Queen would have poke; but Monieur de Charot not giving her time, Alack, Madam, ays he, (to the Dutches d' Aiguillon) will you afflict your elf for uch a mall matter? Don • t you know that we mut not believe above half of what is aid at Court? He had no ooner aid o, but all who were preent fell out a laughing; and the Queen, eeing every body laugh, laught too. This madded the
Dutches extremely, who did not ue to take uch jets; but the time of her Reign being now at an end, and on the other hand, the Queen hating her mortally, he was fain to go away without any other redres.

All people reproach the Unfortunate: This Lady was no ooner out of the Queens preence, but he found ten upon her intead of one; who repeating the word Whore, which he had call'd her elf, would taunt her with the word; which if it was indecent in the mouth of a Man, ure it became a Woman much wore. In hort, they condemn'd her from this; inomuch, that if I had not known what I did, this would have been enough to convince me. Indeed, this Woman, who made all tremble under her in the days of her Uncle, was not company good enough for Dogs, if I may o ay, for having o foolihly expos'd herelf without any conideration, as you have heard: And yet a greater folly than this, tho it did not make o much noie, was that of one of the Queens Maids of Honour, whoe name was Madamoielle de Guerchi, to whom fell out this very unhappy adventure. I hould have told you, that being with Child by the Duke de Vi • ry, he ruin'd her o unfortunately, by endeavouring to hide her digrace with the Death of the Infant; and there happen'd on this occaion, o fale a tep taken by her elf, that he deerv'd to have Stones thrown at her more than Madam d' Aiguillon. The Queen lov'd her above all the ret; and this happen'd to her at a time, when the Queen being buy about ome certain private affairs, had plac'd her at the Cloet door, with order to let no body come in, but uch as he had nam'd: It happen'd as he tood here Monieur de Vic came up to the door, and making an offer to go in, and he not knowing his face, he being newly come from the Army, he ask'd him his Name, which he told her immediately. Now there being but little difference in the French between his Name, and a certain thing which it is not very decent to mention, he tept back in a pa • ion, and flung the Door againt him. The Queen, who by accident had her Eyes that way, oberving the diorder he was in,
askt her what was the matter: But he being urpriz'd only told her, that 'twas an inolent fellow, and that he durt not tell her Majety what it was he aid. The Queen wondring what hould o much diturb her, and make her colour o red, call'd her to her, and abolutely commanded her to tell her what it was; that if it was a thing not fit to be poken in plains terms, he might diguie it, but o as to let her know the meaning of it; which would not be difficult to do, by one that had o much wit as he had. Madamoielle de Guerchi, eeing the Queen had given her an Expedient, reolv'd to tell her, but did it with o ill a grace, that if he had nam'd the thing at length, it could not have been wore. She aid then, that having askt the Gentleman his name, he had told her the name of a thing with which they ay they get Children; Mr. de Gui • au • , Captain of the Queens Guards, who tood by, fell out a laughing as if he would have burt; and when he had a little recover'd himelf, Madam, aid he to the Queen, I'm confident 'twas Monieur de Vic who frighted this Lady, for he came from Flanders but lat night; but the bet of the jet was, that the Lady affirmed till he was not mitaken, but that it was he that chang'd one letter of the name, tho he was not o to be deceiv'd.

The Gentleman who I went to viit at Melun, was call'd the Count de la Chapelle Gantier, a peron of a great deal of honour, and whoe Father was my particular Friend; he was a worn Enemy to another Gentleman that liv'd hard by, call'd the Vicount de Melun, or rather L' Arbatjete; for he did not belong to the honourable Family of Melun, of whom the late Contable de Melun, and the preent Princes d' Epinois are decended; he was far enough from uch a Noble Original, having more Men of the Gown than of the Sword in his Family; and yet if you would believe him, Meieurs de Chatillon are not of a better Decent than he. The Enmity between thee Gentleman began upon this ground, that the Father of one had kill'd the Father of the other, a quarrel o reaonable that no body ever attempted to reconcile them: My Friend
was the Party offended, it being his Father who had the misfortune to be kill'd by the other, ince which if he had but heard his name mention'd, he would have turn'd pale, and hook from head to foot. A Peron of Quality, to whom I am very much oblig'd, deir'd me, when I went from Paris, to attempt the mitiagating of this Hatred by making a Propoal of Marriage to my Friend with Melun's Siter, but I deir'd to be excus'd, for that this was to do a great injury to the Count de la Chapelle, who I knew to be more of a Gentleman than to marry the Daughter of his Father's Murtherer; and that, in hort, I would never undertake uch an Errand; for I knew if I hould, it would be to no purpoe. The Count de Melun alo was a Man of o much ill nature, that intead of endeavouring by his carriage to make my Friend forget the Grudge that was between the Families, as he ought to have done, he took all occaions to increae it: He was very often drunk, and when he had a Glas or two of Wine in his head he was o abuive to my Friend, that if the Laws againt Quarrels and Duels had not been o evere, he had been every day in danger of having his Throat cut. This was a crime in any man, but much more inexcuable in the Son of a man, who had already imbru'd his hands in the blood of my Friend • s Father; beides the King had done as much as was poible to prevent his being us'd in this manner, for he pardon'd his Father but upon this condition, that neither he, nor any of his after him, hould come into the Company, or place, where any of the deceaed's Children hould
• e; and that if at any time any of thoe hould come into Company where he was, or any of his Children, they hould be oblig'd immediately to quit the place, which command of the Kings every one allow'd to be very jut. But the Vicount de Melun, intead of conforming himelf to this Order, as his Father had done, us'd him as I have been telling you: Inomuch, that the firt thing my Friend told me of at my coming to ee him was, that he could endure it no longer; at the ame time, he told me at large the
grounds of his digut, which I could not deny but to be very reaonable. However, I endeavour'd to put the bet face on them I could, becaue I would not enflame him, who I perceiv'd was already diturb'd enough; and at the ame time I told him, he could not have the leat quarrel with him without endangering himelf extreamly; for the ame Order of the Kings, which commanded Melun to keep out of his ight, commanded him alo to bear his Adverary no malice. I told him, that he being the party aggriev'd every body would conclude him to have been the Agreor; that in his circumtances he ought to ue more caution a thouand times than another, having a good Etate to loe, and therefore ought to conider very well before he did any thing of that nature; that I did not deny, but 'twas a very hard cae for any Gentleman to be forc'd to bear o much every day, but that the leat evil is always to be choen; that there was Melun and his Gang deir'd nothing more than to have us take ome wrong tep which they might take advantage of; and in a word, that we had to do with a Prince that would not be jeted with; and unles his Cae was as clear as the day, I would advie him not to meddle in it.

This Gentleman, who had at leat 12 or 15 thouand Livres a year, and expected very much to encreae his Etate by marrying, being enible my reaons had ome weight, acknowledg'd himelf very much oblig'd to me for my advice; for indeed, I believe if it had not been for me, his Paion had run him upon ome foolih action or other in this matter. But having thus calm'd him we minded nothing but our pleaure, he and I together, either hunting or viiting the Neighbouring Gentlemen of that Country; when altogethe •
unexpectedly there hapned a Cae which put my friend in a condition of giving himelf ome mall atisfaction in the matter. One day while we were at Dinner, only he and I, which was very trange, having generally ome Company or other every day, we heard a noie of Horns ounding in the Park: This made him rie from the Table in a heat, and run into the Kitchen where he had
ome Arms; I follow'd him immediately, and taking each of us a Fuil, we made out to that part were we thought the noie came from; preently we aw a great many Dogs running after a Hare, and that they had come in by a breach in the Park. The Count de la Chapelle had no ooner py'd the man who blew the Horn, but he knew him by his Livery to be his Enemy's Huntman, and was jut a going to kill him, for I aw him preent his piece at him; but making reflection upon it a little, he thought he hould revenge himelf better upon his Mater if he kill'd ome of the Dogs, upon which he fir'd three times one after another, and kill'd every time; he call'd to me alo to do the like, but I eeing him in uch a paion, would not dicharge my piece; for I thought if his Enemy, who I uppos'd was not far off, hould appear, 'twould be neceary one of us, at leat, hould be ready for him. In the mean time the Huntman, who had not blown his Horn but to call off his Dogs, and who aw he was like to meet with blows there, got him back by the ame Gap he came in at, the Dogs following him, as if they had known by intinct the danger of taying. The Count de la Chapelle, eeing there was no body left for him to vent his paion upon, would needs ally out to ee if he could find his Enemy, the Vicount de Melun, whom we concluded was not far off, for one might hear the noie of Hores galloping up and down without the Park Wall, which we knew mut be he, or ome of his Company. But I topt him, telling him he had done enough, and ought to be atisfy'd with it, that if Melun had done this action to draw him into danger, he was very finely fitted; and therefore 'twas for his Enemy to run, and not for him; that he had kill'd his Dogs, and had this advantage beides, that the other had trepas'd upon him, and he might make his Complaint of it, and perhaps put him in Prion; but that if he follow'd him out of his own bounds the Cae would be quite alter'd: and therefore I advis'd him not to do it, let he hould do omething he hould be afterwards orry for. He was preently made enible of
my reaons, and being both of us retreated into the Houe together, where we were hardly got, before there came in a Gentleman of that Country one Chii. The Count de la Chapelle knew him to be an Acquaintance of this Melun, and o took it for granted he had ent him. This man took no notice of any thing, but ate down with us at Table, and dicours'd • metimes of one thing, ometimes of another indifferently, without peaking a word of what had happen'd; we began then to think he came in by chance, and knew nothing of the matter, and yet we could not but have a hrewd upicion that he was of the party too, and that he came for Spy to ee how trong we were, and it prov'd no les; for aoon as ever we had din'd, away he goes to Melun, and informing him that we were but two of us, in a quarter of an hour we had him at the Gates with 5 or 6 Horemen in his company. The Count de la Chapelle pying them before they were come up to the Draw-bridge, natcht up his Fuil which he had at hand, at which I thought omething was the matter, and I did the like. We marcht up to the faces of them all, and plainly aw Melun at the head of them, who durt not venture to come upon the Draw-bridge. Aoon as he aw us, he call'd to the Count de la Chapelle, and askt him for his Dogs; but eeing him preent his piece at him, he did not think fit to tay for an anwer: And he was in the right of it, for had he tood a moment longer, 'twas very probable this had been the lat affront he hould ever have given my Friend, or any body ele. Chii and the ret did the like, and they made their retreat in very good order, for no body puru'd them.

This buines could not but make a great noie in the Country, epecially happening among perons of ome condition. I advis'd my Friend to go immediately and enter his complaint at the Court of the Deputies of the Marechals of France; and my reaon was, that having made them acquainted with it, he might then be excus • d from giving way to an Accommodation, which I aw plainly the Gentlemen of the Country would propoe.
But he did not approve of my advice, whether 'twas that he was not acquainted with the Deputies, or that he thought it would be better to apply to the Marechals of France themelves: But while he was preparing to do this the Marquis de St. Heran, Governor of Fountain-bleau, came to ee him, and deir • d him for his ake to top his intended Journey, promiing he would take upon him, that he hould have all the atisfaction he could deire; and being an old Courtier who had known me a long time, he turn'd to me, and deir'd me to ue my interet with the Count to the ame purpoe. I told him, that truly I was his Friend, but he had o much more interet than I, that if he could not prevail upon him, it was not likely I hould. Indeed he had been an old acquaintance of his Father as well as I, and beides that, the Pot he was in (he was the Head Ranger of that part of the Country) gave him uch a particular authority, that all the Gentlemen of the Country took care to keep in with him. Monieur de la Chapelle was perplext at this new Propoal; for on one hand 'twas not Prudence in him to make uch a man as he his Enemy, and on the other hand the pleaure of revenging the Murther of his Father, urg'd him againt all manner of accommodation. So in hopes to perwade the other to deit from his ollicitation, which to ay the truth, as the Cae tood, was a little uncivil; he told him, that if there had been no other quarrel, but that which lately happen'd, between his Family and Mr. de Melun, he hould have had o little occaion to ue intreaties with him, that he would have return'd him thanks for concerning himelf in it; but his Quarrel to the Count de Melun was upon another account, and of a nature not to be forgot; that he would comply with any thing for his ake, but he beought him to reflect upon the reaon he had to eek revenge, and what the world would ay of him, when having o fair an occaion, he hould have had more regard to the Interceion of Friends than the Blood of his Father; that he begg'd of him to conider, that what he deir'd of him was
againt the Law of Nature, and would be a blot upon his Honour, of which he himelf hould be the Judge; wherefore he did not quetion, but that intead of taking it ill, he would have the greater Friendhip for him, tho in this point it was not poible for him to grant what he deir'd.

Thee were the reaons he oppos'd to Monieur de St Heran's olicitations, which I leave to the judgment of any, if they were not very jut and equitable. However Mr. de St Heran, not contented with this, trove all he could to make him alter his mind, and with me alo, to perwade him to it; but finding he gain'd nothing, neither upon one nor t'other, he told the Count de la Chappelle that he would entertain no ill will againt him for this denial, becaue he aw his Paion had got the acendant over him o much, that he was not at preent capable of taking the advice of his Friends; that indeed he expected to find him pretty warm, but that a little time perhaps would allay his fury, and he would then be better dipos'd to take his advice; that therefore he only deir'd him to reolve on no meaures for 24 hours, during which time he deir'd him to remember, that God had commanded us to forgive our Enemies, and that nothing procur'd greater peace of mind, than to practice the Duty in the very Letter of it; that he hop'd he would grant him that mall requet without any difficulty; and that it might not be prejudicial to his interet he gave him his word, the Vicount de Melun hould do nothing on his part.

By this means the Marquis de St Heran, without taking any notice, did the Vicount de Melun the greatet piece of ervice imaginable; for the Count de la Chappelle could not refue o fair a requet, epecially on the aurance that his Enemy hould take no advantage of the delay: o he let it ret for two days; in which time the Marquis de St Heran ent away to Court, and informing the King of a quarrel in general between them, and that it happen'd about matters relating to the Game, deir'd power from the King to
hear and determine it, and, no body being by to peak for the Count de la Chapelle, eaily obtain'd the Grant: So that intead of a Mediator, which he pretended to be, he made himelf a Judge. My Friend was very much urpriz'd at this Finenes; and very much dipleas'd with it: But we aw there was no manner of remedy, for now 'twas too late to apply to the Marechals of France, and 'twas to no purpoe to attempt the Kings revoking his Order. My Friend was then forc'd at lat to go to Fountain-bleau to ee what Jutice he would do him, which indeed was but very indifferent. The Vicount de Melun only askt his pardon for what had happen'd, telling him that 'twas not by any deign of his that his Hounds had broke into his Park; and if he had found his Huntman there, 'twas only to fetch them back; that it was an accident, that the Hare took over his ground; and for his coming up to the Draw-bridge of the Catle, • twas only to ask him for his Dogs which were lot, as he himelf could witnes, and not to offer him any affront: However, that if he thought he would have been affronted at it, he would never have done it; for he was o far from deiring any quarrel with him, that he hould be very glad of any opportunity to how how much he was his Friend; that in the mean time he promis'd him to oberve more trictly the conditions which the King had oblig • d their Families to; to which end, if ever he was hunting, and the Game took the ame way that his did, he would immediately call off his Hounds and a great deal of this ort, which Monieur de le Chappelle was forc • d to be content with, and to tell him, that ince he had made o much acknowledgment, he was very orry he had kill'd any of his Dogs.

This was the concluion of that affair, and 'twas a long time before we could come to know, what it was occaion'd the Marquis de St Heran to be o indutrious to oblige one rather than t • other: But a Gentleman of the Country, who was of neither party told us, it was upon the account of Mr. de Beons, whom Melun was related to by Marriage. We could hardly believe it at firt,
becaue that Match was made againt his conent; but we undertand by another hand that it was certainly true, and quickly after we had poitive proof of it. This Monieur de Beons was a peron of extraordinary wit, and had by his rare Genius gain'd himelf abundance of Friends; but the bet of them all was Monieur the Chancellor, who procur'd for him the place of Intendant of Languedoc, tho he had not been yet Mater of Requets, which was not cutomary; and he had not only enjoy'd that Pot three years, as is uual for the Intendants of Jutice in the Provinces, but had, by the ame favour, been continu • d there five or ix times. In which time he had gain'd o much credit and repect in the Country, that the King himelf could not have more; for indeed I have heard him ay, that the King might publih an Edict, but he mut have his Warrant to it, if he expected to have it punctually executed. I have heard him ay one thing alo more extraordinary than that, and I think I have ventur'd to ay omewhere, 'tis grown a Cutom in thoe Provinces for the Intendants to join their Warrants to every Order that comes from the King, but whether it be o or no I • m not certain: I'le relate the tory as he told it me, which was, that having receiv'd an Order to make out a Proces againt one Roule, who had been an Agent in the Rebellion of Vivares, he caus • d his Head to be et up upon the Gate of Aubenas, but ome of the Relations of the peron that was executed took it down in the Night; upon which he publiht an Order the next day, that they who had taken down the Head hould without delay, carry it back to the ame place in 24 hours time, which was obey • d, and the Head carry • d back accordingly. I don't know whether all people may be of my mind, but I think it is very eldom a Governor has influence enough to make himelf obey'd in uch a cae: But if it be ever o, it is by ome unuual Severity, rather than from the Love of the People. Yet this I mut ay of him, that if he was fear'd he was alo lov'd, epecially by all thoe who lov'd dipatch in their buines; for never had man a
greater Vivacity of Spirit, which made that Province o much concern'd at his removal; and the more, ince Mr. d' Agueea •
who ucceeded him, was jut in the other extreme. I have een him dictate to three Secretaries at once, and yet entertain me at the ame time without any interruption: It was not for uch a man to be long unpreferr'd. After he was call'd to Court the King truted him in affairs of the greatet Intricacy: And the Chancellor, as great a man as he was, did not at all think it below him to take meaures from his advice. He had indeed the greatet Reputation of all the Councellors of State; o that 'twas no trange thing that Mr. de St Heran hould be o willing to oblige him, he being already in a condition to return favours to any man, tho his Fortune was nothing yet to what he hop'd it would be; and it was for what he expected perhaps, rather than any gratitude for what was pat, that he appear'd o ready to erve the Chancellor or any of his Family; for he conider'd, that the King having uch confidence in them, as he really had, the only way to advance himelf was to gain their Recommendation: And yet he was deceiv'd in this point, for tho Mr. the Chancellor, and the Marquis de Louvois his Son, gave him great Tetimony of their friendhip in ome caes, they fail'd him in one where he mot deir'd it. At Monieur Colbert's death, his Ambition prompted him to no les than to ucceed him in that place, and no quetion but he was capable enough to have dicharg • d it, but that favour being deny'd him, and betow'd upon another, the grief of it broke his heart and kill'd him.

The Quarrel that happen'd at the Count de la Chapelle's, having detain'd me longer there than I intended, I had opportunity to be acquainted with all the Country; for there was hardly a Gentleman that knew of the affair but came to viit him, and offer him their ervice, and amongt them ome of all orts, rich and poor; and among the latter the Count de Kermeno, who was not of that Country, as his Name will inform you, but who happen'd to be thereabouts; drawn not
by the Charms of a certain Lady (for I hould belye her to ay he had any) but he had been an old acquaintance, which to him was in lieu of all other Charms. I knew him well enough, the Count de la Chapelle had no need to tell me who he was, for I had een him both at the Court, and in the Army, and he was not one jot more eteem'd at the one than in the other; not but that he was a very good Gentleman born, but he made the meanet figure that ever was een: He had taken up the Trade of a Soldier, which did not become him at all. His Brother the Marquis du Garrot had done the like, and both had found the means to be very fairly caheer'd, after they had run out an Etate of about a Million of Livres.

Having known all thee things before, it was the reaon I took no great notice of him; which the Count de la Chapelle oberving, askt me when he was gone what that man was, ince he had never een him till he came into thoe parts. I told him what I knew, in which I can ay, I neither added nor diminiht any thing from the truth. I acquainted him alo of the adventure of his Brother, of which omething was o odd, that the like was hardly ever heard. The Marquis du Garrot after having pent all his Etate, and not knowing what coure to take, bethought himelf of an Expedient, by which he pretended to raie at leat twelve or fifteen thouand Livres a year, for the laying down of about a thouand Crowns in ready Money. The Project he had for doing this, was to go and publih among the Herb Women, and uch People in the Market, that he would lend them Money at the rate of a penny a day for every Crown, which was the uual Interet among thoe people, and deir'd them to acquaint their friends of it, for that all the Money he had in the Bank hould be at their ervice; and that his Office hould be open at uch and uch contant hours, and a true Regiter hould be kept, as well of Payment as Receipt. Such news as this oon pread about, and brought multitudes to his Office; and he gave his Money o trangely to every body that came
for it, that people thought he was be, divell'd. The Commiary of that quarter hearing of it, goes to the place, but could not come near for the Crowd, till having made way thro the people, he comes in, and there found the Marquis du Garrot himelf, who endeavour'd to diguie himelf, that he might not be known, but coming up to him he demands of him what he was a doing; the Marquis askt him what he had to do to ask that quetion; adding that if he had a mind to give his Money away to whom he pleas'd, he hop'd he might have the liberty to do it, without his intruding himelf to diturb him. The Commiary not us'd to uch rough Anwers, and eeing what a orry figure he made, was a going to carry him to Prion; and he, not being very willing to go, told him who he was, hoping his Name would make ome amends for his ill Mein; but finding he had to do with a fellow that valu'd no body's quality, he was oblig'd to muter up all his Titles, and tell him he had marry'd Mr. de Courcelle's Daughter, Councellor of the Grand Chamber; at which the Commiary, who tood more in fear of a Councellor than of a Marquis, begun to ue him more civilly, and told him, that in repect to his Father-in-law he would not put that affront upon him, but that he mut lay down his new Trade, for it had made too much noie already to be continu'd; and admitting no reply, made him hut up his Coffer and his Regiter. The Marquis eeing the Commiary in earnet, askt him what he mut do for all his Money he had given out; to which he gave him this anwer, that having o freely given about his Money to he did not know who, it was for him to find out the way how to get it again. In hort, he eem'd like the Man who they ay, obtain'd a Grant of the King of Spain for a certain Tax upon all uch as had een a certain Comet, that had appear'd a little before, for as he was never the richer for it, becaue he could never make it out who had een it, and who had not; o our Marquis neither knew who they were that had taken his Money, nor where they dwelt, nor whether they
had taken it in their own Names, or in others.

At my return to Paris I fell ick of an Ague, which I believe might come from my eating more freely tha •
I us'd to do; for the Table was always pread at the Count de la Chapelle's, and I, who had us'd my elf to a very regular life, could not but be indipos • d with o unuual a cutom; for being oblig'd to do as others did, I was ill everal times before I came away. I had recoure to the ordinary remedies in uch caes, of Diet and Bleeding; but my Ague till encraing upon me, I was advis'd to change my Doctor, and they directed me to an Englih Knight, who was mighty famous for Cures of that kind. Indeed, there was no ort of Agues or Feavors almot but he could top them; he cur'd all people that went to him, and there was no doubt but I hould have had the ame benefit: But I undertood, that almot all the people that came to him had their Ditemper return'd upon them again in two or three months, o I did not care for meddling with him. But however to atisfy my friends I ent to him, and deir'd him to do me the favour to come and ee me; which he did: And among other things he made me laugh heartily at a tory he told me of the Marquis de Hautefort, one of the Querries to the Queen, a man of about a hundred thouand Livres a year Etate, but o mierably covetous, that tho he had neither Wife nor Child to provide for, yet he was afraid of every body that came near him. He was much in the ame condition as I was, and ent to this Doctor to tell him, he had occaion to make ue of his Phyick, and therefore deir'd him to come and ee him. When the Doctor came to him he found him extraordinary bad; but having felt his Pule, lookt on his Tongue, and the like, he bid him not be dicourag'd, for he did not quetion but with Gods bleing he hould cure him, and that he would have him make ue of his remedy. But the Marquis reply'd, that before he meddled with it, he would know what the price of it was, for he had been told by ome who had to do with him, that he was a very dear man; that as
Moliere has it, he ought to be o concionable in his prices, that poor ick folks might live, who could not ele afford to be ick. The Doctor was amaz'd, he aid, to hear him talk at that rate, conidering too what an Etate he had, and told him, he hop'd he was but in jet to talk at that rate to one who was o much his humble Servant; that he hould be very glad if he could but cure him; he did not ue to talk of price to perons of his quality, and he hould do what he pleas'd with him, as to that they would not differ; but all this ignify'd nothing, he would have the price fixt, or he would talk no further of it: The Doctor thinking he ought to obey him, told him, that perons of his figure never us'd to offer him les than 50 Pitoles, but that as he had aid before, he hould do what he pleas'd with him; at which words the Marquis roar'd out as if he had been kill'd, that he was afraid the people of the Houe would have thought he had offer'd him ome inolence; that eeing him in uch a paion he left him to vent it by himelf; when after having rav'd for a good while, he call'd for him again, and offer'd him four Pitoles; but the Doctor telling him as before, that he would leave it to him, he flew out in a paion again, and bid him get him out of his Houe, he would have nothing to do with him nor his Phyick; upon which the Doctor immediately how'd him his back, and went away; but was no ooner got home, but he was follow'd by a Lacquey from the Marquis to offer him one Pitole more; and o for four days ucceively he ent the ame Meenger to chaffer with him for his Phyick, till off'ring him every day a Pitole more, till at lat he was pleas'd to dye before the bargain was made.

I gave the more faith to this tory, becaue I knew a great many ordid tricks of his before, and had een one among the ret, than which I never aw a wore, which was in the Progres we made at the Marriage of the Dauphin, for I till endeavour'd to live in the bet figure I could; and tho I had but a mall Etate, yet I always follow'd the Court. In this Journey
I happen'd to lodge in the ame Houe with this Marquis de Hautefort, and the Landlord one day had caught the Marquis's Coachman tealing his Oats; upon which he came to tell his Mater of it, and to require atisfaction. For what? reply'd the Marquis, Why you ay your elf, that you only took him tealing your Corn, and that you made him give it you back again. Yes truly, ays the good man, what I found upon him I made him return, but I have lot half the Oats that were in the Chet; for I know how many were put in, and there are not above half o many left now. A • , ays the Marquis very coldly, they might be eaten by your own Hores; bring me Witnees that 'twas my Coachman tole them, and he hall make you atisfaction. But, Sir, ays the Landlord, is not this Witnes enough that I catcht him in the fact, I have no other Witnees; but I have brought him to you. More hame for thee, reply'd the Marquis; Don't you know well enough, that without Witnes there's nothing to be done at Law? Look you friend, ince you have no Witnes, pray go about your buines, and trouble me no more with uch impertinent tories.

This was all the Jutice the poor man could get of him, and o he came to make his complaint to me, of the wrong he had done him; but I could ay nothing to it, but hrugging up my houlders told him, there was no remedy but patience, which he was forc'd to ue; and indeed he had more occaion for that Vertue afterward: for when he went away, he was o far from paying him for what his men had poil'd, that he hardly paid him for their Diet; or if he did, 'twas at uch a candalous price, that the man never receiv'd the Money it cot him. But ince I am got into this Journey, I mut tell one tory, which is very pleaant, of what happen • d to anA Provincial Judg • . Intendant: He had got a Mitres in a Town where the King and the whole Court lodg'd, and happening to be there when the Quarter-mater General came to the Town, he made friends to have that Houe exempted: this Intendant had the misfortune to be a
little like the Meieurs du Garrot, that is, to make but a very indifferent figure, which made the Quarter-mater, not knowing who he was, tell him by way of banter, Yes, yes, he hould be excus'd, indeed, and why not; but at the ame time taking his Chalk, markt that Houe as he had done the others. The Intendant was not dicourag'd, but perited in his uit, hoping to do it without dicovering himelf, for he was then incognito; he poke to him again, and deir'd him to exempt that Lady, auring him, that if he knew her, he would think it worth his while; but finding that he did not take much notice of that, he told him his quality, and that it might lye in his way to return his kindnes. The Quarter-mater undertanding his character, askt his pardon, that he had not done it at firt, and immediately granted his deire, both on account of the Lady, and alo of his quality. A little before this, jut uch an adventure happen'd to me. A Gentleman of my acquainta • ce, who had ome buines with the Preident de Bretonvilliers, writ to me to wait upon him from him. I went to him to his fine Country Houe in the Ile de Notre Dame, and the Porter telling me he was in his Chamber, I went cros the Court-yard to go up to him: I did not know him in the leat, whether he was old or young, or what manner of man he was; however, I happen'd to light on him, as I was going up the tairs, with a wooden Candletick in his hand, jut as if he had been going down into the Celler; I askt him which was the Preidents Chamber, he told me he was the man; and if my buines was to peak with him, I need go no further. I was o urpriz'd with this udden reply, that I tood like one that had been caught in ome ill fact, but he very civilly helpt me out of my confuion himelf, asking me if there was any thing he could erve me in; o that finding he was not affronted, I oon recover'd my elf. One would infer from what I have aid, that the Preident was no very gentile man that I hould mitake him o; but I mut ay this to his advantage, that he was a peron of a great deal of Honour. This
accident introduc'd me into his acquaintance, and was the occaion that we were afterwards very familiar; and this I can ay of my own knowledge of him, that tho every body now adays eem to regard nothing but their own interet, yet I have een him do thoe things which how him of a truly generous dipoition, tho he was Son of one of the Farmers of the Kings Revenues, a ort of people not very famous for their Honety or Generoity.

It is not every body would o eaily have pat by uch a mitake, epecially when a man is urpriz'd in any figure below his character, of which I had a proof a little before that in another cae; going to ee a Councellor of the Inquets, call'd Machaut, who liv'd in La Rue Michael de Comte, I had a little proces before him, and going by accident by his door, I took that opportunity to ask him, if he would pleae to give himelf the trouble to examine it. He that open'd the door told me he was at home, and deir'd me to walk in, and he would tell him there was one to peak with him. I did o, and coming to a door that lookt into the Garden I open'd it, and thro it I aw a man in his Drawers, with a Night Cap on, hard at work till he weat again: Who hould this be, but my Lawyer, who was a mighty great Florit, and one indeed that eem'd fitter to et Tulips than to try Caues. I lookt on him a good while before he turn'd about, he was o intent upon what he was a doing; but at lat being forc'd to raie himelf up to take breath a little, he py'd me, and coming up briskly, askt me who I would peak with, I told him with Mr. de Machaut, little thinking I poke to him himelf; but he preently made me know it, asking me more briskly than before, What I would have with him; Give him a Brief, aid I, with a little heat, not being very well pleas'd to be us'd o; Give it me then, aid he, in the ame tone he began with, for • I am the peron you would peak with, and that you hall know oon enough to teach you to take a better time to peak to your Judge. Nothing could be pleaanter than our converation; for my Caue being but a trifling matter,
that I did not much care which way it went, I did not pare him at all; 'twould have made any body laugh to hear us. However, tho I was now o much affronted I gave him my Brief, and he vouchaf'd to read it; and he was no ooner come to my Name in it, but immediately changing both his countenance and his tile, he askt me what Family I was of, and if I was not of uch and uch a Family, and a kin to uch and uch, naming their qualities and offices, more than ever I had heard of, tho I thought I knew perfectly all the Preferments had belong'd to any of our Family; however I anwer'd yes to all, the ooner to be rid of his enquiry; upon which he embrac'd me, and told me that we were Relations, and began to reckon up our Genealogy in uch a manner, that for my life I could make nothing at all of it; however I confirm'd every thing he deir'd, and o from that time forward he would needs call me Couin; telling me tho, I hould not mention to any body, that I had poken to him before the judgment of my Suit, becaue if the advere party hould hear of it, 'twere enough to make them reflect on him. I told him, that he might be atisfy'd I would not, and o we parted as good friends as any in the world; and four or five days after he dipatcht my Caue, tho 'twas almot a Proverb of him, that to put a Caue into his hands was the only way to have it never ended.

But in mentioning of Monieur Hautefort, I am inenibly engag'd in tories which I had not deign'd, and am gone off from the tory of the Dauphins Marriage, which I intended, and which perhaps may be as entertaining as any, to thoe who are pleas'd to hear of the motions of great perons, which is a humor much in fahion now. The Princes being arriv'd at Sermaies, and the King and the Dauphin at Chalons, 'twas reolv'd the firt interview hould be about the mid • way. In the mean time the King taking no notice of any thing, ent the Bihop of Condom, who was the Dauphins Tutor, to compliment her in the name of the Bridegroom; but withal to oberve, if he was o reerv'd
as he was aid to be, for there was ome who had reported, that he was a Princes not at all of a humour agreeable to the Genius of the French Nation, who are the mot pleaant and obliging people in the world; and deirous above all things, that the perons who they are oblig'd to obey hould agree with them in humour and dipoition. He had orders alo, in cae he found it o as was reported, to ininuate gently in his dicoure to her, that the manners of the French were quite different from thoe of the Germans; o if it were poible to move her to comply with the French air as much as he could, that he might not only oblige the King and her Husband, but alo the whole Nation, among whom he had already a very good character, by what they had heard of her, as a Princes of the greatet Wit and Gallantry in Europe; but he brought the King word, that he needed none of thoe intructions, for excepting that he lov'd ometimes to be private, there was nothing more civil or obliging in the world. The King himelf alo when he came two leagues from Chalons, had the firt rencounter with her to his infinite atisfaction. Aoon as the King appear'd, and before he could come to alute her, he lighted out of her Coach; which when the King perceiv'd, and that he was coming towards him, he alo alighted, follow'd by the Dauphin at a convenient ditance, as it had without doubt been all appointed before by the King, who gave orders in all uch caes himelf. After the King had poke a few words to the Princes, who kneel'd at his feet, he preented the Dauphin to her, and after that all the perons of Quality of his Train. This firt Enterview was in the open field, which being not a place to • ay l • ng in, they quickly return'd to the Coaches. The King put the Dauphines into his own Coach, and plac • d himelf by her. The Dauphin, to be near her, plac'd himelf in the Boot of the Coach. Being arriv'd at Chalons, the Ceremonies of the Marriage were olemnized. In the mean time, the King had plac • d the Dutches of Riche
• ieu with the young Lady, and had taken her from the
Queen, whom he waited upon before, knowing her to be the mot capable peron in the Kingdom. It was thought trange tho, that being Lady of Honour to the Queen, he could be in no higher quality to the Dauphines, which eem'd rather to degrade, than advance her. But he, who was a Lady of great Wit, did not take it o, for he lookt more upon the confidence the King plac'd in her, than the Title; and in endeavouring to pleae her new Mitres, and in obliging alo the King himelf, he let us know, that Dicretion makes all things eay to perons who undertand themelves.

The King made no tay at Chalons, the Queen waiting for them at Villers Cotterets; and every hour was a year to her, till he aw the Lady who was to be her Sons Wife; and the King alo, being willing enough to gratify her in o jut a deire, lot no time any where till he came thither, where they had prepar'd all manner of diverions to entertain them with; Balls, Muick, Comedies, and every thing they could devie; and tho it was in Lent, yet 'twas thought, no time could dipence them from demontrating that joy which every body was toucht with, to ee the Heir of o mighty a Kingdom wedded to a Princes of o great merit. They tay'd here fifteen days; after which the King went for Paris. I cannot forbear here to give an account of my own folly, for I cannot give a better name to that trong fancy I had to be always following the Court. I taid at Villers Cotterets all the while the King was there, tho with o little accommodation, that I was fain to lye upon Straw. Indeed, the place not being able to lodge the tenth part of the company, ome were fain to go 2 or 3 leagues every night for a Lodging; others encampt in the Fields. For my part, I was o crippled with my hard Lodging, that when I came to get a Horeback I found my elf very uneay. One of thoe who had danc'd at the Ball, eeing me in uch a cae, told me, that if I would lend him my Hore, he would give me his place in the Coach. I took him at his word, for nothing
could have pleas'd me better: But being got into the company of all the great Dancers of the Town, there was a parcel of dicoure which was o far from diverting me, that I was more uneay there than I hould have been upon my Hore; and the weather too prov'd o bad, that we could take but very hort Stages; and at lat, to make up all, the Coach overturn'd, and in o dirty a place, that it was half a day before we could get out, for we were forc'd for help to go to the neighbouring Villages; all this while I torm'd, and call'd my elf a hundred fools for running my elf into this needles trouble. We had et out omething before the ret, that we might be at S. Germain as oon as the King, but now we were like to be left a long way behind. When the King pat by us, in that condition, he ent to ee who we were that were in uch a pickle? and when he was told it was the Dancers, he laught heartily, and aid, He had rather it were they than any others, for they had the bet Legs; but he doubted they would find it hard to dance handomely upon uch a Stage as that. This was told us by a Gentleman of the Wardrobe, who had a relation among us; and tho it is the cutom to admire every thing the King ays, we dipenc'd with doing it now, being too dull at our misfortune to laugh at any thing: at lat, after a great deal of patience, we got out of that ugly place, and were forc'd to get ix freh Hores for the Coach. We were all French-men, and o naturally apt to forget our pat michances; we thought of them no more after we once got to Senlis; we talkt of nothing there but making good cheer, and our Gentlemen finding the Wine very good, drank as much as inclin'd them all to go to leep.

The next day we reacht our Journeys end, and when I came home found a man at my Lodgings that tay'd for me, with whom I once took a longer Journey than this, tho not o unpleaant. 'Twas while I was with the Cardinal de Richelieu. He had ent me into Languedoc to carry ome dipatches to the Duke de Montmorenci, Governour of that Province; and as I was riding pot
back again, I met with uch a bad Hore a little beyon •
Peage in Dauphine, that I think if a man was to be flea'd alive, he could not endure more than I did. I had done better a thouand times, aoon as I had perceiv'd this unlucky chance, to have got upon the Pot-boys Hore, or have gone on Foot; but thinking that by purring and whipping I hould get him along, I fatigu'd my elf o, as I think I never felt o much pain in my life. In the mean time the Pot-boy, whom I had wore at, and threatned hard enough, run away, for fear I hould be as good as my word; o I was left in the middle of a great Plain, like a Vagabond; then I try'd to light and walk a foot, but that brought me into another perplexity, for the Jade would not lead, but hung back, till I was afraid he would have lugg'd my Arm of. I thought I would cure that quickly, o I turn'd her afore, and let her go looe; but then he would tand tock till till I came up to drive her; and then intead of going forward he would do nothing, but go from one ide to the other; o being oon tir'd with that port I got up again: but then I was put to the torture again. I hort, I believe I hould never have reacht the next Stage, if I had not with the help of Whip and Spur overtook a Hore Litter going my way, where the peron who was in it, prov'd the very Man, that, as I aid, taid for me at my Lodgings, with one of his Brothers. I askt them how far it was to Peage, and the Man eeing what a orrowful condition I was in, told me if I pleas'd I might come into the Hore Litter, and his Brother hould get up on my Hore, and then the way would not eem half o long to me. He could not have offer'd me a greater kindnes; then taking him at his word I got up preently, and really I found him a Man of uch an excellent humour, that tho I was intollerable weary, yet I was mightily pleas'd with his converation. Being arriv'd at Peage we upp'd together, and the next day I made ue of his Carriage to Vienne, and from thence to Lyons, where (being in no great hate) I taid 3 or 4 days to ret me. This Man came to Lyons to have a conultation
of Phyitians for an old Ditemper which he had had upon him a long time, and his Brother came with him only to keep him company; but it was the pleaantet Conultation, I believe, that ever was heard of; and I can peak with the more certainty of it, becaue I was there my elf. He told the Doctors, he did not come to them to know if he hould recover his health, by oberving thoe forms and rules of living which they generally impoe upon their Patients, but whether or no he might be cur'd, and yet live on at his own old rate; that he had always eat well, and drunk hard, and lov'd a Woman, and intended to do o till; and if they could undertake to cure him upon thoe terms well and good. The Doctors tar'd upon one another, hearing him talk at this rate, and all with one voice condemn'd him to dye; ince he was reolv'd to live his own way, in contempt of Science and their Rules. However, becaue he hould not altogether loe his labour, they told him, tho they could ay little to him, ince he would not refrain from thoe Debauches; yet they would give him ome mall thing to take, and order him to bleed often. This was indeed the ready way to kill the Man, and o it prov'd, for he dy'd the latter end of that year. He had a Benefice of about a thouand Livres a year, which is coniderable in that Country, and when he dy'd became vacant. His Brother immediately takes Pot, and comes away to me, to deire me to ue any interet to get it for him. I had no great interet truly, but having the honour to belong to the Prime Miniter, made me have ome repect more than ordinary in the world: I went to the Bihop of Valence, in whoe Gift it was, and he granted it me at the firt word; and ever ince the poor Man is o grateful to me, that every year he ends me a Preent of ome thing or other that's rare in the Country; and whenever he comes to Paris, I am always the firt peron he makes a viit to. He was come this time, about a difference he had with the Marquis de Riv • rolles, Colonel of the Royal Regiment of Piemont, one of the Grand Priors of the Order of St. Lazarus; and it was upon
the account of this lat dignity of the Marquis, that he came to have a dipute with him; for having ome Dues, where the Marquis alo had a Claim, their people who liv'd there agreed o ill, that their Maters were fain to be concern'd in it, and were now jut on the point of going to Law. I told him preently he had better never begin it, if he could avoid it, becaue he would have a very powerful Adverary, not becaue of the Marquis de Rivarolles, who had no more friends than other folks, but becaue of Monieur de Louvois, who mut be a Party, as he was Vicar General of the Order: he told me he was of my opinion, and therefore he was come directly to me to beg my aitance, for that he thought he had heard me ay, I was particularly acquainted with Monieur de Rivarolles, and having had o much experience of my friendhip, he did not quetion but I would ait him to the bet of my power. I told him he was very much in the right, for o I would, but that it was not in my power to do him any ervice in this Cae, for that on certain accounts, which I could tell him, Monieur de Rivarolles and I had fallen out, and I had no interet in him at all. Indeed Monieur de Rivarolles was a peron of a thouand good qualities; he was a very gentile man, and a man of Wit and Bravery enough, but withal o very covetous, that he would quarrel with the bet friend he had for the value of Six-pence; by which humour he embroyl'd himelf in a multitude of brangles and quarrels: But as this did not concern me, o I hould not have toucht upon it, if he had but hown himelf a man of honour, and kept his word with me. The difference I had with him was on this account. Meeting him one day at St. Germains, he came up to me and embrac'd me, and after a croud of Carees askt me, what I had done for my Nephew. I told him I had plac'd him in the Kings Regiment; for at that time he was in that Regiment. He told me, that if I would let him have him, he would help him to a Company in his own Regiment, and it hould not cot him a Farthing, for he had a Captain who he did not like, and if it were poible he would
have him caheer'd; and if I would joyn with him, aoon as ever 'twas done he would acquaint me with it, that I might ue my interet to get it; that he did not care to ask it himelf, let it hould be thought he had pickt a quarrel with t'other on purpoe to oblige me; but to be ure they at the Office would peak with him before it was granted to any body, and then he would do his part.

There could be nothing more generous than uch a dicoure as this; and therefore thinking my elf oblig'd to acknowledge it, I took my Nephew along with me to wait upon him, to whom alo he renew'd the ame profeion he had made to me; but he was never able to bring it to pas, and the Captain had o many friends, that 'twas not in his power to turn him out, as he intended. However, I thought my elf extreamly oblig'd to him for what he had done; and as my Nephew was grown weary of erving any longer in the Infantry, I advis'd him to buy a Company in his Regiment; then I enquir'd, if there was any Captain in that Regiment dipos'd to ell, and I undertood the Baron de Montequiou had an inclination to lay down. I went to the Marquis de Rivarolles, and told him, that my Nephew having o much experience of his Friendhip, was reolv • d to erve under him; and that there being no Company to be got gratis, he was reolv'd to buy one; that Monieur de Montequiou was reolv • d to part with his; but before we treated with him I was willing to acquaint him of it, and ask his advice. He told me, I was to blame to be o forward, he was orry that my Nephew had not patience to tay a little longer, that certainly one or other would drop, which it might be in his power to procure for him without paying for it; but if he was o willing to part with his Money, he thought himelf very much oblig'd to me for asking his advice, and giving him an opportunity to erve him, and he would endeavour he hould have no caue to repent it; that they would be Companions, and a great many fine things he aid to me of this ort, and made me tay and dine with him. The Marquis de
Teilon, of the Family of Merodes, who marry'd the Marchiones de Vervi • , din'd with us, they having come together from Avenes, where his Regiment was in Garrion. We drank together all four in the greatet friendhip in the world; and there he told me a tory how Monieur de Teilons man dropt a Bag with 500 Pitoles in it as they came along, and going back immediately, light of the man that found them. In hort, I had all the reaon in the world to think my elf oblig'd to him, and o had my Nephew, we therefore made no more words of it, but went about our Bargain with Mr. de Montequiou; and I immediately went to his Lodgings to peak with him. He was the only Son, and Heir to an Etate of even or eight thouand Livres a year, and the Inclination he had to go and ee his Etate made him the eaier to treat with, o that our Bargain was oon concluded, and I went back to acquaint Mr. de Rivarolles, who told me he was very glad of it, and to tetify that he was indeed willing to do us all the ervice he could, he told me he would manage the buines of the Office for us himelf, which was eay enough for him to do, by acquainting Mr. de St. Pouange, that it was with his conent my Nephew enter'd into his Regiment. That this was the bet coure, and if I pleas'd to be at St. Germains uch a day, I hould ee with my own eyes what pains he would take to erve me.

I had heard a great many people talk of this Monieur de Rivarolles, and of ill things done by him; but eeing him o very gentile to us, I began to ay to my Friends that he had certainly very hard meaure, and that I never met with an honeter Gentleman in my Life. Indeed, who would have thought otherwie of a man, from whom one had never receiv'd any thing but good will; at leat till ome caue had appear'd to the contrary? But it was not long before I had caue enough to alter my opinion; for coming to St. Germains at the time appointed, and finding him out, he told me he had heard ome News that very much urpriz'd him; that Monieur de St. Pouange having undertood that
Montequiou had a deign to quit, had dipos'd of his Company to the eldet Son of the Count de Grand Pre, and he being Nephew to Monieur de Joyeue, Lieutenant General of the Army, he durt not peak againt it for fear of breaking with him; that he was mightily concern'd on my account, but the firt Company that became vacant he would take uch meaures, that we hould not be diappointed again. I guet preently he had trickt me, and leaving him with omething les ceremony than I us'd to do, I met Monieur de Montequiou, who was come on purpoe to give his conent. Aoon as I had told him what had happen'd. Ay, ays he, this is one of Mr. de Rivarolles uual tricks: I could have told you before, that he would put ome ham or other upon you, when I aw you o confident of his Friendhip; but I thought you would not be long before you found him the wort of Villains. This is jut as he erv'd poor Clauel, who was his Lieutenant, and who is now a Captain in the Regiment call'd Chevelier Duc. It is about two years ago that he got him leave himelf to go home; but while he was there he wrote to him, in hort, that he hould not trouble himelf to come again, but to end him his Commiion (which by the way he had old for a thouand Crowns) but Clauel baulkt him; for having made the General acquainted with it, he was forc'd to give him the Money, which Clauel had more mind to than the Office, being not very willing to erve, under a Man, that had hown himelf o bae. But for my part, continu'd he, either your Nephew hall have my Company, or no body hall have it. Monieur de St. Pouange mut not think to dipoe of it without my conent; and I will peak to the King about it if there be occaion, who I don't doubt will do me jutice.

I was mighty glad to hear him talk thus; for I was o vext at this wheadle of Mr. de Rivarolles, that I was very well pleas'd to think he hould meet with ome little mortification, which made me prompt him the more to it. I got him then to go directly to Mr. de St. Pouange; whom he told, that he was urpriz'd to hear he had given away his Company, ince he had always faithfully
erv'd the King, without o much as the leat micarriage in his duty; that ince he had been in the ervice, he had always kept his Company full, and in good condition, and perhaps he could ay, the bet in the Army; that if he had a deign to quit, he hop • d he might have the ame priviledge as others had, who were always allow'd to carry off a little Money; that he had pent ten thouand Crowns of his own in the ervice, and 'twas but reaonable he hould have the advantage of reimburing himelf a little; that he had treated with my Nephew by the Kings permiion, at a price both parties were content with; and if he pleas'd to execute the Agreement, he was there ready to make his Reignation: • f not; he would pend twice as much more, before he would be bubbled by the Marquis de Rivarolles. Mr. de St. Pouange was urpriz'd at this dicoure, for Mr. de Rivarolles had told him, that Montequiou was content, that the Marquis de Grand Pre hould have his Company; however, being a friend of Mr. de Joyeue, who had poke in favour of his Nephew, he return'd, that he could ay nothing to it, but that he hould have poke ooner; the thing being now done, it was pat remedy, for the Commiion was ealed, and wanted nothing but to be deliver'd. Indeed the Commiion lay upon the Table, and to put it out of quetion he how'd it us. Montequiou reply'd reolutely, that its being dipatcht or not ignified nothing to him; that it was upon the account of his having no mind to erve any longer, that the King had gratified Monieur de Grand Pre; but now his mind was alter'd, and he declar'd the contrary; and if it mut be o he would keep it himelf, and to convince him, he would immediately return to Garrion •
Mr. de St. Pouange was not us'd to be talkt to at this rate, and therefore was very much affronted, and fell out in a violent paion, telling us, that ince he would erve again, Monieur de Grand Pre hould not have his Company, but that he would take care alo, that my Nephew hould never have it, and that he hould look that he did his Duty very well, for he
would have an Eye upon his Conduct; bidding him take notice, that if he receiv'd any affront, it hould come from no body but himelf. With thee words he took up the Commiion, and tearing it in three or four pieces, threw it upon the ground, letting us know by this action, what we had heard of him before was true, that when he did epoue any mans interet he did it with a great deal of warmth. We made no quetion, but all this huff was upon the account of Mr. de Joyeue. In the mean time, Monieur de Montequiou, being oblig'd to keep his Company, gave us an example, that it is impoible to avoid our Detiny, being kill'd the next Campaign in Germany. And this obligation his Father had to Mr. de Rivarolles, whom he had erv'd in everal occaions to the utmot; particularly when he had his Leg hot off by a Cannon Bullet before Puicerda, and was carry'd to Tholoue; where he omitted nothing either for his Recovery or his Diverion; and aoon as he aw it would not be prejudicial to his health, brought him ome of the finet Women in the Town to entertain him. Yet at the ame time, tho he was in a condition fitter to think of another world than of this, he could not forbear his old Trade of defaming people, and amongt the ret of a Gentleman in the Army, call • d Madaillan, a peron of quality, who having ome friends in the company that heard it, and inform'd him what the Marquis de Rivarolles had aid of him; this made him come Pot from Paris to demand atisfaction; and was the occaion of a very pleaant adventure. Madaillan at his arrival ent him a Challenge, without informing himelf, whether he was in a condition to fight or not. In hort, he that carry'd the Challenge found him in bed, as 'twas likely enough he hould, a Cannon-hot being not o oon cur'd, (for he lay by it above ix weeks after that.) However, making hew as if he was very ready to give him atisfaction, he only told the Meenger that he had taken Phyick that day; o that it was impoible he could go out; but the next he did not quetion, but he hould be able,
when he would end word where, and at what weapons he would fight him. This anwer being carry'd to Madaillan he was mighty glad, and waited the time appointed with a great deal of impatience. He was awake very early in the morning, when his Servants, who knew nothing of the matter, came and told him, there was a Man below would peak with him from the Marquis de Rivarolles. He made no quetion, but it was to appoint the place, and manner of their meeting, as he had promis • d, and o order'd them to bring him in, and to leave them together. The man, as oon as he was come in, intead of going to the Bed-ide to peak with him, as he expected, goes directly to the Table, where he laid down ome things which he had under his Coat; Madaillan be •• n to laugh at the fellow, and lifting himelf up to look what it was he laid down, he was amaz'd to ee all the Table cover'd over with surgeons Intruments: But imagining that the man might have made ome mitake, he askt him, if he was ure he was right? and if he had not aid he came from the Marquis de Rivarolles? No, Sir, ays the man, it is no mitake, I did ay I came from him, and do o till, for he ent me to deire you to let me cut off one of your Legs; for having ent him a Challenge to fight to day, he uppoes you are more of a Gentleman than to fight him at an advantage; and he has lot one of his Legs at Puicerda, of which he is not yet cur'd; and being not uch a fool as to fight, maim'd as he is, againt a man that has all his Limbs; he deires you would either go firt and loe one of your Legs as he did, or if you have uch a mind to fight, to let me cut off one for you, for 'tis my buines. The man that made him this compliment was really a Surgeon; and Madaillan, for fear he hould be laught at if he abus'd him, took no notice, but bid him take up his Tools and go about his buines; but 'twas never a jot the more ecret for that, for the Marquis de Rivarolles took care to make it publick enough; and it being impoible after that to conceal the quarrel, the Deputies of the Marechals of France prohibited them fighting, and afterwards made them friends.

'Tis eaie to judge from hence what a condition I was in to ait my friend in his dipute with Monieur de Rivarolles, and he being a man of ene, that knew I had good will enough for him, knew I did not peak to refue him my aitance. He apply'd himelf elewhere, and having found one who had more Interet in the Marquis than I, he deir'd him to tell the Marquis that he had no inclination to go to Law unles he was forc'd to it, and therefore begg'd of him he would do him jutice; and if he would not be Judge in his own cae, that then he would leave it to any indifferent peron whom he himelf would chooe. But the Marquis would be brought to no terms, nothing would erve him but the relinquihing all his Dues; which the other being not willing to do, was forc'd to go to Law with him: In the proecution of which, I endeavour'd, with ome other of his friends, to erve him as well as we could with the Judges. At lat there comes a peron to him, who told him he hould not be afraid to deal with him, for he hould not fail either in Proecution, or in making Friends; and that the Marquis himelf hould not make better; and in particular, he would undertake that Monieur de Louvois hould not interet himelf in his Caue, and that he might depend upon this notice. He brought me this news himelf, at the ame time telling me that he knew not who this man was, nor whence he came, nor would he ever let him know him; but when he askt him who he was, and told him 'twould be a greater encouragement to him to believe what he aid; he anwer • d, that he had Orders to do what he did, but he hould ee that he would not forake him when he had occaion.

I was at a los, nor could I imagin for my life, who it hould be that had ent him this meage; for tho I knew the Marquis de Rivarolles had made himelf a great many enemies, yet I could not gues who it hould be, that durt undertake for uch a powerful protection: If they had us'd more Modety, I hould have thought it had been the Marquis de Carman, who had been
Collonel of the Regiment of Languedoc, and who had more caue to hate him than any body; and the Hitory of it will give a true character of the man, and therefore I hall give a ditinct account of it, in all its circumtances, and yet as hort as I can. The Marquis de Rivarolles fell in love with Madam de Carman, who dwelt then at Perpignan, the Capital City of Rouillon, but made no advances in her favour; till at lat undertanding by one of her Women, that he wanted Money, he brings a hundred Pitoles with him in a Pure; with this he comes himelf, at a time when he knew he was in Bed; whether it was, that he thought at that time he would be mot inclin'd to pleaure, or that he thought he might oblige her to comply with him with les difficulty; and being admitted into her Chamber, and after ome time having dicover'd his paion, he at the ame time preented her the Pure, which render'd his dicoure the more perwaive; the Lady making as if he had been yeilding, and yet, that if he did, it was not for the ake of his Money, bid him lay the Pure upon the Toilette, thinking he hould get thoe hundred Louis d' Or very cheap; but the Marquis de Rivarolles, after he had done what he pleas'd, eeing the Pure upon the Toilette as he went out, caught it up again, and took it with him without being een. When the Lady roe, he went to pleae herelf with what he thought herelf ure of, but was trangely urpriz'd when he found 'twas gone, and began to be in trange fears what hould become of her, having heard often enough what kind of a Man the Marquis de Rivarolles was, which indeed might be the reaon he would be paid before-hand; but this he aw had not ucceeded. She conceal'd her reentment; but took up the tranget reolutions poible, and uch, as had he had power uitable to her courage, might have had very ill effects. In the mean time, he, as if it had not been enough to have abus • d her, made it as publick as he could, and made port of it in all company. Such a tory as this oon pread all over the Country, which when he came to hear of it again, it is an eay
matter to imagin what condition he was in; he was a thouand times about to have expos'd herelf to the firt that would revenge her upon him; but while he thus meditated michief, he receiv'd a Letter from her Husband, who by this time had heard of it too, which bid her expect to live no longer than he hould return, which joyn'd to her guilty Concience put her into a grievous fright; and as if he was not yet unhappy enough, he finds that he was with Child by this fact, which aggravated her grief to the lat extremity, and made her take up a reolution which I cannot relate without horror; for tho I did not know her, yet I had the honour to be acquainted with her Father, who was a ueful man, and very well in eteem with Cardinal Mazarine. In hort, he poion'd herelf, aoon as he knew her Husband was on his return from the Army; o he was diappointed in his furious deign, which I think he ought rather to have vented upon him who was the Author of his digrace. But tho he was high enough in threatning his Wife, he had not courage enough to revenge it upon the Adulterer; and tho he came into his company a thouand times, he never durt take notice of it.

All the world knew this tory, and that made me think, that tho Monieur Carman durt not openly quarrel with him, yet he would have been glad to have ome michief befal him, and o had ent privately to my friend about his Suit; but a little after I alter'd my opinion, and rather thought it might be the Marquis de Feuquieres, with whom he had ome difference but a little before. However, he was not to blame in this affair; for whatever my quarrel was at him, I mut tell the truth, and will do o. They had been at play together everal times, and the Marquis de Rivarolles had lot 3 or 400 Pitoles to him, which he had very honetly paid him, and having won back about one hundred and fifty, could not get one penny of it; when at lat, having askt him for the Money a great many times, and he had made him a great many promies, but never kept
one, he goes away to his Tent and eizes upon his Hores, and one of his Grooms making ome oppoition, he Can'd him very handomely. The Marquis de Feuquieres being a peron of quality, uch an affront as this went very near him; and tho there was afterwards an Accommodation, yet 'twas thought he had till a grudge in his mind againt him, at leat I thought o; and having told my friend this tory, we concluded that it mut be from him, and that if it was, his buines would certainly go well, for Mr. de Feuquieres was a peron who had Relations and Friends of very good credit; but that which gave me the greatet hope was the aurance he gave him, that Mr. de Louvois hould not be againt him.
