However, to know whether this was a thing to be truted to or not, I advis'd him to go and ee this Miniter, and acquaint him, that Monieur de Rivarolles had forc'd him to a Proces which was very cruel and unjut, and that before he did any thing in it, he was come to throw himelf and his concerns into his hands; that as it was a thing which had ome relation to the interet of the Order of Saint Lazarus, he knew his duty too well to do any thing before he had askt his leave; that he deir'd no better Judge than himelf, if he could admit himelf from his more weighty affairs to determine it; and if not, he hould be infinitely oblig'd to him, that he would appoint any fit peron to hear it. Mr. de Louvois receiv'd him very kindly, and told him he would leave it to the ordinary Judges, but promis'd him he would not any way hinder him from having jutice done. So the Proceedings began, and the Marquis de Rivarolles, who knew he was at a ditance from home, made at firt a great many hifts and tricks to tire him out. In the mean time, the man who had promis'd to ollicit for him was as good as his word, and aited him coniderably. However, eeing that do whatever he could, and his friend too, the affair went on very lowly, he began to be ick of the Town, and very impatient; o that at lat, being overcome with a violent deire to return into the Country again,
and live in quiet, he offer'd the Marquis de Rivarolles two hundred Pitoles to make an end of it. The Marquis, who aw the tream run againt him in the Court, and that the King, who every year took the field, was now preparing to form a Camp, whether 'twas very likely he hould be oblig'd to go, was overjoy'd at the Propoal; epecially for the convenience of o much ready Money too, which he had no mall occaion for.

My Lodgings were in the Fauxbourg St. Germain. In the morning it was my contant employment to viit my friends, and after Dinner to divert my elf at play; for tho I knew well enough, that Gaming is a dangerous Exercie, yet being too old for the Ladies, there was a neceity I hould do omething to pas away the time. One day a friend of mine carry'd me to a famous Gaming Houe, which was not far from my Lodging, at the little Hotel deCrequi. A dangerous place it was indeed, but epecially for young folks, who have but little experience in the world. In hort, 'twas a meer publick cheat, and I wonder'd that in o orderly a City as Paris, the Government did not take notice of it and above all, I admir'd the Duke de Crequi, under whoe name they kept it, and who had had a thouand complaints made to him of it, hould never take any notice of it. But he left the management to the Officers of his Guards, whoe Fees it was being o mierable covetous, that tho he has a prodigious Etate, and no Children to leave it to but an only Daughter; yet rather than put himelf to any charge, he lets them do what they will, not regarding the michievous effect, o he can but ave the Sallaries of his two wicked Officers. One of whom methinks he hould not be fond to retain, conidering how little it is for his credit to keep uch a fellow in his Houe, who was before only a orry Exempt, and us'd to be hir'd to guard Malefactors to the place of Execution, whether he hould have been carry'd himelf long before, if he had had his due. For the other I can't ay much, being of another ort, having never aw any
great harm by him. He was a Cadet too, o it was more pardonable for him to get Money by any method, eeing his Mater practice it before him.

Under the conduct of thee two Gentlemen, this Office of Tricks and Shams was manag'd, and the very firt day I went among them I aw o many hanging countenances, that I was afraid, intead of bringing me into a Houe, he had brought me into a Wood to be robb'd; my friend perceiving my concern told me, the Rogues that us'd to frequent that place were fled; for ome of the gang having been taken and everely punih'd but a little before, had frighted away the ret, o I needed not be apprehenive of any thing. Indeed there had been two of them taken, who having lot all their Money, had took to the High-way, and were broken upon the Wheel; one was the Count de la Salle, and the other the Chevalier Depine, but their Titles could not ave them. All this however did not give me much atisfaction, no more than the Guards of Mon. de Crequi, who were plac'd in the Anti-Chamber, but I went with a great deal of apprehenion into the place where the Scene lay, and where my friend preenting me to the Directors as a man very fit to ait them in their affairs, I was complimented at a great rate. However, all this did not pleae me, and I believe, if it had been poible, I had immediately came out again, if I had not een the Count de Rouvray, a Gentleman of Burgogndy, who was at play in the corner of the Room with one whom I did not know. I knew him to be a very honet Gentleman, and a Man of a good Etate; o I went to eat my elf by him, but there being no room, I was forc'd to it by him that plaid with him. They were playing at Picquet, for no ort of Game came amis to them here, tho that which the Directors lik'd bet was Lanquenet, becaue they got mot by it; but now they were at Picquet. The Gentleman who plaid with the Count de Rouvray, was one of thoe Game • ers, who have no better fortune than others in an honet way; but I am perwaded he was the finet fellow in the world at cheating. I mut have
been very incredulous indeed if I had not been of that opinion, eeing him, as I did, perform a notable piece of dexterity. I believe he was not very well pleas'd with my itting o near him, which was the reaon, that for ome time he durt not play any of his tricks; but fortune inclining to the Count de Rouvray, made him venture at all hazards, and eeing he was like to loe perhaps all he had in the world, he car'd not what pranks he plaid to recover himelf. They were playing now for the Set, the two games before he lot; the take I believe might be about four and twenty Pitoles, and the Count de Rouvray, who was eldet hand, wanted but fourteen of being up, and he nine. After dicarding, the Count de Rouvray found that he had got the point, which being but five to him, he cou'd not reckon up; the other cou'd, if he had three Queens in his hand, but he had laid out one, yet perceiving the game was lot if the Count de Rouvray Dealt, whoe turn it was, he made bold to reckon them. I thought this had been only a mitake, and was jut a going to tell him of it; but as I was oberving very attentively how this Comedy would end, a Mater Cheat who lookt on, as well as I, and was of the gang, taking up the Card that was laid out, and fooling with it in his hand, at lat let it drop down. The other, in a great deal of hate, as if he had been afraid the Count hould ee it, took it up, which was the Card he wanted, and clapt down another in the room of it. He did this with that light of hand, that I never was more urpriz'd in my Life than I was to ee that Card in his hand, which I had een him lay out. The name of one of thee two Sparks was Guetart, and the other was call'd the Chevalier de Lignerac, two famous Sharpers. Tho I think all their Tricks made them never a jot the richer; for the firt, who had a good Etate of his own, had pent it every Groat, tho he was not above five and thirty; and the other, after having plaid his Pranks with every body he could, was forc'd to culk about in priviledg'd places, and Gentlemens houes for protection, for fear of a Goal.

Any body may gues what opinion I had of this honet place. The next morning, before I was up, came a Man to my Lodgings, one I had never een in my Life; but he told me he had een me in uch a place, and believing me to be a Gameter, he waited on me to acquaint me who undertood things, and who did not: You mut note, he meant by thoe that undertood things, thoe that could cheat and trick, as I have decrib'd them; and thoe who he term'd ignorant, were uch as play'd fairly. He told me, if I pleas'd, he would teach me all their Tricks; not that he thought I would practice them, but that I might know them, and prevent being put upon my elf. I thankt him for his offer; and tho I did not think fit to make ue of him, yet like the Lawyers, who expect their Fees tho they do no buines, he askt me for omething, but very modetly truly; telling me he was a Gentleman, that he did not ue to be in the condition he was now in, and hop'd it would be oon otherwie; and if I would lend him but four Pitoles, he promis'd me on the word of a Man of Honour to repay me. This being at my own Lodgings, and not at L' Hotel de Crequi, I thought I might eaily tand this ort of an attack; but he was o importunate, that whatever I could ay to the point, I could not get off from him, tho I cap'd cheaper than four Pitoles too; for eeing it impoible to bring me up o high he fell to three, and then to two, and one, and at lat to half a Crown, which I was glad to give away to be rid of him. He gave me a thouand thanks; and was hardly gone out of doors, but in comes another figure, who I knew no better than I did the lat; and his Compliment was of another ort, he came to invite me to Dinner; and his buines it eems was, when he had lot all his own Money, to get people together to make a Company at Lanquenet. Then he began to tell me the Hitory of his good fortune at play; that as mean a condition as I aw him in now, he had kept his Coach and Hores, with four Footmen, and uch an Equipage, as no Ambaador had a greater; that he us'd to wear a
different Suit of Cloaths every day, with his Sword-hilt and Buttons of May Gold; and he did not quetion but to live to ee himelf in the ame condition again, for all this.

After he had run on at this rate a while, he would needs how me, what an Artit he was at play; and pulling a Pack of Cards out of his Pocket, he how'd me the Tricks and Slights with which they ue to manage their Game. I expected however, that the bottom of all this would be only the ame with the t'other, a Petition for ome Money; but it eems I had to do with one now, that was not quite o low and neceitous as the lat; and whoe place it eems did bring him in omething, for he had a quarter part of the Profit of the Box Charges deducted; the other three parts being divided between Dugas, Lieutenant of the Guards to Monieur de Crequi; Du Four, an Enign of the ame Guards; and one Bragalogne, a fellow that was once in great credit for thee ort of Gaming-Houes: But the King had prohibited him from keeping any uch Houe any more, ever ince Monieur Foucaut, a Councellor of the Parliament, and one that lot all his Etate at gaming, was kill'd at his Houe. This Bragalogne had in his time, all the perons of quality in the Court came to him; and the other hoping, that he having uch a great acquaintance, would bring a great deal of company to their Houe, took him into their Partnerhip: But the Houe was grown o infamous, that people of quality would not come near it; and beides he had quite lot his credit too, particularly in a buines about the Abbot de Lignerac, Brother to the Chevalier I mention'd before. This Abbot had a mind to counterfeit a little honety, tho he lov'd it no better than his Brother; and being much in the ame circumtances, had the good Fortune, or rather the Art, to win four or five hundred thouand Francs; for he undertood things (to ue the Term my Gentleman taught me.) At lat, having got a great deal of Money among them, but not o honetly but he was afraid he hould be oblig'd to make retitution; meeting therefore one
day with a Gentleman whoe name is Erouard, of whom he had got even or eight hundred Pitoles; he told him, that if he would releae him for threecore Pitoles, of what he might owe him, he would give him them preently. Erouard, taking this for raillery, and that he only jeer'd him, becaue he had won his Money, told him, he demanded nothing of him, nor knew of any thing he ow'd him. Upon which the Abbot pretending to inform him, told him, that he had ome cruple upon his mind about it; that he had taken the advantage of his Age, which made him remis, and not mind his Play as he ought to have done; which made him fear, that the Money he had won of him, when they play'd together at Bregalogne's, was not honetly gain'd; that 'tis true many people would not be o crupulous, but for his part, rather than have any thing of that kind lye upon his concience, he choe to make him the retitution he had offer'd. Erouard, as old as he was, yet undertood the meaning of all this, and eeing it was better to have 60 Pitoles of his Money than nothing, readily took them, and gave him a dicharge. The Abbot telling the Money out, told him alo, that he hould go to Bragalogne, and if he manag'd him rightly, he would make him refund too; that he had always gone halves when they play'd together, and his own guilt would make him comply. But it would not take with Bragalogne, who was us'd to win, but not to return it again; he told him plainly, the Abbot de Lignerac might well make him uch a Preent, becaue he had a very good Etate; but as for him, his circumtances were not o well, and in hort, he had neither Inclination nor Ability.

Thus thee Gentlemen, not content to get all the Gameters Money at the years end, by their Impoition and Tax upon Play, which they call'd by the name of de Ronde; endeavour'd alo to ecure it by other means more hort and expeditious. In fine, he that carry'd me thither the day before, coming in jut as the Man invited me to Dinner, they got me away in pight of my reolution; where I aw Monieur de Four was
not far behind Bragalogne: he was at play with a young Coxcomb newly come from Sea, and had et a Rogue to look on his game, and give him notice by igns what Cards he had in his hand. Every body aw it, as well as I, and talkt of it publickly, the thing was o plain. I askt them what this Cully's Name was, and omebody telling me it was the Chevalier de Liac, I enquir'd whence he came, for I remembred there was once a Man of that Name that did me a particular kindnes; they told me he was of the County of Foix, and the party I meant being of thoe parts, I imagin'd he might be of that Family; and being concern'd to ee him there, I told him, if he would take my advice I would have him play no more. Du Four was in ome confuion at my aying o, imagining I uppoe that I had perceiv'd omething. However Liac would not leave off; but du Four left off himelf, for fear, I believe, that I hould tell at lat what I had oberv'd. In hort, I took Monieur de Liac aide, and telling him who I was, I convinc'd him how much he had been abus'd; which put him into uch a rage as made him almot mad; for he not only ventur'd to quarrel with him in the place, which was indeed a madnes, he being in the midt of his Guards and of his Gang, but dar'd him to his very Teeth when he came out. However, there was no michief done then, becaue of peoples being by, and I took him away with me, and told him, that if he was well advis'd, he hould never et his foot within that Cut-throat place again; that as for me, I'd tell him plainly, I would be content to be hang'd if ever they catcht me there again, tho I had come off without loing my Money, and I w • ht he could ay the ame: But he, deaf to all my advice, and tranported with rage, would needs go back again. The affair being already come to the • ars of Mon • ieur de Crequi, du Four thought himelf oblig • d to renounce his Interet for once, hoping by that to in ••• uate into the world that 'twas all but a lye; upon which, tho he deir'd nothing more than the company of uch •••• ies, yet he gave orders when he hould come again to
hut the door againt him. Liac durt ay nothing to all this, for fear of making Monieur de Crequi his Enemy: 'Twas very hard to ee himelf thus dealt with by a Racal, yet he was forc'd to take it patiently. If this was a enible affront, it prov'd however a good fortune to him, ince it av'd his Money, which he had certainly lot if he had tay'd, for immediately after he had made up his Company, he was oblig'd to leave Paris, and o avoided a ruine which a great many young Gentlemen fell into. I might be excus'd to eek in this manner to pas away the time, for 'tis the misfortune of men of my profeion to have a great many idle hours lye upon our hands; and tho I took all the ways I could to divert my elf, ometimes reading, otherwhile gaming, and ometimes walking abroad, yet putting all together, I mut acknowledge no condition is o unhappy as a Gentleman's; if I had been religiouly inclin'd it had been a great happines to me, having o much leiure for reflection; but indeed I had no manner of motion that way, a dipoition conformable to the trictnes of Religion is not given to every body, and I was one to whom it was deny'd. I had a Relation of mine who was marry'd, about 12 or 15 Leagues from Paris, on Normandy ide, who had many times invited me to her Houe, and now I ent her word, if he would end her Coach uch a day for me, as far as Pontoie, I would wait on her: She not only ent her Coach, as I deir'd, but came her elf too; and being arriv'd at the Great Hart Inn pretty early, he walk'd out of the Town a little, to ee if he could meet the Roan Stage Coach, by which I ent her word I hould come down. She was no handome Woman, he would have been to blame to pretend to it; but however, a good air which he had, and the care he took to et herelf off, made her well eteem'd, and everal Admirers he had. Among the ret two Gentlemen, both Strangers to her, tho they were both of that County, taking her for another ort of Lady than he was, made their Court to her, and behav'd themelves civilly enough at firt; he did
not refue them her company. Her freedom of converation confirm'd them in their opinion of her; upon which, while he was at the Inn, they reolv'd to puh on the matter. If one may believe herelf, he only intended to banter them, and every body ele on that account. However, he brought herelf into a broil with them: For refuing to conent, and they preing upon her, he tood upon her guard, and put herelf into a poture of defence, and the buines was carry'd o high, that her Corne • s were t • re off her head, and all the Houe was in an uproar about it, jut when I came in. Aoon as I got out of the Coach, and had enquir'd what the matter was, I was very much urpriz'd; and running up to her Chamber, I found her upon the Bed, and telling her how much I was concern'd at this accident, askt her, if he had order'd any coure to be taken with the perons who had offer'd her this affront. She told me, he had no body to advie with about it, or to direct her what was fit to be done, and therefore he had done nothing at all; but that now I was come, he deir'd me to inform her, what I thought proper for her to do. I blam'd her for having omitted it, and telling her he ought to have given notice of it to the Officers of Jutice; I went immediately and did it for her. The young Sparks, who had offer'd this violence to her, found themelves in an ill cae, when they aw what meaures we were going to take with them; and epecially perceiving they had to do with a peron of quality, who wanted neither Money nor Friends to proecute them; and ome body advis'd them to come and ask pardon of the Lady; and accordingly a peron was ent to know, if that would be accepted; but I told the Meenger, that would not erve their turn for an action o notoriouly foul as this was. 'Tis true, I took a fale tep in applying my elf to the ordinary coure of Jutice; I hould rather have made my Complaint before the Marechals of France, where we hould have had more jutice, and been ooner dipatcht. But my paion tranported me o far, that I never thought of that, till I had begun their proces a little
too hatily; not conidering that we were bringing our elves into a tedious Suit, that we could not quit when we pleas'd. In hort, our Adveraries taking advantage of this occaion, got before us, and made a Complaint there themelves; and tho they could pretend nothing in that Court againt a Woman, yet they o entangled things with their tricks and turns, that they got an Arret to top a Judgment which we had obtain'd againt them in the other Court.

The buines was then brought before the Parliament, and that Court not being in hate to end matters of this nature, took care to keep this alive, by bringing up againt this Lady and her Husband, (who was now made a party) every thing that could be thought of in all the coure of their lives, and a great many invented things that had never been acted, that they might, if poible, tire them into an accommodation. This Gentleman and his Lady had one misfortune, which is but too common in this age, their Daughter had been a little too free with her Brothers Tutor, and there was a Child in the cae; the Father was o enrag'd at it, that once he had like to have tabb'd her, and I believe he had done it, if I had not advis'd him to end her away to the Plantations in the Wet-Indies, and give out that he was dead; he lik'd the propoal well enough, and o it was firt told abroad that his Daughter was very ick, and then that he was dead, and a formal Funeral was made for her; in the mean time he was ent away in the night to Rochelle to be hipt off: however this could not be done o privately, but ome whiperings of it got abroad, and thee people got ome knowledge of it in general, as that it was but a ham Funeral, upon which they immediately uppos'd the Girl had been murthered, and entred a proces for the dicovery, requiring to have the Coffin taken up again, and open'd in the preence of the Magitrate; which being granted, trangely perplext my Couins, and they try'd a thouand tricks of the Law to avoid bringing an affair upon
the tage o much to their dihonour: and truly they were got among uch a parcel of Lawyers both of Paris and Roan, that no tricks were to be plaid of that kind, but they could have them done. However, all ignified nothing, the Coffin was opened, and there was found a Log of Wood, intead of a Corps; and Tetification of this being made, they had now the Sollicitor General upon their backs, who demanded to know what they had done with their Daughter. If it was a Mortification to have the whole tory of this brought before the Parliament, which the advere Lawyers did not fail to do with all the aggravations they could, 'twas wore to them to find out a way how to give an account of the Girl herelf. For it eems, intead of going to the Wet Indies, as her Father and Mother thought he had done, truly he had got another fellow, that falling in love with her, had procured her liberty, on conditions much like what he had formerly granted the Tutor. 'Twas a hard Chapter to tell this to a Court of Jutice, and yet harder to prove it, if it was not believed. In hort, the Court was not at all atisfy'd with it, but they were order'd to produce the Young Woman, or to anwer for her; at which, knowing not what either to do, or ay, they tood as if they had been amaz'd; which the Court taking as an effect of guilt, order'd them both to be taken up, and put into the Conciergeric. I was enibly afflicted when I heard this news, and the more, becaue I was foolihly the occaion of their beginning this unhappy proces, and thinking my elf obliged, whatever it cot me, to relieve them in this ditres, I enquir'd, as privately as I could poibly, of a certain ort of Women, whoe Employment is not very honet, and which you may gues at, I uppoe, without naming. I askt them, I ay, if they had not among their Virgins, uch and uch a young Lady, decribing her as well as I could; the great reward I promis'd them, made them betir themelves a little for the dicovery: For indeed, I did not know who ele to apply my elf to; imagining, and that as I
thought not without reaon, that a young Girl, cat off by her Father and Mother, and who had already been that way given, would preently apply herelf to uch people as thoe: tho 'twas really a hard cae, that any peron of quality hould be forc'd to uch a earch, and that their misfortunes hould oblige them to ave their Lives by the expoing the dihonour of their Family upon Record. In the mean time, thee good Women, taking no notice on what account it was, procur'd me the ight of a great number of young Ladies. I had always heard indeed, that Paris was full of uch people, but I never thought it was poible there could be o many of them. It took me up at leat a month to viit all thee houes, and there was never les than ten or twelve at a place, and yet among them all I could not find out her I wanted; but all I could learn of her was, that he had been een at a certain Tire-womans call'd La Marchand; that a Gentleman being in love with her, had taken her a private Lodging, and kept her, but no body could tell me who this man was, nor where he liv'd; o that, in hort, one had as good look a Needle in a Bottle of Hay, as the Proverb ays, as to expect to find them out in uch a large place as Paris: I put an end to my earch. However, ince I knew this part of the tory was true, both by ome circumtances, as alo that he had dicover'd herelf to a friend, who had told us of it. The Advocates, to defer the Proceedings againt my Kinman and his Wife, thought it proper to have her heard in Court, for the Judges could not but know, that uch perons as we would not come to a dicovery of that nature, if there was nothing at all in it; but this Womans Tetimony, becaue of her Infamy, not being allow'd for lawful Witnes, all my labour was lot, and I was forc'd to take new meaures.

Our Adveraries triumpht at all this, and carry'd it o inolently, that had we liv'd in other times, as old as I was, I am ure I had handled them after another manner. But the King, among a multitude of great actions, like himelf, has done nothing o great, or o
much to his glory, as the abolute prohibiting of Duels; which is o evere on that point, that he is certain to ruine himelf that attempts it; and yet I had much ado to refrain from it, when I aw them at the Palace; but I could not pas by them, without jotling them, tho they did not take notice of it; and that which madded me wort was, that they were a parcel of Racals we had to do with. In the mean time nothing was done, and the Judges told me plainly, that unles we could get ome better proofs, that the young Lady was alive, her Father and Mother both was in great danger. Upon this I went to the Dean of the Commiaries du Chatelet, and pray'd them to publih an Advertiement to all their Officers, that when people came to regiter Lodgings and Chambers to lett, they hould examine the Landlords and Landladies, whether they had not uch a peron came to lodge with them; and I promis'd a hundred Pitoles to whoever hould make the dicovery. This made them do their bet, and by this means I came to undertand, that a young Lady, omething like what I had decrib'd, lodg'd in la Rue Calande, near la Place Maubert; and immediately going thither and pretending to take Lodgings, I was admitted up tairs, and there I found the party I lookt for, but in uch a mierable condition, that had I not een her a great many times, it had been impoible to have known her.

She was urpriz'd at the ight of me, epecially when calling her by her name, I began to reproach her with what he had done; and fancying he might eaily get away from uch an old fellow as I was, he eem'd to cry, but watcht an opportunity to give me the lip, and get out of the door; but I had my Eyes about me, and lookt o narrowly to her, as he could not poibly do it; and having thus perceiv'd her deign, I taid with her till I had more company; and her Father and Mother having got an Order for me to lay her fat, if I hould have the good fortune to find her; I made ue of that Warrant, and carry'd her to the Madelonet • es, a Prion appointed for Women of ill fame. It was a
ingular good fortune to us all, the finding out this young Jilt, her Father and Mother being upon the very point of being condemn'd; and I know not what might have come of it, if this dicovery had not been made. But now their Daughter being produc'd, all the projects their Adveraries laid to ruin them were vain, and their meaures broken. They would have till procur'd them to be detain'd, upon pretence of having offer'd an abue to the Ceremonies of the Church, in making a olemn Burial for a Log of Wood, and having the uual Prayer aid over it, as if it had been a Chritian. In hort, they were fain to make friends to get rid of this Accuation; and yet they could not come off without a Fine neither. However, the Judges could not but ee, that all this was Recrimination and Malice; and tho they could not avoid the Sentence which was pat, yet aoon as that was over, they took into conideration the Cae of my Kinwoman, and began to think of doing her ome Jutice. In hort, they condemn'd the two fellows, firt to pay all the charges of the Proces, which was very coniderable; and afterwards to be baniht, which was a great dihonour to their Families, who made ome figure in the Country.

Monieur and Madame ... were atisfied with o jut a Decree; and at their return home were congratulated by their Friends and Relations upon the happy iue of this troubleome affair. They would needs have my company down with them into the Country; where they endeavour'd by the kindet Treatment in the world to make me amends, for all the pains I had taken upon their account. Monieur ... knowing that I lov'd Hawking paionately, hew'd me all the diverion poible of that ott; o that in my life, I never pat any time more pleaantly than I did a fortnight there: and o obliging they were, that when I offer'd to take my leave, they would by no means uffer me to tir. I had no great buines at Paris, o was eaily overcome by their perwaions. In hort, I continu'd there two months longer; not that at firt I had any thoughts of
taying, but was detain'd by a particular occaion; which was, that in my Doting Age I had like to have committed a folly, from which all the ret of my days I had believ'd my elf ecure enough. About five or ix leagues from thence liv'd a young Lady, the Charms of whoe Beauty and Wit it was impoible to reit, who coming to viit Monieur and Madam ... I aw, and from the firt moment felt my elf o enibly toucht, that I could not have been more at five and twenty. The two days he taid there, I pat ighing at her feet; and he (who had little fortune of her own, and judg'd of mine by the figure I made) treated me in uch a manner, as gave me no caue to depair. We are all naturally apt to flatter our elves: I had my hare of this vanity, when I thought one of my years, gay and vigorous enough to inpire Love in o young and charming a Creature. I had promis'd to wait on her in a few days, but before he could well be got half way home, I was preparing to make my viit. Monieur and Madam ... rally'd me very heartily upon this; but I, who could hearken to nothing but my paion, took Hore immediately, and tho I engag'd not to tay above two days at farthet, yet I taid there a fortnight: And then return'd o tranported, or rather o damn'd foolihly in Love, that when I but reflect on it now, it puts me into extream confuion. Monieur and Madam ... who knew nothing of my circumtances, but imagin'd, becaue I had been formerly pretty well at Court, that I mut haye laid up omething coniderable; told me, that I ought to marry this young Gentlewoman, and make her fortune; that he was a peron of condition, and of great vertue; and it would be much better to leave her what I had, than leave it to thoe whom perhaps I did not care for; that as to matter of Etate, I ought not to conider it, at my Age, when I was not likely to have many Children; and the few I might have would be no great charge to me, ince I hould never live to ee 'em grown up. If they had known all, they had not needed to have us'd thee arguments with me, for I had before hand reolv'd
to gratify my inclinations at any rate; and tho I was enible, that marrying a Woman with my mall fortune, was a certain way to bring her to miery; yet all thee coniderations were not powerful enough to reduce me to reaon. The only thing then that eem'd to tick with me was my Age, which I objected; but they told me, I ought not to init upon that, ince I did not look to be above Forty; and o, in hort, if I were dipos'd to it, they would erve me in bringing this Match about. I made 'em no anwer; but two or three days after, going to viit the Lady again, I propos • d it to her my elf, auring her, at the ame time, that I would deal ingenuouly with her. I told her, I mut confes it was my own fault I was not richer, ince I had been a very bad Husband, and had choe to make other peoples fortune rather than my own; that I had a Mother-in-law who had ruin'd me by reviving the old Debts of the Family, and laying her claim to them; by which means it happen'd, that I could make an Offer of no great matter, when I offer'd her my elf: That what I had now was an Annuity for Life out of the Bank of Lyons, which had been formerly a thouand Crowns a year, but was now reduc'd to half of it. This Income, I told her, with about 14 or 15 thouand Livres, which I had put into the hands of ome particular friends, was my whole Etate; and it was for her to conider, whither he would accept of a Man, who if he had 20 thouand a year, lov'd her well enough to lay it all at her feet, but whoe misfortune it was to have a great deal les. For all the incerity I pretended to, you may ee; I told her, I had more than what really I had, ince I reckon'd into the account, the Money I gave Meieurs de Saillant, and la Jonche • e, which was gone to all intents and purpoes. Yet I did not quetion, but to have •• me off handomely with her, and at lat to have atisfy'd her, when he hould have known all the circumtances of this misfortune. Thus had Love got the acendant over my Reaon, and made me act, as if I had not been my elf.

However, the young Lady lik'd my Propoals; which compliance of hers o perfectly charm'd me, that I thought I could never do enough for her. She had dependance upon none but a Mother, with whom he could do what he pleas'd, o that our Marriage was oon concluded on, and the report of it preading round the Country, we were complimented by all the People of Quality thereabouts. She, who now began to look upon me as her Husband, made no cruple to allow me thoe Liberties that he might do with honour enough, but which inflam'd and tranported me o, that ome things happen'd to me, which good manners oblige me to conceal. This effect, tho I may ay they had, as to convince her, that I was not o old as he took me to be; for uch Raptures I was in, that no Young man, with all his vigour and inclination, could have expret more force of nature, or warmth of imagination, than I did upon ome occaions. I mention this to let you ee, that Women do not always declare what they think, for tho he had often perceiv'd the ame thing, he never took the leat notice of it, till one day he happen'd to dicover it, to the good fortune of us both. We had been at Vepers together, but her Devotion not atisfy'd with that, he would oblige me to tay the other ervice that follows preently after. I was content, and when they came to ing that Hymn, in which there is this paage, Ne polluantur corpora, he jogg'd me, and at the repeating of thoe words bid me, that I hould take care I was not guilty of that frailty any more. I was trangely urpriz'd to find her o knowing, and askt her who it was that had o well inform'd her, at which he only bluht, and was in an extreme confuion. The more I oberv'd her confuion, the more I upected ome mytery in it; and not caring to have a young Woman too knowing in thoe matters, epecially one I deign'd to make my Wife, I told her plainly, and in ome paion too, that I would be atisfy'd how he came o well intructed. She told me then, with the greatet ingenuity poible, that being once at a Gentlemans, one
that marry'd a Relation of hers, and whom he nam'd; he came up one morning and caught her in Bed, where he behav'd himelf with that Indecency, that he could not but take notice of ome things, to which before he had been a perfect tranger. This was enough to poes me, that he lov'd her. He was a man of a very good Etate, and one to whom he how'd a great deal of repect, which till I mitook, and imputed to a quite different caue than what he pretended; which was, he aid, for fear of ever having an occaion to make proof of his generoity. In fine, I grew jealous of him as a Rival, or to peak more plainly, I thought I hould have nothing but his Leavings; for which upicion I mut humbly ask her pardon, and confes I wrong'd her, whoe Vertue even exceeded her own admirable Beauty. The wedding day was agreed on, and all things provided; when under pretence of giving orders about omething that was to be done abroad, I took Hore and left her, but not without writing her a long and paionate Letter, in which appear'd the contet of my Love and Jealouy, each by turns eeming to have got the better in my divided heart; at lat, I concluded it with a thouand aurances, that I hould ever love and honour her, tho I could not think of her for a Wife. Monieur and Madam —oon perceiv'd the etrangement, and knowing not from whence it hould proceed, would have endeavour'd to reconcile us; but beides, that her reentment would not uffer her to hearken to uch a Propoal, I was too nice to offer it: I deir'd 'em therefore, not to give themelves any trouble, in an affair which I was enible would never ucceed. If I had had to do with ome Women, I hould not have ecap'd a Proces for uch an abue, and without doubt hould have paid for it; but he carry'd herelf like a true peron of honour, and not only didaining uch mean coures of revenge, but much more to be oblig'd to me, return'd all the Preents I had ever made her, At firt, I would by no means take 'em, and told the peron that brought 'em, that he mut even carry back
thoe trifles, which were given without condition to the Woman I once lov'd above the world. Yet would he not accept of them, tho they were of the value of 2 or 300 Pitoles, but ent them back again with orders to leave them with Monieur and Madam—if I hould perit to refue them.

Thus ended this affair, which I hould have repented a thouand times that I mit, if I had an Etate to have made that Woman happy. But Reaon coming to the aitance of my Jealouy, (which my paion might perhaps have conquer'd in time) I began to reflect eriouly on the conequences of uch a Marriage, and the mierable condition I mut have left a Wife and Children in, after my death. Upon all which I concluded, that it was infinitely the bet as it was, and that he had ecap'd a misfortune, which it had been a pity a peron of her merit hould have ever prov'd: I had no deign to live all my days at Monieurs and Madam —o that now I thought it was high time to take my leave: But they, who till continu • d their civility, would keep me, tho it was by meer force. I made all the pretences poible, and told them, that I had buines of moment at Paris, which I mut necearily attend, but all in vain, for they took them all for Excues, and caus'd the Saddles of my Hores to be laid out of the way; that when I inited upon leaving 'em, and was jut a going, the Saddles were no where to be found. I perceiv'd the conequence, and that it would be in vain to reit their kindnes, I told 'em then, I would conent to tay, if they would fix the time how long, and after that would not top me. They nam'd eight days; in which time, as if they had known what hould happen, or had reolv'd I hould be at a Wedding, tho not my own, fell out the Marriage of their Daughter; who, after all that I have mention'd of her, was yet o fortunate, as to meet with a Husband of a very plentiful fortune, and one who not only loves, but dotes on her, and admires her. My time was jut expiring, when the very day before I was to go, about 3 or 4 a Clock in the afternoon,
Monieur and Madam—had word brought them, that there was a trange Gentleman without, who deir'd to peak with them: The Servants had order to pray him to walk in; and immediately there enters the Room a man of a very good Mien, but whom I guet, the firt minute, to be a Foreigner by his Dres. I was not mitaken it eems, for he was a Swis; and that we all knew well enough aoon as he began to peak. He told Monieur and Madam—in a language half French and half gibberih, that he was their mot humble Servant before ever he aw them, and that upon the account of their good character; but now, ince he had the honour to kis their hands, he deign'd himelf a far greater honour, if they pleas'd to permit him to render them his mot humble Services. This Compliment was a little train'd I fancy'd, but yet he deliver'd it with omething of that air, as made me have a better opinion of him, than I had of thoe Countrymen of his, who took Biroche's Puppets for young Devils; and for his ake I might have been induc'd to believe, that there were ome men of. Wit amongt the Swis, as amongt other Nations, if it had not been for what happen • d afterwards, which chang'd my mind, or at leat made me conclude, that if they had wit, 'twas af • er their own fahion, and was not attended with very much honour. For after the Compliment I told you of, he deir'd to dicoure Monieur and Madam—in private, where he told them, that having een Madamoielle their Daughter, he was fallen deperately in love with her, and that if they would give conent to his marrying of her, he hould be extreamly oblig'd to them; that he might perhaps have done this without asking them leave, but he knew his duty better than that came to, tho he was a Foreigner; and particularly the repect which was due to perons of their rank and merit: That he did not ask what they would give with their Daughter; becaue he choe rather out of a prin • i • le of honour to marry without Portion, and make t •• Fortune of a Woman he lov'd: That he had <…> Land, but he had a Company of Foot,
which was as good to him as an Etate, and 50000 Livres beides he had in ready Money: That tho 'twas true, he met with her in a place, from whence others might make ome cruple of taking a Wife; yet he was not apt to believe ill of any, and o it could never enter into his head, that ome reports he had heard of her were any thing but calumnies: That if there hould be omething true in them, he was enible a poor young Girl was naturally weak, and a failure in one of them was not minded in his Country; tho a marry'd Woman, who trangret the Rules of Honour, was infinitely blam'd, becaue he had a Husband to upply all her neceities; and a Gallant upon that account was intolerable. In fine, that there were ome cenorious people in the world, whom he could not approve, who becaue a Woman had committed a fault once, and afterwards had been een to ue a little gaiety more than ordinary in mens company, concluded preently, that he was lewd, and abandon'd; and Lewdnes indeed was never to be forgiven.

He added a great deal more of this nature, to prove that what ever a woman did before Marriage ignify'd nothing, and urg'd it from the practice of everal very honet Gentlemen, whom he would have nam'd, if they had not been too many to enumerate; however he would intance, he aid, in two or three, who perhaps they might know; as the Count du Bours, a Collonel of Hore, St. Quintin, and Mountfabes. The firt marry'd a Woman that had a Child by his Father, the econd marry'd a Cat Mitres of the Duke of Epernon, and the third, one of o notorious a Character, that he had a Tryal before the Parliament: Yet there was none that could deny, but the two firt were men of Honour, and if the other was not eteemed uch, it 'twas his own fault, and not his Wives; that thee were French; but for his own Countrymen; he carce knew one that had not done the ame; that Monieur Stoup took his Wife from a place, where he had been himelf witnes of her Vertue, and yet he liv'd in great eteem here, and in his own Country;
and was in favour with the King, who had conferr'd everal Honours upon him; that tho at firt Madam Stoup's reputation was a little call'd in quetion, yet now he was no les repected, than if he had never kept company with any, but Dutchees and Ladies of the firt quality: That Madam Renold, Wife to a Captain in the Swis Guards, was one of the ame Character, which he tok care to publih her elf before Marriage; o that in hort, all things conider'd, too much a nicety in thee caes, was ridiculous and only fit for Coxcombs to init on.

Monieur and Madam—could not chooe but be pleas'd to hear him talk at this rate, and from uch jut reaoning, and o moving a dicoure; thought if he hould ever have the misfortue to be cahier'd, that he was ufficiently qualified with Retorick to make a very able Pleader. Having no mind therefore to loe uch a Son-in-law, they were not long in giving their conent, and that without any further enquiry who he was, than upon his own word and honour. This was o great a favour, that the thanks he return'd 'em, were enough to convince 'em how highly enible he was of it. However there aroe a little difficulty; he deir'd that before all was concluded on, his Mitres might be brought home, that he might marry her in a more honourable place than where he found her. But this they excus • d as well as they could, looking upon it as a pretence to leave her on their hands: All had like to have been ruin'd by this means, till communicating to me this matter; I put 'em in a way which I was ure would leave 'em no room to doubt of his incerity. I advis'd 'em then to oblige him to buy an Etate near them, which if he did, it was a certain ign he meant 'em no foul play. I thought I had propos'd an admirable expedient, but was anwer'd, that they had rather while they liv'd, pay their Daughter an Annuity, than be troubled with uch neighbours. That they had better purchae near the Count du Bourg 15 or 20 leagues off, who was as candalous as themelves, and o might be uppos'd to agree well
enough together. When I aw this I told 'em plainly, they were to blame to trifle in this matter; that there was a neceity to rique omething on that occaion, and tho their fears hould prove jut, the inconvenience was not o great but it might be remedy'd; for if they hould end for their Daughter home, and the man hould go back from his word, at wort, it was but putting her into her Convent again. And o I advis'd em upon o groundles a fear, not to let lip uch an advantageous offer, which they would repent of before they dy'd, if they did not embrace: When indeed at any rate they ought to dicharge themelves of one that was a burden and digrace to the Family.

Monieur and Madam—had not a word to ay to this, but yeilded to my reaons, yet told me ince it was at my perwaions, that they reolv'd to make this Venture, I hould not leave 'em till the affair was perfectly concluded. I had a great mind, I confes, to ee how our Swis would behave himelf amongt all the Kindred, that was to be there upon this occaion; and whether the next Morning he would appear as well atisfy'd with the Bride, as the day before his Wedding. Upon this account therefore, I aur'd Monieur and Madam—that I was at their ervice, and they might command me what they pleas'd. The next thing then to be done, was to go to Paris and find out the Bride; where they carry'd me in their own Coach. She, who was very deirous to get out of her Convent, and was now more in hopes than ever, had taken a world of pains to make herelf look fair; o that we found her very agreeable when we came there. Our Lover diverted us upon the Road with a hundred uch like tories as he had told Monieur and Madam—in private, which were o very imple, that tho I had ome little knowledge of his Countrymen, I hould never have believ'd from any bodys mouth but his. Beides all this, to give us the lat proof of his incerity, he deir'd before we lite any where, to carry him directly
to his Inn, where begging the favour of his Father and Mother-in-law to go up with him; he open'd a little Box, and took out a Bill for 50000 Livres upon the Bankers, which he hew'd 'em for their atisfaction: He would needs that I hould ee it too, and brings it to me in the Coach where I was, being taken uddenly ill with a pain omething like the Gout, that I was not able to tir, but which however the next day I got rid off.

We tay'd eight days at Paris, before we return'd to conclude this Marriage; in which time Madamoielle—receiv'd a great many preents from her Lover. I could not ufficiently admire her good fortune, when I conider'd that an honeter woman perhaps, could not have got uch luck in a Husband. He was not above eight or nine and twenty, and for his company in the Guards, which he aid indeed, was as good as an Etate in Land, brought him in one year with another four and twenty thouand Livres. When I found he was a man of that ubtance, I began to pity him: His condition tho I knew was happy, while he was ignorant, and it came into my head to do him a piece of ignal ervice. He had repeated a thouand times how that he hould never have the wore opinion of his Wife, for finding her in uch a a upicious place. To continue him therefore in thee good entiments, I bethought my elf of the Pomatum I found in the Lodgings of the Queens Maids of Honour, which I told you of: I endeavoured all I could to get ome of the ame ort, to make a preent of it to his Lady; but as fortune would have it, when I did not want it, that I hould tumble upon it, o now I could meet with none when I had o great an occaion for it. But Madamoielle de—God be thanked, had been long enough in too good a School, to be ignorant of any of thoe kind of matters; if he knew not that ecret, he was acquainted with another, that did the buines as well; for with the white of Eggs as he manag'd them, he rectify'd all diorders in the cae, and o perfectly deceiv'd
the good Husband, that he got up early the next morning, and came tranported to tell us, that it was not without reaon that he could aure us now of what he had o often told us. We gave him joy of his good fortune, whilt he was o charm'd with his Spoue, that he forgot no fondnes or complaiance for her, which made us all conclude, that if there are uch things as good Husbands in the world, they are undoubtedly to be found among the Swis.

All the Country was urpriz'd at this Marriage, knowing the hitory of the young Lady, which was too publick to be conceal'd; and every body, on pretence of congratulating the new marry'd couple, came to ee them, to oberve how the Bridegroom lookt, but they could not perceive, but that a Cuckold looks jut like other folks. As for the Bride, he told thoe with whom he was intimate, that they hould not wonder her Husband appear'd o well atisfy'd, for the people of his Country were not troubled with too much Wit, and that he was but too happy for a Swis; many a Woman, I don't quetion, who had as much occaion for uch a well-meaning Husband as he had, envy'd her happines, epecially when they aw her ride in her Coach with an Equipage and every thing anwerable. The young Lady that I was like to have marry'd was not here all this while, tho he was very well acquainted in the Family, and I heard Monieur and Madam—often aying, they wondred at it; but for my part, I did not wonder at it at all, for I guet at the reaon of it. Indeed, he hearing, that I was not only at the Wedding, but that I tay'd till at the Houe, had never et her foot within the door, while I taid there, if a peron of quality of the neighbourhood, had not trepann • d her thither, without letting her know where he was: he found the Coach jut going in at the Catle gate, before he dicover'd at what place he was got, he appear'd very much diatisfy'd; but the Lady making her the bet excues he could, he was oblig'd to go in with her. I was never o urpriz'd in my life as when I aw her, and
being very well acquainted with her humour, I preently guet ome violence had been offer'd her, and my old Wounds were not o well cur'd, but that they began to bleed afreh. I could not cat my eyes on a peron I had o paionately lov'd, and whom perhaps I lov'd till, as well as ever I did, without ome diorder in my oul: I wiht a thouand times I had been a Swis, that I might not have been o nice; and in hort, I was o near being overcome, that had any body but prompted me in the leat to the thing, I had fallen under the temptation, and run into all the pat follies again; but ome body having o little dicretion, as to peak of that affair before her, he roe up, and with a cornful countenance, giving them a hearty frown, turn'd out of the room without peaking a word, and went into the Garden; which being perceiv'd, no body after that offer'd to open their mouths about it, and he going away the ame day, put a top to the diorder that it procur'd to us both.

The Wedding being over I return'd to Paris, and like thoe Ladies of pleaure, who never lodge three months in a place, I took a Lodging now at a Barbers near St. Pauls; my Landlord was a little brisk man, and fit for any thing, but o lewd a Rake, that he had not his fellow, and o trangely addicted to gaming, that he would loe in an hour more than he could get in a month. I laid great part of the fault to his Wife, who intead of winning him by oft and gentle methods, did nothing but cold, and rail, and make uch a noie at him, as made him o uneaie at home, that he would never be there any more than needs mut. I knew him firt when he was Servant to Dupin, who liv'd in the Rue St. Antoine, who was of the ame Trade, and where I had lodg'd at leat five or ix years at times; everal perons of quality lodg'd at his Houe at the ame time, and while I taid there, there happen'd an adventure which had omething in it urprizing enough, as the Reader will acknowledge, if he pleae to give credit to the relation; Dupin is till alive, and the people I am
going to tell of, belong to perons of uch quality, that their names are not unknown even to trangers, and it is eay to know of them, whether the tory I tell be true or no: However, I hall blame no bodies incredulity, till they have made ome enquiry, for the thing appear'd o extraordinary, that I could hardly believe my own eyes. There were two men of quality who were very intimate friends, one was the Marquis de Rambouillet, eldet Brother to the Dutches de Montauier, and the other was the Marquis de Preci, the eldet Son of the Family of Nantouillet; one of whom had been Chancellor of the Kingdom, and in o great favour in the Reign of one of our Kings, that he oblig'd his Mater, while he govern • d the State with an abolute authority, to get him a Cardina • 's Cap. Thee two Gentlemen went both into the Army, as all people of quality do in France firt or lat, and falling into dicoure of the world to come, after everal dicoures, by which they dicover'd they did not very well undertand what they talkt of, they made a olemn promie to one another, that the firt that dy'd of them two, hould come and bring an account of thoe things he aw to his friend, and having hook hands upon it, in tetimony that they really intended, and reolv'd if it were poible to perform it, they fell into other dicoure les erious. Two or three months pat after this, without perhaps either of them o much as thinking on this agreement, and the time for the opening of the Campaign coming on, Monieur de Rambouillet went away for Flanders; but Preci, being ick of a Malignant Fever, was left behind at D pin
• s, where he lodg'd. A month or five weeks after, about ix a clock in the morning, omething •• ung back the Curtains of Monieur
• reci
• s Bed a • l of a udden, and he turning himelf to ee who it was, ees M • nieur de Rambouillet tand at the Bed ide booted and in Buff; he would have took him about the Neck to embrace him, but the Marquis de Rambouillet retiring two teps, told him, thoe Care •• es were now improper, that he came to him, to dicharge his promie made at uch a
time; that he had been kill'd the day before in uch and uch an Action, and that there was nothing more certain, than thoe things which had been told them of the other world, therefore he hould think of living after another manner than he us • d to do; that he would be kill • d alo in the firt engagement he met with, and therefore he had no time to loe. I need not ay how much this dicou • e urpriz'd the Marquis de Preci; nevertheles he could not believe what he heard, but jumpt out of Bed to embrace his friend, believing he had done this only to amue him, but he embrac'd nothing but the air; and Rambouillet eeing he would not believe him, how'd him the place where he was hot, which was in the reins, and lookt as if it were all bloody, and then he vanih'd. Preci, who was not much diturb'd before, was now perfectly confounded and frighted, and throwing himelf down again upon the Bed, he cry'd out at uch a rate, as put all the houe in an uproar: I got up among the ret, and running up into his Chamber with Dupin, to ee what the matter was; when he told us the tory, we thought it was only the violence of his Fever (which till was upon him) which made him light-headed, and o pray • d him to lye down again, telling him, that this was nothing but fancy. He was very angry to ee we took him to be dilirious; and to convince us, told us all the particulars as I have related them. However, he might ay what he would, we were of the ame opinion, and o continu'd till the Pot came in from Flanders, which bringing an account that the Marquis was really kill'd, we began to look upon one another, and to think there mut be omething in it, epecially comparing it with the particulars he had told us. The News of this paage being pread about the Town, folks took it for a made tory; but others, deirous to know the truth of it, came to the houe to enquire: I believe I had a hundred Notes ent to me about it, and as many Viiters; for my acquaintance knowing I lodg'd in the houe, thought to have a more particular account of it from me: But for all I could ay, they
could hardly be perwaded to believe it, and the truth of it all eem'd to depend upon what the Apparition had told Preci hould befal him, that he hould be kill'd in the firt action he was engag'd in; and o people had their eyes upon that, as the effectual proof of the tory and as a convincing argument that what we hear from the Pulpit of thoe things, is not all Prietcraft, as our Modern Atheits would have us believe; which the event oon confirm'd it. The Civil War being begun, he would needs go to the Battel of St. Antoine, tho his Father and his Mother begg'd of him as it were on their knees not to go, being afraid of the Propheie the Spectre had left of him; but he would go, and was kill'd, to the great regret of all his Relations, who had much more hopes of his advancing their Family than he who was to ucceed him, who had marry'd a Wife of a mean Birth and no Fortune, and one that had none of the bet Characters beides. But 'tis the fate of good Families ometimes to have dihonour reflected on them by ome of the unworthy members, and he is not the firt that has plaid the Fool; tho that does not excue him.

But to return to my new Landlord: His Wife making her complaints to me of his gaming, I made bold, one time when he was trimming me to tell him of it; but intead of giving heed to what I aid, tho I thought I knew enough of the world to be able to advie him, he told me he got as much by it as he lot; that he play'd at nothing but Tennis, which was a game he undertood as well as any body; that he did not drink, o he might very well allow himelf this diverion. I told him this ort of talk was well enough for a man of ten thouand Livres a year Etate, but for him who had a Family to maintain, and nothing to live upon but his Trade, 'twas a very ill coure of life; that if he did not loe his money, yet he always lot his time which was not a thing of mall conequence to a man in his circumtances, to whom diligence in his buines was more proper, and without which he could never
expect to make any thing of it; that what I poke to him was in good will, and for his benefit, ince the wor •• would be his own, if he did not make his advantage of it. Thus I left it to him; but he continuing his old trade, his Wife came to me one day in a ad condition, begging me to have compa •• i • n on her; that her Husband was at play at an houe hard by, where he was quandring away his Money; and if I would be o kind to go to him, and perwade him to leave off, I hould ave him loing a great deal of Money. I did not care to go to uch places, epecially ince I was too old for thoe ort of diverions, I had lov • d them well enough formerly, but I was part it now. However, the Tennis Court, being as it were next door to us, I went thither as if I had come in by accident; where I aw a man who play'd o ill, that tho I had not handled a Racket in twenty year, I durt have given him odds and plaid with him. I did then what his Wife deir'd me, and he not daring to contradict me, I brought him home along with me. The next morning he came to wait on me at my Levee, and when I told him that I wonder'd how he could have the confidence to commend his play, when, by what I aw of it, I would lay him a Wager, as old as I was, if I would give my elf the trouble, I would beat him. He told me he would give me fifteen if I durt venture to play with him; and having a great mind to let him ee what a Coxcomb he was, I took him at his word, and went away immediately in my Gown as I was; but as I told him, I would not play for a mall Summ, o I made him car • y all the Money he had in the Houe with him. We play'd at ten Pitoles every eight games; and I o far mater'd him, that I never let him get but when I pleas • d, yet he would till hold me at fifteen; but I told him no, I was able enough to deal with him, and if he would play upon the quare I'd hold him; he was glad at the offer, and taking down 20 Pitoles, he •• t them as eaily as he had done the others. He was urpriz'd to find himelf in
for thirty Pitoles o quickly; but having till ome left, he askt me if I would play for the ret, I told him with all my heart, and I would give him fifteen; he fancy'd by this I had no mind to go away with his Money, and being mighty glad to have to do with one that was o generous, he cut everal Capers for joy, at which he was more dexterous than at Tennis; but his joy lated but a hort while, for I minded my play o that I might not fateigue my elf, and having beat him again, I broke him of threecore Pitoles, and left him in the greatet confuion imaginable.

He pray'd me to ay nothing to his Wife, and I promis'd him, but with a deign not to perform it, for I had a mind he hould have the pleaure of colding at him for loing his Money. In hort, I told her aoon as ever I came home, how I had found out a ecret that would reclaim her Husband, that I was deceiv • d if ever he plaid any more as long as he liv'd, after the accident that had befallen him to day; that I had perfectly broke him, for I had won threecore Louis d • Ors of him, and o I told her the whole tory, but withall I added, that I did not deign to make ue of the advantage I had got, but had done it to let him ee, that he was but a Novice at play, and to beat him off of it; that I would give her the Pitoles, but he hould not peak a word to him of it, till I gave her leave; he thankt me, as indeed I deerv'd; and yet the diorder the firt part of my tory put her in, could not be topt, till he aw the effect of my words by the retitution of the Money, but then he begun to laugh, and told me, that he would ee him reduc'd to the greatet neceities, before he would let him have a farthing of it again; that he would ee what coure he would take to maintain his Children, of which he had a great many, now he had thrown away his Money; and he kept her word o punctually with him, that the Family was without any Victuals for a day or two, for he was o well known, that no body would lend him a Farthing; eeing him in uch a trait as this, I took occaion one day, to • e • d him a econd lecture
upon the old ubject, and the miery he was reduc'd to made him a little more tractable than he was before, but the iue was but a dull compliment to me, and in which I had mot need of chooling; for upon the whole he deir'd me to lend him ten Pitoles, and I like a Fool could not refue him, having but jut before won ixty of him, unles I would have told him, that I had given them all to his Wife, which I was not willing to do; a little while after he came for ten more, and I being in already, and beides being enible it was for the ubitance of his Family, let him have it again, for I thought, that having given his Wife all the Money before, I hould have it again at any time, when I thought fit to acquaint him with what I had done. In hort, he got forty Louis d' Ors of me at four everal times, and all I had to how for it was a Note under his hand. In the mean time, he promis'd me every day to be wier for the future; and indeed he did take up a little, whether 'twas that having occaion of me made him diemble, becaue he would not dioblige me, or that the los he had met with had till ome effect upon him; but his Wife found uch a change in him, that he thankt me for it every day with a great many acknowledgments of her obligation to me. At lat, I told her of the Money I had let him have, letting her know how it was for the neceity of their Family, to which he made me no anwer, but that I was too kind to him.

'Tis no uch trange thing in Paris for a man not to know the perons that lodge in the ame houe with him; under my Chamber lodg'd a man that made a figure good enough, but liv'd o extravagantly, that tho he had omething of an Etate, yet he eldom had a penny in his pocket: This fellow hearing my Valet de Chambre talking how I had won above two hundred Pitoles at Tric-trac, which was true enough, reolv'd to et upon me and rob me; and having communicated his deign to his Valet, who had liv'd with him a great while, he agreed to do it for him, and immediately laid his meaures for the execution.

My man and he being Companions, he took his time when I was gone out, feigning to be in a paion about omething to come up to the Window, and break a quare of the Glas as near the opening of the Caement as he could; he made as if he had done this by accident, and only told my man he would pate a piece of paper over it to keep out the wind, and accordingly pulls out a piece of paper, and goes to work on it himelf; he did this that he might open my Window on the outide as often as he pleas'd, for there was nothing but Sahes, without either Shutters or Bars; having thus made way for his intended michief, the next day he makes a bargain with my man to go to the Tavern to drink, and eeming to be very kind to him he treated him, and kept him there from 3 a clock in the afternoon till ten at night. I generally taid out pretty late a nights, but happen'd to come home that night ooner than I us'd to do, and wonder • d my man was not to be found. I enquir'd if they had een him lately; but they told me he went out preently after me: I had a mind to go to bed, o I call'd a Boy I kept to undres me, and being jut going into bed, my man came home; I askt him where he had been, and why he taid out o late? he askt my pardon, and told me, that an acquaintance of his had come to invite him to Supper, and not thinking I would come home ooner than I us'd to do, he had taid there, but that he would take care not to let it be o any more, I aid little to him; for I ever was an ill Mater to a Servant, nor ever truck one in my life; but I went into bed, and fell aleep immediately, and o did my man, who lept o oundly, that I had much ado to wake him, as I'm going to tell you. About midnight the fellow that had broke my Window, taking this opportunity, gets up to the ide of my Chamber, for there was a Window out of the Stair-cae, that was not above 4 or 5 foot ditant from mine; he had provided a board which he laid cros, and getting out upon it, pull • d off the Paper, and putting in but two fingers, eaily open'd the Caement, and o lipt himelf into my Chamber,
and immediately tept to the Door to let in 2 or 3 uch Rogues as himelf, who he had ready for the purpoe; as it happen'd my man, who lay upon a Palate Bed not above 3 teps from mine had barr'd the door, o that pulling to get the door open, with unbarring it, he made uch a noie as wak'd me: I thought, the Houe being full of Lodgers, ome or other of them having found the Key on the outide, had open'd the Door to bid me good night; o I call'd and askt, Who is there? but no body anwering, I call'd my Valet, who was dead aleep and noring, and I had a hard task to wake him. In the mean time, the noie I made had frighted thoe without, as well as him that was got in; as for him, he knew every corner of the Chamber o well, that he lipt oftly back in the dark, and hid himelf in the Chimney, and the ret run away over the tops of the Houes; his Mater had poted himelf half a core teps out of his door, to be ready as there hould be occaion; but finding his project had fail'd, retreated into his Chamber, very much diturb'd for fear of his man, who was got into my Chamber. Aoon as I had wak'd my man, I bid him go to the door, and ee who it was, for I was o far from apprehending the danger I was in, that I till thought it was ome of my friends; my man being got up, open'd the door, and telling me there was no body there, went back again to bed, and I went to leep again; as for him, when I had thus wak'd him, it pleas'd God he could not go to leep again, o that when the fellow, who had hid himelf in the Chamber, attempted to get out again he heard him, and being frighted, gets under the Bed, and cry'd out to me to have a care of my elf, for there were Thieves in the room. This indeed made me afraid, remembring what had happen'd before I went to leep, and taking hold of my Sword, which I always had at hand, I askt him what it was? By this time my man was got to the Window, and finding it open, py'd the board that was laid cros, by which the fellow had got in: He threw it down into the Court, let any more Rogues hould get in there, and come behind
him, and then told me what he had done, and that for certain the Thieves came in that way, and he was ure there was ome body in the Chamber till; for which reaon he deir'd me to defend the Door, and he wou'd guard the Window. I leave the Reader to gues what condition the fellow was in all this while, who was in the Chamber; he had made his retreat ••
the Chimney again as oftly as 'twas poible, but that was of no ue to him but only to hide him a little: I bid my man cry Thieves, and he, being at the Window, preently gave the alarm to the whole Houe: The Rogue, perceiving that he mut of neceity be taken, came out of the Chimney, reolving to be kill'd rather than to be brought to the light; but as we made paes with our Swords every way at random, my man happen'd to give him a wound in the Thigh; and thinking he had light upon ome body, he call'd to me to have a care of my elf for he had wounded ome body he believ'd. The Thief not at all terrify'd, ought more than before to throw himelf upon his enemy, and receiv'd another thrut in the body, which however did not hinder him from cloing in with my man, with whom by this time he began to be warmly engag'd; I was too near them not to know how it was with them, but durt not in the dark make ue of my Sword, not knowing which was which, o that all I could do was to encourage my man, telling him the people of the houe were coming, and we hould have help immediately: Indeed I heard them up, and the noie they heard in my Chamber made them make the more hate; however I thought it very long, and my Valet had a great deal of difficulty to mater that wretch, who fought with the utmot fury of a man in depair; but at lat he eas'd my mind, by telling me he was ure now he could not ecape him, for he had got him fat by the Throat; and indeed he needed not have told me o, for I could hear him draw his breath as if he were almot throttled, which was what he was in a fair way to be in reality; in the interim, the Barber and his Wife came up with a Light, and knockt at the door, and being very well atisfy'd it was they, I let
them in, and then going to ee who it was my man had got hold of, I was urpriz'd to ee it was one of the houe, and o was the Barber and his Wife: but above all, my Valet was the mot concern'd, who but jut before came from the Tavern with him: Wherefore not valuing the letting me know what he had conceal'd from me before, O you Dog! ays he, was it to rob my Mater then that you carry'd me to the Tavern to night, and did all you could to make me drunk; you thought, I warrant you, I hould leep o oundly, I hould not be in a condition to help him. Thee words made me plainly ee what I had ecap • d, epecially when I was inform'd alo that 'twas he broke the Square of Glas in the Window, and that it was a premeditated deign: I had certainly run my Sword immediately through him, if I had been les amazed; but my atonihment truck me enceles, therefore I only turn'd to the Barber and his Wife, and askt them if they could have believ'd it? they hook their heads at it; and examining the fellow, I heard him two or three times over ay very oftly to himelf, Ah! Dogs, one half hour ooner and it had been done. I askt him what he meant, but he would not explain himelf; and all I could gather from it, was, that he had appointed his Comrades to come ooner than they did, they I mean, who had made their ecape over the Tiles, where we could ee their footteps in a Guttur, by which they got away; all this while the fellows blood run about the Chamber, as if one had kill • d an Ox; and being afraid he hould die in our hands before he was examin'd, I bid them end for the Commiair; they told me, if I would have it o, they would do it; but they pray'd me to conider, and take heed, I did not bring my elf into an affair which might cot me a great deal of Money; that I was neither wounded nor robb'd, and that if I hou'd hang that wretch it wou'd do me no good: I did not dilike the advice, and the rather, becaue the fellow had no Weapons about him; and, to jutifie himelf, aid he came only to have atisfaction of my man, with whom he had quarrell'd at the Tavern. Indeed, he being a cunning fellow, had ome words with him before they
went out; to the end, if he was taken, he might have that for his excue: but the Glas, which had been broke at leat three days before that, hew'd the contrary: and if I had carry'd him before the Judges, he mut have ung another Song. In hort, I uffer'd my elf to be prevail'd on by the intreaties of the Barber and his Wife, who begg'd hard for him; which they were orry for afterwards, having been cheated by his Mater, who they dicover'd to be in the plot with him.

The buines being over in this manner, I began to think of leaving a houe, where I had been in o much danger; and having ent my things to a place where I had formerly lodg'd in the Fauxbourg Saint Germain, I askt the Barber to make up accounts with me; he told me the account was very eaie to make up, but that to give me any Money, truly he had none, and therefore deir'd me to have patience; I told him miling, that I wou'd, but that I wou'd not tay long; and that I had given his Wife the ixty Pitoles I had won of him; and if we had not told him of it, 'twas only that he might uffer a little for his folly, and make him out of love with play: He gave me a thouand thanks, and I dare wear with all his heart, and immediately call'd his Wife to pay me what he ow'd me; but truly he told him, he had nothing to do with his debt, for he was by herelf, and all the things in the houe belong'd to her.

I aw he was in earnet, which indeed urpriz'd me, conidering how I had oblig'd her, wherefore I bid her think on it a little, for if he us • d me o, I hou'd give her uch a character, that no body wou'd come near her Houe; that he knew in her own Concience the Money I had given her was in compaion to her family, and to upply her neceities; and that I had particularly told her o, that he might not plead Ignorance: that this was far enough from acknowledging my kindnes, which I did not ay to reproach her, but he <>
not deerve to be us • d o generouly as I had us'd her; and I askt no more than the forty Pitoles I had lent him; however, ay what I could I was not able to
perwade her to pay me; and her Husband, tho he was in a violent paion, could do no more good with her than I; I mut do him this jutice, that I believe he did his bet, for he not only torm'd at her, but bang'd her too; and if I had not parted them I believe it might have come to a et battle, for he did not take it patiently at all, but gave him as good as he brought, and any body but I, would have given his Money for uch a ight: her Husband finding I would not let him handle her as he had begun to do, told me, he was mightily troubled, that his Wife was o bae to him, and o unreaonable to me, but that I hould loe nothing by him, and that as fat as Money came in he would bring it me. I was forc'd to be contented with his fair words, and went my way, but to promie and perform is always two things, and o 'twas with him, for he not only took no care to perform, but would always avoid me if he aw me in the treet. I ent to him two or three times to put him in mind, that an honet man is always as good as his word; but whether 'twas that he took no care about it, or that he was really not able, he always put the Meenger off with uch illy excues, that I aw 'twas to no purpoe to expect any thing of him; but the pleaantet jet was, that his Wife one day, when one of my Servants had been there for Money, bid him get out of doors, or he would claw his eyes out, that 'twas long of his Mater that no body came to their houe, and that ince that damn'd buines of his, every body hunn'd her houe, as if they hould have their throats cut there.

I did not tay long at my new Lodgings at St. Germains, a friend of mine that was newly marry'd in the Country, having ent for me, I went down to ee him, where I found a great deal of good company. The Gentleman I went to ee was not only very rich, but was one that deign'd to continue o too; to which end he had taken up a certain reolution, which is ince grown very much in fahion among perons of quality, which was to treat very generouly all his friends, but
never to entertain either Servants or Hores; and that his friends might not pretend a neceity to intrude upon him, and break his new cutom for lack of a place of entertainment, he built a good large Inn about 200 yards from his Houe, which beides the profit of of it, rid him of the company of thoe poorer ort of Gentry which are numerous; for they having not always Money in their Pockets to defray the charge of their Equipage, choe rather to live as they could themelves, than to pay for their good chear at o dear a rate; they grumbled, and made ome reflections, but they were not worth taking notice of; for Gentlemen of any quality lik'd the way very well, and found it much for their convenience. I am ure I made no cruple of it, but ent my Hores and my Servants thither, as other people did, and went away to ee my friend. I never was better pleas'd in any company in my life, for we had all manner of diverions, and which was better than all of it, I won four hundred Pitoles at play. They ay Fortune never ides with old age, and ome folks will believe no other; and yet as old as I was, I had no reaon to ay • o, for if I had kept account of the los and gain I had made at play, I am ure I hould find I had clear'd a thouand Pitoles.
