And now, that I might put my elf out of a condition to loe it back again, I reolv'd to put it out to the Bankers, knowing that then there was no danger; to which purpoe, a Gentleman going to Paris, I deir'd him to take me with him in the Coach, reolving to come back again aoon as I had done my buines, and therefore took but only a Boy with me, leaving my Lacquay at the Inn with my Valet de Chambre, giving them order however to meet me at a certain time and place, but they having a deign to rob me, as-it afterward appear • d, march'd quite away, o that when I came to the place appointed, there was neither Hore nor Men, nor no news to be had of them: I could not imagin what hould hinder them, and never dreamt of what really was the caue. I fancy'd ome accident had happen'd
to my Equipage, or that ome hunting match having been made in the Country, my friend might make bold with my Hores, having not enough in his Stable for all the company.

Thus I thought with my elf, tho with very little reaon, for I might have conider'd, if my friend had had never o much occaion, he would not have taken my Hores, becaue I was to come back on them; and then as to any accident befalling my Equipage, they would be ure to have ent me word, and end me other Hores. However, as we are often mot ingenious in deceiving our elves, I pleas • d my elf with thee imaginations till the next morning, and from thence to night again; but hearing nothing then, I began to mitrut ome michief was in it. Indeed I mut ay it was my own fault, for I had known enough by that Valet of mine to give me caue of mitrut, if I had but taken notice of it. He was one of the impudentet Rogues alive; and as I undertood ince I catcht him, us'd to take his time, and go upon the Pad, and trip People upon the Road. Indeed, the behaving himelf o well in that accident, which, as I have told you, befel me in my Chamber, made me the more confident in him, but I never thought he had been uch a Racal. Having waited thus till my patience was quite worn out, I dipatcht away a Meenger to the Inn where I left them, and he brought me word, they had been gone five days afore to meet me, as they aid. This was enough to put me out of my pain, I preently then concluded what was befallen me, and away I went back again to Paris, to advie what was bet to be done in the cae. In the interim, my Lacquay having a Brother who liv'd in the Fauxboug St. Antoine, I went to him, and deir'd him to give me notice if his Brother came to ee him, and that I would pardon him upon his dicovering the other, for I knew it was no contrivance of his, but that he was wheedled and drawn in by the t'other, who I knew was a Racal; that I was very orry he hould be o led aide, having a great kindnes for the
young man; I bid him tell him all this, and withal that 'twas the only way to ave his life, to throw himelf upon my kindnes, that he had liv • d five or ix years with me, and he knew I was a man of my word; and that if he did not, he would be in a great deal of danger.

I told him indeed nothing but the truth, for I never had a prettier Servant, nor one that was more faithful, and I think the other Rogue bewitcht him, or he would never have plaid this extravagant prank. In a fit of icknes which he had, not above five or ix months before, I had taken as much care of him, as if he had been my own Child; and fancying if he was brought to recollect all my kindnes hew'd to him, it might work upon him, and the more too, when he hould know how eay I was to forgive him, if he had been led to commit this folly only out of exces of Wine. This cour •• I took, and the ucces was anwerable, tho I dare ay, it would not have ucceeded o well to a great many others; for certainly there are few people ue a Servant o gently as I, but every body does in that as uits with their humour; and the method mot us'd is not always the bet, as appear'd in the confidence the fellow put in my promie; for coming to ee his Brother, and hearing what I had aid, and that I, would forgive him, he comes immediately to find me out, and asking my pardon, told me, he was drawn into the fact by ill counel, and he knew no way to convince me of it better, than by coming to throw himelf at my feet, as he now did; that he knew his life was in my hand, and he acknowledg'd he had deerv'd death, but hop'd, ince I had given my word to his Brother, I would not be evere upon him. I told him he hould fear nothing, provided he would do but what I deir'd him; that I believ'd my Valet de Chambre had debauch'd him, and if he expected any favour from me, he mut find him for me, for unles I could take him, he had as good do nothing. Then I askt him where he was, and what they had done with my Hores? He told me, that for the mot ecurity
they had taken their opportunity to come to Town the evening before me, and o knowing I was out of the way, had carry'd them to Market publickly, and old one to a Hore-Courer in La Rue St. Martin, a little below St. Nicholas in the Fields, and the t'other two were in la Cimitiere St. Jean, in an Inn where they had taken up their Lodging.

This account pleas'd me o well, that I confirm'd my promie to pardon him, but I order'd him to go back again to his Comrade, that he might not upect any thing, being reolv'd to take him the next morning in his Bed; to which purpoe I order'd him to come to me by break of day, to a certain place which I nam'd to him; if there was no danger of being een in the Houe; o I got ready the Provots men over night, and poting them in the mid way, I would needs go my elf to ee him taken. Being come to the place, my Footman came exactly as I appointed him, but told me, that he did not lodge at home that night, and deir'd me to take great care let I hould be een, for if the leat notice hould be taken of my deign, I hould never catch him. I approv'd what he aid well enough, and therefore ending the Provots men away to a Tavern, I reted upon his care in the matter. I fancy'd the fellow would certainly come in two or three hours, but the Rogue having got the Money in his Pocket that he made of my Hore, was reolv'd to live well while it lated; and noon being pat without any dicovery, I began to upect my Footman had been fale to me, and had given him notice; and when he came to me, as he did every now and then, for fear I hould be impatient, I told him plainly what I apprehended of him, and withal, that if he had trickt me, I hould find it out firt or lat, and then I hould how him no mercy; but he aur'd me of his fidelity with uch protetations, as fully atisfy'd me, and I reolv'd to wait till night; but 'twas all one, the fellow lik'd his port too well where he was, and there he tay'd all the next day, all which time I was very uneay with waiting. Then it was that I concluded the
Lacquay had without doubt deluded me, and the very thought of it put me in uch a paion, that I was jut upon the point of arreting him: but he told me, he was content I hould hang him if I found it o; that he began to think himelf, the fellow was fled, but at the ame time he could not imagin, how he hould get any notice of our deign. Indeed, I was o far atisfy'd, that I went to the Inn my elf to eize upon my Hores, and as I was ordering them ome Corn before I took them away, they came running in to me to ask me if my Valet had not uch a ort of a Belt on, for they aw a fellow coming a good way off that lookt like him, as I had decrib'd him; I ent my Lacquay, who was ordering the Hores, to ee if it was the right, and order'd him to go and accot him, that they might not be mitaken, for that was the ign agreed on. In hort, being atisfy'd it was he, he comes up to him, and tells him, how if he had come a little ooner, he had met with ome Cutomers for the Hores. While he kept him thus in upence, the Provots men eized upon him, and he truggling to clear himelf from them, the noie brought me out, thinking they might want help; before he aw me he laid about him with all his might, but when I appear'd he made no more reitance; o true it is, that the Face of the man one has really injur'd, dipirits the mind, and the reproach of a mans concience takes away all his reolution; therefore putting himelf in a poture of ubmiion, Ah Mater, Mater, aid he, I beg your pardon heartily. I forgot to tell you, that with my Hores he had carry • d away all my Clothes, and my Linnen, all which he either old or pawn'd. Having ecur'd my man, I had him to a Magitrate of my acquaintance, where, when I had brought him, I told him, that it was now in my power to proecute, and perhaps to hang him; but however, that I would be o kind to pare him, provided he would retore the things he had tole from me; that he hould tell me where my things were, and carry the man his Money again who had bought my Hore, that when I hould oblige him to retore the
Ho • e, he hould not oblige me to proecute him. This was without quetion a very kind propoal on my part, but the poor fellow unhappily had met with a curvy accident: In the little time he had been gone, he had gotten into a gang of harping Pick Pocket Rogues, who had drawn him into play, and had cheated him of all his Money; o that intead of refunding the Money for the Hore, he had not one Farthing in his Pocket; he durt not tell me how it was, and begun to make excues; but eeing how it was, and giving no credit to his pretences, I let him go to Prion, In the mean time, that I might get my Hore, without being oblig'd to proecute the fellow, I went to the man who had bought him, and pretending to buy a Hore, among the ret he how'd me my own. I made no great difficulty of agreeing to his price, knowing already what he cot him, I bid him profit enough, and we oon agreed, o I deir'd him to end him to my Lodging, and come and fetch his Money; but when he c • me to be paid, I told him how it was, that it was my own Hore, and that he had been tolen from me, and that he who was a Jocky by Trade, ought to know a little better who he bought Hores of. The Man was very much upriz'd, for he was an honet Man, and knew nothing of the matter. However, he told me I was a tranger to him, and he deir'd to be atisfy'd that what I alledg'd was true. I told him 'twas eay enough for me to atisfy him of that, for the fellow that tole him from me, and old him to him, was now actually in the Chatelet, and if he pleas'd, I would go along with him, and how him the Man, who was my Valet de Chambre; he agreed, and we went directly to the Prion, where he had the atifaction of eeing that it was even o, and that he could have no more claim to the Hore. However, after this, ome Attorney having advis'd him to preent a Petition, in which he made his complaint, that I came and took the Hore away by main force, he got leave to eize him again, and ent an Officer at a time, when he knew I was not at home: he that came deir'd
to ee him out, under pretence of carrying him to a place where goods are attacht, but indeed to give the Hore Merchant poeion, after which I had no remedy but againt the poor Stable-keeper, whoe Wife it may be would have paid me with a ham of her being a F • me Sole, as the Barbers Wife had done; but my Landlord would not uffer that, and choe rather to be the Sequetre, and to take it into his keeping. This Proceeding of the Jockeys brought me into a Suit at Law, which I would have willingly declin'd, and going to Council about it, they advis'd me to demand a Warrant. I went then to the new Chatellet in the Fauxbourg St. Germain, where I lodg'd, and Monieur Girardin being Chief in that Court of Judicature, I needed not go twice to him to be heard, for he is a peron always very obliging to perons of any quality. My Caue was o clear, that he granted what I askt at firt word; however I was forc • d to give ecurity till the Proces hould be made out againt my Valet, who was proecuted by the Sollicitor General at the Kings Suit, for one of my friends, who undertood thoe things better than I, had taken care to order that for me, telling me the King was better able to bear the Charges than I was; by which he av'd me three or four hundred Franks in my pocket, and I was very much oblig'd to him for it.

In the next place, I brought a Citizen of my Acquaintance to be Security, and having entred into a Recognizance to the Regitry, I thoug • t all was over; but it prov'd a trange Suit for me. My Valet de Chambre before he came to me, belong'd to the Marquis de l' Aigle, a Gentleman of Normandy, who ma •• y'd the Marquis de Rarcy's Daughter, a Gentleman of but a mean quality, but being ally'd to a Family of good Repute, and of great peronal Merit, he liv'd all his days in a great deal of Credit; I was acquainted with him, and his Daughter, who had een me everal times at his Houe and knew I was the fellows Mater, who had formerly liv'd with her Husband, came to me to peak in his behalf, and pray'd me to be favourable to
him, and he would o order it, that I hould loe nothing by it, he would give me her word for it; I told her I deir'd no more, and before he came to me, I had offer'd o much to the Prioner; that I was orry he had no Requet of greater conequence to make to me, that I might have the honour to oblige her; that I was an old friend of her Fathers, and o much hers alo, that he might depend upon any thing which lay in my pow'r to be done: however, I told her, I apprehended there might be ome difficulty now in the thing; that the Man being put into the hand of Jutice, he could not take him out when he would, and we ought to take advice of thoe who undertood thoe things, what was to be done; he approv'd of what I aid, and taking me into her Coach, we went to the Regiter, who was a friend of hers. He told us indeed, 'twould be a hard matter to bring the fellow off now; that if I had not committed him it might have been done, but however he would try; he aid the thing depended on the Depoition of the Witnees who hould come in againt him, and they having not been examin'd yet, it lay in my power to direct them what they hould ay.

Madam de l' Aigle was mighty glad of this expedient, telling me, that now it was all in my power, and repeating her promies as he had before, that I hould loe nothing, I parted from her, upon condition he hould come forthwith and perform them; but two or three days after he came to me again, and told me, he was extreamly troubled, that he had promis'd me what he could not perform; that what he had aid, was upon Propoals made to her by the Prioner; and that now when it was come to the point, he could not find Money but jut to atisfie the Hore Merchant, and that if I was not inclin'd to how him ome pity, he was a dead man. This pretty fetch urpriz'd me extreamly, epecially coming from uch a Woman as he, who ought to have had all her meaures ready-before hand, and beides I thought indeed, he had intended to have done o much for the poor fellow herelf, and o I told
her; upon which he reply'd, he had done more for him than I thought of, that 'twas he helpt him to the Money to pay the Hore Courer, and that he could not do any more, and begg'd me to bear a little of the los to ave a poor Wretch from the Gallows. I protet, I was very unwilling to do any thing, after her having broke the promies he made me at firt, but conidering that I hould not be much the better for hanging a poor fellow, I told her I would do any thing for her ake, and ince he would have it o, it was granted. So we parted, after her giving me a great many thanks for my generoity, and the like. Things being iued thus far, I thought I might venture to go a mall Journey into the Country, which I had deferr'd for ome time upon this account. I have told you before, that I had my Arm put out of joynt, going to ee Father d' Aviano; and that falling into the hands of an ignorant Surgeon, I was forc'd to go to the Hangman of Ruremond, who had given me eae; but whether it was that he had not perfectly cur'd it, or that uch accidents as thoe generally leave pains and aches which are felt when one comes to be old, I have had ince that, every now and then, a pain there, epecially againt the change of weather. I had conulted with the whole College of Phyitians, and with thoe of Saint Come, and they all advis'd me to go to Barbottans, near the Pyrennees, a place nam'd from the Baths that are there, which are different from all Baths, for they are not of clear water, but very muddy; yet of uch virtue, that trange cures are done by them, upon uch as are troubled with weaknees in the Nerves and Joynts, or the remains of any dilocated part, as mine was. Before I went away I took my leave of Madam de l' Aigle, and told her, my going out of Town hould not hinder the doing what he deir'd, that I would leave order for the Witnees to come to her for directions before they were examin'd; and ince the Regiter had told us, that all depended upon their depoitions, he might be atisfy'd the thing would be done.

Upon this I went my way, reting upon her promie, not dreaming in the leat, that a Woman of her quality, and who I had dealt o fairly with, could be o bae as to break her word a econd time; but he had marry'd a Norman, the Maxim of whoe Country it is, that a Man ought not to be a Slave to his Word. She had no ooner een me clear of Paris, but he dicover'd, that he had alo marry'd the Manners and Cutoms of the Normans; for after he had order'd every thing as he deir'd it, with the Witnees, according to the orders I had left, intead of performing her agreement with me, he goes to the Prioner, and tells him he would bring him off well enough, that he hould now tand in his own jutification, and tell the Court, that intead of robbing his Mater, he had done nothing but what he order'd him; that having not Money to end him to defray the charges of my Hores and Servants, I had left him a verbal order to ell my Equipage and Cloaths if I wanted; and if he had old one Hore at Paris, it was only to pay for the keeping of the other two, having not found me at Paris as I appointed. If I had been upon the pot, it had been an eay matter for me to have confuted all thee ham tories; but my Sollicitor, and the Witnees too, having had orders from me to peak nothing of him but what he directed, I could not blame them if they endeavour'd to clear him; and he, intead of bearing me harmles, left me in the lurch, to be cat in the Cot and Damages of the Tryal, and to pay to the Hore Merchant the umm of four hundred and fifty Livres, which was the price of the Hore, with interet from the time I bought him. 'Twas certainly as trange a thing as ever befel a man, in o plain a cae as mine was, and a great caue of triumph to a Racal who ought to have been hang'd; and yet all this was nothing to what follow'd. The Hore Courer having gotten judgment againt me, and I not being to be found, he gave notice to the Man who was ecurity for me, to prepare to pay the Money in my room; and this demand coming upon him, jut at a time when he had a great man
Bills to pay, and at the ame time one came to be proteted for non-payment, the Man was quite ruin'd, having neither Money nor Friends to tand by him at uch a pinch. I confes, I cannot peak of this part of the tory without being mov'd at Madam de l' Aigle, whoe bae dealing was the occaion of all this confuion; and had it been a Man, I hould not have fail'd to have reveng'd it, when I firt heard of it, one way or t • other. But to go on with the tory of this Racal, which was, I think, the wort that ever happen'd to me in my life, tho I have had a pretty many troubleome buinees too. Within two days after notice given to my Security, as before, they eiz'd his Goods, and he having no body to redeem them, they carry'd them off, and expos'd them to ale in the place appointed for Sale of Goods eiz'd in Execution. I leave it to any body to judge, what a fraction this made in the affairs of a Shop-keeper; all the remedy he had, was to ummon me to top the Proceedings, and for default of appearing, to protet againt me for all the Cots, Damages and Interets.

I was upon the road when all this happen'd, going to the Bath, and not imagining any uch thing could befal me, I had not left directions to write to me before I came to my Journeys end, o that tho a great many Letters were ent to places where it was probable I might come, yet having no notice of any uch thing, I met with none of them. • Twas very trange, I thought, that among uch a multitude of people, that ue to call themelves my Friends, and humble Servants, there was not one to be found would lay down fifty Pitoles for me in my abence, to have topt all this Villany, and above all, to ave the poor Man that was bound for me, who was but in a very ill cae; for uch people who live by Trade, are never without a number of Creditors, and thee came all upon him, hearing what had happen'd, and believing he was pa ••
remedy, eeing he could not top uch a mall thing as that, o falling in with the Hore Courer they proecuted the Sale of the Goods, and the poor Man lot all
that ever he had in one days time, and poil'd his Credit too, which was wore than all the ret. However, as I was really innocent of all that had happen'd, all my anger was bent againt Madam de l • Aigle. I will not pretend to decribe what a paion I was in at her, for indeed 'tis impoible; you mut think I thought of nothing but revenge, and I was very deeply toucht to do what I did. I had not undertaken uch a long Journey, as I aid before, but in hopes of recovering my health; now I was upon the pot, and ought to expect the ucces, yet upon the news of this I made back again immediately, reolving to do my utmot rather than to be thus fool'd. I have given you an account already how I had been inform'd, that my Valet de Chambre had us'd to rob on the High-way. I now made enquiry to find out what proof I could have of it, and finding I had too plain proof to fail bringing him to the Gallows, I had nothing to do then but to find him out, which as it happen'd was not o difficult as I thought it was: having given order to one of my Boys to put off his Livery, and go to the Marquis de l' Aigle's, upon pretence of getting a place, he preently learnt, that the fellow was got into his ervice again; this Norman not mattering wh • were his Servants, o he could but get them for little or no Wages. In hort, he took him on that very core, for he was a Man that never mit his advantage, if he had an opportunity.

Having learnt where this Rogue had hous • d himelf, I got a Decree againt him, and reolv'd not only to take him, but to take him out of his new Maters Houe, that the affront might be the greater to him; to which end I got every thing ready, and taking no les than a Gang of thirty Provots Men, that I might be provided in cae of reitance, we went to the Houe betimes in the morning, and the Door being open'd, we took the Rogue out of his Bed. The Marquis de l' Aigle hearing a great noie, got up to ee what was the matter, and o did his Lady, and hufft at the Officers, theatning them for daring to enter the Houe of a peron of their quality: but uch ort of people don't
ue to trouble their heads about folks quality, nor <>
neither, and the he had like to have found to her cot, one or two of them having offer'd the butt end of their pieces at her, and perhaps had done her a michief, but that the Magitrate who was at the head of them prevented it; but at the ame time the Commiary (for there is not much difference between one of thoe Magitrates, and one of their M • n, as to their civility) told her, that if he had been hurt he had no more than he deerv • d, that he hould know her elf a little better than to threaten thoe that came to execute the Law; and if he had any thing to ay, he might make her complaint where he ought. This was a great mortification to a Woman of her pirit, but he was forc'd to bear it, and alo omething more, which I had intructed one of the Officers to ay to her, if he appear'd, that made her preently know it was I had brought this about, and thereupon he and her Huband began to contrive, which way to defeat me again, (for they were both as excellent at tricking as Lawyers) thinking it was all on the old buines. 'Tis true, as to the crime, a Man could not be tried twice for the ame fact, nor would further Evidence ignify any thing, and this was what they built upon, and o making it a point of honour, away they went in their Coach to each the Jaylors Book of the Prioners Names, but they were ent back again with a vengeance, when they undertood there was more in it than they had heard of; and as great as they were they durt not meddle with it, nor o much as appear, when they heard of a High-way Robbery in the cae; they did what they could, indeed, by their friends, and underhand, but all was to no purpoe, nor much to their credit neither, for all would not do to ave a Rogue, whoe crime was as plain as the Sun at noon day; but he was condemn • d to be broken upon the Wheel, and all they could do for him was, that intead of being broken alive, as he deerv'd, (for he had been an Aainate too) he had the favour to be trangled firt.

This however, did not hinder me from endeavouring
to make up the matter with the Man that had been bound for me, and had uffer'd o deeply for it. He had proteted, as before, againt me, for the Charges, Damages, and Interets, and it was but jut indeed that I hould give him omething, and that coniderable too: indeed tho I was not the caue of his Creditors coming upon him, yet I was of the confuion of his affairs, which brought them upon him, and in conideration of this I offer'd him 2000 Franks, and after that 1000 Crowns, but he flew out at me as if I had done him ome great injury, telling me ix times as much would not make him atisfaction; that on my account his Goods had been old for half the value, and that I was oblig'd to bear the los, which was at leat 4000 Crowns; that beides, I had been the occaion of his hutting up his Shop, where he got his Livelihood, and I ought to give him a conideration for that; that it would require a great deal of time before he could et up again, and get into credit as he was before, and the like, and thee he call'd his Damages and Interets; and he hop'd I would not ee his Wife and Children turn'd into the treet a begging for his good will in doing me a kindnes. But indeed he would have ent me a begging if I hould have done as he deir'd; o I was forc'd to go to Law with him, his Demands being o extravagant, which ended o much to my advantage, that intead of 1000 Crowns, which I had offer'd him, I was awarded to pay him jut half the umm; but becaue I would be generous, he having really uffer • d on my account, I gave him the thouand Crowns I had tender'd him before.

And thus ended this affair, which I hould till call unfortunate, had it not very much conducd to how me the vanity of this world; and indeed conidering, that nothing is to be met with here but Affliction, Croes and Dicontent, I began to reolve to do, what I had a long time intended: And o at lat I am retir'd into a Religious Houe, where burthen'd with years, and depret with the infirmities that ineparably attend old Age, I am waiting with patience the good hour, when it hall pleae Almighty God to take me to himelf.
